Utah Code Annotated - Title 26B - Utah Health and Human Services Code
=====================================================================

Utah Code Annotated - Title 26B - Chapter 1 - Department of Health and Human Services
*************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this title:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-102(1): 26B-1-201 "Department" means the Department of Health and Human Services created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-102(2): 26B-1-203 "Executive director" means the executive director of the department appointed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-102(3): 26A-1-102 "Local health department" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-102(4): "Public health authority" means an agency or authority of the United States, a state, a territory, a political subdivision of a state or territory, an Indian tribe, or a person acting under a grant of authority from or a contract with such an agency, that is responsible for public health matters as part of the agency or authority's official mandate.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-103 Purpose of title -- Consolidation of functions into single state agency.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The purpose of this title is to consolidate into a single agency of state government all of the functions previously exercised by the Department of Health and the Department of Human Services to more efficiently and effectively carry out the responsibilities delegated to the department by state law.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-104 Severability of code provisions.
----------------------------------------------------------------
If a provision of this title or

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-105 Individual rights protected.
------------------------------------------------------------
Nothing in this title prohibits an individual from choosing the diet, therapy, or mode of treatment to be administered to an individual or an individual's family.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-201 Department of Health and Human Services -- Creation -- Duties.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-201(1): There is created within state government the Department of Health and Human Services, which has all of the policymaking functions, regulatory and enforcement powers, rights, duties, and responsibilities outlined in this title and previously vested in the Department of Health and the Department of Human Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-201(2): Subject to the limitation and grants of authority in state law, the department shall serve as the health, health planning, medical assistance, and social services authority of the state, and for administration of federally assisted state programs or plans is designated as the sole state agency for:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-201(2)(a): social service block grants;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-201(2)(b): alcohol, drug, and mental health programs, including block grants;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-201(2)(c): child welfare;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-201(2)(d): state programs supported under the Older Americans Act, 42 U.S.C. Sec. 3001, et seq.;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-201(2)(e): public health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-201(2)(f): health planning;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-201(2)(g): maternal and child health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-201(2)(h): services for individuals with a disability; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-201(2)(i): medical assistance.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-201(3): A state plan or program administered by the department:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-201(3)(a): shall be developed in the appropriate divisions or offices of the department in accordance with applicable requirements of state and federal law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-201(3)(b): may be amended by the executive director to achieve coordination, efficiency, or economy.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-201(4): (1); Title 26, Utah Health Code; Title 62A, Utah Human Services Code In addition to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-201(4)(a): Title 26, Utah Health Code
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-201(4)(b): Title 62A, Utah Human Services Code


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202 Department authority and duties.
----------------------------------------------------------------
The department may, subject to applicable restrictions in state law and in addition to all other authority and responsibility granted to the department by law:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(1): adopt rules, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, and not inconsistent with law, as the department may consider necessary or desirable for providing health and social services to the people of this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(2): establish and manage client trust accounts in the department's institutions and community programs, at the request of the client or the client's legal guardian or representative, or in accordance with federal law;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(3): purchase, as authorized or required by law, services that the department is responsible to provide for legally eligible persons;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(4): conduct adjudicative proceedings for clients and providers in accordance with the procedures of Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(5): establish eligibility standards for the department's programs, not inconsistent with state or federal law or regulations;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(6): take necessary steps, including legal action, to recover money or the monetary value of services provided to a recipient who was not eligible;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(7): set and collect fees for the department's services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(8): license agencies, facilities, and programs, except as otherwise allowed, prohibited, or limited by law;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(9): acquire, manage, and dispose of any real or personal property needed or owned by the department, not inconsistent with state law;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(10): receive gifts, grants, devises, and donations; gifts, grants, devises, donations, or the proceeds thereof, may be credited to the program designated by the donor, and may be used for the purposes requested by the donor, as long as the request conforms to state and federal policy; all donated funds shall be considered private, nonlapsing funds and may be invested under guidelines established by the state treasurer;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(11): accept and employ volunteer labor or services; the department is authorized to reimburse volunteers for necessary expenses, when the department considers that reimbursement to be appropriate;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(12): carry out the responsibility assigned in the workforce services plan by the State Workforce Development Board;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(13): 26B-1-430 carry out the responsibility assigned by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(14): provide training and educational opportunities for the department's staff;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(15): collect child support payments and any other money due to the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(16): apply the provisions of Title 81, Chapter 6, Child Support, to parents whose child lives out of the home in a department licensed or certified setting;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(17): 80-6-403 establish policy and procedures, within appropriations authorized by the Legislature, in cases where the Division of Child and Family Services or the Division of Juvenile Justice and Youth Services is given custody of a minor by the juvenile court under Title 80, Utah Juvenile Code, or the department is ordered to prepare an attainment plan for a minor found not competent to proceed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(17)(a): designation of interagency teams for each juvenile court district in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(17)(b): delineation of assessment criteria and procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(17)(c): minimum requirements, and timeframes, for the development and implementation of a collaborative service plan for each minor placed in department custody; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(17)(d): provisions for submittal of the plan and periodic progress reports to the court;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(18): carry out the responsibilities assigned to the department by statute;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(19): 26B-5-101 examine and audit the expenditures of any public funds provided to a local substance abuse authority, a local mental health authority, a local area agency on aging, and any person, agency, or organization that contracts with or receives funds from those authorities or agencies. Those local authorities, area agencies, and any person or entity that contracts with or receives funds from those authorities or area agencies, shall provide the department with any information the department considers necessary. The department is further authorized to issue directives resulting from any examination or audit to a local authority, an area agency, and persons or entities that contract with or receive funds from those authorities with regard to any public funds. If the department determines that it is necessary to withhold funds from a local mental health authority or local substance abuse authority based on failure to comply with state or federal law, policy, or contract provisions, the department may take steps necessary to ensure continuity of services. For purposes of this Subsection (19) "public funds" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(20): 26B-2-104 in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(21): 63J-1-206 within legislative appropriations, promote and develop a system of care and stabilization services:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(21)(a): in compliance with Title 63G, Chapter 6a, Utah Procurement Code; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(21)(b): 63J-1-206 that encompasses the department, department contractors, and the divisions, offices, or institutions within the department, to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(21)(b)(i): navigate services, funding resources, and relationships to the benefit of the children and families whom the department serves;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(21)(b)(ii): centralize department operations, including procurement and contracting;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(21)(b)(iii): develop policies that govern business operations and that facilitate a system of care approach to service delivery;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(21)(b)(iv): 63J-1-206 allocate resources that may be used for the children and families served by the department or the divisions, offices, or institutions within the department, subject to the restrictions in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(21)(b)(v): create performance-based measures for the provision of services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(21)(b)(vi): centralize other business operations, including data matching and sharing among the department's divisions, offices, and institutions;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(22): 63G-22-102 ensure that any training or certification required of a public official or public employee, as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(22)(a): under this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(22)(b): by the department; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(22)(c): by an agency or division within the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(23): enter into cooperative agreements with the Department of Environmental Quality to delineate specific responsibilities to assure that assessment and management of risk to human health from the environment are properly administered;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(24): consult with the Department of Environmental Quality and enter into cooperative agreements, as needed, to ensure efficient use of resources and effective response to potential health and safety threats from the environment, and to prevent gaps in protection from potential risks from the environment to specific individuals or population groups;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(25): to the extent authorized under state law or required by federal law, promote and protect the health and wellness of the people within the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(26): establish, maintain, and enforce rules authorized under state law or required by federal law to promote and protect the public health or to prevent disease and illness;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(27): investigate the causes of epidemic, infectious, communicable, and other diseases affecting the public health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(28): provide for the detection and reporting of communicable, infectious, acute, chronic, or any other disease or health hazard which the department considers to be dangerous, important, or likely to affect the public health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(29): collect and report information on causes of injury, sickness, death, and disability and the risk factors that contribute to the causes of injury, sickness, death, and disability within the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(30): collect, prepare, publish, and disseminate information to inform the public concerning the health and wellness of the population, specific hazards, and risks that may affect the health and wellness of the population and specific activities which may promote and protect the health and wellness of the population;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(31): abate nuisances when necessary to eliminate sources of filth and infectious and communicable diseases affecting the public health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(32): make necessary sanitary and health investigations and inspections in cooperation with local health departments as to any matters affecting the public health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(33): establish laboratory services necessary to support public health programs and medical services in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(34): establish and enforce standards for laboratory services which are provided by any laboratory in the state when the purpose of the services is to protect the public health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(35): cooperate with the Labor Commission to conduct studies of occupational health hazards and occupational diseases arising in and out of employment in industry, and make recommendations for elimination or reduction of the hazards;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(36): cooperate with the local health departments, the Department of Corrections, the Administrative Office of the Courts, the Division of Juvenile Justice and Youth Services, and the Crime Victim Reparations and Assistance Board to conduct testing for HIV infection of alleged sexual offenders, convicted sexual offenders, and any victims of a sexual offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(37): investigate the causes of maternal and infant mortality;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(38): establish, maintain, and enforce a procedure requiring the blood of adult pedestrians and drivers of motor vehicles killed in highway accidents be examined for the presence and concentration of alcohol, and provide the Commissioner of Public Safety with monthly statistics reflecting the results of these examinations, with necessary safeguards so that information derived from the examinations is not used for a purpose other than the compilation of these statistics;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(39): 41-6a-523; 53-10-405; 72-10-502; 77-23-213 establish qualifications for individuals permitted to draw blood under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(40): establish a uniform public health program throughout the state which includes continuous service, employment of qualified employees, and a basic program of disease control, vital and health statistics, sanitation, public health nursing, and other preventive health programs necessary or desirable for the protection of public health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(41): conduct health planning for the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(42): monitor the costs of health care in the state and foster price competition in the health care delivery system;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(43): establish methods or measures for health care providers, public health entities, and health care insurers to coordinate among themselves to verify the identity of the individuals the providers serve;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(44): designate Alzheimer's disease and related dementia as a public health issue and, within budgetary limitations, implement a state plan for Alzheimer's disease and related dementia by incorporating the plan into the department's strategic planning and budgetary process;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(45): coordinate with other state agencies and other organizations to implement the state plan for Alzheimer's disease and related dementia;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(46): 63G-22-102 ensure that any training or certification required of a public official or public employee, as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(47): 53G-9-404 oversee public education vision screening as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(48): issue code blue alerts in accordance with Title 35A, Chapter 16, Part 7, Code Blue Alert; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(49): 26B-1-243(4) as allowed by state and federal law, share data with the Office of Families that is relevant to the duties described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(49)(a): demographic data concerning family structures in the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(49)(b): data regarding the family structure associated with:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(49)(b)(i): suicide, depression, or anxiety; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-202(49)(b)(ii): various health outcomes.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203 Executive director -- Appointment -- Compensation -- Qualifications -- Deputy directors required -- Responsibilities.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(1): Title 67, Chapter 22, State Officer Compensation
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(1)(a): The chief administrative officer of the department is the executive director, who shall be appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(1)(b): The executive director may be removed at the will of the governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(1)(c): Title 67, Chapter 22, State Officer Compensation The executive director shall receive a salary established by the governor within the salary range fixed by the Legislature in
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(2): The executive director shall be experienced in administration, management, and coordination of complex organizations.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(3): If the executive director is not a physician, the executive director or a deputy director shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(3)(a): be informed and experienced in public health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(3)(b): have successfully completed at least a master's degree of public health or public administration from an accredited school of public health or from an accredited program of public health or public administration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(3)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(3)(c)(i): have at least five years of professional full-time experience, of which at least two years have been in public health in a senior level administrative capacity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(3)(c)(ii): have at least five years of professional full-time experience in public health programs, of which at least three years have been in a senior level administrative capacity.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(4): The executive director shall appoint a deputy director of the department who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(4)(a): shall have successfully completed at least one year's graduate work in an accredited school of public health or an accredited program of public health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(4)(b): shall have at least five years of professional full-time experience in public health programs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(4)(c): is a physician licensed to practice medicine in the state with experience in public health.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(5): The executive director is responsible for:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(5)(a): administration and supervision of the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(5)(b): coordination of policies and program activities conducted through the boards, divisions, and offices of the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(5)(c): approval of the proposed budget of each board, division, and office within the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(5)(d): other duties as the Legislature or governor shall assign to the executive director.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-203(6): The executive director may appoint deputy or assistant directors to assist the executive director in carrying out the department's responsibilities.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-206 Limitation on establishment of advisory bodies.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-206(1): A department division or board:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-206(1)(a): may not establish permanent, ongoing advisory groups unless otherwise specifically created in federal or state statute; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-206(1)(b): shall comply with the provisions of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-206(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-206(2)(a): A division or board may establish subject-limited and time-limited ad hoc advisory groups to provide input necessary to carry out the division's or board's assigned responsibilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-206(2)(b): When establishing such an advisory group, the board shall establish in writing a specific charge and time limit.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-206(3): The department shall consolidate an advisory group or committee with another committee or advisory group as appropriate to create greater efficiencies and budgetary savings for the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-206(4): A member of any ad hoc advisory group shall receive no compensation or benefits for their service.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-206(5): The provision of staffing and support to any ad hoc advisory group is contingent on availability of human and financial resources.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207 Policymaking responsibilities -- Regulations for local health departments prescribed by department -- Local standards not more stringent than federal or state standards -- Consultation with local health departments -- Committee to evaluate health policies and to review federal grants.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(1): In establishing public health policy, the department shall consult with the local health departments established under Title 26A, Chapter 1, Local Health Departments.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(2): 26A-1-102; 26A-1-102; 26A-1-121; 63G-3-304
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(2)(a): 26A-1-102 In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the department may prescribe by administrative rule made in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, reasonable requirements not inconsistent with law for a local health department as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(2)(b): 26A-1-102 Except where specifically allowed by federal law or state statute, a local health department, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(2)(c): 26A-1-121; 63G-3-304 Nothing in this Subsection (2), limits the ability of a local health department to make standards and regulations in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(2)(c)(i): 63G-3-304 emergency rules made in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(2)(c)(ii): items not regulated under federal law, state statute, or state administrative rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3): 26A-1-116
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(a): As used in this Subsection (3):
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(a)(i): "Committee" means the committee established under Subsection (3)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(a)(ii): "Exempt application" means an application for a federal grant that meets the criteria established under Subsection (3)(c)(iv).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(a)(iii): "Expedited application" means an application for a federal grant that meets the criteria established under Subsection (3)(c)(v).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(a)(iv): "Federal grant" means a grant from the federal government that could provide funds for local health departments to help them fulfill their duties and responsibilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(a)(v): "Reviewable application" means an application for a federal grant that is not an exempt application.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(b): The department shall establish a committee consisting of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(b)(i): the executive director, or the executive director's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(b)(ii): two representatives of the department, appointed by the executive director; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(b)(iii): three representatives of local health departments, appointed by all local health departments.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(c): 26A-1-116 The committee shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(c)(i): 26A-1-116 evaluate the allocation of public health resources between the department and local health departments, including whether funds allocated by contract were allocated in accordance with the formula described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(c)(ii): evaluate policies and rules that affect local health departments in accordance with Subsection (3)(g);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(c)(iii): consider department policy and rule changes proposed by the department or local health departments;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(c)(iv): establish criteria by which an application for a federal grant may be judged to determine whether it should be exempt from the requirements under Subsection (3)(d); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(c)(v): establish criteria by which an application for a federal grant may be judged to determine whether committee review under Subsection (3)(d)(i) should be delayed until after the application is submitted because the application is required to be submitted under a timetable that makes committee review before it is submitted impracticable if the submission deadline is to be met.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(d)(i): The committee shall review the goals and budget for each reviewable application:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(d)(i)(A): before the application is submitted, except for an expedited application; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(d)(i)(B): for an expedited application, after the application is submitted but before funds from the federal grant for which the application was submitted are disbursed or encumbered.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(d)(ii): Funds from a federal grant under a reviewable application may not be disbursed or encumbered before the goals and budget for the federal grant are established bya two-thirds vote of the committee, following the committee review under Subsection (3)(d)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(e): An exempt application is exempt from the requirements of Subsection (3)(d).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(f): The department may use money from a federal grant to pay administrative costs incurred in implementing this Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(g): When evaluating a policy or rule that affects a local health department, the committee shall determine:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(g)(i): whether the department has the authority to promulgate the policy or rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(g)(ii): an estimate of the cost a local health department will bear to comply with the policy or rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(g)(iii): whether there is any funding provided to a local health department to implement the policy or rule; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(g)(iv): whether the policy or rule is still needed.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-207(3)(h): Before November 1 of each year, the department shall provide a report to the Rules Review and General Oversight Committee regarding the determinations made under Subsection (3)(g).

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-208(2): Wherever state law authorizes a board, director, division, or office of the department to accept any grant, fund, or service which is to be advanced or contributed in whole or in part by the federal government, that acceptance shall be subject to the approval or disapproval of the executive director.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-214 Executive director -- Enforcement powers.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Subject to the restrictions in this title and to the extent permitted by state law, the executive director is empowered to issue orders to enforce state laws and rules established by the department except where the enforcement power is given to a committee created under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-215 Actions on behalf of department -- Party in interest.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-215(1): The executive director, each of the department's boards, divisions, offices, and the director of each division or office, shall, in the exercise of any power, duty, or function under any statute of this state, is considered to be acting on behalf of the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-215(2): The department, through the executive director or through any of the department's boards, divisions, offices, or directors, shall be considered the party in interest in all actions at law or in equity, where the department or any constituent, board, division, office, or official thereof is authorized by any statute of the state to be a party to any legal action.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-216(3): develop an integrated human services system and implement a system of care by:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-218 Intergenerational poverty mitigation reporting.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-218(1): 35A-9-102; 35A-9-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-218(1)(a): 35A-9-102 "Cycle of poverty" means the same as that term is defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-219(1)(b)(i): "Rationing criteria" means any requirement, guideline, process, or recommendation regarding:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-219(1)(c)(ii): that, based on the circumstances described in Subsection (1)(c)(i), is distributed or provided using written requirements, guidelines, processes, or recommendations as a factor in the decision to distribute or provide the health care resource; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-219(1)(c)(iii): that the federal government has allocated to the state to distribute.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-222 Violation of public health laws or orders unlawful.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It shall be unlawful for any person, association, or corporation, and the officers thereof:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-222(1): to willfully violate, disobey, or disregard the provisions of the public health laws or the terms of any lawful notice, order, standard, rule, or regulation issued thereunder;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-222(2): to fail to remove or abate from private property under the person's control at the person's own expense, within 48 hours, or such other reasonable time as the health authorities shall determine, after being ordered to do so by the health authorities, any nuisance, source of filth, cause of sickness, dead animal, health hazard, or sanitation violation within the jurisdiction and control of the department, whether the person, association, or corporation shall be the owner, tenant, or occupant of such property; provided, however, when any such condition is due to an act of God, it shall be removed at public expense;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-222(3): 26B-1-220; 26B-1-228 to pay, give, present, or otherwise convey to any officer or employee of the department any gift, remuneration or other consideration, directly or indirectly, which such officer or employee is forbidden to receive by the provisions of Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-222(4): to fail to make or file reports required by law or rule of the department relating to the existence of disease or other facts and statistics relating to the public health.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-223 Unlawful acts by department officers and employees.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It shall be unlawful for any officer or employee of the department:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-223(1): 26B-1-220; 26B-1-228 to accept any gift, remuneration, or other consideration, directly or indirectly, for an incorrect or improper performance of the duties imposed upon the officer or employee by or in behalf of the department or by the provisions of Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-223(2): to perform any work, labor, or services other than the duties assigned to the officer or employee on behalf of the department during the hours such officer or employee is regularly employed by the department, or to perform the officer or employee's duties as an officer or employee of the department under any condition or arrangement that involves a violation of this or any other law of the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-226 Representatives of department authorized to enter regulated premises.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-226(1): Authorized representatives of the department upon presentation of appropriate identification shall be authorized to enter upon the premises of properties regulated under this title to perform routine inspections to ensure compliance with rules adopted by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-226(2): This section does not authorize the department to inspect private dwellings.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-227 Authority of department as to functions transferred from other agencies.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-227(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-227(1)(a): If functions transferred from other agencies are vested by this code in the department, the department shall be the successor in every way, with respect to such functions, except as otherwise provided by this code.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-227(1)(b): Every act done in the exercise of such functions by the department shall have the same force and effect as if done by the agency in which the functions were previously vested.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-227(2): Whenever any such agency is referred to or designated by law, contract, or other document, the reference or designation shall apply to the department.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-234 Handling of child sexual abuse material.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-234(1): 76-5b-103 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-234(1)(a): 76-5b-103 "Child sexual abuse material" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-234(1)(b): "Secure" means to prevent and prohibit access, electronic upload, transmission, or transfer of an image.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-234(2): The department or a division within the department may not retain child sexual abuse material longer than is necessary to comply with the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-234(3): When the department or a division within the department obtains child sexual abuse material as a result of an employee unlawfully viewing child sexual abuse material, the department or division shall consult with and follow the guidance of the Division of Human Resource Management regarding personnel action and local law enforcement regarding retention of the child sexual abuse material.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-234(4): When the department or a division within the department obtains child sexual abuse material as a result of a report or an investigation, the department or division shall immediately secure the child sexual abuse material, or the electronic device if the child sexual abuse material is digital, and contact the law enforcement office that has jurisdiction over the area where the division's case is located.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-243 Office of Families -- Definitions -- Director -- Purpose and duties.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-243(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-243(1)(a): "Director" means the director of the office appointed under Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-243(1)(b): "Office" means the Office of Families.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-243(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-243(2)(a): The governor shall appoint a director of the office.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-243(2)(b): The director serves at the pleasure of the governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-243(2)(c): The governor shall establish the director's salary within the salary range fixed by the Legislature in Title 67, Chapter 22, State Officer Compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-243(3): The director is the administrative head of the office and shall serve as an advisor to the governor on family issues.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-243(4): The office shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-243(4)(a): promote policies and develop initiatives which support the needs of families and children;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-243(4)(b): analyze the impact of laws, government policies, boards, commissions, rules and regulations, and policy proposals on families, parents, and children;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-243(4)(c): evaluate the impact of tax policies on families and children; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-243(4)(d): advocate for policies that strengthen the ability to create and form families.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-243(5): As necessary, the director may request staff and administrative support from the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-243(6): The office may:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-243(6)(a): coordinate with other governmental entities in fulfilling the office's duties; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-243(6)(b): as allowed by state and federal law, request data or information from other governmental entities that is relevant to the office's duties.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-301 Executive director -- Power to accept funds and gifts.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The executive director may accept and receive such other funds and gifts as may be made available from private and public groups for the purposes of promoting and protecting the public health or for the provision of health services to the people of the state and shall expend the same as appropriated by the Legislature.

------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(1): 26B-1-418 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(1)(a): 26B-1-418 "Advisory committee" means the Brain and Spinal Cord Injury Advisory Committee created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(1)(b): "Qualified charitable clinic" means a professional medical clinic that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(1)(b)(i): provides therapeutic services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(1)(b)(ii): employs licensed therapy clinicians;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(1)(b)(iii): has at least five years experience operating a post-acute care rehabilitation clinic in the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(1)(b)(iv): has obtained tax-exempt status under Internal Revenue Code, 26 U.S.C. Sec. 501(c)(3).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(1)(c)(i): "Therapeutic services" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(1)(c)(i)(A): rehabilitation services to individuals who have a spinal cord or brain injury that tends to be non-progressive or non-deteriorating and require post-acute care; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(1)(c)(i)(B): rehabilitation services for children with neurological conditions and who require post-acute care.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(1)(c)(ii): "Therapeutic services" include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(1)(c)(ii)(A): physical, occupational, and speech therapy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(1)(c)(ii)(B): other services as determined by the department, in consultation with the advisory committee, through rule made in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(2): There is created an expendable special revenue fund known as the "Brain and Spinal Cord Injury Fund."
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(3): 41-6a-1406; 41-1a-1201; 41-22-8 The fund shall consist of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(3)(a): gifts, grants, donations, or any other conveyance of money that may be made to the fund from private sources; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(3)(b): additional amounts as appropriated by the Legislature;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(3)(c): 41-6a-1406 a portion of the impound fee as designated in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(3)(d): 41-1a-1201; 41-22-8 the fees collected by the Motor Vehicle Division under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(4): The fund shall be administered by the executive director, in consultation with the advisory committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(5): Fund money may be used to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(5)(a): educate the general public and professionals regarding understanding, treatment, and prevention of brain injury;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(5)(b): provide access to evaluations and coordinate short-term care to assist an individual in identifying services or support needs, resources, and benefits for which the individual may be eligible;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(5)(c): develop and support an information and referral system for persons with a brain injury and their families;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(5)(d): provide grants to persons or organizations to provide the services described in Subsections (5)(a), (b), and (c);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(5)(e): assist one or more qualified charitable clinics to provide therapeutic services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(5)(f): purchase equipment for use in the qualified charitable clinic.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(6): Each year, approximately no less than:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(6)(a): 40% of the fund shall be used for programs and services described in Subsections (5)(a) through (d);

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(6)(c): 10 % of the fund shall be used to assist children with neurological conditions under Subsections (5)(e) and (f).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(7): An individual who receives services either paid for from the fund, or through an organization under contract with the fund, shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(7)(a): be a resident of Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(7)(b): have been diagnosed by a qualified professional as having a brain injury or other neurological condition which results in impairment of cognitive or physical function; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(7)(c): have a need that can be met within the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-318(8): The fund may not duplicate any services or support mechanisms being provided to an individual by any other government or private agency.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328 Psychiatric and Psychotherapeutic Consultation Program Account -- Creation -- Administration -- Uses.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(1): 35A-3-102; 58-67-102; 58-70a-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(1)(a): 35A-3-102 "Child care" means the child care services defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(1)(b): "Child care provider" means a person who provides child care or mental health support or interventions to a child during early childhood.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(1)(c): "Child mental health care facility" means a facility that provides licensed mental health care programs and services to children and families and employs a child mental health therapist.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(1)(d): "Child mental health therapist" means a mental health therapist who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(1)(d)(i): is knowledgeable and trained in early childhood mental health; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(1)(d)(ii): provides mental health services to children during early childhood.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(1)(e): "Division" means the Division of Integrated Healthcare within the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(1)(f): "Early childhood" means the time during which a child is zero to six years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(1)(g): "Early childhood psychotherapeutic telehealth consultation" means a consultation regarding a child's mental health care during the child's early childhood between a child care provider or a mental health therapist and a child mental health therapist that is focused on psychotherapeutic and psychosocial interventions and is completed through the use of electronic or telephonic communication.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(1)(h): "Health care facility" means a facility that provides licensed health care programs and services and employs at least two psychiatrists, at least one of whom is a child psychiatrist.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(1)(i): 58-67-102; 58-70a-102 "Primary care provider" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(1)(i)(i): an individual who is licensed to practice as an advanced practice registered nurse under Title 58, Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(1)(i)(ii): 58-67-102 a physician as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(1)(i)(iii): 58-70a-102 a physician assistant as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(1)(j): "Psychiatrist" means a physician who is board eligible for a psychiatry specialization recognized by the American Board of Medical Specialists or the American Osteopathic Association's Bureau of Osteopathic Specialists.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(1)(k): "Telehealth psychiatric consultation" means a consultation regarding a patient's mental health care, including diagnostic clarification, medication adjustment, or treatment planning, between a primary care provider and a psychiatrist that is completed through the use of electronic or telephonic communication.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(2): 58-60-102 Upon appropriation, the Office of Substance Use and Mental Health shall award grants from the appropriation to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(2)(a): at least one health care facility to implement a program that provides a primary care provider access to a telehealth psychiatric consultation when the primary care provider is evaluating a patient for or providing a patient mental health treatment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(2)(b): 58-60-102 at least one child mental health care facility to implement a program that provides access to an early childhood psychotherapeutic telehealth consultation to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(2)(b)(i): 58-60-102 a mental health therapist as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(2)(b)(ii): a child care provider when the child care provider is providing child care to a child.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(3): The Office of Substance Use and Mental Health may award and distribute grant money to a health care facility or child mental health care facility only if the health care facility or child mental health care facility:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(3)(a): is located in the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(3)(b): submits an application in accordance with Subsection (4).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(4): An application for a grant under this section shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(4)(a): the number of psychiatrists employed by the health care facility or the number of child mental health therapists employed by the child mental health care facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(4)(b): the health care facility's or child mental health care facility's plan to implement the telehealth psychiatric consultation program or the early childhood psychotherapeutic telehealth consultation program described in Subsection (2);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(4)(c): the estimated cost to implement the telehealth psychiatric consultation program or the early childhood psychotherapeutic telehealth consultation program described in Subsection (2);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(4)(d): any plan to use one or more funding sources in addition to a grant under this section to implement the telehealth psychiatric consultation program or the early childhood psychotherapeutic telehealth consultation program described in Subsection (2);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(4)(e): the amount of grant money requested to fund the telehealth psychiatric consultation program or the early childhood psychotherapeutic telehealth consultation program described in Subsection (2); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(4)(f): any existing or planned contract or partnership between the health care facility and another person to implement the telehealth psychiatric consultation program or the early childhood psychotherapeutic telehealth consultation program described in Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(5): A health care facility or child mental health care facility that receives grant money under this section shall file a report with the division before October 1 of each year that details for the immediately preceding calendar year:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(5)(a): the type and effectiveness of each service provided in the telehealth psychiatric program or the early childhood psychotherapeutic telehealth consultation program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(5)(b): the utilization of the telehealth psychiatric program or the early childhood psychotherapeutic telehealth consultation program based on metrics or categories determined by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(5)(c): the total amount expended from the grant money; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-328(5)(d): the intended use for grant money that has not been expended.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-329(1)(b)(i): conducting a professional evaluation of an individual's condition of mental health, mental illness, or emotional disorder consistent with standards generally recognized by mental health therapists;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-329(1)(b)(ii): establishing a diagnosis in accordance with established written standards generally recognized by mental health therapists;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-329(1)(b)(iii): prescribing a plan or medication for the prevention or treatment of a condition of a mental illness or an emotional disorder; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-329(1)(b)(iv): engaging in the conduct of professional intervention, including psychotherapy by the application of established methods and procedures generally recognized by mental health therapists.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-334 Licensed Provider Assessment Fund -- Creation -- Deposits -- Uses.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-334(1): Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection; Title 26B, Chapter 1, Part 4, Child Care Licensing; Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 1, Human Services Programs and Facilities There is created an expendable special revenue fund known as the "Licensed Provider Assessment Fund" consisting of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-334(1)(a): Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection; Title 26B, Chapter 1, Part 4, Child Care Licensing; Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 1, Human Services Programs and Facilities the assessments collected under, and any interest and penalties levied with the administration of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-334(1)(a)(i): Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-334(1)(a)(ii): Title 26B, Chapter 1, Part 4, Child Care Licensing
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-334(1)(a)(iii): Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 1, Human Services Programs and Facilities
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-334(1)(b): money appropriated or otherwise made available by the Legislature; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-334(1)(c): any interest earned on the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-334(2): Money in the fund may only be used by the department:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-334(2)(a): for upgrades to and maintenance of licensing databases and applications;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-334(2)(b): for training for providers and staff;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-334(2)(c): to assist individuals during a facility shutdown; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-334(2)(d): for administrative expenses, if the administrative expenses for the fiscal year do not exceed 3% of the money deposited into the fund during the fiscal year.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-335 Division of Services for People with Disabilities Restricted Account.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-335(1): As used in this section, "account" means the Division of Services for People with Disabilities Restricted Account created in Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-335(2): There is created a restricted account within the General Fund known as the "Division of Services for People with Disabilities Restricted Account."
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-335(3): The account consists of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-335(3)(a): carry forward funds from the division's budget; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-335(3)(b): unexpended balances lapsed to the account from the division's budget.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-335(4): At the close of a fiscal year, the division may, without an appropriation, deposit into the account carry forward funds described in Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-335(5): Subject to appropriation, the Department of Health and Human Services may expend funds from the account to serve individuals eligible for division services statewide.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402 Rare Disease Advisory Council Grant Program -- Creation -- Reporting.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(1)(a): "Council" means the Rare Disease Advisory Council described in Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(1)(b): "Grantee" means the recipient of a grant under this section to operate the program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(1)(c): "Rare disease" means a disease that affects fewer than 200,000 individuals in the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(2)(a): Within legislative appropriations, the department shall issue a request for proposals for a grant to administer the provisions of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(2)(b): The department may issue a grant under this section if the grantee agrees to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(2)(b)(i): convene the council in accordance with Subsection (3);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(2)(b)(ii): provide staff and other administrative support to the council; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(2)(b)(iii): in coordination with the department, report to the Legislature in accordance with Subsection (4).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(3): The Rare Disease Advisory Council convened by the grantee shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(3)(a): advise the Legislature and state agencies on providing services and care to individuals with a rare disease;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(3)(b): make recommendations to the Legislature and state agencies on improving access to treatment and services provided to individuals with a rare disease;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(3)(c): identify best practices to improve the care and treatment of individuals in the state with a rare disease;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(3)(d): meet at least two times in each calendar year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(3)(e): be composed of members identified by the department, including at least the following individuals:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(3)(e)(i): a representative from the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(3)(e)(ii): researchers and physicians who specialize in rare diseases, including at least one representative from the University of Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(3)(e)(iii): two individuals who have a rare disease or are the parent or caregiver of an individual with a rare disease; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(3)(e)(iv): two representatives from one or more rare disease patient organizations that operate in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(4): Before November 30 of every odd-numbered year, the grantee shall report to the Health and Human Services Interim Committee on:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(4)(a): the activities of the grantee and the council; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-402(4)(b): recommendations and best practices regarding the ongoing needs of individuals in the state with a rare disease.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409 Utah Digital Health Service Commission -- Creation -- Membership -- Duties.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(1)(a): "Commission" means the Utah Digital Health Service Commission created in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(1)(b): "Digital health service" means the electronic transfer, exchange, or management of related data for diagnosis, treatment, consultation, educational, public health, or other related purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(2): There is created within the department the Utah Digital Health Service Commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(3): 26B-2-201 The governor shall appoint or reappoint 13 members to the commission with the advice and consent of the Senate, as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(3)(a): a physician who is involved in digital health service;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(3)(b): 26B-2-201 a representative of a health care system or a licensed health care facility as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(3)(c): a representative of rural Utah, which may be a person nominated by an advisory committee on rural health issues;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(3)(d): a member of the public who is not involved with digital health service;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(3)(e): a nurse who is involved in digital health service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(3)(f): eight members who fall into one or more of the following categories:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(3)(f)(i): individuals who use digital health service in a public or private institution;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(3)(f)(ii): individuals who use digital health service in serving medically underserved populations;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(3)(f)(iii): nonphysician health care providers involved in digital health service;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(3)(f)(iv): information technology professionals involved in digital health service;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(3)(f)(v): representatives of the health insurance industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(3)(f)(vi): telehealth digital health service consumer advocates; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(3)(f)(vii): individuals who use digital health service in serving mental or behavioral health populations.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(4)(a): The commission shall annually elect a chairperson from its membership.  The chairperson shall report to the executive director of the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(4)(b): The commission shall hold meetings at least once every three months.  Meetings may be held from time to time on the call of the chair or a majority of the board members.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(4)(c): Seven commission members are necessary to constitute a quorum at any meeting and, if a quorum exists, the action of a majority of members present shall be the action of the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(5)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (5)(b), a commission member shall be appointed for a three-year term and eligible for two reappointments.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(5)(b): Notwithstanding Subsection (5)(a), the governor shall, at the time of appointment or reappointment, adjust the length of terms to ensure that the terms of commission members are staggered so that approximately 1/3 of the commission is appointed each year.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(5)(c): A commission member shall continue in office until the expiration of the member's term and until a successor is appointed, which may not exceed 90 days after the formal expiration of the term.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(5)(d): Notwithstanding Subsection (5)(c), a commission member who fails to attend 75% of the scheduled meetings in a calendar year shall be disqualified from serving.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(5)(e): When a vacancy occurs in membership for any reason, the governor shall, with the advice and consent of the Senate, appoint a replacement for the unexpired term.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(6): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 A member may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service, but, at the executive director's discretion, may receive per diem and travel expenses in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(6)(a): 63A-3-106 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(6)(b): 63A-3-107 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(6)(c): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 rules made by the Division of Finance pursuant to Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(7): The department shall provide informatics staff support to the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(8): The funding of the commission shall be a separate line item to the department in the annual appropriations act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(9): The commission shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(9)(a): advise and make recommendations on digital health service issues to the department and other state entities;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(9)(b): advise and make recommendations on digital health service related patient privacy and information security to the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(9)(c): promote collaborative efforts to establish technical compatibility, uniform policies, privacy features, and information security to meet legal, financial, commercial, and other societal requirements;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(9)(d): identify, address, and seek to resolve the legal, ethical, regulatory, financial, medical, and technological issues that may serve as barriers to digital health service;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(9)(e): explore and encourage the development of digital health service systems as a means of reducing health care costs and increasing health care quality and access, with emphasis on assisting rural health care providers and special populations with access to or development of electronic medical records;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(9)(f): seek public input on digital health service issues; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(9)(g): in consultation with the department, advise the governor and Legislature on:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(9)(g)(i): the role of digital health service in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(9)(g)(ii): the policy issues related to digital health service;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(9)(g)(iii): the changing digital health service needs and resources in the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-409(9)(g)(iv): state budgetary matters related to digital health service.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-411 Creation and membership of Kurt Oscarson Children's Organ Transplant Coordinating Committee -- Expenses -- Purposes.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-411(1): There is created the Kurt Oscarson Children's Organ Transplant Coordinating Committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-411(2): The committee shall have five members representing the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-411(2)(a): the executive director or the executive director's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-411(2)(b): two representatives from public or private agencies and organizations concerned with providing support and financial assistance to the children and families of children who need organ transplants; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-411(2)(c): two individuals who have had organ transplants, have children who have had organ transplants, who work with families or children who have had or are awaiting organ transplants, or community leaders or volunteers who have demonstrated an interest in working with families or children in need of organ transplants.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-420(13)(c): a list of potential drug-drug interactions between medications that the United States Food and Drug Administration has approved and cannabis, cannabinoid products, and expanded cannabinoid products; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-420(13)(d): any other guideline the board determines appropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-420(14): (13) The board shall submit the guidelines described in Subsection
