Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421 Compassionate Use Board.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(1): 26B-4-201 The definitions in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(2)(a): The department shall establish a Compassionate Use Board consisting of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(2)(a)(i): seven qualified medical providers that the executive director appoints with the advice and consent of the Senate:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(2)(a)(i)(A): who are knowledgeable about the medicinal use of cannabis;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(2)(a)(i)(B): who are physicians licensed under Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act, or Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(2)(a)(i)(C): who are board certified by the American Board of Medical Specialties or an American Osteopathic Association Specialty Certifying Board in the specialty of neurology, pain medicine and pain management, medical oncology, psychiatry, infectious disease, internal medicine, pediatrics, family medicine, or gastroenterology; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(2)(a)(ii): as a nonvoting member and the chair of the Compassionate Use Board, the executive director or the director's designee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(2)(b): In appointing the seven qualified medical providers described in Subsection (2)(a), the executive director shall ensure that at least two have a board certification in pediatrics.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(3)(a): Of the members of the Compassionate Use Board that the executive director first appoints:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(3)(a)(i): three shall serve an initial term of two years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(3)(a)(ii): the remaining members shall serve an initial term of four years.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(3)(b): After an initial term described in Subsection (3)(a) expires:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(3)(b)(i): each term is four years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(3)(b)(ii): each board member is eligible for reappointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(3)(c): A member of the Compassionate Use Board may serve until a successor is appointed.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(3)(d): Four members constitute a quorum of the Compassionate Use Board.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(4): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-107 A member of the Compassionate Use Board may receive:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(4)(a): 63A-3-106 notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(4)(b): 63A-3-107; 63A-3-107 travel expenses in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5): 26B-4-213; 26B-4-213; 26B-4-213; 26B-4-213 The Compassionate Use Board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5)(a): 26B-4-213; 26B-4-213 review and recommend for department approval a petition to the board regarding an individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5)(a)(i): for an individual who is not otherwise qualified to receive a medical cannabis card, the individual's recommending medical provider is actively treating the individual for an intractable condition that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5)(a)(i)(A): substantially impairs the individual's quality of life; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5)(a)(i)(B): has not, in the recommending medical provider's professional opinion, adequately responded to conventional treatments;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5)(a)(ii): the recommending medical provider:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5)(a)(ii)(A): recommends that the individual or minor be allowed to use medical cannabis; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5)(a)(ii)(B): provides a letter, relevant treatment history, and notes or copies of progress notes describing relevant treatment history including rationale for considering the use of medical cannabis; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5)(a)(iii): the Compassionate Use Board determines that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5)(a)(iii)(A): the recommendation of the individual's recommending medical provider is justified; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5)(a)(iii)(B): based on available information, it may be in the best interests of the individual to allow the use of medical cannabis;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5)(b): 26B-4-213; 26B-4-213 when a recommending medical provider recommends that an individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5)(c): unless no petitions are pending:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5)(c)(i): meet to receive or review compassionate use petitions at least quarterly; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5)(c)(ii): if there are more petitions than the board can receive or review during the board's regular schedule, as often as necessary;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5)(d): except as provided in Subsection (6), complete a review of each petition and recommend to the department approval or denial of the applicant for qualification for a medical cannabis card within 90 days after the day on which the board received the petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5)(e): consult with the department regarding the criteria described in Subsection (6); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5)(f): report, before November 1 of each year, to the Health and Human Services Interim Committee and the Medical Cannabis Governance Structure Working Group:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5)(f)(i): the number of compassionate use recommendations the board issued during the past year;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5)(f)(ii): the types of conditions for which the board recommended compassionate use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(5)(f)(iii): the number of applications that are not completed.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(6): The department shall make rules, in consultation with the Compassionate Use Board and in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to establish a process and criteria for a petition to the board to automatically qualify for expedited final review and approval or denial by the department in cases where, in the determination of the department and the board:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(6)(a): time is of the essence;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(6)(b): engaging the full review process would be unreasonable in light of the petitioner's physical condition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(6)(c): sufficient factors are present regarding the petitioner's safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(7)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(7)(a)(i): The department shall review:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(7)(a)(i)(A): any compassionate use for which the Compassionate Use Board recommends approval under Subsection (5)(d) to determine whether the board properly exercised the board's discretion under this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(7)(a)(i)(B): any expedited petitions the department receives under the process described in Subsection (6).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(7)(a)(ii): If the department determines that the Compassionate Use Board properly exercised the board's discretion in recommending approval under Subsection (5)(d) or that the expedited petition merits approval based on the criteria established in accordance with Subsection (6), the department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(7)(a)(ii)(A): issue the relevant medical cannabis card; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(7)(a)(ii)(B): provide for the renewal of the medical cannabis card in accordance with the recommendation of the recommending medical provider described in Subsection (5)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(7)(b): If the Compassionate Use Board recommends denial under Subsection (5)(d), the individual seeking to obtain a medical cannabis card may petition the department to review the board's decision.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(7)(c): In reviewing the Compassionate Use Board's recommendation for approval or denial under Subsection (5)(d) in accordance with this Subsection (7), the department shall presume the board properly exercised the board's discretion unless the department determines that the board's recommendation was arbitrary or capricious.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(8): Any individually identifiable health information contained in a petition that the Compassionate Use Board or department receives under this section is a protected record in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(9): The Compassionate Use Board shall annually report the board's activity to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(9)(a): the Cannabis Research Review Board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-421(9)(b): the advisory board.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422 Early Childhood Utah Advisory Council -- Creation -- Compensation -- Duties.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(1): 53E-3-301 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(1)(a): "Early childhood" refers to a child in the state who is eight years old or younger; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(1)(b): 53E-3-301 "State superintendent" means the state superintendent of public instruction appointed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(2): There is created the Early Childhood Utah Advisory Council.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(3)(a): The department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(3)(a)(i): make rules establishing the membership, duties, and procedures of the council in accordance with the requirements of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(3)(a)(i)(A): this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(3)(a)(i)(B): the Improving Head Start for School Readiness Act of 2007, 42 U.S.C. Sec. 9837b; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(3)(a)(i)(C): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(3)(a)(ii): provide necessary administrative and staff support to the council.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(3)(b): A member of the council may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(4): The duties of the council include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(4)(a): improving and coordinating the quality of programs and services for children in accordance with the Improving Head Start for School Readiness Act of 2007, 42 U.S.C. Sec. 9837b;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(4)(b): supporting Utah parents and families by providing comprehensive and accurate information regarding the availability of voluntary services for children in early childhood from state agencies and other private and public entities;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(4)(c): facilitating improved coordination between state agencies and community partners that provide services to children in early childhood;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(4)(d): sharing and analyzing information regarding early childhood issues in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(4)(e): providing recommendations to the department, the Department of Workforce Services, and the State Board of Education regarding a comprehensive delivery system of services for children in early childhood that addresses the following four areas:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(4)(e)(i): family support and safety;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(4)(e)(ii): health and development;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(4)(e)(iii): early learning; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(4)(e)(iv): economic development; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(4)(f): identifying opportunities for and barriers to the alignment of standards, rules, policies, and procedures across programs and agencies that support children in early childhood.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5): To fulfill the duties described in Subsection (4), the council shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5)(a): directly engage with parents, families, community members, and public and private service providers to identify and address:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5)(a)(i): the quality, effectiveness, and availability of existing services for children in early childhood and the coordination of those services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5)(a)(ii): gaps and barriers to entry in the provision of services for children in early childhood; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5)(a)(iii): community-based solutions in improving the quality, effectiveness, and availability of services for children in early childhood;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5)(b): seek regular and ongoing feedback from a wide range of entities and individuals that use or provide services for children in early childhood, including entities and individuals that use, represent, or provide services for any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5)(b)(i): children in early childhood who live in urban, suburban, or rural areas of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5)(b)(ii): children in early childhood with varying socioeconomic backgrounds;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5)(b)(iii): children in early childhood with varying ethnic or racial heritages;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5)(b)(iv): children in early childhood from various geographic areas of the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5)(b)(v): children in early childhood with special needs;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5)(c): study, evaluate, and report on the status and effectiveness of policies, procedures, and programs that provide services to children in early childhood;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5)(d): study and evaluate the effectiveness of policies, procedures, and programs implemented by other states and nongovernmental entities that address the needs of children in early childhood;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5)(e): identify policies, procedures, and programs that are impeding efforts to help children in early childhood in the state and recommend changes to those policies, procedures, and programs;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5)(f): identify policies, procedures, and programs related to children in early childhood in the state that are inefficient or duplicative and recommend changes to those policies, procedures, and programs;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5)(g): recommend policy, procedure, and program changes to address the needs of children in early childhood;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5)(h): develop methods for using interagency information to inform comprehensive policy and budget decisions relating to early childhood services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5)(i): develop strategies and monitor efforts concerning:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5)(i)(i): increasing school readiness;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5)(i)(ii): improving access to early child care and early education programs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(5)(i)(iii): improving family and community engagement in early childhood education and development.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(6): In fulfilling the council's duties, the council may request and receive, from any state or local governmental agency or institution, information relating to early childhood, including reports, audits, projections, and statistics.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422(7): On or before August 1, 2024, and at least every five years thereafter, the council shall provide to the executive director, the executive director of the Department of Workforce Services, and the state superintendent a statewide needs assessment concerning the quality and availability of early childhood education, health, and development programs and services for children in early childhood.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422.1 Reports.
------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422.1(1): 26B-1-422; 26B-1-422
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422.1(1)(a): 26B-1-422 On or before August 1 of each year, the Early Childhood Utah Advisory Council created in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422.1(1)(b)(ii)(B): evaluating the overall participation of children in existing federal, state, and local child care programs and early childhood health, development, family support, and education programs;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422.1(1)(b)(ii)(D): recommending improvements to the state's early learning standards and high-quality comprehensive early learning standards; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422.1(1)(b)(iii): 26B-1-422 the recommendations described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-422.1(2): In addition to the annual report described in Subsection (1)(a), on or before August 1, 2024, and at least every five years thereafter, the council shall provide to the executive director, the executive director of the Department of Workforce Services, and the state superintendent, a statewide needs assessment concerning the quality and availability of early childhood education, health, and development programs and services for children in early childhood.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-425(4): 26B-4-705 The executive director shall appoint at least five but not more than ten additional members that represent diverse perspectives regarding Utah's health workforce as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-425(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-425(5)(a): A member appointed by the executive director under Subsection (4) shall serve a four-year term.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-425(7)(b)(v): advise the Utah Board of Higher Education and the Legislature on the status and needs of the health workforce who are in training.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426 Board of Aging and Adult Services -- Members, appointment, terms, vacancies, chairperson, compensation, meetings, quorum.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(1): 26B-1-204 The Board of Aging and Adult Services created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(2)(a): Except as required by Subsection (2)(b), each member shall be appointed for a term of four years, and is eligible for one reappointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(2)(b): Notwithstanding the requirements of Subsection (2)(a), the governor shall, at the time of appointment or reappointment, adjust the length of terms to ensure that the terms of board members are staggered so that approximately half of the board is appointed every two years.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(2)(c): Board members shall continue in office until the expiration of their terms and until their successors are appointed, which may not exceed 90 days after the formal expiration of a term.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(2)(d): When a vacancy occurs in the membership for any reason, the governor shall, with the advice and consent of the Senate in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 2, Vacancies, appoint a replacement for the unexpired term.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(3)(a): No more than four members of the board may be from the same political party.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(3)(b): The board shall have diversity of gender, ethnicity, and culture; and members shall be chosen on the basis of their active interest, experience, and demonstrated ability to deal with issues related to  the Board of Aging and Adult Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(4)(a): The board shall annually elect a chairperson from the board's membership.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(4)(b): The board shall hold meetings at least once every three months.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(4)(c): Within budgetary constraints, meetings may be held from time to time on the call of the chairperson or of the majority of the members of the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(4)(d): Four members of the board are necessary to constitute a quorum at any meeting, and, if a quorum exists, the action of the majority of members present shall be the action of the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(5): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 A member may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service, but, at the executive director's discretion, may receive per diem and travel expenses in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(5)(a): 63A-3-106 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(5)(b): 63A-3-107 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(5)(c): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 rules made by the Division of Finance pursuant to Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(6)(a): The board shall adopt bylaws governing its activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(6)(b): The bylaws described in Subsection (6)(a) shall include procedures for removal of a board member who is unable or unwilling to fulfill the requirements of the board member's appointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(7): The board has program policymaking authority for the division over which the board presides.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-426(8): A member of the board shall comply with the conflict of interest provisions described in Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 3, Conflicts of Interest.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427 Alcohol Abuse Tracking Committee -- Tracking effects of abuse of alcoholic products.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(1): There is created a committee within the department known as the Alcohol Abuse Tracking Committee that consists of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(1)(a): the executive director or the executive director's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(1)(b): the commissioner of the Department of Public Safety or the commissioner's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(1)(c): the director of the Department of Alcoholic Beverage Services or that director's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(1)(d): the executive director of the Department of Workforce Services or that executive director's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(1)(e): the chair of the Utah Substance Use and Mental Health Advisory Council or the chair's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(1)(f): the state court administrator or the state court administrator's designee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(1)(g): the director of the Division of Technology Services or that director's designee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(2): The executive director or the executive director's designee shall chair the committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(3)(a): Four members of the committee constitute a quorum.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(3)(b): A vote of the majority of the committee members present when a quorum is present is an action of the committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(4): The committee shall meet at the call of the chair, except that the chair shall call a meeting at least twice a year:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(4)(a): with one meeting held each year to develop the report required under Subsection (7); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(4)(b): with one meeting held to review and finalize the report before the report is issued.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(5): The committee may adopt additional procedures or requirements for:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(5)(a): voting, when there is a tie of the committee members;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(5)(b): how meetings are to be called; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(5)(c): the frequency of meetings.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(6): The committee shall establish a process to collect for each calendar year the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(6)(a): the number of individuals statewide who are convicted of, plead guilty to, plead no contest to, plead guilty in a similar manner to, or resolve by diversion or its equivalent to a violation related to underage drinking of alcohol;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(6)(b): the number of individuals statewide who are convicted of, plead guilty to, plead no contest to, plead guilty in a similar manner to, or resolve by diversion or its equivalent to a violation related to driving under the influence of alcohol;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(6)(c): the number of violations statewide of Title 32B, Alcoholic Beverage Control Act, related to over-serving or over-consumption of an alcoholic product;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(6)(d): the cost of social services provided by the state related to abuse of alcohol, including services provided by the Division of Child and Family Services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(6)(e): the location where the alcoholic products that result in the violations or costs described in Subsections (6)(a) through (d) are obtained; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(6)(f): any information the committee determines can be collected and relates to the abuse of alcoholic products.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(7): The committee shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(7)(a): report the information collected under Subsection (6) annually to the governor, the Law Enforcement and Criminal Justice Interim Committee, and the State Commission on Criminal and Juvenile Justice by no later than the July 1 immediately following the calendar year for which the information is collected; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-427(7)(b): provide all data collected before January 1, 2024, under Subsection (6) to the State Commission on Criminal and Juvenile Justice.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429 Utah State Developmental Center Board -- Creation -- Membership -- Duties -- Powers.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(1): There is created the Utah State Developmental Center Board within the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(2): The board is composed of nine members as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(2)(a): the director of the Division of Services for People with Disabilities or the director's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(2)(b): the superintendent of the developmental center or the superintendent's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(2)(c): the executive director or the executive director's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(2)(d): a resident of the Utah State Developmental Center selected by the superintendent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(2)(e): five members appointed or reappointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the Senate as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(2)(e)(i): three members of the general public; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(2)(e)(ii): two members who are parents or guardians of individuals who receive services at the Utah State Developmental Center.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(3): In making appointments to the board, the governor shall ensure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(3)(a): no more than three members have immediate family residing at the Utah State Developmental Center; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(3)(b): members represent a variety of geographic areas and economic interests of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(4)(a): The governor shall appoint each member described in Subsection (2)(e) for a term of four years.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(4)(b): An appointed member may not serve more than two full consecutive terms unless the governor determines that an additional term is in the best interest of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(4)(c): Notwithstanding the requirements of Subsections (4)(a) and (b), the governor shall, at the time of appointment or reappointment, adjust the length of terms to ensure that the terms of appointed members are staggered so that approximately half of the appointed members are appointed every two years.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(4)(d): Appointed members shall continue in office until the expiration of their terms and until their successors are appointed, which may not exceed 120 days after the formal expiration of a term.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(4)(e): When a vacancy occurs in the membership for any reason, the governor shall, with the advice and consent of the Senate, appoint a replacement for the unexpired term.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(5)(a): The director shall serve as the chair.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(5)(b): The board shall appoint a member to serve as vice chair.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(5)(c): The board shall hold meetings quarterly or as needed.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(5)(d): Five members are necessary to constitute a quorum at any meeting, and, if a quorum exists, the action of the majority of members present shall be the action of the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(5)(e): The chair shall be a non-voting member except that the chair may vote to break a tie vote between the voting members.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(6): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 An appointed member may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service, but, at the executive director's discretion, may receive per diem and travel expenses in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(6)(a): 63A-3-106 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(6)(b): 63A-3-107 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(6)(c): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 rules made by the Division of Finance pursuant to Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(7)(a): The board shall adopt bylaws governing the board's activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(7)(b): Bylaws shall include procedures for removal of a member who is unable or unwilling to fulfill the requirements of the member's appointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(8): 26B-6-402; 26B-6-403; 26B-6-502; 26B-6-504; 26B-6-506; 26B-1-330; 26B-1-331; 26B-6-507; 10-2-419 The board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(8)(a): act for the benefit of the Utah State Developmental Center and the Division of Services for People with Disabilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(8)(b): 26B-6-402; 26B-6-403; 26B-6-502; 26B-6-504; 26B-6-506 advise and assist the Division of Services for People with Disabilities with the division's functions, operations, and duties related to the Utah State Developmental Center, described in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(8)(c): 26B-1-330 administer the Utah State Developmental Center Miscellaneous Donation Fund, as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(8)(d): 26B-1-331 administer the Utah State Developmental Center Long-Term Sustainability Fund, as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(8)(e): 26B-6-507 approve the sale, lease, or other disposition of real property or water rights associated with the Utah State Developmental Center, as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-429(8)(f): 10-2-419 within 21 days after the day on which the board receives the notice required under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435 Medical Cannabis Policy Advisory Board creation -- Membership -- Duties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(1): There is created within the department the Medical Cannabis Policy Advisory Board.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(2): 4-41a-102
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(2)(a): 4-41a-102 The advisory board shall consist of the following members:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(2)(a)(i): appointed by the executive director:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(2)(a)(i)(A): a qualified medical provider who has recommended medical cannabis to at least 100 patients before being appointed;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(2)(a)(i)(B): a medical research professional;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(2)(a)(i)(C): a mental health specialist;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(2)(a)(i)(D): an individual who represents an organization that advocates for medical cannabis patients;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(2)(a)(i)(E): an individual who holds a medical cannabis patient card; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(2)(a)(i)(F): a member of the general public who does not hold a medical cannabis card; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(2)(a)(ii): 4-41a-102 appointed by the commissioner of the Department of Agriculture and Food:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(2)(a)(ii)(A): 4-41a-102 an individual who owns or operates a licensed cannabis cultivation facility, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(2)(a)(ii)(B): an individual who owns or operates a licensed medical cannabis pharmacy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(2)(a)(ii)(C): a law enforcement officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(2)(b): The commissioner of the Department of Agriculture and Food shall ensure that at least one individual appointed under Subsection (2)(a)(ii)(A) or (B) also owns or operates a licensed cannabis processing facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(3)(a): Subject to Subsection (3)(b), a member of the advisory board shall serve for a four year term.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(3)(b): When appointing the initial membership of the advisory board, the executive director and the commissioner of the Department of Agriculture and Food shall coordinate to appoint four advisory board members to serve a term of two years to ensure that approximately half of the board is appointed every two years.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(4)(a): If an advisory board member is no longer able to serve as a member, a new member shall be appointed in the same manner as the original appointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(4)(b): A member appointed in accordance with Subsection (4)(a) shall serve for the remainder of the unexpired term of the original appointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(5)(a): A majority of the advisory board members constitutes a quorum.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(5)(b): The action of a majority of a quorum constitutes an action of the advisory board.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(5)(c): For a term lasting one year, the advisory board shall annually designate members of the advisory board to serve as chair and vice-chair.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(5)(d): When designating the chair and vice-chair, the advisory board shall ensure that at least one individual described Subsection (2)(a)(i) is appointed as chair or vice-chair.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(6): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 An advisory board member may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service on the advisory board but may receive per diem and reimbursement for travel expenses incurred as an advisory board member in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(6)(a): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(6)(b): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 rules made by the Division of Finance pursuant to Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(7): The department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(7)(a): provide staff support for the advisory board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(7)(b): assist the advisory board in conducting meetings.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(8): The advisory board may recommend:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(8)(a): to the department or the Department of Agriculture and Food changes to current or proposed medical cannabis rules or statutes;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-435(8)(b): to the appropriate legislative committee whether the advisory board supports a change to medical cannabis statutes.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(1): 80-1-102 "Abuse" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(2): 80-1-102 "Child" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(3): 26B-1-503; 26B-1-504 "Committee" means a fatality review committee that is formed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(4): 80-1-102 "Dependency" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(5): 26B-1-502 "Formal review" means a review of a death or a near fatality that is ordered under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(6): "Near fatality" means alleged abuse or neglect that, as certified by a physician or physician assistant, places a child in serious or critical condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7): "Qualified individual" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(a): at the time that the individual dies, is a resident of a facility or program that is owned or operated by the department or a division of the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(b)(i): is in the custody of the department or a division of the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(b)(ii): is placed in a residential placement by the department or a division of the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(c): at the time that the individual dies, has an open case for the receipt of child welfare services, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(c)(i): an investigation for abuse, neglect, or dependency;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(c)(ii): foster care;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(c)(iii): in-home services; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(c)(iv): substitute care;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(d): had an open case for the receipt of child welfare services within one year before the day on which the individual dies;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(e): was the subject of an accepted referral received by Adult Protective Services within one year before the day on which the individual dies, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(e)(i): the department or a division of the department is aware of the death; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(e)(ii): the death is reported as a homicide, suicide, or an undetermined cause;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(f): received services from, or under the direction of, the Division of Services for People with Disabilities within one year before the day on which the individual dies;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(g): dies within 60 days after the day on which the individual is discharged from the Utah State Hospital, if the department is aware of the death;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(h): is a child who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(h)(i): suffers a near fatality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(h)(ii): is the subject of an open case for the receipt of child welfare services within one year before the day on which the child suffered the near fatality, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(h)(ii)(A): an investigation for abuse, neglect, or dependency;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(h)(ii)(B): foster care;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(h)(ii)(C): in-home services; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(h)(ii)(D): substitute care; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(7)(i): is designated as a qualified individual by the executive director.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(8): 80-1-102 "Neglect" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-501(9): 80-1-102 "Substitute care" means the same as that term is defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502 Initial review.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(1): 26B-1-501; 26B-1-501 Within seven days after the day on which the department knows that a qualified individual has died or is an individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(1)(a): 26B-1-501
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(1)(a)(i): for a death, complete a deceased client report form, created by the department; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(1)(a)(ii): 26B-1-501 for an individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(1)(b): forward the completed client report form to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(1)(b)(i): the director of the office or division that has jurisdiction over the region or facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(1)(b)(ii): the executive director;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(1)(b)(iii): the director of the Division of Continuous Quality and Improvement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(1)(b)(iv): the fatality review coordinator, or the fatality review coordinator's designee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(2): Within 10 days after the day on which the fatality review coordinator or the fatality review coordinator's designee receives a copy of the near fatality client report form or the deceased client report form, the fatality review coordinator or the fatality review coordinator's designee shall request a copy of all relevant department case records, or electronic access to all relevant department case records, regarding the individual who is the subject of the client report form.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(3): Each person who receives a request for a record described in Subsection (2) shall provide a copy of the record, or electronic access to the record, to the fatality review coordinator or the fatality review coordinator's designee, by a secure method, within seven days after the day on which the request is made.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(4): Within 30 days after the day on which the fatality review coordinator or the fatality review coordinator's designee receives the case records requested under Subsection (2), the fatality review coordinator, or the fatality review coordinator's designee, shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(4)(a): review the client report form, the case files, and other relevant information received by the fatality review coordinator; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(4)(b): make a recommendation to the director of the Division of Continuous Quality and Improvement regarding whether a formal review of the death or near fatality should be conducted.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(5): 26B-1-501
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(5)(a): In accordance with Subsection (5)(b), within 14 days after the day on which the fatality review coordinator or the fatality review coordinator's designee makes the recommendation described in Subsection (4)(b), the director of the Division of Continuous Quality and Improvement or the director's designee shall determine whether to order that a review of the death or near fatality be conducted.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(5)(b): 26B-1-501 The director of the Division of Continuous Quality and Improvement or the director's designee shall order that a formal review of the death or near fatality be conducted if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(5)(b)(i): 26B-1-501 at the time of the near fatality or the death, the qualified individual is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(5)(b)(i)(A): 26B-1-501 an individual described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(5)(b)(i)(A)(I): the near fatality or the death is due to a natural cause; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(5)(b)(i)(A)(II): the director of the Division of Continuous Quality and Improvement or the director's designee determines that the near fatality or the death was not in any way related to services that were provided by, or under the direction of, the department or a division of the department; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(5)(b)(i)(B): a child in foster care or substitute care, unless the near fatality or the death is due to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(5)(b)(i)(B)(I): a natural cause; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(5)(b)(i)(B)(II): an accident;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(5)(b)(ii): it appears, based on the information provided to the director of the Division of Continuous Quality and Improvement or the director's designee, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(5)(b)(ii)(A): a provision of law, rule, policy, or procedure relating to the qualified individual or the individual's family may not have been complied with;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(5)(b)(ii)(B): the near fatality or the fatality was not responded to properly;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(5)(b)(ii)(C): a law, rule, policy, or procedure may need to be changed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(5)(b)(ii)(D): additional training is needed;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(5)(b)(iii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(5)(b)(iii)(A): the death is caused by suicide; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(5)(b)(iii)(B): the near fatality is caused by attempted suicide; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-502(5)(b)(iv): the director of the Division of Continuous Quality and Improvement or the director's designee determines that another reason exists to order that a review of the near fatality or the death be conducted.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-504 Fatality review committees for a resident of the Utah State Hospital or the Utah State Developmental Center.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-504(1): If a qualified individual who is the subject of a formal review was a resident of the Utah State Hospital or the Utah State Developmental Center, the fatality review coordinator of that facility shall organize a fatality review committee to review the near fatality or the death.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-504(2): (4); (1) Except as provided in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-505 Fatality review committee proceedings.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-505(1): A majority vote of committee members present constitutes the action of the committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-505(2): 63G-2-305 The department shall give the committee access to all reports, records, and other documents that are relevant to the near fatality or the death under investigation, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-505(2)(a): narrative reports;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-505(2)(b): case files;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-505(2)(c): autopsy reports; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-505(2)(d): 63G-2-305 police reports, unless the report is protected from disclosure under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-505(3): The Utah State Hospital and the Utah State Developmental Center shall provide protected health information to the committee if requested by a fatality review coordinator.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-505(4): A committee shall convene monthly, unless this time is extended, for good cause, by the director of the Division of Continuous Quality and Improvement.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-505(5): A committee may interview a staff member, a provider, or any other person who may have knowledge or expertise that is relevant to the formal review.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-505(6): A committee shall render an advisory opinion regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-505(6)(a): whether the provisions of law, rule, policy, and procedure relating to the qualified individual and the individual's family were complied with;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-505(6)(b): whether the near fatality or the death was responded to properly;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-505(6)(c): whether to recommend that a law, rule, policy, or procedure be changed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-505(6)(d): whether additional training is needed.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-506(1): 26B-1-505; 26B-1-505 Within 20 days after the day on which the committee proceedings described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-506(1)(a): 26B-1-505 a written report to the executive director that includes:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-506(1)(a)(ii): any recommendations regarding action that should be taken in relation to an employee of the department or a person who contracts with the department; and

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-506(2): Within 60 days after the day on which the director described in Subsection (1)(b)(i) receives a copy of the report described in Subsection (1)(a), the department shall provide a written response, with only identifying information redacted, to the Office of Legislative Research and General Counsel, if the report:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-506(2)(b): indicates that the near fatality or the death was not responded to properly;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-506(2)(c): recommends that a law, rule, policy, or procedure be changed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-506(2)(d): indicates that additional training is needed.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-1-506(4): A report described in Subsection (1) and the response described in Subsection (2) is a protected record.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(1): 80-2-801 "Adoption services" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(2): "Adult day care" means nonresidential care and supervision:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(2)(a): for three or more adults for at least four but less than 24 hours a day; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(2)(b): that meets the needs of functionally impaired adults through a comprehensive program that provides a variety of health, social, recreational, and related support services in a protective setting.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(3): "Applicant" means a person that applies for an initial license or a license renewal under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(4): 17-43-301; 17-43-201
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(4)(a): "Associated with the licensee" means that an individual is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(4)(a)(i): affiliated with a licensee as an owner, director, member of the governing body, employee, agent, provider of care, department contractor, or volunteer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(4)(a)(ii): applying to become affiliated with a licensee in a capacity described in Subsection (4)(a)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(4)(b): 17-43-301; 17-43-201 "Associated with the licensee" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(4)(b)(i): 17-43-301; 17-43-201 service on the following bodies, unless that service includes direct access to a child or a vulnerable adult:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(4)(b)(i)(A): 17-43-301 a local mental health authority described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(4)(b)(i)(B): 17-43-201 a local substance abuse authority described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(4)(b)(i)(C): a board of an organization operating under a contract to provide mental health or substance use programs, or services for the local mental health authority or substance abuse authority; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(4)(b)(ii): a guest or visitor whose access to a child or a vulnerable adult is directly supervised at all times.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(5)(a): "Boarding school" means a private school that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(5)(a)(i): uses a regionally accredited education program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(5)(a)(ii): provides a residence to the school's students:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(5)(a)(ii)(A): for the purpose of enabling the school's students to attend classes at the school; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(5)(a)(ii)(B): as an ancillary service to educating the students at the school;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(5)(a)(iii): has the primary purpose of providing the school's students with an education, as defined in Subsection (5)(b)(i); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(5)(a)(iv): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(5)(a)(iv)(A): does not provide the treatment or services described in Subsection (40)(a); or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(5)(a)(iv)(B): provides the treatment or services described in Subsection (40)(a) on a limited basis, as described in Subsection (5)(b)(ii).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(5)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(5)(b)(i): For purposes of Subsection (5)(a)(iii), "education" means a course of study for one or more grades from kindergarten through grade 12.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(5)(b)(ii): For purposes of Subsection (5)(a)(iv)(B), a private school provides the treatment or services described in Subsection (40)(a) on a limited basis if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(5)(b)(ii)(A): the treatment or services described in Subsection (40)(a) are provided only as an incidental service to a student; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(5)(b)(ii)(B): the school does not:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(5)(b)(ii)(B)(I): specifically solicit a student for the purpose of providing the treatment or services described in Subsection (40)(a); or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(5)(b)(ii)(B)(II): have a primary purpose of providing the treatment or services described in Subsection (40)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(5)(c): "Boarding school" does not include a therapeutic school.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(6): "Certification" means a less restrictive level of licensure issued by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(7): "Child" means an individual under 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(8): "Child placing" means receiving, accepting, or providing custody or care for any child, temporarily or permanently, for the purpose of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(8)(a): finding a person to adopt the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(8)(b): placing the child in a home for adoption; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(8)(c): foster home placement.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(9): "Child-placing agency" means a person that engages in child placing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(10): "Client" means an individual who receives or has received services from a licensee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(11)(a): "Congregate care program" means any of the following that provide services to a child:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(11)(a)(i): an outdoor youth program;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(11)(b)(ii): is approved by the office to service a child for a limited time.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(12)(a): a client less than 24 hours a day; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(12)(b): four or more persons who:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(13)(a): provides services under a contract with the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(13)(b): due to the contract with the department, has or will likely have direct access to a child or vulnerable adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(14): "Direct access" means that an individual has, or likely will have:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(14)(a): contact with or access to a child or vulnerable adult that provides the individual with an opportunity for personal communication or touch; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(14)(b): an opportunity to view medical, financial, or other confidential personal identifying information of the child, the child's parents or legal guardians, or the vulnerable adult.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(38)(a)(v)(B): is run as a business venture, either for-profit or not-for-profit.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(38)(b): "Recovery residence" does not mean:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(38)(b)(i): a residential treatment program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(38)(b)(ii): residential support program; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(38)(b)(iii): a home, residence, or facility, in which:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(38)(b)(iii)(A): residents, by a majority vote of the residents, establish, implement, and enforce policies governing the living environment, including the manner in which applications for residence are approved and the manner in which residents are expelled;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(38)(b)(iii)(B): residents equitably share rent and housing-related expenses; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(38)(b)(iii)(C): a landlord, owner, or operator does not receive compensation, other than fair market rental income, for establishing, implementing, or enforcing policies governing the living environment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(39): "Regular business hours" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(39)(a): the hours during which services of any kind are provided to a client; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(39)(b): the hours during which a client is present at the facility of a licensee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(40): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(40)(a): "Residential support program" means a program that arranges for or provides the necessities of life as a protective service to individuals or families who have a disability or who are experiencing a dislocation or emergency that prevents them from providing these services for themselves or their families.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(40)(b): "Residential support program" includes a program that provides a supervised living environment for individuals with dysfunctions or impairments that are:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(40)(b)(i): emotional;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(40)(b)(ii): psychological;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(40)(b)(iii): developmental; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(40)(b)(iv): behavioral.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(40)(c): Treatment is not a necessary component of a residential support program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(40)(d): "Residential support program" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(40)(d)(i): a recovery residence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(40)(d)(ii): a program that provides residential services that are performed:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(40)(d)(ii)(A): exclusively under contract with the department and provided to individuals through the Division of Services for People with Disabilities; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(40)(d)(ii)(B): in a facility that serves fewer than four individuals.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(41): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(41)(a): "Residential treatment" means a 24-hour group living environment for four or more individuals unrelated to the owner or provider that offers room or board and specialized treatment, behavior modification, rehabilitation, discipline, emotional growth, or habilitation services for persons with emotional, psychological, developmental, or behavioral dysfunctions, impairments, or chemical dependencies.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(41)(b): "Residential treatment" does not include a:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(41)(b)(i): boarding school;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(41)(b)(ii): foster home; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(41)(b)(iii): recovery residence.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(42): "Residential treatment program" means a program or facility that provides:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(42)(a): residential treatment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(42)(b): intermediate secure treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(43): "Seclusion" means the involuntary confinement of an individual in a room or an area:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(43)(a): away from the individual's peers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(43)(b): in a manner that physically prevents the individual from leaving the room or area.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(44): 80-3-102; 26B-2-120; 80-3-102 "Short-term relief care provider" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(44)(a): provides short-term and temporary relief care to a foster parent:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(44)(a)(i): for less than six consecutive nights; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(44)(a)(ii): in the short-term relief care provider's home;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(44)(b): 80-3-102 is an immediate family member or relative, as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(44)(c): 26B-2-120 is direct access qualified, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(44)(d): has been approved to provide short-term relief care by the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(44)(e): is not reimbursed by the department for the temporary relief care provided; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(44)(f): 80-3-102 is not an immediate family member or relative, as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(45): "Social detoxification" means short-term residential services for persons who are experiencing or have recently experienced drug or alcohol intoxication, that are provided outside of a health care facility licensed under Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection, and that include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(45)(a): room and board for persons who are unrelated to the owner or manager of the facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(45)(b): specialized rehabilitation to acquire sobriety; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(45)(c): aftercare services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(46): 26B-5-501 "Substance abuse disorder" or "substance use disorder" mean the same as "substance use disorder" is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(47): "Substance abuse treatment program" or "substance use disorder treatment program" means a program:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(47)(a): designed to provide:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(47)(a)(i): specialized drug or alcohol treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(47)(a)(ii): rehabilitation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(47)(a)(iii): habilitation services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(47)(b): that provides the treatment or services described in Subsection (47)(a) to persons with:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(47)(b)(i): a diagnosed substance use disorder; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(47)(b)(ii): chemical dependency disorder.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(48): "Therapeutic school" means a residential group living facility:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(48)(a): for four or more individuals that are not related to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(48)(a)(i): the owner of the facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(48)(a)(ii): the primary service provider of the facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(48)(b): that serves students who have a history of failing to function:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(48)(b)(i): at home;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(48)(b)(ii): in a public school; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(48)(b)(iii): in a nonresidential private school; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(48)(c): that offers:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(48)(c)(i): room and board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(48)(c)(ii): an academic education integrated with:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(48)(c)(ii)(A): specialized structure and supervision; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(48)(c)(ii)(B): services or treatment related to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(48)(c)(ii)(B)(I): a disability;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(48)(c)(ii)(B)(II): emotional development;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(48)(c)(ii)(B)(III): behavioral development;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(48)(c)(ii)(B)(IV): familial development; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(48)(c)(ii)(B)(V): social development.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(49): "Unrelated persons" means persons other than parents, legal guardians, grandparents, brothers, sisters, uncles, or aunts.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(50): "Vulnerable adult" means an elder adult or an adult who has a temporary or permanent mental or physical impairment that substantially affects the person's ability to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(50)(a): provide personal protection;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(50)(b): provide necessities such as food, shelter, clothing, or mental or other health care;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(50)(c): obtain services necessary for health, safety, or welfare;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(50)(d): carry out the activities of daily living;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(50)(e): manage the adult's own resources; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(50)(f): comprehend the nature and consequences of remaining in a situation of abuse, neglect, or exploitation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(51): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(51)(a): "Youth program" means a program designed to provide behavioral, substance use, or mental health services to minors that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(51)(a)(i): serves adjudicated or nonadjudicated youth;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(51)(a)(ii): charges a fee for the program's services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(51)(a)(iii): may provide host homes or other arrangements for overnight accommodation of the youth;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(51)(a)(iv): may provide all or part of the program's services in the outdoors;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(51)(a)(v): may limit or censor access to parents or guardians; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(51)(a)(vi): prohibits or restricts a minor's ability to leave the program at any time of the minor's own free will.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(51)(b): "Youth program" does not include recreational programs such as Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts, 4-H, and other such organizations.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(52): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(52)(a): "Youth transportation company" means any person that transports a child for payment to or from a congregate care program in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(52)(b): "Youth transportation company" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(52)(b)(i): a relative of the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(52)(b)(ii): a state agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-101(52)(b)(iii): a congregate care program's employee who transports the child from the congregate care program that employs the employee and returns the child to the same congregate care program.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-102 Purpose of licensure.
-----------------------------------------------------
The purpose of licensing under this part is to permit or authorize a public or private agency to provide defined human services programs within statutory and regulatory guidelines.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-103 Division of Licensing and Background Checks. 
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-103(1): There is created the Division of Licensing and Background Checks within the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-103(2): The division shall be the licensing and background screening authority for the department, and is vested with all the powers, duties, and responsibilities described in:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-103(2)(a): this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-103(2)(b): Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-103(2)(c): Part 4, Child Care Licensing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-103(2)(d): Part 6, Mammography Quality Assurance.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-103(3): The executive director shall appoint the director of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-103(4): There are created within the division the Office of Licensing and the Office of Background Processing.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-105 Licensure requirements -- Expiration -- Renewal.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-105(1): 26B-2-115 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-105(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-105(2)(a): For purposes of this Subsection (2), "member" means a person or entity that is associated with another person or entity:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-105(2)(a)(i): as a member;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-105(2)(a)(ii): as a partner;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-105(2)(a)(iii): as a shareholder; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-105(2)(a)(iv): as a person or entity involved in the ownership or management of a human services program owned or managed by the other person or entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-105(2)(b): A license issued under this part may not be assigned or transferred.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-105(2)(c)(ii)(A): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-105(2)(c)(ii)(A)(I): had a license revoked under this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-105(2)(c)(ii)(A)(II): the revoked license described in Subsection (2)(c)(ii)(A)(I) is not reinstated before the application described in this Subsection (2)(c) is made; or

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-105(2)(c)(ii)(B)(I): was a member of an entity that had a license revoked under this part at any time before the license was revoked; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-105(2)(c)(ii)(B)(II): the revoked license described in Subsection (2)(c)(ii)(B)(I) is not reinstated before the application described in this Subsection (2)(c) is made.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107 Administrative inspections.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(1)(a): "Foster home" does not include a residence that is licensed or certified for proctor care or care by a professional parent.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(1)(b): "Material change" means a significant change in circumstances that may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(1)(b)(i): a loss or gain of employment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(1)(b)(ii): a change in marital status;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(1)(b)(iii): a change of individuals living in the home; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(1)(b)(iv): other changes that may affect a foster child's well-being.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(2)(a): Subject to Subsections (2)(b) and (3), the office may, for the purpose of ascertaining compliance with this part, enter and inspect on a routine basis the facility of a licensee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(2)(b)(i): The office shall enter and inspect a congregate care program at least once each calendar quarter.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(2)(b)(ii): At least two of the inspections described in Subsection (2)(b)(i) shall be unannounced.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(2)(c): If another government entity conducts an inspection that is substantially similar to an inspection conducted by the office, the office may conclude the inspection satisfies an inspection described in Subsection (2)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(3)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (3)(b):
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(3)(a)(i): for the first two years of a foster home's license, the office shall enter and inspect the facility once each year;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(3)(a)(ii): after a foster home has been licensed for two years, the office shall enter and inspect the facility once every three years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(3)(a)(iii): for a foster home licensed for two or more years as of May 1, 2023, and that was inspected by the office on or after May 1, 2023, the office may not enter and inspect the facility until three years after the date of the last inspection.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(3)(b)(i): If a foster home has not had a placement for more than 12 months after the date of the office's last inspection, the office shall enter and inspect the facility within 30 days after the date on which the foster home receives a new placement.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(3)(b)(ii): If the license for a foster home is placed on conditions, suspended, or revoked by the office, or voluntarily returned to the office by the licensee, the office may enter and inspect the facility on a routine basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(3)(b)(iii): If there is a material change to a foster home:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(3)(b)(iii)(A): the foster parent shall immediately notify the office of the material change; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(3)(b)(iii)(B): the office shall inspect the foster home as soon as practicable after receiving notice of or otherwise becoming aware of the material change.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(3)(b)(iv): If a health and safety concern is reported to the office, the office may conduct an unannounced inspection of the foster home during regular business hours.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(3)(c): Except as provided in Subsection (3)(b)(iv), an inspection of a foster home shall be announced.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(4): 26B-2-707 Before conducting an inspection under Subsection (2) or (3), the office shall, after identifying the person in charge:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(4)(a): give proper identification;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(4)(b): request to see the applicable license;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(4)(c): describe the nature and purpose of the inspection; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(4)(d): 26B-2-707 if necessary, explain the authority of the office to conduct the inspection and the penalty for refusing to permit the inspection as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(5): In conducting an inspection under Subsection (2) or (3), the office may, after meeting the requirements of Subsection (4):
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(5)(a): inspect the physical facilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(5)(b): inspect and copy records and documents;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(5)(c): interview officers, employees, clients, family members of clients, and others; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(5)(d): observe the licensee in operation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(6): An inspection conducted under Subsection (2) shall be during regular business hours and may be announced or unannounced.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(7): The licensee shall make copies of inspection reports available to the public upon request.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-107(8): The provisions of this section apply to on-site inspections and do not restrict the office from contacting family members, neighbors, or other individuals, or from seeking information from other sources to determine compliance with this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-108 Adoption of inspections, examinations, and studies.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The office may adopt an inspection, examination, or study conducted by a public or private entity, as identified by rule, to determine whether a licensee has complied with a licensing requirement imposed by virtue of this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-109 Human services program non-discrimination.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
A human services program:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-109(1): shall perform an individualized assessment when classifying and placing an individual in programs and living environments; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-109(2): subject to the office's review and approval, shall create policies and procedures that include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-109(2)(a): a description of what constitutes sex and gender based abuse, discrimination, and harassment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-109(2)(b): procedures for preventing and reporting abuse, discrimination, and harassment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-109(2)(c): procedures for teaching effective and professional communication with individuals of all sexual orientations and genders.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-115 Exclusions from chapter.
--------------------------------------------------------
The provisions of this part do not apply to:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-115(1): a facility or program owned or operated by an agency of the United States government;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-115(2): a facility or program operated by or under an exclusive contract with the Department of Corrections;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-115(3): Title 58, Chapter 60, Mental Health Professional Practice Act unless required otherwise by a contract with the department, individual or group counseling by a mental health professional licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-115(4): Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection a general acute hospital, small health care facility, specialty hospital, nursing care facility, or other health care facility licensed by the department under
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-115(5): a boarding school.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(4)(a): With the personal identifying information the office submits to the bureau under Subsection (3), the bureau shall check against state and regional criminal background databases for the applicant's criminal history.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(4)(c): Upon direction from the office, and with the personal identifying information and fingerprints the office submits to the bureau under Subsection (3)(c), the bureau shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(4)(c)(i): maintain a separate file of the fingerprints for search by future submissions to the local and regional criminal records databases, including latent prints; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(4)(c)(ii): monitor state and regional criminal background databases and identify criminal activity associated with the applicant.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(4)(d): The bureau is authorized to submit the fingerprints to the Federal Bureau of Investigation Next Generation Identification System, to be retained in the Federal Bureau of Investigation Next Generation Identification System for the purpose of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(4)(d)(i): being searched by future submissions to the national criminal records databases, including the Federal Bureau of Investigation Next Generation Identification System and latent prints; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(4)(d)(ii): monitoring national criminal background databases and identifying criminal activity associated with the applicant.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(4)(e): The Bureau shall notify and release to the office all information of criminal activity associated with the applicant.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(7): 80-2-1001
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(7)(a): 80-2-1001 The comprehensive review shall include an examination of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(7)(a)(i): the date of the offense or incident;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(7)(a)(ii): the nature and seriousness of the offense or incident;
