Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(7)(a)(iv): the age of the perpetrator when the offense or incident occurred;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(7)(a)(v): whether the offense or incident was an isolated or repeated incident;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(7)(a)(vi): whether the offense or incident directly relates to abuse of a child or vulnerable adult, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(7)(a)(vi)(A): actual or threatened, nonaccidental physical, mental, or financial harm;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(7)(a)(vi)(B): sexual abuse;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(7)(a)(vi)(C): sexual exploitation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(7)(a)(vi)(D): negligent treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(7)(a)(vii): any evidence provided by the applicant of rehabilitation, counseling, psychiatric treatment received, or additional academic or vocational schooling completed;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(7)(a)(viii): the applicant's risk of harm to clientele in the program or in the capacity for which the applicant is applying; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(7)(a)(ix): 80-2-1001 if the background check of an applicant is being conducted for the purpose of giving direct access qualified status to an applicant seeking a position in a congregate care program or to become a prospective foster or adoptive parent, any listing in the Division of Child and Family Services' Management Information System described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(7)(b): At the conclusion of the comprehensive review, the office shall deny direct access qualified status to an applicant if the office finds the approval would likely create a risk of harm to a child or vulnerable adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(8): The office shall grant direct access qualified status to an applicant who is not denied under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(9)(a): The office may conditionally grant direct access qualified status to an applicant, for a maximum of 60 days after the day on which the office sends written notice, without requiring that the applicant be directly supervised, if the office:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(9)(a)(i): is awaiting the results of the criminal history search of national criminal background databases; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(9)(a)(ii): would otherwise grant direct access qualified status to the applicant under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(9)(b): The office may conditionally grant direct access qualified status to an applicant, for a maximum of one year after the day on which the office sends written notice, without requiring that the applicant be directly supervised if the office:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(9)(b)(i): is awaiting the results of an out-of-state registry for providers other than foster and adoptive parents; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(9)(b)(ii): would otherwise grant direct access qualified status to the applicant under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(9)(c): Upon receiving the results of the criminal history search of a national criminal background database, the office shall grant or deny direct access qualified status to the applicant in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(10)(a): Each time an applicant is associated with a licensee, the department shall review the current status of the applicant's background check to ensure the applicant is still eligible for direct access qualified status in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(10)(b): A licensee may not permit an individual to have direct access to a child or a vulnerable adult without being directly supervised unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(10)(b)(i): the individual is the parent or guardian of the child, or the guardian of the vulnerable adult;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(10)(b)(ii): the individual is approved by the parent or guardian of the child, or the guardian of the vulnerable adult, to have direct access to the child or the vulnerable adult;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(10)(b)(iii): the individual is only permitted to have direct access to a vulnerable adult who voluntarily invites the individual to visit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(10)(b)(iv): the individual only provides incidental care for a foster child on behalf of a foster parent who has used reasonable and prudent judgment to select the individual to provide the incidental care for the foster child.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(10)(c): Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, an applicant who is denied direct access qualified status shall not have direct access to a child or vulnerable adult unless the office grants direct access qualified status to the applicant through a subsequent application in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-120(11): If the office denies direct access qualified status to an applicant, the applicant may request a hearing in the department's Office of Administrative Hearings to challenge the office's decision.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123 Congregate care program regulation.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(1): 80-1-102; 80-1-102
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(1)(a): 80-1-102; 80-1-102 A congregate care program may not use a cruel, severe, unusual, or unnecessary practice on a child, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(1)(a)(i): a strip search unless the congregate care program determines and documents that a strip search is necessary to protect an individual's health or safety;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(1)(a)(ii): a body cavity search unless the congregate care program determines and documents that a body cavity search is necessary to protect an individual's health or safety;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(1)(a)(iii): inducing pain to obtain compliance;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(1)(a)(iv): hyperextending joints;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(1)(a)(v): peer restraints;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(1)(a)(vi): discipline or punishment that is intended to frighten or humiliate;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(1)(a)(vii): requiring or forcing the child to take an uncomfortable position, including squatting or bending;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(1)(a)(viii): for the purpose of punishing or humiliating, requiring or forcing the child to repeat physical movements or physical exercises such as running laps or performing push-ups;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(1)(a)(ix): spanking, hitting, shaking, or otherwise engaging in aggressive physical contact;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(1)(a)(x): denying an essential program service;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(1)(a)(xi): depriving the child of a meal, water, rest, or opportunity for toileting;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(1)(a)(xii): denying shelter, clothing, or bedding;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(1)(a)(xiii): withholding personal interaction, emotional response, or stimulation;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(1)(a)(xiv): prohibiting the child from entering the residence;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(1)(a)(xv): 80-1-102 abuse as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(1)(a)(xvi): 80-1-102 neglect as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(1)(b): A properly used emergency safety intervention is not considered a cruel, severe, unusual, or unnecessary practice.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(2): Before a congregate care program may use a restraint, seclusion, or emergency safety intervention, the congregate care program shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(2)(a): develop and implement written policies and procedures that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(2)(a)(i): describe the circumstances under which a staff member may use a restraint, seclusion, or emergency safety intervention;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(2)(a)(ii): describe which staff members are authorized to use a restraint, seclusion, or emergency safety intervention;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(2)(a)(iii): describe procedures for monitoring a child that is restrained or in seclusion;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(2)(a)(iv): describe time limitations on the use of a restraint or seclusion;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(2)(a)(v): require immediate and continuous review of the decision to use a restraint, seclusion, or emergency safety intervention;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(2)(a)(vi): require documenting the use of a restraint, seclusion, or emergency safety intervention;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(2)(a)(vii): describe record keeping requirements for records related to the use of a restraint, seclusion, or emergency safety intervention;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(2)(a)(viii): to the extent practicable, require debriefing the following individuals if debriefing would not interfere with an ongoing investigation, violate any law or regulation, or conflict with a child's treatment plan:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(2)(a)(viii)(A): each witness to the event;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(2)(a)(viii)(B): each staff member involved; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(2)(a)(viii)(C): the child who was restrained or in seclusion;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(2)(a)(ix): include a procedure for complying with Subsection (5); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(2)(a)(x): provide an administrative review process and required follow up actions after a child is restrained or put in seclusion; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(2)(b): consult with the office to ensure that the congregate care program's written policies and procedures align with applicable law.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(3): A congregate care program:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(3)(a): may use a passive physical restraint only if the passive physical restraint is supported by a nationally or regionally recognized curriculum focused on non-violent interventions and de-escalation techniques;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(3)(b): may not use a chemical or mechanical restraint unless the office has authorized the congregate care program to use a chemical or mechanical restraint;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(3)(c): shall ensure that a staff member that uses a restraint on a child is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(3)(c)(i): properly trained to use the restraint; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(3)(c)(ii): familiar with the child and if the child has a treatment plan, the child's treatment plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(3)(d): shall train each staff member on how to intervene if another staff member fails to follow correct procedures when using a restraint.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(4)(a): A congregate care program:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(4)(a)(i): may use seclusion if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(4)(a)(i)(A): the purpose for the seclusion is to ensure the immediate safety of the child or others; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(4)(a)(i)(B): no less restrictive intervention is likely to ensure the safety of the child or others; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(4)(a)(ii): may not use seclusion:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(4)(a)(ii)(A): for coercion, retaliation, or humiliation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(4)(a)(ii)(B): due to inadequate staffing or for the staff's convenience.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(4)(b): While a child is in seclusion, a staff member who is familiar to the child shall actively supervise the child for the duration of the seclusion.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(5): Subject to the office's review and approval, a congregate care program shall develop:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(5)(a): suicide prevention policies and procedures that describe:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(5)(a)(i): how the congregate care program will respond in the event a child exhibits self-injurious, self-harm, or suicidal behavior;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(5)(a)(ii): warning signs of suicide;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(5)(a)(iii): emergency protocol and contacts;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(5)(a)(iv): training requirements for staff, including suicide prevention training;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(5)(a)(v): procedures for implementing additional supervision precautions and for removing any additional supervision precautions;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(5)(a)(vi): suicide risk assessment procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(5)(a)(vii): documentation requirements for a child's suicide ideation and self-harm;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(5)(a)(viii): special observation precautions for a child exhibiting warning signs of suicide;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(5)(a)(ix): communication procedures to ensure all staff are aware of a child who exhibits warning signs of suicide;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(5)(a)(x): a process for tracking suicide behavioral patterns; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(5)(a)(xi): a post-intervention plan with identified resources; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(5)(b): based on state law and industry best practices, policies and procedures for managing a child's behavior during the child's participation in the congregate care program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(6)(a): A congregate care program:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(6)(a)(i): subject to Subsection (6)(b), shall facilitate weekly confidential voice-to-voice communication between a child and the child's parents, guardian, foster parents, and siblings, as applicable;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(6)(a)(ii): shall ensure that the communication described in Subsection (6)(a)(i) complies with the child's treatment plan, if any; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(6)(a)(iii): may not use family contact as an incentive for proper behavior or withhold family contact as a punishment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(6)(b): For the communication described in Subsection (6)(a)(i), a congregate care program may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(6)(b)(i): deny the communication unless state law or a court order prohibits the communication; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(6)(b)(ii): modify the frequency or form of the communication unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(6)(b)(ii)(A): the office approves the modification; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-123(6)(b)(ii)(B): state law or a court order prohibits the frequency or the form of the communication.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-124 Congregate care program requirements.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-124(1): As used in this section, "disruption plan" means a child specific plan used:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-124(1)(a): when the private-placement child stops receiving services from a congregate care program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-124(1)(b): for transporting a private-placement child to a parent or guardian or to another congregate care program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-124(2): A congregate care program shall keep the following for a private-placement child whose parent or guardian lives outside the state:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-124(2)(a): regularly updated contact information for the parent or guardian that lives outside the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-124(2)(b): a disruption plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-124(3): If a private-placement child whose parent or guardian resides outside the state leaves a congregate care program without following the child's disruption plan, the congregate care program shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-124(3)(a): notify the parent or guardian, office, and local law enforcement authorities;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-124(3)(b): assist the state in locating the private-placement child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-124(3)(c): after the child is located, transport the private-placement child:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-124(3)(c)(i): to a parent or guardian;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-124(3)(c)(ii): back to the congregate care program; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-124(3)(c)(iii): to another congregate care program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-124(4): This section does not apply to a guardian that is a state or agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-124(5): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The office shall make rules in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-124(5)(a): additional mandatory provisions for a disruption plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-124(5)(b): how a congregate care program shall notify the office when a private-placement child begins receiving services.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-128 Numerical limit of foster children in a foster home.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-128(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-128(1)(a): No more than four foster children may reside in the foster home of a licensed foster parent.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-128(1)(b): No more than three foster children may reside in the foster home of a certified foster parent.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-128(2): When placing a child into a foster home, the limits under Subsection (1) may be exceeded:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-128(2)(a): to place a child into a foster home where a sibling of the child currently resides; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-128(2)(b): to place a child in a foster home where the child previously resided.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-128(3): The limits under Subsection (1) may be exceeded for:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-128(3)(a): placement of a sibling group in a foster home with no more than one other foster child placement;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-128(3)(b): placement of a child or sibling group in a foster home where the child or sibling group previously resided; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-128(3)(c): placement of a child in a foster home where a sibling currently resides.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-129 Licensure of tribal foster homes.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-129(1): The Indian Child Welfare Act, 25 U.S.C. Secs. 1901-1963, provides that Indian tribes may develop and implement tribal foster home standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-129(2): The office shall give full faith and credit to an Indian tribe's certification or licensure of a tribal foster home for an Indian child and siblings of that Indian child, both on and off Indian country, according to standards developed and approved by the Indian tribe, pursuant to the Indian Child Welfare Act, 25 U.S.C. Secs. 1901-1963.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-129(3): If the Indian tribe has not developed standards, the office shall license tribal foster homes pursuant to this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-132 Child-placing agency proof of authority in a proceeding.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A child-placing agency is not required to present the child-placing agency's license issued under this part, the child placing agency's certificate of incorporation, or proof of the child-placing agency's authority to consent to adoption, as proof of the child-placing agency's authority in any proceeding in which the child-placing agency is an interested party, unless the court or a party to the proceeding requests that the child-placing agency or the child-placing agency's representative establish proof of authority.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(1): "Abortion clinic" means a type I abortion clinic or a type II abortion clinic.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(2): "Activities of daily living" means essential activities including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(2)(a): dressing;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(2)(b): eating;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(2)(c): grooming;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(2)(d): bathing;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(2)(e): toileting;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(2)(f): ambulation;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(2)(g): transferring; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(2)(h): self-administration of medication.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(3): "Ambulatory surgical facility" means a freestanding facility, which provides surgical services to patients not requiring hospitalization.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(4): "Assistance with activities of daily living" means providing of or arranging for the provision of assistance with activities of daily living.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(5)(a): "Assisted living facility" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(5)(a)(i): a type I assisted living facility, which is a residential facility that provides assistance with activities of daily living and social care to two or more residents who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(5)(a)(i)(A): require protected living arrangements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(5)(a)(i)(B): are capable of achieving mobility sufficient to exit the facility without the assistance of another person; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(5)(a)(ii): a type II assisted living facility, which is a residential facility with a home-like setting that provides an array of coordinated supportive personal and health care services available 24 hours per day to residents who have been assessed under department rule to need any of these services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(5)(b): Each resident in a type I or type II assisted living facility shall have a service plan based on the assessment, which may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(5)(b)(i): specified services of intermittent nursing care;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(5)(b)(ii): administration of medication; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(5)(b)(iii): support services promoting residents' independence and self-sufficiency.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(6): 26B-2-228 "Birthing center" means a facility that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(6)(a): receives maternal clients and provides care during pregnancy, delivery, and immediately after delivery; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(6)(b): 26B-2-228
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(6)(b)(i): is freestanding; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(6)(b)(ii): 26B-2-228 is not freestanding, but meets the requirements for an alongside midwifery unit described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(7): 26B-1-204 "Committee" means the Health Facility Committee created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(8): "Consumer" means any person not primarily engaged in the provision of health care to individuals or in the administration of facilities or institutions in which such care is provided and who does not hold a fiduciary position, or have a fiduciary interest in any entity involved in the provision of health care, and does not receive, either directly or through his spouse, more than 1/10 of his gross income from any entity or activity relating to health care.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(9): "End stage renal disease facility" means a facility which furnishes staff-assisted kidney dialysis services, self-dialysis services, or home-dialysis services on an outpatient basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(10): "Freestanding" means existing independently or physically separated from another health care facility by fire walls and doors and administrated by separate staff with separate records.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(11): "General acute hospital" means a facility which provides diagnostic, therapeutic, and rehabilitative services to both inpatients and outpatients by or under the supervision of physicians.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(12): "Governmental unit" means the state, or any county, municipality, or other political subdivision or any department, division, board, or agency of the state, a county, municipality, or other political subdivision.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(13): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(13)(a): "Health care facility" means general acute hospitals, specialty hospitals, home health agencies, hospices, nursing care facilities, residential-assisted living facilities, birthing centers, ambulatory surgical facilities, small health care facilities, abortion clinics, facilities owned or operated by health maintenance organizations, end stage renal disease facilities, and any other health care facility which the committee designates by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(13)(b): "Health care facility" does not include the offices of private physicians or dentists, whether for individual or group practice, except that it does include an abortion clinic.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(14): "Health maintenance organization" means an organization, organized under the laws of any state which:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(14)(a): is a qualified health maintenance organization under 42 U.S.C. Sec. 300e-9; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(14)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(14)(b)(i): provides or otherwise makes available to enrolled participants at least the following basic health care services: usual physician services, hospitalization, laboratory, x-ray, emergency, and preventive services and out-of-area coverage;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(14)(b)(ii): is compensated, except for copayments, for the provision of the basic health services listed in Subsection (14)(b)(i) to enrolled participants by a payment which is paid on a periodic basis without regard to the date the health services are provided and which is fixed without regard to the frequency, extent, or kind of health services actually provided;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(14)(b)(iii): provides physicians' services primarily directly through physicians who are either employees or partners of such organizations, or through arrangements with individual physicians or one or more groups of physicians organized on a group practice or individual practice basis; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(14)(b)(iv): provides physician assistant services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(15): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(15)(a): "Home health agency" means an agency, organization, or facility or a subdivision of an agency, organization, or facility which employs two or more direct care staff persons who provide licensed nursing services, therapeutic services of physical therapy, speech therapy, occupational therapy, medical social services, or home health aide services on a visiting basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(15)(b): "Home health agency" does not mean an individual who provides services under the authority of a private license.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(16): "Hospice" means a program of care for the terminally ill and their families which occurs in a home or in a health care facility and which provides medical, palliative, psychological, spiritual, and supportive care and treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(17): "Nursing care facility" means a health care facility, other than a general acute or specialty hospital, constructed, licensed, and operated to provide patient living accommodations, 24-hour staff availability, and at least two of the following patient services:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(17)(a): a selection of patient care services, under the direction and supervision of a registered nurse, ranging from continuous medical, skilled nursing, psychological, or other professional therapies to intermittent health-related or paraprofessional personal care services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(17)(b): a structured, supportive social living environment based on a professionally designed and supervised treatment plan, oriented to the individual's habilitation or rehabilitation needs; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(17)(c): a supervised living environment that provides support, training, or assistance with individual activities of daily living.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(18): "Person" means any individual, firm, partnership, corporation, company, association, or joint stock association, and the legal successor thereof.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(19): "Resident" means a person 21 years old or older who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(19)(a): as a result of physical or mental limitations or age requires or requests services provided in an assisted living facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(19)(b): does not require intensive medical or nursing services as provided in a hospital or nursing care facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(20): "Small health care facility" means a four to 16 bed facility that provides licensed health care programs and services to residents.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(21): "Specialty hospital" means a facility which provides specialized diagnostic, therapeutic, or rehabilitative services in the recognized specialty or specialties for which the hospital is licensed.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(22): "Substantial compliance" means in a department survey of a licensee, the department determines there is an absence of deficiencies which would harm the physical health, mental health, safety, or welfare of patients or residents of a licensee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-201(23): 76-7-301; 76-7-301 "Type I abortion clinic" means a facility, including a physician's office, but not including a general acute or specialty hospital, that:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-205 Exempt facilities.
--------------------------------------------------
This part does not apply to:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-205(1): a dispensary or first aid facility maintained by any commercial or industrial plant, educational institution, or convent;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-205(2): a health care facility owned or operated by an agency of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-205(3): the office of a physician, physician assistant, or dentist whether it is an individual or group practice, except that it does apply to an abortion clinic;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-205(4): a health care facility established or operated by any recognized church or denomination for the practice of religious tenets administered by mental or spiritual means without the use of drugs, whether gratuitously or for compensation, if it complies with statutes and rules on environmental protection and life safety;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-205(5): 64-13-2 any health care facility owned or operated by the Department of Corrections, created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-205(6): a residential facility providing 24-hour care:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-205(6)(a): that does not employ direct care staff;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-205(6)(b): in which the residents of the facility contract with a licensed hospice agency to receive end-of-life medical care; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-205(6)(c): that meets other requirements for an exemption as designated by administrative rule.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-206 License required -- Not assignable or transferable -- Posting -- Expiration and renewal -- Time for compliance by operating facilities.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-206(1): 26B-2-205
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-206(1)(a): A person or governmental unit acting severally or jointly with any other person or governmental unit, may not establish, conduct, or maintain a health care facility in this state without receiving a license from the department as provided by this part and the rules  adopted pursuant to this part .
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-206(1)(b): 26B-2-205 This Subsection (1) does not apply to facilities that are exempt under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-206(2): A license issued under this part is not assignable or transferable.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-206(3): The current license shall at all times be posted in each health care facility in a place readily visible and accessible to the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-206(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-206(4)(a): The department may issue a license for a period of time not to exceed 12 months from the date of issuance for an abortion clinic and not to exceed 24 months from the date of issuance for other health care facilities that meet the provisions of this part and department rules adopted pursuant to this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-206(4)(b): Each license expires at midnight on the day designated on the license as the expiration date, unless previously revoked by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-206(4)(c): The license shall be renewed upon completion of the application requirements, unless the department finds the health care facility has not complied with the provisions of this part or the rules adopted pursuant to this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-206(5): A license may be issued under this section only for the operation of a specific facility at a specific site by a specific person.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-206(6): Any health care facility in operation at the time of adoption of any applicable rules as provided under this part shall be given a reasonable time for compliance as determined by the committee.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-207 Application for license -- Information required -- Public records.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-207(1): An application for license shall be made to the department in a form prescribed by the department.  The application and other documentation requested by the department as part of the application process shall require such information as the committee determines necessary to ensure compliance with established rules.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-207(2): Information received by the department in reports and inspections shall be public records, except the information may not be disclosed if it directly or indirectly identifies any individual other than the owner or operator of a health facility (unless disclosure is required by law) or if its disclosure would otherwise constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-207(3): Information received by the department from a  health care facility, pertaining to that  facility's accreditation by a voluntary accrediting organization, shall be private data except for a summary prepared by the department related to licensure standards.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-212 Intermediate care facilities for people with an intellectual disability -- Licensing.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-212(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-212(1)(a): It is the Legislature's intent that a person with a developmental disability be provided with an environment and surrounding that, as closely as possible, resembles small community-based, homelike settings, to allow those persons to have the opportunity, to the maximum extent feasible, to exercise their full rights and responsibilities as citizens.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-212(1)(b): It is the Legislature's purpose, in enacting this section, to provide assistance and opportunities to enable a person with a developmental disability to achieve the person's maximum potential through increased independence, productivity, and integration into the community.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-212(2): After July 1, 1990, the department may only license intermediate care beds for people with an intellectual disability in small health care facilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-212(3): The department may define by rule "small health care facility" for purposes of licensure under this section and adopt rules necessary to carry out the requirements and purposes of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-212(4): This section does not apply to the renewal of a license or the licensure to a new owner of any facility that was licensed on or before July 1, 1990, and that licensure has been maintained without interruption.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-213 Rural hospital -- Optional service designation.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-213(1): The Legislature finds that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-213(1)(a): the rural citizens of this state need access to hospitals and primary care clinics;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-213(1)(b): financial stability of remote-rural hospitals and their integration into remote-rural delivery networks is critical to ensure the continued viability of remote-rural health care; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-213(1)(c): administrative simplicity is essential for providing large benefits to small-scale remote-rural providers who have limited time and resources.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-213(2): After July 1, 1995, the department may grant variances to remote-rural acute care hospitals for specific services currently required for licensure under general hospital standards established by department rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-213(3): For purposes of this section, "remote-rural hospitals" are hospitals that are in a county with less than 20 people per square mile.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-217 Department agency of state to contract for certification of facilities under Social Security Act.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department is the sole agency of the state authorized to enter into a contract with the United States government for the certification of health care facilities under Title XVIII and Title XIX of the Social Security Act, and any amendments thereto.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-219 Requirement for hospitals to provide statements of itemized charges to patients.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-219(1): As used in this section, "hospital" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-219(1)(a): an ambulatory surgical facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-219(1)(b): a general acute hospital; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-219(1)(c): a specialty hospital.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-219(2): A hospital shall provide a statement of itemized charges to any patient receiving medical care or other services from that hospital.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-219(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-219(3)(a): The statement shall be provided to the patient or the patient's personal representative or agent at the hospital's expense, personally, by mail, or by verifiable electronic delivery after the hospital receives an explanation of benefits from a third party payer which indicates the patient's remaining responsibility for the hospital charges.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-219(3)(b): If the statement is not provided to a third party, it shall be provided to the patient as soon as possible and practicable.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-219(4): (3)(b) The statement required by this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-219(4)(a): shall itemize each of the charges actually provided by the hospital to the patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-219(4)(b): (3)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-219(4)(b)(i): shall include the words in bold "THIS IS THE BALANCE DUE AFTER PAYMENT FROM YOUR HEALTH INSURER"; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-219(4)(b)(ii): (3)(b) shall include other appropriate language if the statement is sent to the patient under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-219(4)(c): may not include charges of physicians who bill separately.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-219(5): The requirements of this section do not apply to patients who receive services from a hospital under Title XIX of the Social Security Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-219(6): Nothing in this section prohibits a hospital from sending an itemized billing statement to a patient before the hospital has received an explanation of benefits from an insurer.  If a hospital provides a statement of itemized charges to a patient prior to receiving the explanation of benefits from an insurer, the itemized statement shall be marked in bold: "DUPLICATE: DO NOT PAY" or other appropriate language.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-220 Authentication of medical records.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Any entry in a medical record compiled or maintained by a health care facility may be authenticated by identifying the author of the entry by:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-220(1): a signature including first initial, last name, and discipline; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-220(2): the use of a computer identification process unique to the author that definitively identifies the author.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(1)(c)(ii): a specialty hospital;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(1)(c)(iv): a hospice;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(1)(c)(xiii): a health care clinic; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(1)(c)(xiv): any other health care facility that the committee designates by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(2)(a): In order to discourage identity theft and health insurance fraud, and to reduce the risk of medical errors caused by incorrect medical records, a medical facility or a health professional office shall request identification from an individual prior to providing in-patient or out-patient services to the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(2)(b): If the individual who will receive services from the medical facility or a health professional office lacks the legal capacity to consent to treatment, the medical facility or a health professional office shall request identification:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(2)(b)(i): for the individual who lacks the legal capacity to consent to treatment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(2)(b)(ii): from the individual who consents to treatment on behalf of the individual described in Subsection (2)(b)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(3): A medical facility or a health professional office:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(3)(a): that is subject to EMTALA:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(3)(a)(i): may not refuse services to an individual on the basis that the individual did not provide identification when requested; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(3)(a)(ii): shall post notice in its emergency department that informs a patient of the patient's right to treatment for an emergency medical condition under EMTALA;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(3)(b): may not be penalized for failing to ask for identification;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(3)(c): is not subject to a private right of action for failing to ask for identification; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(3)(d): may document or confirm patient identity by:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(3)(d)(i): photograph;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(3)(d)(ii): fingerprinting;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(3)(d)(iii): palm scan; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(3)(d)(iv): other reasonable means.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(4): The identification described in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(4)(a): is intended to be used for medical records purposes only; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-224(4)(b): shall be kept in accordance with the requirements of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-231(1)(b): if multiple air medical transport providers are capable of providing the patient with services, provide the patient or the patient's representative with an opportunity to choose the air medical transport provider.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-232 Treatment of aborted remains.
-------------------------------------------------------------
"You have the right to decide what you would like to do with the aborted fetus. You may decide for the provider to be responsible for disposition of the fetus. If you are having a medication-induced abortion, you also have the right to bring the aborted fetus back to this provider for disposition after the fetus is expelled. The provider may dispose of the aborted fetus by burial or cremation. You can ask the provider if you want to know the specific method for disposition."Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-232(1): 76-7-301 As used in this section, "aborted fetus" means a product of human conception, regardless of gestational age, that has died from an abortion as that term is defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-233 Treatment of miscarried remains.
----------------------------------------------------------------
"You have the right to decide what you would like to do with the miscarried fetus. You may decide for the provider to be responsible for disposition of the fetus. The provider may dispose of the miscarried fetus by burial or cremation. You can ask the provider if you want to know the specific method for disposition."Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-233(1): As used in this section, "miscarried fetus" means a product of human conception, regardless of gestational age, that has died from a spontaneous or accidental death before expulsion or extraction from the mother, regardless of the duration of the pregnancy.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-233(2)(b)(ii): immediate disposition is required under state or federal law.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-233(6)(c): (6)(c)(i)

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-233(6)(c)(ii): (6)(c)(i) The records described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-233(6)(c)(ii)(A): maintained for at least two years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-233(6)(c)(ii)(B): made available to the department for inspection upon request by the department.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-235 Sepsis protocols for general acute hospitals -- Presenting protocols upon inspection.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-235(1): As used in this section, "sepsis" means a life-threatening complication of an infection.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-235(2): A general acute hospital may develop protocols for the treatment of sepsis and septic shock that are consistent with current evidence-based guidelines for the treatment of severe sepsis and septic shock.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-235(3): (2) When developing the protocols described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-235(3)(a): a process for screening and recognizing patients with sepsis;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-235(3)(b): a process to screen out individuals for whom the protocols would not be appropriate for treating sepsis;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-235(3)(c): timeline goals for treating sepsis;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-235(3)(d): different possible methods for treating sepsis and reasons to use each method;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-235(3)(e): specific protocols to treat children who present with symptoms of sepsis or septic shock; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-235(3)(f): training requirements for staff.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-235(4): A general acute hospital may update the general acute hospital's sepsis protocols as new data on the treatment of sepsis and septic shock becomes available.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-235(5): The department, or an entity assigned by the department to inspect a general acute hospital, may request a copy of the sepsis protocols described in this section when inspecting a general acute hospital.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236 Monitoring device -- Installation, notice, and consent -- Admission and discharge -- Liability.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(1)(a): "Facility" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(1)(a)(i): an assisted living facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(1)(a)(ii): a secure memory care unit inside of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(1)(a)(ii)(A): a nursing care facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(1)(a)(ii)(B): any other medical or mental health facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(1)(b): "Legal representative" means an individual who is legally authorized to make health care decisions on behalf of another individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(1)(c)(i): "Monitoring device" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(1)(c)(i)(A): a video surveillance camera; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(1)(c)(i)(B): a microphone or other device that captures audio.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(1)(c)(ii): "Monitoring device" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(1)(c)(ii)(A): a device that is specifically intended to intercept wire, electronic, or oral communication without notice to or the consent of a party to the communication; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(1)(c)(ii)(B): a device that is connected to the Internet or that is set up to transmit data via an electronic communication.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(1)(d): "Resident" means an individual who receives health care from a facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(1)(e): "Room" means a resident's private or shared primary living space.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(1)(f): "Roommate" means an individual sharing a room with a resident.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(2): A resident or the resident's legal representative may operate or install a monitoring device in the resident's room if the resident and the resident's legal representative, if any, unless the resident is incapable of informed consent:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(2)(a): notifies the resident's facility in writing that the resident or the resident's legal representative, if any:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(2)(a)(i): intends to operate or install a monitoring device in the resident's room; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(2)(a)(ii): consents to a waiver agreement, if required by a facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(2)(b): obtains written consent from each of the resident's roommates, and their legal representative, if any, that specifically states the hours when each roommate consents to the resident or the resident's legal representative operating the monitoring device; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(2)(c): assumes all responsibility for any cost related to installing or operating the monitoring device.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(3): A facility shall not be civilly or criminally liable to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(3)(a): a resident or resident's roommate for the operation of a monitoring device consistent with this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(3)(b): any person other than the resident or resident's roommate for any claims related to the use or operation of a monitoring device consistent with this part, unless the claim is caused by the acts or omissions of an employee or agent of the facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(4)(a): A facility may not deny an individual admission to the facility for the sole reason that the individual or the individual's legal representative requests to install or operate a monitoring device in the individual's room.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(4)(b): A facility may not discharge a resident for the sole reason that the resident or the resident's legal representative requests to install or operate a monitoring device in the individual's room.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(4)(c): A facility shall prohibit all employees of a facility from deactivating, repositioning, or otherwise interfering with the operation of a monitoring device in an individual's room.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(4)(d): A facility may require the resident or the resident's legal representative to place a sign near the entrance of the resident's room that states that the room contains a monitoring device.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(5): Notwithstanding any other provision of this part, an individual may not, under this part, operate a monitoring device in a facility without a court order:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(5)(a): in secret; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-236(5)(b): with an intent to intercept a wire, electronic, or oral communication without notice to or the consent of a party to the communication.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-237(1): 26B-2-301 As used in this section:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-237(1)(c)(ii): is legally authorized to make health care decisions on behalf of the resident.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-237(2): (3) A facility is subject to the requirements in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-237(2)(a): is initiated by the facility for any reason;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-237(2)(b): is objected to by the resident or the resident's responsible person;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-237(2)(d): is inconsistent with the resident's preferences and stated goals for care.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-237(3): (2); (3)(a); (3)(a); (3)(a) Before a transfer or discharge described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-237(3)(a)(ii): the effective date of the transfer or discharge;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-237(3)(c): (3)(a) provide the notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-237(3)(c)(i): notice for a shorter period of time is necessary to protect:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-237(3)(c)(i)(A): the safety of individuals in the assisted living facility from endangerment due to the medical or behavioral status of the resident; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-237(3)(c)(i)(B): the health of individuals in the assisted living facility from endangerment due to the resident's continued residency;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-237(3)(c)(ii): an immediate transfer or discharge is required by the resident's urgent medical needs; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-237(3)(c)(iii): the resident has not resided in the assisted living facility for at least 30 days;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-237(3)(d): update the transfer or discharge notice as soon as practicable before the transfer or discharge if information in the notice changes before the transfer or discharge;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-237(3)(e): orally explain to the resident:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-237(3)(e)(i): the services available through the ombudsman; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-237(3)(e)(ii): the contact information for the ombudsman; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-237(3)(f): provide and document the provision of preparation and orientation for the resident, in a language and manner the resident is most likely to understand, to ensure a safe and orderly transfer or discharge from the assisted living facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-237(4): In the event of an assisted living facility closure, the assisted living facility shall provide written notification of the closure to the ombudsman, each resident of the facility, and each resident's responsible person.

---------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(3): "Covered contractor" means a person that supplies covered individuals, by contract, to a covered employer or covered provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(4): "Covered employer" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(4)(a): engages a covered individual to provide services in a private residence to:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(4)(c): is not a licensed health care facility within the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(5): "Covered individual":
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(5)(a): means an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(5)(a)(i): whom a covered body engages; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(5)(a)(ii): who may have direct patient access;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(5)(b): includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(5)(b)(i): a nursing assistant, as defined by department rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(5)(b)(ii): a personal care aide, as defined by department rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(5)(b)(iii): an individual licensed to engage in the practice of nursing under Title 58, Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(5)(b)(iv): a provider of medical, therapeutic, or social services, including a provider of laboratory and radiology services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(5)(b)(v): an executive;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(5)(b)(vi): administrative staff, including a manager or other administrator;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(5)(b)(vii): dietary and food service staff;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(5)(b)(viii): housekeeping and maintenance staff; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(5)(b)(ix): any other individual, as defined by department rule, who has direct patient access; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(5)(c): does not include a student, as defined by department rule, directly supervised by a member of the staff of the covered body or the student's instructor.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(6): "Covered provider" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(6)(a): an end stage renal disease facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(6)(b): a long-term care hospital;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(6)(c): a nursing care facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(6)(d): a small health care facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(6)(e): an assisted living facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(6)(f): a hospice;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(6)(g): a home health agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(6)(h): a personal care agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(7): "Direct patient access" means for an individual to be in a position where the individual could, in relation to a patient or resident of the covered body who engages the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(7)(a): cause physical or mental harm;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(7)(b): commit theft; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(7)(c): view medical or financial records.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(8): "Engage" means to obtain one's services:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(8)(a): by employment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(8)(b): by contract;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(8)(c): as a volunteer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(8)(d): by other arrangement.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(9): "Long-term care hospital":
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(9)(a): means a hospital that is certified to provide long-term care services under the provisions of 42 U.S.C. Sec. 1395tt; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(9)(b): does not include a critical access hospital, designated under 42 U.S.C. Sec. 1395i-4(c)(2).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(10): "Patient" means an individual who receives health care services from one of the following covered providers:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(10)(a): an end stage renal disease facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(10)(b): a long-term care hospital;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(10)(c): a hospice;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(10)(d): a home health agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(10)(e): a personal care agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(11): "Personal care agency" means a health care facility defined by department rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(12): "Rap back system" means a system that enables authorized entities to receive ongoing status notifications of any criminal history reported on individuals who are registered in the system.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(13): "Resident" means an individual who receives health care services from one of the following covered providers:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(13)(a): a nursing care facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(13)(b): a small health care facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(13)(c): an assisted living facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(13)(d): a hospice that provides living quarters as part of its services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(14): "Residential setting" means a place provided by a covered provider:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(14)(a): for residents to live as part of the services provided by the covered provider; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(14)(b): where an individual who is not a resident also lives.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-238(15): "Volunteer" means an individual, as defined by department rule, who provides services without pay or other compensation.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-240 Department authorized to grant, deny, or revoke clearance -- Department may limit direct patient access -- Clearance.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-240(1): 26B-2-238 The definitions in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-240(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-240(2)(a): As provided in this section, the department may grant, deny, or revoke certification for direct patient access for an individual, including a covered individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-240(2)(b): The department may limit the circumstances under which a covered individual granted certification for direct patient access may have direct patient access, based on the relationship factors under Subsection (4) and other mitigating factors related to patient and resident protection.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242 Visitation policy.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(1): (3) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(1)(a): "Patient" means an individual who receives care or services from a health care facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(1)(b): "Personal representative" means an individual described in 45 C.F.R. Sec. 164.502(g).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(1)(c): (3) "Primary visitor" means an individual who a patient designates under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(2): A health care facility shall establish visitation policies and procedures that shall, at a minimum, include provisions regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(2)(a): infection control;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(2)(b): infection control education for visitors;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(2)(c): personal protective equipment requirements when necessary for infection control;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(2)(d): for a visitor who is not a primary visitor:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(2)(d)(i): maximum duration of visits;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(2)(d)(ii): maximum number of visitors a patient may have each day;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(2)(d)(iii): maximum number of visitors a patient may have at one time; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(2)(e): the individual or position at the health care facility that is responsible for ensuring that staff adhere to the policies and procedures.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(3): (5)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(3)(a): A patient or the patient's personal representative may designate one individual as a primary visitor.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(3)(b): (5) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(4): (5); (5) A health care facility may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(4)(a): require a visitor or primary visitor to comply with infection control measures that are more restrictive than the infection control measures the health care facility requires of the health care facility's staff;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(4)(b): require a visitor or primary visitor to show proof of vaccination or immunization status;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(4)(c): (5) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(4)(d): (5) deny a visitor or primary visitor access to the patient unless visitation is denied, modified, or limited as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(5): A health care facility may:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(5)(a): exclude certain areas of the health care facility from visitor and primary visitor access;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(5)(b): require a visitor or a primary visitor to agree in writing to follow the health care facility's visitation policies and procedures before allowing access to the patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(5)(c): suspend or refuse in-person visitation for a visitor or a primary visitor if the visitor or primary visitor violates the health care facility's visitation policies and procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(5)(d): remove a visitor or primary visitor or deny visitation, if the patient is undergoing a procedure or receiving treatment that would be impeded by visitation;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(5)(e): deny visitation for a visitor or primary visitor if the patient or personal representative objects to the visit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(5)(f): prohibit physical contact or visitation if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(5)(f)(i): the visit or physical contact is prohibited by law;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(5)(f)(ii): the patient is in the custody of the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(5)(f)(iii): the health care facility determines the visit or physical contact:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(5)(f)(iii)(A): creates a physical safety risk to the patient, the visitor or primary visitor, or the health care facility's staff;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(5)(f)(iii)(B): is counter therapeutic to the patient's well-being; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(5)(f)(iii)(C): is disruptive to the patient's care or treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(6): A health care facility shall provide the department with a copy of the health care facility's visitation policies and procedures:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(6)(a): upon the department's request; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(6)(b): when the health care facility:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(6)(b)(i): obtains a license to operate from the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(6)(b)(ii): renews the license from the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(6)(b)(iii): changes ownership.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(7): A health care facility shall make visitation policies and procedures created in accordance with this section available on the health care facility's website.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(8): The department shall provide:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(8)(a): a description of the requirements of this section on the department's website; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(8)(b): a method for the public to report a violation of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-242(9): This section does not apply to the Utah State Hospital.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-302 Legislative findings -- Purpose -- Ombudsman.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-302(1): The Legislature finds and declares that the citizens of this state should be assisted in asserting their civil and human rights as patients, residents, and clients of long-term care facilities created to serve their specialized needs and problems; and that for the health, safety, and welfare of these citizens, the state should take appropriate action through an adequate legal framework to address their difficulties.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-302(2): The purpose of this part is to establish within the division the Long-Term Care Ombudsman Program for the citizens of this state and identify duties and responsibilities of that program and of the ombudsman, in order to address problems relating to long-term care and to fulfill federal requirements.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-303 Long-Term Care Ombudsman Program -- Responsibilities.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-303(1): 26B-6-110
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-303(1)(a): There is created within the division the ombudsman program for the purpose of promoting, advocating, and ensuring the adequacy of care received and the quality of life experienced by residents of long-term care facilities within the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-303(1)(b): 26B-6-110 Subject to the rules made under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-303(1)(b)(i): receiving and resolving complaints relating to residents of long-term care facilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-303(1)(b)(ii): conducting investigations of any act, practice, policy, or procedure of a long-term care facility or government agency that the ombudsman has reason to believe affects or may affect the health, safety, welfare, or civil and human rights of a resident of a long-term care facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-303(1)(b)(iii): coordinating the department's services for residents of long-term care facilities to ensure that those services are made available to eligible citizens of the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-303(1)(b)(iv): providing training regarding the delivery and regulation of long-term care to public agencies, local ombudsman program volunteers, and operators and employees of long-term care facilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-303(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-303(2)(a): A long-term care facility shall display an ombudsman program information poster in a location that is readily visible to all residents, visitors, and staff members.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-303(2)(b): The division is responsible for providing the posters, which shall include phone numbers for local ombudsman programs.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-304 Powers and responsibilities of ombudsman.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
The long-term care ombudsman shall:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-304(1): comply with Title VII of the federal Older Americans Act, 42 U.S.C. 3058 et seq.;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-304(2): establish procedures for and engage in receiving complaints, conducting investigations, reporting findings, issuing findings and recommendations, promoting community contact and involvement with residents of long-term care facilities through the use of volunteers, and publicizing its functions and activities;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-304(3): investigate an administrative act or omission of a long-term care facility or governmental agency if the act or omission relates to the purposes of the ombudsman. The ombudsman may exercise its authority under this subsection without regard to the finality of the administrative act or omission, and it may make findings in order to resolve the subject matter of its investigation;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-304(4): recommend to the division rules that it considers necessary to carry out the purposes of the ombudsman;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-304(5): cooperate and coordinate with governmental entities and voluntary assistance organizations in exercising its powers and responsibilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-304(6): request and receive cooperation, assistance, services, and data from any governmental agency, to enable it to properly exercise its powers and responsibilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-304(7): establish local ombudsman programs to assist in carrying out the purposes of this part, which shall meet the standards developed by the division, and possess all of the authority and power granted to the ombudsman program under this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-304(8): exercise other powers and responsibilities as reasonably required to carry out the purposes of this part.

The ombudsman shall comply with the procedures and requirements of

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-306 Investigation of complaints -- Procedures.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-306(1): The ombudsman shall investigate each complaint the ombudsman receives.  An investigation may consist of a referral to another public agency, the collecting of facts and information over the telephone, or an inspection of the long-term care facility that is named in the complaint.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-306(2): (3) In making an investigation, the ombudsman may engage in actions the ombudsman considers appropriate, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-306(2)(a): making inquiries and obtaining information;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-306(2)(b): holding investigatory hearings;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-306(2)(c): entering and inspecting any premises, without notice to the facility, provided the investigator presents, upon entering the premises, identification as an individual authorized by this part to inspect the premises; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-306(2)(d): (3) inspecting or obtaining a book, file, medical record, or other record required by law to be retained by the long-term care facility or governmental agency, pertaining to residents, subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-306(3): (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-306(3)(a): Before reviewing a resident's records, the ombudsman shall seek to obtain from the resident, or the resident's legal representative, permission in writing, orally, or through the use of auxiliary aids and services to review the records.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-306(3)(b): (3)(a) The effort to obtain permission under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-306(3)(c): If the ombudsman's attempt to obtain permission fails for a reason other than the refusal of the resident or the resident's legal representative to give permission, the ombudsman may review the records.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-306(3)(d): If the ombudsman has reasonable cause to believe that the resident is incompetent to give permission and that the resident's legal representative is not acting in the best interest of the resident, the ombudsman shall determine whether review of the resident's records is in the best interest of the resident.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-306(3)(e): If the ombudsman determines that review of the resident's records is in the best interest of the resident, the ombudsman shall review the records.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-307 Confidentiality of materials relating to complaints or investigations -- Immunity from liability -- Discriminatory, disciplinary, or retaliatory actions prohibited.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-307(1): The ombudsman shall establish procedures to ensure that all files maintained by the ombudsman program are disclosed only at the discretion of and under the authority of the ombudsman.  The identity of a complainant or resident of a long-term care facility may not be disclosed by the ombudsman unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-307(1)(a): the complainant or resident, or the legal representative of either, consents in writing, orally, or through the use of auxiliary aids and services to the disclosure;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-307(1)(b): disclosure is ordered by the court; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-307(1)(c): the disclosure is approved by the ombudsman and is made, as part of an investigation involving the resident, to an agency that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-307(1)(c)(i): has statutory responsibility for the resident;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-307(1)(c)(ii): has statutory responsibility over the action alleged in the complaint;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-307(1)(c)(iii): is able to assist the ombudsman to achieve resolution of the complaint; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-307(1)(c)(iv): is able to provide expertise that would benefit the resident.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-307(2): Neither the ombudsman nor the ombudsman's agent or designee may be required to testify in court with respect to confidential matters, except as the court finds necessary to enforce this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-307(3): Any person who makes a complaint to the ombudsman pursuant to this part is immune from any civil or criminal liability unless the complaint was made maliciously or without good faith.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-307(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-307(4)(a): Discriminatory, disciplinary, or retaliatory action may not be taken against a volunteer or employee of a long-term care facility or governmental agency, or against a resident of a long-term care facility, for any communication made or information given or disclosed to aid the ombudsman or other appropriate public agency in carrying out its duties and responsibilities, unless the same was done maliciously or without good faith.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-307(4)(b): This subsection does not infringe on the rights of an employer to supervise, discipline, or terminate an employee for any other reason.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-308 Prohibited acts -- Penalty.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-308(1): No person may:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-308(1)(a): give or cause to be given advance notice to a long-term care facility or agency that an investigation or inspection under the direction of the ombudsman is pending or under consideration, except as provided by law;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-308(1)(b): disclose confidential information submitted to the ombudsman pursuant to this part, except as provided by law;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-308(1)(c): willfully interfere with the lawful actions of the ombudsman;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-308(1)(d): willfully refuse to comply with lawful demands of the ombudsman, including the demand for immediate entry into or inspection of the premises of any long-term care facility or agency or for immediate access to a resident of a long-term care facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-308(1)(e): offer or accept any compensation, gratuity, or promise thereof in an effort to affect the outcome of a matter being investigated or of a matter that is before the ombudsman for determination of whether an investigation should be conducted.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-308(2): Violation of any provision of this part constitutes a class B misdemeanor.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
