Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(1): "Capacity limit" means the maximum number of qualifying children that a regulated provider may care for at any given time, in accordance with rules made by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(2): 26B-2-405
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(2)(a): "Center based child care" means child care provided in a facility or program that is not the home of the provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(2)(b): 26B-2-405 "Center based child care" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(2)(b)(i): residential child care; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(2)(b)(ii): 26B-2-405 care provided in a facility or program exempt under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(3): 26B-2-404 "Certified provider" means a person who holds a certificate from the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(4): "Child care" means continuous care and supervision of a qualifying child, that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(4)(a): in lieu of care ordinarily provided by a parent in the parent's home;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(4)(b): for less than 24 hours a day; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(4)(c): for direct or indirect compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(5): "Child care program" means a child care facility or program operated by a regulated provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(6): 26B-2-405(2) "Exempt provider" means a person who provides care described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(7): 26B-2-403 "Licensed provider" means a person who holds a license from the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(8): 26B-1-204 "Licensing committee" means the Child Care Provider Licensing Committee created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(9): "Public school" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(9)(a): a school, including a charter school, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(9)(a)(i): is directly funded at public expense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(9)(a)(ii): provides education to qualifying children for any grade from first grade through twelfth grade; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(9)(b): a school, including a charter school, that provides:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(9)(b)(i): preschool or kindergarten to qualifying children, regardless of whether the preschool or kindergarten is funded at public expense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(9)(b)(ii): education to qualifying children for any grade from first grade through twelfth grade, if each grade, from first grade to twelfth grade, that is provided at the school, is directly funded at public expense.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(10): "Qualifying child" means an individual who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(10)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(10)(a)(i): under the age of 13 years old; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(10)(a)(ii): under the age of 18 years old, if the person has a disability; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(10)(b): a child of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(10)(b)(i): a person other than the person providing care to the child;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(10)(b)(ii): a regulated provider, if the child is under the age of four; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(10)(b)(iii): an employee or owner of a licensed child care center, if the child is under the age of four.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(11): "Regulated provider" means a licensed provider or certified provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-401(12): "Residential child care" means child care provided in the home of the provider.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402 Duties of the department -- Enforcement of part -- Licensing committee requirements.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(1): With regard to residential child care licensed, certified, or subject to criminal background checks under this part, the department may:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(1)(a): make and enforce rules to implement this part and, as necessary to protect qualifying children's common needs for a safe and healthy environment, to provide for:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(1)(a)(i): adequate facilities and equipment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(1)(a)(ii): competent caregivers, considering the age of the children and the type of program offered by the licensee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(1)(b): make and enforce rules necessary to carry out the purposes of this part, in the following areas:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(1)(b)(i): requirements for applications, the application process, and compliance with other applicable statutes and rules;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(1)(b)(ii): documentation and policies and procedures that providers shall have in place in order to be licensed, in accordance with Subsection (1)(a);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(1)(b)(iii): categories, classifications, and duration of initial and ongoing licenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(1)(b)(iv): changes of ownership or name, changes in licensure status, and changes in operational status;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(1)(b)(v): license expiration and renewal, contents, and posting requirements;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(1)(b)(vi): procedures for inspections, complaint resolution, disciplinary actions, and other procedural measures to encourage and assure compliance with statute and rule; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(1)(b)(vii): guidelines necessary to assure consistency and appropriateness in the regulation and discipline of licensees.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(2): The department shall enforce the rules established by the licensing committee, with the concurrence of the department, for center based child care.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(3): The department shall make rules that allow a regulated provider to provide after school child care for a reasonable number of qualifying children in excess of the regulated provider's capacity limit, without requiring the regulated provider to obtain a waiver or new license from the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(4): Rules made under this part by the department, or the licensing committee  with the concurrence of the department,  shall be made in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(5)(a): The licensing committee and the department may not regulate educational curricula, academic methods, or the educational philosophy or approach of the provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(5)(b): The licensing committee and the department shall allow for a broad range of educational training and academic background in certification or qualification of child day care directors.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(6): In licensing and regulating child care programs, the licensing committee and the department shall reasonably balance the benefits and burdens of each regulation and, by rule, provide for a range of licensure, depending upon the needs and different levels and types of child care provided.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(7): 26B-2-401 Notwithstanding the definition of "qualifying child" in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(7)(a): a licensed residential child care provider; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(7)(b): an owner or employee of a licensed child care center.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(8): Notwithstanding Subsection (1)(a)(i), the licensing committee and the department may not exclude floor space used for furniture, fixtures, or equipment from the minimum square footage requirement for indoor and outdoor areas if the furniture, fixture, or equipment is used:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(8)(a): by qualifying children;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(8)(b): for the care of qualifying children; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(8)(c): to store classroom materials.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(9)(a): A child care center constructed prior to January 1, 2004, and licensed and operated as a child care center continuously since January 1, 2004, is exempt from the licensing committee's and the department's group size restrictions, if the child to caregiver ratios are maintained, and adequate square footage is maintained for specific classrooms.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(9)(b): An exemption granted under Subsection (9)(a) is transferrable to subsequent licensed operators at the center if a licensed child care center is continuously maintained at the center.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(10): The licensing committee , with the concurrence of the  department, shall develop, by rule, a five-year phased-in compliance schedule for playground equipment safety standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-402(11): 26B-1-209 The department shall set and collect licensing and other fees in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(1): "Capacity building" means strengthening an individual's or a community's ability to participate in shared decision making.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(2): "Community health worker" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(2)(a): works to improve a social determinant of health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(2)(b): acts as an intermediary between a community and health services or social services to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(2)(b)(i): facilitate access to services; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(2)(b)(ii): improve the quality and cultural competence of service delivery; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(2)(c): increases health knowledge and self-sufficiency of an individual or a community through outreach, capacity building, community education, informal counseling, social support, and other similar activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(3): "Core-skill education" means education regarding each of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(3)(a): self-reliance;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(3)(b): outreach;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(3)(c): capacity building;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(3)(d): individual and community assessment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(3)(e): coordination skills;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(3)(f): relationship building;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(3)(g): facilitation of services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(3)(h): communication;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(3)(i): professional conduct; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(3)(j): health promotion.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(4): "Core-skill training" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(4)(a): 90 hours of competency-based education; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(4)(b): 300 hours of community involvement as determined by the department through rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(5): "Social determinate of health" means any condition in which an individual or a community lives, learns, works, plays, worships, or ages, that affects the individual's or the community's health or quality of life outcomes or risks.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-501(6): 26B-2-504(1) "State certified" means that an individual has obtained the state certification described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-506 Certification is voluntary.
-----------------------------------------------------------
This part does not prohibit an individual from acting as a community health worker if the individual does not have a certificate described in this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-601 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-601(1): "Diagnostic mammography" means mammography performed on a woman having suspected breast cancer.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-601(2): "Facility" means a facility that provides screening or diagnostic breast mammography services.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-605 Women's cancer screening notification requirement.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"Your mammogram indicates that you have dense breast tissue. Dense breast tissue is common and is found in as many as half of all women. However, dense breast tissue can make it more difficult to fully and accurately evaluate your mammogram and detect early signs of possible cancer in the breast. This information is being provided to inform and encourage you to discuss your dense breast tissue and other breast cancer risk factors with your health care provider. Together, you can decide what may be best for you. A copy of your mammography report has been sent to your health care provider. Please contact them if you have any questions or concerns about this notice."Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-605(1): As used in this section, "dense breast tissue" means heterogeneously dense tissue or extremely dense tissue as defined in the Breast Imaging and Reporting Data System established by the American College of Radiology.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-605(2): 26B-2-603 A facility that is certified under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-606 Breast cancer mortality reduction program.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department shall create a breast cancer mortality reduction program.  The program shall include:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-606(1): education programs for health professionals regarding skills in cancer screening, diagnosis, referral, treatment, and rehabilitation based on current scientific knowledge;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-606(2): education programs to assist the public in understanding:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-606(2)(a): the benefits of regular breast cancer screening;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-606(2)(b): resources available in the medical care system for cancer screening, diagnosis, referral, treatment, and rehabilitation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-606(2)(c): available options for treatment of breast cancer and the ramifications of each approach; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-606(3): subsidized screening mammography for low-income women as determined by the department standards.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-701 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-701(1): "Certificate" means a residential child care certificate issued by the office.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-701(2): "Certification" means an approval to operate in compliance with local or federal requirements or regulations, completed by the office or on behalf of the office for a local or federal agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-701(3): "Client" means an individual, resident, or patient who receives services from a provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-701(4): "Program or facility" means the settings, activities, services, procedures, and premises used by a provider to provide services regulated by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-701(5): "Provider" means a license holder, certificate holder, or legally responsible person that provides services regulated by the department.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-702 Licensure.
------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-702(1): A person that operates a program or facility that requires a license, certificate, or certification under this chapter is subject to this part regardless of whether the person holds a license, certificate, or certification.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-702(2): A person may not offer a service, operate or provide services, or engage in any activity regulated by this chapter without holding a license, certificate, or certification issued or approved under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-702(3): A person who holds a license, certificate, or certification under this chapter may only provide services to the extent allowed by the license, certificate, or certification.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-702(4): A person may not advertise or represent that the person holds a license, certificate, or certification required by this chapter unless the person holds that license, certificate, or certification.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-702(5): 26B-1-224 A person who violates this section is subject to Section


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703 Sanctions -- Penalties and adjudicative procedure -- Rulemaking.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(1): If the department has reason to believe that a provider has failed to comply with this chapter or rules made pursuant to this chapter, the department may serve a notice of agency action to commence an adjudicative proceeding in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(2): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act, the department may deny, place conditions on, suspend, or revoke a license, certificate, or certification, and invoke penalties, including restricting or prohibiting new admissions to a program or facility, if the department finds that there has been:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(2)(a): a failure to comply with:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(2)(a)(i): rules established under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(2)(a)(ii): any lawful order of the department or a local health department, or applicable rule, statute, regulation, or requirement;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(2)(b): aiding, abetting, or permitting the commission of any illegal act;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(2)(c): conduct adverse to the standards required to provide services and promote public trust, including aiding, abetting, or permitting the commission of abuse, neglect, exploitation, harm, mistreatment, or fraud; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(2)(d): a failure to provide applicable health and safety services for clients.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(3)(a): The department may act on an emergency basis if the department determines immediate action is necessary to protect a client.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(3)(b): Immediate action taken under Subsection (3)(a) may include restricting new admissions to a program or facility, or increased monitoring of the operations of a program or facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(4): The department may impose civil monetary penalties against any person, in a sum not to exceed $10,000 per violation, in:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(4)(a): an administrative action in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(4)(b): a similar administrative proceeding adopted by a county or local government; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(4)(c): a judicial civil proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(5): Assessment of a civil penalty or administrative penalty does not preclude the department or a local health department from:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(5)(a): seeking criminal penalties;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(5)(b): denying, revoking, imposing conditions on, or refusing to renew a license, certificate, or certification; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(5)(c): seeking injunctive or equitable remedies.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(6): If the department revokes a license, certificate, or certification, the office may not grant a new license, certificate, or certification unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(6)(a): at least five years have passed since the day on which the provider was served with final notice that the provider's license, certificate, or certification was revoked; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(6)(b): the office determines that the interests of the public will not be jeopardized by granting the provider a new license, certificate, or certification.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(7): If the department does not renew a license, certificate, or certification because of noncompliance with the provisions of this part or rules adopted under this part, the department may not issue a new license, certificate, or certification unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(7)(a): at least one year has passed since the day on which the renewal was denied;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(7)(b): the provider complies with all renewal requirements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(7)(c): the office determines that the interests of the public will not be jeopardized by issuing a new license, certificate, or certification.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(8): The office may suspend a license, certificate, or certification for up to three years.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(9): When a license, certificate, or certification has been suspended, the office may restore, or restore subject to conditions, the suspended license, certificate, or certification upon a determination that the:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(9)(a): conditions upon which the suspension were based have been completely or partially corrected; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(9)(b): interests of the public will not be jeopardized by restoration of the license, certificate, or certification.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(10): If a provider fails to comply with the provisions of this chapter, the department may impose a penalty on the provider that is less than or equal to the cost incurred by the department, which may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(10)(a): the cost to continue providing services, including ensuring client safety and relocating clients through the transition or closure of a program or facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(10)(b): the cost to place an administrator or department representative as a monitor in a program or facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(10)(c): the cost to assess to the provider those costs incurred by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(11): 26B-2-124; 26B-2-124 If a congregate care program or facility knowingly fails to comply with the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(12): 76-7-314; 76-7a-201 If the department finds that an abortion has been performed in violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(13): A provider, program or facility, or person may commence adjudicative proceedings in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act, regarding all agency actions that determine the legal rights, duties, privileges, immunities, or other legal interests of the provider, program or facility, or persons associated with the provider, including all office actions to grant, deny, place conditions on, revoke, suspend, withdraw, or amend an authority, right, license, certificate, or certification under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-703(14): Subject to the requirements of federal and state law, the office shall make rules in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to establish sanctions, penalties, and adjudicative proceedings as described in this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-705 Immediate access restriction.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-705(1): If, in any program or facility requiring a license, certificate, or certification under this part, the department finds a condition that is a clear hazard to the public health or safety, the department may immediately order that the facility restrict access and may prevent the entrance of any client onto the premises of that facility until the condition is eliminated.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-705(2): Parties aggrieved by the actions of the department under this section may obtain an adjudicative proceeding and judicial review.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-706 Action by department for injunction.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Notwithstanding the existence of any other remedy, the department may, in the manner provided by law and upon the advice of the attorney general, who shall represent the department in the proceedings, maintain an action in the name of the state for injunction or other process against any person or governmental unit to restrain or prevent the establishment, conduct, management, or operation of a program or facility in violation of this chapter or rules established under this chapter.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(1): 26B-1-224
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(1)(a): 26B-1-224 In addition to the penalties in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(a): any discount, payment, waiver of payment, or payment practice not prohibited by 42 U.S.C. Sec. 1320a-7(b) or regulations made under 42 U.S.C. Sec. 1320a-7(b);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(b): patient referrals within a practice group;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(c): payments by a health insurer who reimburses, provides, offers to provide, or administers health, mental health, or substance use disorder goods or services under a health benefit plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(d): payments to or by a health care provider, practice group, or substance use disorder treatment program that has contracted with a local mental health authority, a local substance abuse authority, a health insurer, a health care purchasing group, or the Medicare or Medicaid program to provide health, mental health, or substance use disorder services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(e): payments by a health care provider, practice group, or substance use disorder treatment program to a health, mental health, or substance use disorder information service that provides information upon request and without charge to consumers about providers of health care goods or services to enable consumers to select appropriate providers or facilities, if the information service:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(e)(i): does not attempt, through standard questions for solicitation of consumer criteria or through any other means, to steer or lead a consumer to select or consider selection of a particular health care provider, practice group, or substance use disorder treatment program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(e)(ii): does not provide or represent that the information service provides diagnostic or counseling services or assessments of illness or injury and does not make any promises of cure or guarantees of treatment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(e)(iii): charges and collects fees from a health care provider, practice group, or substance use disorder treatment program participating in information services that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(e)(iii)(A): are set in advance;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(e)(iii)(B): are consistent with the fair market value for those information services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(e)(iii)(C): are not based on the potential value of the goods or services that a health care provider, practice group, or substance use disorder treatment program may provide to a patient; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(f): payments by a laboratory to a person that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(f)(i): does not have a financial interest in or with a facility or person who refers a clinical sample to the laboratory;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(f)(ii): is not related to an owner of a facility or a person who refers a clinical sample to the laboratory;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(f)(iii): is not related to and does not have a financial relationship with a health care provider who orders the laboratory to conduct a test that is used toward the furnishing of an item or service for the treatment of a substance use disorder;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(f)(iv): identifies, in advance of providing marketing or sales services, the types of clinical samples that each laboratory will receive, if the person provides marketing or sales services to more than one laboratory;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(f)(v): the person does not identify as or hold itself out to be a laboratory or part of a network with an insurance payor, if the person provides marketing or sales services under a contract with a laboratory, as described in Subsection (4)(f)(vii)(B);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(f)(vi): the person identifies itself in all marketing materials as a salesperson for a licensed laboratory and identifies each laboratory that the person represents, if the person provides marketing or sales services under a contract with a laboratory, as described in Subsection (4)(f)(vii)(B); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(f)(vii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(f)(vii)(A): is a sales person employed by the laboratory to market or sell the laboratory's services to a person who provides substance use disorder treatment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(4)(f)(vii)(B): is a person under contract with the laboratory to market or sell the laboratory's services to a person who provides substance use disorder treatment, if the total compensation paid by the laboratory does not exceed the total compensation that the laboratory pays to employees of the laboratory for similar marketing or sales services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(5)(a): A person may not knowingly or willfully, in exchange for referring an individual to a youth transportation company:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(5)(a)(i): offer, pay, promise to pay, solicit, or receive any remuneration directly or indirectly, overtly or covertly, in cash or in kind, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(5)(a)(i)(A): a commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(5)(a)(i)(B): a bonus;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(5)(a)(i)(C): a kickback;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(5)(a)(i)(D): a bribe; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(5)(a)(i)(E): a rebate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-707(5)(a)(ii): engage in any split-fee arrangement.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-2-708 Injunctive relief and civil penalty for unlawful child placing -- Enforcement by county attorney or attorney general.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated - Title 26B - Chapter 3 - Health Care - Administration and Assistance
*****************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-101(1): "Applicant" means any person who requests assistance under the medical programs of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-101(2): "CMS" means the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services within the United States Department of Health and Human Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-101(3): 26B-3-102 "Division" means the Division of Integrated Healthcare within the department, established under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-101(4): "Enrollee" or "member" means an individual whom the department has determined to be eligible for assistance under the Medicaid program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-101(5): "Medicaid program" means the state program for medical assistance for persons who are eligible under the state plan adopted pursuant to Title XIX of the federal Social Security Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-101(6): "Medical assistance" means services furnished or payments made to or on behalf of a member.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-101(7): 41-1a-102; 41-1a-102; 13-14-102
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-101(7)(a): "Passenger vehicle" means a self-propelled, two-axle vehicle intended primarily for operation on highways and used by an applicant or recipient to meet basic transportation needs and has a fair market value below 40% of the applicable amount of the federal luxury passenger automobile tax established in 26 U.S.C. Sec. 4001 and adjusted annually for inflation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-101(7)(b): 41-1a-102; 41-1a-102; 13-14-102 "Passenger vehicle" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-101(7)(b)(i): 41-1a-102 a commercial vehicle, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-101(7)(b)(ii): 41-1a-102 an off-highway vehicle, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-101(7)(b)(iii): 13-14-102 a motor home, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-101(8): 31A-1-301 "PPACA" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-101(9): "Recipient" means a person who has received medical assistance under the Medicaid program.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-102 Division -- Creation.
-----------------------------------------------------
There is created, within the department, the Division of Integrated Healthcare which shall be responsible for implementing, organizing, and maintaining the Medicaid program and the Children's Health Insurance Program established in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-103 State Medicaid director -- Appointment -- Responsibilities.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-103(1): The state Medicaid director shall be appointed by the governor, after consultation with the executive director, with the advice and consent of the Senate.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-103(2): The state Medicaid director may employ other employees as necessary to implement the provisions of this chapter, and shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-103(2)(a): administer the responsibilities of the division as set forth in this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-103(2)(b): administer the division's budget; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-103(2)(c): establish and maintain a state plan for the Medicaid program in compliance with federal law and regulations.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-104 Division responsibilities -- Emphasis -- Periodic assessment.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-104(1): In accordance with the requirements of Title XIX of the Social Security Act and applicable federal regulations, the division is responsible for the effective and impartial administration of this chapter in an efficient, economical manner.  The division shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-104(1)(a): establish, on a statewide basis, a program to safeguard against unnecessary or inappropriate use of Medicaid services, excessive payments, and unnecessary or inappropriate hospital admissions or lengths of stay;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-104(1)(b): deny any provider claim for services that fail to meet criteria established by the division concerning medical necessity or appropriateness; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-104(1)(c): place its emphasis on high quality care to recipients in the most economical and cost-effective manner possible, with regard to both publicly and privately provided services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-104(2): 26B-3-105; 58-17b-606 The division shall implement and utilize cost-containment methods, where possible, which may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-104(2)(a): prepayment and postpayment review systems to determine if utilization is reasonable and necessary;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-104(2)(b): preadmission certification of nonemergency admissions;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-104(2)(c): mandatory outpatient, rather than inpatient, surgery in appropriate cases;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-104(2)(d): second surgical opinions;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-104(2)(e): procedures for encouraging the use of outpatient services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-104(2)(f): 26B-3-105; 58-17b-606 consistent with Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-104(2)(g): coordination of benefits; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-104(2)(h): review and exclusion of providers who are not cost effective or who have abused the Medicaid program, in accordance with the procedures and provisions of federal law and regulation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-104(3): The state Medicaid director shall periodically assess the cost effectiveness and health implications of the existing Medicaid program, and consider alternative approaches to the provision of covered health and medical services through the Medicaid program, in order to reduce unnecessary or unreasonable utilization.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-104(4): 63A-13-201; (2); 63A-13-202
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-104(4)(a): The department shall ensure Medicaid program integrity by conducting internal audits of the Medicaid program for efficiencies, best practices, and cost avoidance.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-104(4)(b): 63A-13-201; (2); 63A-13-202 The department shall coordinate with the Office of the Inspector General for Medicaid Services created in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107 Dental benefits.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(1): (8)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(1)(a): (8) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(1)(b): The division may bid out the Medicaid dental benefits separately from other program benefits.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(2): The division shall use the following criteria to evaluate dental bids:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(2)(a): ability to manage dental expenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(2)(b): proven ability to handle dental insurance;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(2)(c): efficiency of claim paying procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(2)(d): provider contracting, discounts, and adequacy of network; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(2)(e): other criteria established by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(3): The division shall request bids for the program's benefits at least once every five years.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(4): The division's contract with dental plans for the program's benefits shall include risk sharing provisions in which the dental plan must accept 100% of the risk for any difference between the division's premium payments per client and actual dental expenditures.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(5): The division may not award contracts to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(5)(a): more than three responsive bidders under this section; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(5)(b): an insurer that does not have a current license in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(6): (6)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(6)(a): The division may cancel the request for proposals if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(6)(a)(i): there are no responsive bidders; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(6)(a)(ii): the division determines that accepting the bids would increase the program's costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(6)(b): (6)(a) If the division cancels a request for proposal or a contract that results from a request for proposal described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(7): Title 63G, Chapter 6a, Utah Procurement Code
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(8)(a): The division may:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(8)(a)(i): establish a dental health care delivery system and payment reform pilot program for Medicaid dental benefits to increase access to cost effective and quality dental health care by increasing the number of dentists available for Medicaid dental services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(8)(a)(ii): target specific Medicaid populations or geographic areas in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(8)(b): The pilot program shall establish compensation models for dentists and dental hygienists that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-107(8)(b)(i): increase access to quality, cost effective dental care; and

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111 Income and resources from institutionalized spouses.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(1): 35A-1-102; 26B-2-201 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(1)(a): "Community spouse" means the spouse of an institutionalized spouse.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(1)(b)(i): "Community spouse monthly income allowance" means an amount by which the minimum monthly maintenance needs allowance for the spouse exceeds the amount of monthly income otherwise available to the community spouse, determined without regard to the allowance, except as provided in Subsection (1)(b)(ii).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(1)(b)(ii): If a court has entered an order against an institutionalized spouse for monthly income for the support of the community spouse, the community spouse monthly income allowance for the spouse may not be less than the amount of the monthly income so ordered.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(1)(c): "Community spouse resource allowance" is the amount of combined resources that are protected for a community spouse living in the community, which the division shall establish by rule made in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, based on the amounts established by the United States Department of Health and Human Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(1)(d): 35A-1-102 "Excess shelter allowance" for a community spouse means the amount by which the sum of the spouse's expense for rent or mortgage payment, taxes, and insurance, and in the case of condominium or cooperative, required maintenance charge, for the community spouse's principal residence and the spouse's actual expenses for electricity, natural gas, and water utilities or, at the discretion of the department, the federal standard utility allowance under SNAP as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(1)(e): "Family member" means a minor dependent child, dependent parents, or dependent sibling of the institutionalized spouse or community spouse who are residing with the community spouse.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(1)(f): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(1)(f)(i): "Institutionalized spouse" means a person who is residing in a nursing facility and is married to a spouse who is not in a nursing facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(1)(f)(ii): An "institutionalized spouse" does not include a person who is not likely to reside in a nursing facility for at least 30 consecutive days.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(1)(g): 26B-2-201 "Nursing care facility" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(2): The division shall comply with this section when determining eligibility for medical assistance for an institutionalized spouse.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(3): The community spouse resource allowance shall be increased by the division by an amount as determined annually by CMS.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(4): The division shall compute, as of the beginning of the first continuous period of institutionalization of the institutionalized spouse:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(4)(a): the total value of the resources to the extent either the institutionalized spouse or the community spouse has an ownership interest; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(4)(b): a spousal share, which is 1/2 of the resources described in Subsection (4)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(5): At the request of an institutionalized spouse or a community spouse, at the beginning of the first continuous period of institutionalization of the institutionalized spouse and upon the receipt of relevant documentation of resources, the division shall promptly assess and document the total value described in Subsection (4)(a) and shall provide a copy of that assessment and documentation to each spouse and shall retain a copy of the assessment.  When the division provides a copy of the assessment, it shall include a notice stating that the spouse may request a hearing under Subsection (11).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(6): When determining eligibility for medical assistance under this chapter:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(6)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (6)(b), all resources held by either the institutionalized spouse, community spouse, or both, are considered to be available to the institutionalized spouse.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(6)(b): Resources are considered to be available to the institutionalized spouse only to the extent that the amount of those resources exceeds the community spouse resource allowance at the time of application for medical assistance under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(7)(a): The division may not find an institutionalized spouse to be ineligible for medical assistance by reason of resources determined under Subsection (5) to be available for the cost of care when:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(7)(a)(i): the institutionalized spouse has assigned to the state any rights to support from the community spouse;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(7)(a)(ii): except as provided in Subsection (7)(b), the institutionalized spouse lacks the ability to execute an assignment due to physical or mental impairment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(7)(a)(iii): the division determines that denial of medical assistance would cause an undue burden.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(7)(b): Subsection (7)(a)(ii) does not prevent the division from seeking a court order for an assignment of support.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(8): During the continuous period in which an institutionalized spouse is in an institution and after the month in which an institutionalized spouse is eligible for medical assistance, the resources of the community spouse may not be considered to be available to the institutionalized spouse.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(9): When an institutionalized spouse is determined to be eligible for medical assistance, in determining the amount of the spouse's income that is to be applied monthly for the cost of care in the nursing care facility, the division shall deduct from the spouse's monthly income the following amounts in the following order:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(9)(a): a personal needs allowance, the amount of which is determined by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(9)(b): a community spouse monthly income allowance, but only to the extent that the income of the institutionalized spouse is made available to, or for the benefit of, the community spouse;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(9)(c): a family allowance for each family member, equal to at least 1/3 of the amount that the amount described in Subsection (10)(a) exceeds the amount of the family member's monthly income; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(9)(d): amounts for incurred expenses for the medical or remedial care for the institutionalized spouse.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(10): The division shall establish a minimum monthly maintenance needs allowance for each community spouse that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(10)(a): an amount established by the division by rule made in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, based on the amounts established by the United States Department of Health and Human Services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(10)(b): an excess shelter allowance.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(11)(a): An institutionalized spouse or a community spouse may request a hearing with respect to the determinations described in Subsections (11)(e)(i) through (v) if an application for medical assistance has been made on behalf of the institutionalized spouse.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(11)(b): A hearing under this subsection regarding the community spouse resource allowance shall be held by the division within 90 days from the date of the request for the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(11)(c): If either spouse establishes that the community spouse needs income, above the level otherwise provided by the minimum monthly maintenance needs allowance, due to exceptional circumstances resulting in significant financial duress, there shall be substituted, for the minimum monthly maintenance needs allowance provided under Subsection (10), an amount adequate to provide additional income as is necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(11)(d): If either spouse establishes that the community spouse resource allowance, in relation to the amount of income generated by the allowance is inadequate to raise the community spouse's income to the minimum monthly maintenance needs allowance, there shall be substituted, for the community spouse resource allowance, an amount adequate to provide a minimum monthly maintenance needs allowance.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(11)(e): A hearing may be held under this subsection if either the institutionalized spouse or community spouse is dissatisfied with a determination of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(11)(e)(i): the community spouse monthly income allowance;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(11)(e)(ii): the amount of monthly income otherwise available to the community spouse;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(11)(e)(iii): the computation of the spousal share of resources under Subsection (4);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(11)(e)(iv): the attribution of resources under Subsection (6); or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(11)(e)(v): the determination of the community spouse resource allocation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(12): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(12)(a): An institutionalized spouse may transfer an amount equal to the community spouse resource allowance, but only to the extent the resources of the institutionalized spouse are transferred to or for the sole benefit of the community spouse.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(12)(b): The transfer under Subsection (12)(a) shall be made as soon as practicable after the date of the initial determination of eligibility, taking into account the time necessary to obtain a court order under Subsection (12)(c).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-111(12)(c): Part 10, Medical Benefits Recovery, does not apply if a court has entered an order against an institutionalized spouse for the support of the community spouse.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-112 Maximizing use of premium assistance programs -- Utah's Premium Partnership for Health Insurance.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-112(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-112(1)(a): The department shall seek to maximize the use of Medicaid and Children's Health Insurance Program funds for assistance in the purchase of private health insurance coverage for Medicaid-eligible and non-Medicaid-eligible individuals.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-112(1)(b): The department's efforts to expand the use of premium assistance shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-112(1)(b)(i): include, as necessary, seeking federal approval under all Medicaid and Children's Health Insurance Program premium assistance provisions of federal law, including provisions of PPACA;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-112(1)(b)(ii): give priority to, but not be limited to, expanding the state's Utah Premium Partnership for Health Insurance program, including as required under Subsection (2); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-112(1)(b)(iii): encourage the enrollment of all individuals within a household in the same plan, where possible, including enrollment in a plan that allows individuals within the household transitioning out of Medicaid to retain the same network and benefits they had while enrolled in Medicaid.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-112(2): The department shall seek federal approval of an amendment to the state's Utah Premium Partnership for Health Insurance program to adjust the eligibility determination for single adults and parents who have an offer of employer sponsored insurance.  The amendment shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-112(2)(a): be within existing appropriations for the Utah Premium Partnership for Health Insurance program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-112(2)(b): provide that adults who are up to 200% of the federal poverty level are eligible for premium subsidies in the Utah Premium Partnership for Health Insurance program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-112(3): For the fiscal year 2020-21, the department shall seek authority to increase the maximum premium subsidy per month for adults under the Utah Premium Partnership for Health Insurance program to $300.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-112(4): In each fiscal year, the department may increase premium subsidies for single adults and parents who have an offer of employer-sponsored insurance to keep pace with the increase in insurance premium costs, subject to appropriation of additional funding.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-114 Department standards for eligibility under Medicaid -- Funds for abortions.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-114(1): 26B-3-108
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-114(1)(a): 26B-3-108 The department may develop standards and administer policies relating to eligibility under the Medicaid program if the standards and policies comply with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-114(1)(b): An applicant receiving Medicaid assistance may be limited to particular types of care or services or to payment of part or all costs of care determined to be medically necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-114(2): The department may not provide any funds for medical, hospital, or other medical expenditures or medical services to otherwise eligible persons where the purpose of the assistance is to perform an abortion, unless the life of the mother would be endangered if an abortion were not performed.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-114(3): Any employee of the department who authorizes payment for an abortion contrary to the provisions of this section is guilty of a class B misdemeanor and subject to forfeiture of office.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-114(4): Any person or organization that, under the guise of other medical treatment, provides an abortion under auspices of the Medicaid program is guilty of a third degree felony and subject to forfeiture of license to practice medicine or authority to provide medical services and treatment.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-115 Contracts for provision of medical services -- Federal provisions modifying department rules -- Compliance with Social Security Act.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-115(1): The department may contract with other public or private agencies to purchase or provide medical services in connection with the programs of the division.  Where these programs are used by other government entities, contracts shall provide that other government entities, in compliance with state and federal law regarding intergovernmental transfers, transfer the state matching funds to the department in amounts sufficient to satisfy needs of the specified program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-115(2): Contract terms shall include provisions for maintenance, administration, and service costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-115(3): If a federal legislative or executive provision requires modifications or revisions in an eligibility factor established under this chapter as a condition for participation in medical assistance, the department may modify or change its rules as necessary to qualify for participation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-115(4): The provisions of this section do not apply to department rules governing abortion.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-115(5): The department shall comply with all pertinent requirements of the Social Security Act and all orders, rules, and regulations adopted thereunder when required as a condition of participation in benefits under the Social Security Act.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-117 Federal aid -- Authority of executive director.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-117(1): The executive director, with the approval of the governor, may bind the state to any executive or legislative provisions promulgated or enacted by the federal government which invite the state to participate in the distribution, disbursement or administration of any fund or service advanced, offered or contributed in whole or in part by the federal government for purposes consistent with the powers and duties of the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-117(2): Such funds shall be used as provided in this chapter and be administered by the department for purposes related to medical assistance programs.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-118 Medical vendor rates.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-118(1): Medical vendor payments made to providers of services for and in behalf of recipient households shall be based upon predetermined rates from standards developed by the division in cooperation with providers of services for each type of service purchased by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-118(2): As far as possible, the rates paid for services shall be established in advance of the fiscal year for which funds are to be requested.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-121 Rural hospitals.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-121(1): As used in this section "rural hospital" means a hospital located outside of a standard metropolitan statistical area, as designated by the United States Bureau of the Census.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-121(2): For purposes of the Medicaid program, the division may not discriminate among rural hospitals on the basis of size.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-129(2)(a): notify and educate providers and health care professionals subject to audit and investigation under the Medicaid program of the providers' and health care professionals' responsibilities and rights under the administrative rules adopted by the department under the provisions of this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-129(2)(b): ensure that the department, or any entity that contracts with the department to conduct audits:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-129(2)(b)(i): has on staff or contracts with a medical or dental professional who is experienced in the treatment, billing, and coding procedures used by the type of provider being audited; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-129(2)(b)(ii): uses the services of the appropriate professional described in Subsection (3)(b)(i) if the provider who is the subject of the audit disputes the findings of the audit;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-129(2)(c): 63A-13-102 ensure that a finding of overpayment or underpayment to a provider is not based on extrapolation, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-129(2)(c)(i): there is a determination that the level of payment error involving the provider exceeds a 10% error rate:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-129(2)(c)(i)(A): for a sample of claims for a particular service code; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-129(2)(c)(i)(B): over a three year period of time;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-129(2)(c)(ii): documented education intervention has failed to correct the level of payment error; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-129(2)(c)(iii): the value of the claims for the provider, in aggregate, exceeds $200,000 in reimbursement for a particular service code on an annual basis; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-129(2)(d): require that any entity with which the office contracts, for the purpose of conducting an audit of a service provider, shall be paid on a flat fee basis for identifying both overpayments and underpayments.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-129(3):

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-129(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-129(3)(b)(i): If extrapolation is used under this section, a provider may, at the provider's option, appeal the results of the audit based on:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130 Medicaid intergovernmental transfer report -- Approval requirements.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(1): 63J-5-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(1)(a)(i): "Intergovernmental transfer" means the transfer of public funds from:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(1)(a)(i)(A): a local government entity to another nonfederal governmental entity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(1)(a)(i)(B): from a nonfederal, government owned health care facility regulated under Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection, to another nonfederal governmental entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(1)(a)(ii): "Intergovernmental transfer" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(1)(a)(ii)(A): the transfer of public funds from one state agency to another state agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(1)(a)(ii)(B): a transfer of funds from the University of Utah Hospitals and Clinics.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(1)(b)(i): "Intergovernmental transfer program" means a federally approved reimbursement program or category that is authorized by the Medicaid state plan or waiver authority for intergovernmental transfers.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(1)(b)(ii): "Intergovernmental transfer program" does not include the addition of a provider to an existing intergovernmental transfer program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(1)(c): 63J-5-102 "Local government entity" means a county, city, town, special service district, special district, or local education agency as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(1)(d): "Non-state government entity" means a hospital authority, hospital district, health care district, special service district, county, or city.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(2)(a): An entity that receives federal Medicaid dollars from the department as a result of an intergovernmental transfer shall, on or before August 1, 2017, and on or before August 1 each year thereafter, provide the department with:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(2)(a)(i): information regarding the payments funded with the intergovernmental transfer as authorized by and consistent with state and federal law;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(2)(a)(ii): information regarding the entity's ability to repay federal funds, to the extent required by the department in the contract for the intergovernmental transfer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(2)(a)(iii): other information reasonably related to the intergovernmental transfer that may be required by the department in the contract for the intergovernmental transfer.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(2)(b): On or before October 15, 2017, and on or before October 15 each subsequent year, the department shall prepare a report for the Executive Appropriations Committee that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(2)(b)(i): the amount of each intergovernmental transfer under Subsection (2)(a);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(2)(b)(ii): a summary of changes to CMS regulations and practices that are known by the department regarding federal funds related to an intergovernmental transfer program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(2)(b)(iii): other information the department gathers about the intergovernmental transfer under Subsection (2)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(3): 63J-5-206; 63J-5-102 The department shall not create a new intergovernmental transfer program after July 1, 2017, unless the department reports to the Executive Appropriations Committee, in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(4)(a): The department shall enter into new Nursing Care Facility Non-State Government-Owned Upper Payment Limit program contracts and contract amendments adding new nursing care facilities and new non-state government entity operators in accordance with this Subsection (4).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(4)(b)(i): If the nursing care facility expects to receive less than $1,000,000 in federal funds each year from the Nursing Care Facility Non-State Government-Owned Upper Payment Limit program, excluding seed funding and administrative fees paid by the non-state government entity, the department shall enter into a Nursing Care Facility Non-State Government-Owned Upper Payment Limit program contract with the non-state government entity operator of the nursing care facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(4)(b)(ii): If the nursing care facility expects to receive between $1,000,000 and $10,000,000 in federal funds each year from the Nursing Care Facility Non-State Government-Owned Upper Payment Limit program, excluding seed funding and administrative fees paid by the non-state government entity, the department shall enter into a Nursing Care Facility Non-State Government-Owned Upper Payment Limit program contract with the non-state government entity operator of the nursing care facility after receiving the approval of the Executive Appropriations Committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(4)(b)(iii): If the nursing care facility expects to receive more than $10,000,000 in federal funds each year from the Nursing Care Facility Non-State Government-Owned Upper Payment Limit program, excluding seed funding and administrative fees paid by the non-state government entity, the department may not approve the application without obtaining approval from the Legislature and the governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(4)(c): A non-state government entity may not participate in the Nursing Care Facility Non-State Government-Owned Upper Payment Limit program unless the non-state government entity is a special service district, county, or city that operates a hospital or holds a license under Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(4)(d)(iii)(A): for each nursing care facility, available for patient care until the end of the non-state government entity's fiscal year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(4)(d)(iii)(B): used exclusively for operating expenses for nursing care facility operations, patient care, capital expenses, rent, royalties, and other operating expenses; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(4)(d)(iv): the non-state government entity has completed all licensing, enrollment, and other forms and documents required by federal and state law to register a change of ownership with the department and with CMS.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(5): The department shall add a nursing care facility to an existing Nursing Care Facility Non-State Government-Owned Upper Payment Limit program contract if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(5)(a): the nursing care facility is managed by or affiliated with the same non-state government entity that also manages one or more nursing care facilities that are included in an existing Nursing Care Facility Non-State Government-Owned Upper Payment Limit program contract; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(5)(b): the non-state government entity makes the certification described in Subsection (4)(d)(ii).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(6): The department may not increase the percentage of the administrative fee paid by a non-state government entity to the department under the Nursing Care Facility Non-State Government-Owned Upper Payment Limit program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(7): The department may not condition participation in the Nursing Care Facility Non-State Government-Owned Upper Payment Limit program on:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(7)(a): a requirement that the department be allowed to direct or determine the types of patients that a non-state government entity will treat or the course of treatment for a patient in a non-state government nursing care facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(7)(b): a requirement that a non-state government entity or nursing care facility post a bond, purchase insurance, or create a reserve account of any kind.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-130(8): The non-state government entity shall have the primary responsibility for ensuring compliance with Subsection (4)(d)(ii).

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-133 Reimbursement for long-acting reversible contraception immediately following childbirth.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-133(1): As used in this section, "long-acting reversible contraception" means a contraception method that requires administration less than once per month, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-133(1)(a): an intrauterine device; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-133(1)(b): a contraceptive implant.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-133(2): The division shall separately identify and reimburse, from other labor and delivery services within the Medicaid program, the provision and insertion of long-acting reversible contraception immediately after childbirth.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-134 Coverage of exome sequence testing.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-134(1): As used in this section, "exome sequence testing" means a genomic technique for sequencing the genome of an individual for diagnostic purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-134(2): The Medicaid program shall reimburse for exome sequence testing:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-134(2)(a): for an enrollee who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-134(2)(a)(i): is younger than 21 years old; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-134(2)(a)(ii): who remains undiagnosed after exhausting all other appropriate diagnostic-related tests;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-134(2)(b): performed by a nationally recognized provider with significant experience in exome sequence testing;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-134(2)(c): that is medically necessary; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-134(2)(d): at a rate set by the Medicaid program.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-136(2): 26B-3-124; 26B-3-901

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-136(2)(b)(i): 26B-3-124 promote health insurance coverage for children in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-136(2)(b)(ii): conduct research regarding families who are eligible for Medicaid and CHIP to determine awareness and understanding of available coverage;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-136(2)(b)(iv)(B): any barriers during the application process;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-136(2)(b)(v): develop promotional material regarding CHIP and children's Medicaid eligibility, including outreach through social media, video production, and other media platforms;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-136(2)(b)(vi): identify ways that the eligibility website for enrollment in CHIP and children's Medicaid can be redesigned to increase accessibility and enhance the user experience;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-136(2)(b)(vii): identify outreach opportunities, including partnerships with community organizations including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-136(2)(b)(vii)(A): schools;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-136(2)(b)(vii)(B): small businesses;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-136(2)(b)(vii)(C): unemployment centers;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-136(2)(b)(vii)(D): parent-teacher associations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-136(2)(b)(vii)(E): youth athlete clubs and associations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-136(2)(b)(viii): develop messaging to increase awareness of coverage options that are available through the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-136(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-136(3)(a): The department may not delegate implementation of the program to a private entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-136(3)(b): Notwithstanding Subsection (3)(a), the department may contract with a media agency to conduct the activities described in Subsection (2)(b)(iv) and (vii).


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-137 Reimbursement for diabetes prevention program.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-137(1): As used in this section, "DPP" means the National Diabetes Prevention Program developed by the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-137(2): Beginning July 1, 2022, the Medicaid program shall reimburse a provider for an enrollee's participation in the DPP if the enrollee:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-137(2)(a): meets the DPP's eligibility requirements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-137(2)(b): has not previously participated in the DPP after July 1, 2022, while enrolled in the Medicaid program.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-137(4): The department may apply for a state plan amendment if necessary to implement this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-137(5): (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-137(5)(a): On or after July 1, 2025, but before October 1, 2025, the department shall provide a written report regarding the efficacy of the DPP and reimbursement under this section to the Health and Human Services Interim Committee.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-137(5)(b)(i): the total number of enrollees with a prediabetic condition as of July 1, 2022;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-137(5)(b)(ii): the total number of enrollees as of July 1, 2022, with a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-137(5)(b)(iii): the total number of enrollees who participated in the DPP;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-137(5)(b)(iv): the total cost incurred by the state to implement this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-137(5)(b)(v): any conclusions that can be drawn regarding the impact of the DPP on the rate of type 2 diabetes for enrollees.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140 Medical assistance accountability -- Division duties -- Reporting.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(1)(a): "Abuse" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(1)(a)(i): an action or practice that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(1)(a)(i)(A): is inconsistent with sound fiscal, business, or medical practices; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(1)(a)(i)(B): results, or may result, in unnecessary Medicaid related costs or other medical or hospital assistance costs; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(1)(a)(ii): reckless or negligent upcoding.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(1)(b): "Fraud" means intentional or knowing:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(1)(b)(i): deception, misrepresentation, or upcoding in relation to Medicaid funds, costs, claims, reimbursement, or practice; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(1)(b)(ii): deception or misrepresentation in relation to medical or hospital assistance funds, costs, claims, reimbursement, or practice.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(1)(c): "Upcoding" means assigning an inaccurate billing code for a service that is payable or reimbursable by Medicaid funds, if the correct billing code for the service, taking into account reasonable opinions derived from official published coding definitions, would result in a lower Medicaid payment or reimbursement.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(1)(d): "Waste" means overutilization of resources or inappropriate payment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(2): (2)(c) The division shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(2)(a): develop and implement procedures relating to Medicaid funds and medical or hospital assistance funds to ensure that providers do not receive:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(2)(a)(i): duplicate payments for the same goods or services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(2)(a)(ii): payment for goods or services by resubmitting a claim for which:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(2)(a)(ii)(A): payment has been disallowed on the grounds that payment would be a violation of federal or state law, administrative rule, or the state plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(2)(a)(ii)(B): the decision to disallow the payment has become final;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(2)(a)(iii): payment for goods or services provided after a recipient's death, including payment for pharmaceuticals or long-term care; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(2)(a)(iv): payment for transporting an unborn infant;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(2)(b): consult with CMS, other states, and the Office of Inspector General of Medicaid Services to determine and implement best practices for discovering and eliminating fraud, waste, and abuse of Medicaid funds and medical or hospital assistance funds;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(2)(c): actively seek repayment from providers for improperly used or paid:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(2)(c)(i): Medicaid funds; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(2)(c)(ii): medical or hospital assistance funds;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(2)(d): (2)(c) coordinate, track, and keep records of all division efforts to obtain repayment of the funds described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(2)(e): keep Medicaid pharmaceutical costs as low as possible by actively seeking to obtain pharmaceuticals at the lowest price possible, including, on a quarterly basis for the pharmaceuticals that represent the highest 45% of state Medicaid expenditures for pharmaceuticals and on an annual basis for the remaining pharmaceuticals:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(2)(e)(i): tracking changes in the price of pharmaceuticals;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(2)(e)(ii): checking the availability and price of generic drugs;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(2)(e)(iii): reviewing and updating the state's maximum allowable cost list; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(2)(e)(iv): comparing pharmaceutical costs of the state Medicaid program to available pharmacy price lists; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-140(2)(f): provide training, on an annual basis, to the employees of the division who make decisions on billing codes, or who are in the best position to observe and identify upcoding, in order to avoid and detect upcoding.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-141 Medical assistance from division or Department of Workforce Services and compliance under adoption assistance interstate compact -- Penalty for fraudulent claim.
