Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-201 Independent foster care adolescents.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-201(1): As used in this section, an "independent foster care adolescent" includes any individual who reached 18 years old while in the custody of the department if the department was the primary case manager, or a federally recognized Indian tribe.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-201(2): An independent foster care adolescent is eligible, when funds are available, for Medicaid coverage until the individual reaches 21 years old.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-202 Waivers to maximize replacement of fee-for-service delivery model -- Cost of mandated program changes.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-202(1): The department shall develop a waiver program in the Medicaid program to replace the fee-for-service delivery model with one or more risk-based delivery models.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-202(2): (4) The waiver program shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-202(2)(a): restructure the program's provider payment provisions to reward health care providers for delivering the most appropriate services at the lowest cost and in ways that, compared to services delivered before implementation of the waiver program, maintain or improve recipient health status;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-202(2)(b): restructure the program's cost sharing provisions and other incentives to reward recipients for personal efforts to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-202(2)(b)(i): maintain or improve their health status; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-202(2)(b)(ii): use providers that deliver the most appropriate services at the lowest cost;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-202(2)(c): identify the evidence-based practices and measures, risk adjustment methodologies, payment systems, funding sources, and other mechanisms necessary to reward providers for delivering the most appropriate services at the lowest cost, including mechanisms that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-202(2)(c)(i): pay providers for packages of services delivered over entire episodes of illness rather than for individual services delivered during each patient encounter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-202(2)(c)(ii): reward providers for delivering services that make the most positive contribution to a recipient's health status;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-202(2)(d): limit total annual per-patient-per-month expenditures for services delivered through fee-for-service arrangements to total annual per-patient-per-month expenditures for services delivered through risk-based arrangements covering similar recipient populations and services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-202(2)(e): (4) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-202(3): To the extent possible, the department shall operate the waiver program with the input of stakeholder groups representing those who will be affected by the waiver program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-202(4): (4); (2)(e)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-202(4)(a): (4) For purposes of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-202(4)(b): A mandated program change shall be included in the base budget for the Medicaid program for the fiscal year in which the Medicaid program adopted the mandated program change.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-202(4)(c): (2)(e) The mandated program change is not subject to the limit on the rate of growth in per-patient-per-month General Fund expenditures for the program established in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-202(5): A managed care organization or a pharmacy benefit manager that provides a pharmacy benefit to an enrollee shall establish a unique group number, payment classification number, or bank identification number for each Medicaid managed care organization plan for which the managed care organization or pharmacy benefit manager provides a pharmacy benefit.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-209 Medicaid long-term support services housing coordinator.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-209(1): There is created within the Medicaid program a full-time-equivalent position of Medicaid long-term support services housing coordinator.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-209(2): The coordinator shall help Medicaid recipients receive long-term support services in a home or other community-based setting rather than in a nursing home or other institutional setting by:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-209(2)(a): working with municipalities, counties, the Housing and Community Development Division within the Department of Workforce Services, and others to identify community-based settings available to recipients;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-209(2)(b): working with the same entities to promote the development, construction, and availability of additional community-based settings;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-209(2)(c): training Medicaid case managers and support coordinators on how to help Medicaid recipients move from an institutional setting to a community-based setting; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-209(2)(d): performing other related duties.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210 Medicaid waiver expansion.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(1): 26B-3-207 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(1)(a): 26B-3-207 "Federal poverty level" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(1)(b): "Medicaid waiver expansion" means an expansion of the Medicaid program in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(2)(a): Before January 1, 2019, the department shall apply to CMS for approval of a waiver or state plan amendment to implement the Medicaid waiver expansion.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(2)(b): The Medicaid waiver expansion shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(2)(b)(i): expand Medicaid coverage to eligible individuals whose income is below 95% of the federal poverty level;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(2)(b)(ii): obtain maximum federal financial participation under 42 U.S.C. Sec. 1396d(y) for enrolling an individual in the Medicaid program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(2)(b)(iii): provide Medicaid benefits through the state's Medicaid accountable care organizations in areas where a Medicaid accountable care organization is implemented;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(2)(b)(iv): integrate the delivery of behavioral health services and physical health services with Medicaid accountable care organizations in select geographic areas of the state that choose an integrated model;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(2)(b)(v): include a path to self-sufficiency, including work activities as defined in 42 U.S.C. Sec. 607(d), for qualified adults;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(2)(b)(vi): require an individual who is offered a private health benefit plan by an employer to enroll in the employer's health plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(2)(b)(vii): sunset in accordance with Subsection (5)(a); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(2)(b)(viii): permit the state to close enrollment in the Medicaid waiver expansion if the department has insufficient funding to provide services to additional eligible individuals.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(3): 26B-1-315 If the Medicaid waiver described in Subsection (2)(a) is approved, the department may only pay the state portion of costs for the Medicaid waiver expansion with appropriations from:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(3)(a): 26B-1-315 the Medicaid ACA Fund, created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(3)(b): county contributions to the non-federal share of Medicaid expenditures; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(3)(c): any other contributions, funds, or transfers from a non-state agency for Medicaid expenditures.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(4)(a): In consultation with the department, Medicaid accountable care organizations and counties that elect to integrate care under Subsection (2)(b)(iv) shall collaborate on enrollment, engagement of patients, and coordination of services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(4)(b): As part of the provision described in Subsection (2)(b)(iv), the department shall apply for a waiver to permit the creation of an integrated delivery system:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(4)(b)(i): for any geographic area that expresses interest in integrating the delivery of services under Subsection (2)(b)(iv); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(4)(b)(ii): in which the department:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(4)(b)(ii)(A): may permit a local mental health authority to integrate the delivery of behavioral health services and physical health services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(4)(b)(ii)(B): may permit a county, local mental health authority, or Medicaid accountable care organization to integrate the delivery of behavioral health services and physical health services to select groups within the population that are newly eligible under the Medicaid waiver expansion; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(4)(b)(ii)(C): may make rules in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to integrate payments for behavioral health services and physical health services to plans or providers.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(5)(a): If federal financial participation for the Medicaid waiver expansion is reduced below 90%, the authority of the department to implement the Medicaid waiver expansion shall sunset no later than the next July 1 after the date on which the federal financial participation is reduced.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-210(5)(b): The department shall close the program to new enrollment if the cost of the Medicaid waiver expansion is projected to exceed the appropriations for the fiscal year that are authorized by the Legislature through an appropriations act adopted in accordance with Title 63J, Chapter 1, Budgetary Procedures Act.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211 Primary Care Network enhancement waiver program.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(1): 26B-3-207; 26B-3-108 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(1)(a): "Enhancement waiver program" means the Primary Care Network enhancement waiver program described in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(1)(b): "Federal poverty level" means the poverty guidelines established by the secretary of the United States Department of Health and Human Services under 42 U.S.C. Sec. 9902(2).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(1)(c): 26B-3-207 "Health coverage improvement program" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(1)(d): "Income eligibility ceiling" means the percentage of federal poverty level:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(1)(d)(i): established by the Legislature in an appropriations act adopted pursuant to Title 63J, Chapter 1, Budgetary Procedures Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(1)(d)(ii): under which an individual may qualify for coverage in the enhancement waiver program in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(1)(e): "Optional population" means the optional expansion population under PPACA if the expansion provides coverage for individuals at or above 95% of the federal poverty level.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(1)(f): 26B-3-108 "Primary Care Network" means the state Primary Care Network program created by the Medicaid primary care network demonstration waiver obtained under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(2): The department shall continue to implement the Primary Care Network program for qualified individuals under the Primary Care Network program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(3): 26B-3-210; 26B-3-210; 26B-3-210
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(3)(a): 26B-3-210; 26B-3-210 The division shall apply for a Medicaid waiver or a state plan amendment with CMS to implement, within the state Medicaid program, the enhancement waiver program described in this section within six months after the day on which:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(3)(a)(i): 26B-3-210 the division receives a notice from CMS that the waiver for the Medicaid waiver expansion submitted under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(3)(a)(ii): 26B-3-210 the division withdraws the waiver for the Medicaid waiver expansion submitted under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(3)(b): 26B-3-210 The division may not apply for a waiver under Subsection (3)(a) while a waiver request under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(4): An individual who is eligible for the enhancement waiver program may receive the following benefits under the enhancement waiver program:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(4)(a): the benefits offered under the Primary Care Network program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(4)(b): diagnostic testing and procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(4)(c): medical specialty care;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(4)(d): inpatient hospital services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(4)(e): outpatient hospital services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(4)(f): outpatient behavioral health care, including outpatient substance use care; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(4)(g): for an individual who qualifies for the health coverage improvement program, as approved by CMS, temporary residential treatment for substance use in a short term, non-institutional, 24-hour facility, without a bed capacity limit, that provides rehabilitation services that are medically necessary and in accordance with an individualized treatment plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(5): An individual is eligible for the enhancement waiver program if, at the time of enrollment:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(5)(a): the individual is qualified to enroll in the Primary Care Network or the health coverage improvement program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(5)(b): the individual's annual income is below the income eligibility ceiling established by the Legislature under Subsection (1)(d); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(5)(c): the individual meets the eligibility criteria established by the department under Subsection (6).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(6): 26B-3-207; 26B-3-207; 26B-1-315
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(6)(a): 26B-3-207; 26B-3-207 Based on available funding and approval from CMS, the department shall determine the criteria for an individual to qualify for the enhancement waiver program, based on the following priority:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(6)(a)(i): 26B-3-207 adults in the expansion population, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(6)(a)(ii): 26B-3-207 adults with dependent children who qualify for the health coverage improvement program  under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(6)(a)(iii): adults with dependent children who do not qualify for the health coverage improvement program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(6)(a)(iv): if funding is available, adults without dependent children.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(6)(b): The number of individuals enrolled in the enhancement waiver program may not exceed 105% of the number of individuals who were enrolled in the Primary Care Network on December 31, 2017.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(6)(c): 26B-1-315 The department may only use appropriations from the Medicaid ACA Fund created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(7): The department may request a modification of the income eligibility ceiling and the eligibility criteria under Subsection (6) from CMS each fiscal year based on enrollment in the enhancement waiver program, projected enrollment in the enhancement waiver program, costs to the state, and the state budget.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(8): The department may implement the enhancement waiver program by contracting with Medicaid accountable care organizations to administer the enhancement waiver program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(9): 26B-3-207 In accordance with Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(10): If the department expands the state Medicaid program to the optional population, the department:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(10)(a): except as provided in Subsection (11), may not accept any new enrollees into the enhancement waiver program after the day on which the expansion  to the optional population  is effective;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(10)(b): shall suspend the enhancement waiver program within one year after the day on which the expansion  to the optional population  is effective; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(10)(c): shall work with CMS to maintain the waiver for the enhancement waiver program submitted under Subsection (3) while the enhancement waiver program is suspended under Subsection (10)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-211(11): If, after the expansion to the optional population described in Subsection (10) takes effect, the expansion to the optional population is repealed by either the state or the federal government, the department shall reinstate the enhancement waiver program and continue to accept new enrollees into the enhancement waiver program in accordance with the provisions of this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-212 Limited family planning services for low-income individuals.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-212(1): 76-7-301; 76-7a-101 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-212(1)(a): 76-7-301; 76-7a-101
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-212(1)(a)(i): "Family planning services" means family planning services that are provided under the state Medicaid program, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-212(1)(a)(i)(A): sexual health education and family planning counseling; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-212(1)(a)(i)(B): other medical diagnosis, treatment, or preventative care routinely provided as part of a family planning service visit.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-212(1)(a)(ii): 76-7-301; 76-7a-101 "Family planning services" do not include an abortion, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-212(1)(b): "Low-income individual" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-212(1)(b)(i): has an income level that is equal to or below 185% of the federal poverty level; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-212(1)(b)(ii): does not qualify for full coverage under the Medicaid program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-212(2): Before January 1, 2024, the division shall apply for a Medicaid waiver or a state plan amendment with CMS to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-212(2)(a): offer a program that provides family planning services to low-income individuals; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-212(2)(b): receive a federal match rate of 90% of state expenditures for family planning services provided under the waiver or state plan amendment.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-213 Medicaid waiver for mental health crisis lines and mobile crisis outreach teams.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-213(1): 26B-5-610; 58-60-102; 26B-5-610 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-213(1)(a): 26B-5-610 "Local mental health crisis line" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-213(1)(b): "Mental health crisis" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-213(1)(b)(i): a mental health condition that manifests itself in an individual by symptoms of sufficient severity that a prudent layperson who possesses an average knowledge of mental health issues could reasonably expect the absence of immediate attention or intervention to result in:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-213(1)(b)(i)(A): serious danger to the individual's health or well-being; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-213(1)(b)(i)(B): a danger to the health or well-being of others; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-213(1)(b)(ii): a mental health condition that, in the opinion of a mental health therapist or the therapist's designee, requires direct professional observation or the intervention of a mental health therapist.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-213(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-213(1)(c)(i): "Mental health crisis services" means direct mental health services and on-site intervention that a mobile crisis outreach team provides to an individual suffering from a mental health crisis, including the provision of safety and care plans, prolonged mental health services for up to 90 days, and referrals to other community resources.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-213(1)(c)(ii): "Mental health crisis services" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-213(1)(c)(ii)(A): local mental health crisis lines; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-213(1)(c)(ii)(B): the statewide mental health crisis line.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-213(1)(d): 58-60-102 "Mental health therapist" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-213(1)(e): "Mobile crisis outreach team" or "MCOT" means a mobile team of medical and mental health professionals that, in coordination with local law enforcement and emergency medical service personnel, provides mental health crisis services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-213(1)(f): 26B-5-610 "Statewide mental health crisis line" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-213(2): 63C-18-202
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-213(2)(a): The department shall develop a proposal to amend the state Medicaid plan to include mental health crisis services, including the statewide mental health crisis line, local mental health crisis lines, and mobile crisis outreach teams.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-213(2)(b): 63C-18-202 The department shall develop the proposal described in Subsection (2)(a) in consultation with the Behavioral Health Crisis Response Committee created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-213(3): By January 1, 2019, the department shall apply for a Medicaid waiver with CMS, if necessary to implement, within the state Medicaid program, the mental health crisis services described in Subsection (2).

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-215 Coverage for in vitro fertilization and genetic testing.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-215(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-215(1)(a): "Qualified condition" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-215(1)(a)(i): cystic fibrosis;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-215(1)(a)(ii): spinal muscular atrophy;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-215(1)(a)(iii): Morquio Syndrome;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-215(1)(a)(iv): myotonic dystrophy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-215(1)(a)(v): sickle cell anemia.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-215(1)(b): "Qualified enrollee" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-215(1)(b)(i): is enrolled in the Medicaid program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-215(1)(b)(ii): has been diagnosed by a physician as having a genetic trait associated with a qualified condition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-215(1)(b)(iii): intends to get pregnant with a partner who is diagnosed by a physician as having a genetic trait associated with the same qualified condition as the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-215(2): (3) Before January 1, 2021, the department shall apply for a Medicaid waiver or a state plan amendment with the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services within the United States Department of Health and Human Services to implement the coverage described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217 Medicaid waiver for coverage of qualified inmates leaving prison or jail.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(1): 64-13-1 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(1)(a): 64-13-1 "Correctional facility" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(1)(a)(i): a county jail;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(1)(a)(ii): 64-13-1 a prison, penitentiary, or other institution operated by or under contract with the Department of Corrections for the confinement of an offender, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(1)(a)(iii): a facility for secure confinement of minors operated by the Division of Juvenile Justice and Youth Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(1)(b): "Limited Medicaid benefit" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(1)(b)(i): reentry case management services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(1)(b)(ii): physical and behavioral health clinical services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(1)(b)(iii): medications and medication administration;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(1)(b)(iv): medication-assisted treatment, including all United States Food and Drug Administration approved medications, including coverage for counseling; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(1)(b)(v): other services as determined by rule made in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(1)(c): "Qualified inmate" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(1)(c)(i): is incarcerated in a correctional facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(1)(c)(ii): is ineligible for Medicaid as a result of incarceration but would otherwise qualify for Medicaid.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(2): Subject to appropriation, before July 1, 2024, the division shall apply for a Medicaid waiver, or amend an existing Medicaid waiver application, with CMS to offer a program to provide a limited Medicaid benefit to a qualified inmate for up to 90 days immediately before the day on which the qualified inmate is released from a correctional facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(3)(a): Savings to state and local funds that result from the use of federal funds provided under this section shall be used in accordance with a reinvestment plan as mandated by CMS.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(3)(b): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the department shall make rules for a participating county to establish a reinvestment plan described in Subsection (3)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(4): If the waiver or amended waiver described in Subsection (2) is approved, the department shall report to the Health and Human Services Interim Committee each year before November 30 while the waiver is in effect regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(4)(a): the number of qualified inmates served under the program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(4)(b): the cost of the program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(4)(c): the effectiveness of the program, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(4)(c)(i): any reduction in the number of emergency room visits or hospitalizations by inmates after release from a correctional facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(4)(c)(ii): any reduction in the number of inmates undergoing inpatient treatment after release from a correctional facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(4)(c)(iii): any reduction in overdose rates and deaths of inmates after release from a correctional facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(4)(c)(iv): any other costs or benefits as a result of the program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(5): Before July 1, 2024, the department shall amend the Medicaid waiver related to housing support services to include an individual that was a qualified inmate within the previous 12 months.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-217(6): The department may elect to not apply for a Medicaid waiver or limit services described in this section based on appropriation.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-222 Medicaid waiver expansion for extraordinary care reimbursement.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-222(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-222(1)(a): "Existing home and community-based services waiver" means an existing home and community-based services waiver in the state that serves an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-222(1)(a)(i): with an acquired brain injury;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-222(1)(a)(ii): with an intellectual or physical disability; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-222(1)(a)(iii): who is 65 years old or older.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-222(1)(b): "Guardian" means a person appointed by a court to manage the affairs of a living individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-222(1)(c): "Parent" means a biological parent, adoptive parent, or step-parent of an individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-222(1)(d): "Personal care services" means a service that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-222(1)(d)(i): is furnished to an individual who is not an inpatient nor a resident of a hospital, nursing facility, intermediate care facility, or institution for mental diseases;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-222(1)(d)(ii): is authorized for an individual described in Subsection (1)(d)(i) in accordance with a plan of treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-222(1)(d)(iii): is provided by an individual who is qualified to provide the services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-222(1)(d)(iv): is furnished in a home or another community-based setting.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-222(1)(e): "Waiver enrollee" means an individual who is enrolled in an existing home and community-based services waiver.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-222(2): Before July 1, 2021, the department shall apply with CMS for an amendment to an existing home and community-based services waiver to implement a program to offer reimbursement to an individual who provides personal care services that constitute extraordinary care to a waiver enrollee who is the individual's spouse.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-222(3): If CMS approves the amendment described in Subsection (2), the department shall implement the program described in Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-222(4): The department shall by rule, made in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, define "extraordinary care" for purposes of Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-222(5): Before July 1, 2023, the department shall apply with CMS for an amendment to an existing home and community-based services waiver to implement a program to offer reimbursement to an individual who provides personal care services that constitute extraordinary care to a waiver enrollee to whom the individual is a parent or guardian.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-222(6): If CMS approves the amendment described in Subsection (5), the department shall implement the program described in Subsection (5).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-222(7): The department shall by rule, made in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, define "extraordinary care" for purposes of Subsection (5).

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-223(5)(e): timely resolve any disputes between a provider or enrollee with the managed care plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-223(6): The department may take corrective action if the managed care organization fails to comply with the terms of the managed care organization's contract.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225 Coverage for autism spectrum disorder.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1): Title 58, Occupations and Professions; (1)(d); (1)(c)(ii) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(a)(i): "Applied behavior analysis" means the design, implementation, and evaluation of environmental modifications, using behavioral stimuli and consequences, to produce socially significant improvement in human behavior.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(a)(ii): "Applied behavior analysis" includes the use of direct observation, measurement, and functional analysis of the relationship between environment and behavior.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(b): "Autism spectrum disorder" means pervasive developmental disorders as defined by the most recent edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(c): Title 58, Occupations and Professions "Behavioral health treatment" means counseling and treatment programs, including applied behavior analysis, that are:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(c)(i): necessary to develop, maintain, or restore, to the maximum extent practicable, the functioning of an individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(c)(ii): Title 58, Occupations and Professions provided or supervised by:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(c)(ii)(A): a board certified behavior analyst; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(c)(ii)(B): Title 58, Occupations and Professions an individual licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(d): "Diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder" means medically necessary assessments, evaluations, or tests:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(d)(i): performed by:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(d)(i)(A): a licensed physician who is board certified in neurology, psychiatry, or pediatrics and has experience diagnosing autism spectrum disorder; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(d)(i)(B): a licensed psychologist with experience diagnosing autism spectrum disorder; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(d)(ii): necessary to diagnose whether an individual has an autism spectrum disorder.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(e): "Pharmacy care" means medications prescribed by a licensed physician and any health-related services considered medically necessary to determine the need or effectiveness of the medications.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(f): "Psychiatric care" means direct or consultative services provided by a psychiatrist licensed in the state in which the psychiatrist practices.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(g): "Psychological care" means direct or consultative services provided by a psychologist licensed in the state in which the psychologist practices.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(h): "Therapeutic care" means services provided by a licensed or certified speech therapist, occupational therapist, or physical therapist.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(i): (1)(d); (1)(c)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(i)(i): (1)(d) "Treatment for autism spectrum disorder" means evidence-based care and related equipment prescribed or ordered for an enrollee diagnosed with an autism spectrum disorder by a physician or a licensed psychologist described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(i)(ii): (1)(c)(ii) "Treatment for autism spectrum disorder" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(i)(ii)(A): (1)(c)(ii) behavioral health treatment, provided or supervised by a person described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(i)(ii)(B): pharmacy care;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(i)(ii)(C): psychiatric care;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(i)(ii)(D): psychological care; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(1)(i)(ii)(E): therapeutic care.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-225(2): The department shall request a state plan amendment with CMS to provide treatment for autism spectrum disorder for an enrollee diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226 Medicaid waiver for rural healthcare for chronic conditions.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(1)(a): "Qualified condition" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(1)(a)(i): diabetes;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(1)(a)(ii): high blood pressure;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(1)(a)(iii): congestive heart failure;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(1)(a)(iv): asthma;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(1)(a)(v): obesity;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(1)(a)(vi): chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(1)(a)(vii): chronic kidney disease.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(1)(b): "Qualified enrollee" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(1)(b)(i): is enrolled in the Medicaid program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(1)(b)(ii): has been diagnosed as having a qualified condition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(1)(b)(iii): is not enrolled in an accountable care organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(2): Before January 1, 2024, the department shall apply for a Medicaid waiver with CMS to implement the coverage described in Subsection (3) for a three-year pilot program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(3): If the waiver described in Subsection (2) is approved, the Medicaid program shall contract with a single entity to provide coordinated care for the following services to each qualified enrollee:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(3)(a): a telemedicine platform for the qualified enrollee to use;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(3)(b): an in-home initial visit to the qualified enrollee;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(3)(c): daily remote monitoring of the qualified enrollee's qualified condition;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(3)(d): all services in the qualified enrollee's language of choice;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(3)(e): individual peer monitoring and coaching for the qualified enrollee;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(3)(f): available access for the qualified enrollee to video-enabled consults and voice-enabled consults 24 hours a day, seven days a week;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(3)(g): in-home biometric monitoring devices to monitor the qualified enrollee's qualified condition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(3)(h): at-home medication delivery to the qualified enrollee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(4): The Medicaid program may not provide the coverage described in Subsection (3) until the waiver is approved.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(5): Each year the waiver is active, the department shall submit a report to the Health and Human Services Interim Committee before November 30 detailing:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(5)(a): the number of patients served under the waiver;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(5)(b): the cost of the waiver; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(5)(c): any benefits of the waiver, including an estimate of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(5)(c)(i): the reductions in emergency room visits or hospitalizations;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(5)(c)(ii): the reductions in 30-day hospital readmissions for the same diagnosis;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(5)(c)(iii): the reductions in complications related to qualified conditions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-226(5)(c)(iv): any improvements in health outcomes from baseline assessments.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-228 Medicaid coverage for certain postpartum women.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-228(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-228(1)(a): "Extended postpartum period" means the period after a woman's pregnancy ends:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-228(1)(a)(i): beginning the day after the initial postpartum period; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-228(1)(a)(ii): ending on the last day of the month that is 12 months after the day on which the woman's pregnancy ends.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-228(1)(b): "Initial postpartum period" means the period:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-228(1)(b)(i): beginning on the day on which a woman's pregnancy ends; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-228(1)(b)(ii): ending on the last day of the month that is 60 days after the day on which the woman's pregnancy ends.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-228(1)(c): "Miscarriage" means the spontaneous or accidental loss of a fetus, regardless of gestational age or the duration of the pregnancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-228(2): 76-7a-201 Before July 1, 2023, the division shall request a waiver or state plan amendment to, in accordance with 42 U.S.C. Sec. 1396a(e)(16), provide continuous Medicaid coverage during the woman's extended postpartum period if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-228(2)(a): the woman is eligible for Medicaid during the woman's pregnancy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-228(2)(b): 76-7a-201 the woman's pregnancy ended by way of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-228(2)(b)(i): birth;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-228(2)(b)(ii): miscarriage;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-228(2)(b)(iii): stillbirth; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-228(2)(b)(iv): 76-7a-201 an abortion that is permitted under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-230 Traditional healing services waiver.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-230(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-230(1)(a): "Eligible facility" means any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-230(1)(a)(i): an Indian Health Service facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-230(1)(a)(ii): a tribal health program designated under the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act, Pub. L. No. 93-638;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-230(1)(a)(iii): an urban Indian organization as that term is defined in 25 U.S.C. Sec. 1603; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-230(1)(a)(iv): a facility operated by a person that contracts with an organization described in Subsection (1)(a)(iii).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-230(1)(b): "Traditional healing provider" means an individual who provides traditional healing services in a manner that is recognized by an American Indian or Alaskan Native tribe as being consistent with the tribe's traditional healing practices.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-230(1)(c): "Traditional healing services" means a system of culturally appropriate healing methods for physical, mental, and emotional healing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-230(2): On or before January 1, 2025, the department shall apply for a Medicaid waiver to reimburse for traditional healing services provided by a traditional healing provider in an eligible facility to an enrollee who is a member of an American Indian or Alaskan Native tribe.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-230(3): A service under this section may not be reimbursed if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-230(3)(a): the traditional healing provider is restricted from providing the service;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-230(3)(b): the service is contraindicated by a medical provider due to the potential to cause harm; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-230(3)(c): the service is not part of the patient's plan of care.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-230(4): The department may further define and limit services described in this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(1): "Appropriate and medically necessary" means, regarding drug prescribing, dispensing, and patient usage, that it is in conformity with the criteria and standards developed in accordance with this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(2): 26B-3-302 "Board" means the Drug Utilization Review Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(3): "Certified program" means a nursing care facility program with Medicaid certification.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(4): "Compendia" means resources widely accepted by the medical profession in the efficacious use of drugs, including "American Hospital Formulary Service Drug Information," "U.S. Pharmacopeia - Drug Information," "A.M.A. Drug Evaluations," peer-reviewed medical literature, and information provided by manufacturers of drug products.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(5): "Counseling" means the activities conducted by a pharmacist to inform Medicaid recipients about the proper use of drugs, as required by the board under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(6): "Criteria" means those predetermined and explicitly accepted elements used to measure drug use on an ongoing basis in order to determine if the use is appropriate, medically necessary, and not likely to result in adverse medical outcomes.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(7): "Drug-disease contraindications" means that the therapeutic effect of a drug is adversely altered by the presence of another disease condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(8): "Drug-interactions" means that two or more drugs taken by a recipient lead to clinically significant toxicity that is characteristic of one or any of the drugs present, or that leads to interference with the effectiveness of one or any of the drugs.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(9): "Drug Utilization Review" or "DUR" means the program designed to measure and assess, on a retrospective and prospective basis, the proper use of outpatient drugs in the Medicaid program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(10): "Intervention" means a form of communication utilized by the board with a prescriber or pharmacist to inform about or influence prescribing or dispensing practices.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(11): "Medicaid certification" means the right of a nursing care facility, as a provider of a nursing care facility program, to receive Medicaid reimbursement for a specified number of beds within the facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(12): Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(12)(a): Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection "Nursing care facility" means the following facilities licensed by the department under
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(12)(a)(i): skilled nursing facilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(12)(a)(ii): intermediate care facilities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(12)(a)(iii): an intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(12)(b): "Nursing care facility" does not mean a critical access hospital that meets the criteria of 42 U.S.C. Sec. 1395i-4(c)(2) (1998).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(13): "Nursing care facility program" means the personnel, licenses, services, contracts, and all other requirements that shall be met for a nursing care facility to be eligible for Medicaid certification under this part and division rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(14): "Overutilization" or "underutilization" means the use of a drug in such quantities that the desired therapeutic goal is not achieved.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(15): Title 58, Chapter 17b, Pharmacy Practice Act "Pharmacist" means a person licensed in this state to engage in the practice of pharmacy under
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(16): "Physical facility" means the buildings or other physical structures where a nursing care facility program is operated.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(17): 58-67-301; 58-68-301 "Physician" means a person licensed in this state to practice medicine and surgery under  Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(18): "Prospective DUR" means that part of the drug utilization review program that occurs before a drug is dispensed, and that is designed to screen for potential drug therapy problems based on explicit and predetermined criteria and standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(19): "Retrospective DUR" means that part of the drug utilization review program that assesses or measures drug use based on an historical review of drug use data against predetermined and explicit criteria and standards, on an ongoing basis with professional input.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(20): (20)(a) "Rural county" means a county with a population of less than 50,000, as determined by:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(20)(a): the most recent official census or census estimate of the United States Bureau of the Census; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(20)(b): (20)(a) the most recent population estimate for the county from the Utah Population Committee, if a population figure for the county is not available under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(21): "Service area" means the boundaries of the distinct geographic area served by a certified program as determined by the division in accordance with this part and division rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(22): "Standards" means the acceptable range of deviation from the criteria that reflects local medical practice and that is tested on the Medicaid recipient database.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(23): "SURS" means the Surveillance Utilization Review System of the Medicaid program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(24): "Therapeutic appropriateness" means drug prescribing and dispensing based on rational drug therapy that is consistent with criteria and standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(25): "Therapeutic duplication" means prescribing and dispensing the same drug or two or more drugs from the same therapeutic class where periods of drug administration overlap and where that practice is not medically indicated.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-301(26): "Urban county" means a county that is not a rural county.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302 DUR Board -- Creation and membership -- Expenses.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(1): There is created a 12-member Drug Utilization Review Board responsible for implementation of a retrospective and prospective DUR program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(2): (2)(b); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(2)(a): (2)(b) Except as required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(2)(b): (2)(a) Notwithstanding the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(2)(c): Persons appointed to the board may be reappointed upon completion of their terms, but may not serve more than two consecutive terms.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(2)(d): The executive director shall provide for geographic balance in representation on the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(3): When a vacancy occurs in the membership for any reason, the replacement shall be appointed for the unexpired term.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(4): Title 58, Chapter 69, Dentist and Dental Hygienist Practice Act The membership shall be comprised of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(4)(a): four physicians who are actively engaged in the practice of medicine or osteopathic medicine in this state, to be selected from a list of nominees provided by the Utah Medical Association;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(4)(b): one physician in this state who is actively engaged in academic medicine;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(4)(c): three pharmacists who are actively practicing in retail pharmacy in this state, to be selected from a list of nominees provided by the Utah Pharmaceutical Association;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(4)(d): one pharmacist who is actively engaged in academic pharmacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(4)(e): one person who shall represent consumers;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(4)(f): one person who shall represent pharmaceutical manufacturers, to be recommended by the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(4)(g): Title 58, Chapter 69, Dentist and Dental Hygienist Practice Act one dentist licensed to practice in this state under
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(5): Physician and pharmacist members of the board shall have expertise in clinically appropriate prescribing and dispensing of outpatient drugs.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(6): The board shall elect a chair from among its members who shall serve a one-year term, and may serve consecutive terms.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(7): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 A member may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service, but may receive per diem and travel expenses in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(7)(a): 63A-3-106 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(7)(b): 63A-3-107 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-302(7)(c): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 rules made by the Division of Finance pursuant to Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303 DUR Board -- Responsibilities.
--------------------------------------------------------------
The board shall:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(1): develop rules necessary to carry out its responsibilities as defined in this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(2): oversee the implementation of a Medicaid retrospective and prospective DUR program in accordance with this part, including responsibility for approving provisions of contractual agreements between the Medicaid program and any other entity that will process and review Medicaid drug claims and profiles for the DUR program in accordance with this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(3): develop and apply predetermined criteria and standards to be used in retrospective and prospective DUR, ensuring that the criteria and standards are based on the compendia, and that they are developed with professional input, in a consensus fashion, with provisions for timely revision and assessment as necessary.  The DUR standards developed by the board shall reflect the local practices of physicians in order to monitor:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(3)(a): therapeutic appropriateness;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(3)(b): overutilization or underutilization;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(3)(c): therapeutic duplication;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(3)(d): drug-disease contraindications;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(3)(e): drug-drug interactions;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(3)(f): incorrect drug dosage or duration of drug treatment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(3)(g): clinical abuse and misuse;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(4): develop, select, apply, and assess interventions and remedial strategies for physicians, pharmacists, and recipients that are educational and not punitive in nature, in order to improve the quality of care;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(5): disseminate information to physicians and pharmacists to ensure that they are aware of the board's duties and powers;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(6): provide written, oral, or electronic reminders of patient-specific or drug-specific information, designed to ensure recipient, physician, and pharmacist confidentiality, and suggest changes in prescribing or dispensing practices designed to improve the quality of care;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(7): utilize face-to-face discussions between experts in drug therapy and the prescriber or pharmacist who has been targeted for educational intervention;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(8): conduct intensified reviews or monitoring of selected prescribers or pharmacists;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(9): create an educational program using data provided through DUR to provide active and ongoing educational outreach programs to improve prescribing and dispensing practices, either directly or by contract with other governmental or private entities;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(10): provide a timely evaluation of intervention to determine if those interventions have improved the quality of care;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(11): publish the annual Drug Utilization Review report required under 42 C.F.R. Sec. 712;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(12): develop a working agreement with related boards or agencies, including the State Board of Pharmacy, Physicians' Licensing Board, and SURS staff within the division, in order to clarify areas of responsibility for each, where those areas may overlap;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(13): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act establish a grievance process for physicians and pharmacists under this part, in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(14): publish and disseminate educational information to physicians and pharmacists concerning the board and the DUR program, including information regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(14)(a): identification and reduction of the frequency of patterns of fraud, abuse, gross overuse, inappropriate, or medically unnecessary care among physicians, pharmacists, and recipients;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(14)(b): potential or actual severe or adverse reactions to drugs;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(14)(c): therapeutic appropriateness;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(14)(d): overutilization or underutilization;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(14)(e): appropriate use of generics;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(14)(f): therapeutic duplication;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(14)(g): drug-disease contraindications;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(14)(h): drug-drug interactions;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(14)(i): incorrect drug dosage and duration of drug treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(14)(j): drug allergy interactions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(14)(k): clinical abuse and misuse;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(15): develop and publish, with the input of the State Board of Pharmacy, guidelines and standards to be used by pharmacists in counseling Medicaid recipients in accordance with this part.  The guidelines shall ensure that the recipient may refuse counseling and that the refusal is to be documented by the pharmacist.  Items to be discussed as part of that counseling include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(15)(a): the name and description of the medication;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(15)(b): administration, form, and duration of therapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(15)(c): special directions and precautions for use;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(15)(d): common severe side effects or interactions, and therapeutic interactions, and how to avoid those occurrences;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(15)(e): techniques for self-monitoring drug therapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(15)(f): proper storage;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(15)(g): prescription refill information; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(15)(h): action to be taken in the event of a missed dose; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(16): establish procedures in cooperation with the State Board of Pharmacy for pharmacists to record information to be collected under this part.  The recorded information shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(16)(a): the name, address, age, and gender of the recipient;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(16)(b): individual history of the recipient where significant, including disease state, known allergies and drug reactions, and a comprehensive list of medications and relevant devices;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(16)(c): the pharmacist's comments on the individual's drug therapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(16)(d): name of prescriber; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(16)(e): name of drug, dose, duration of therapy, and directions for use.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(15)(g): prescription refill information; and

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(16): establish procedures in cooperation with the State Board of Pharmacy for pharmacists to record information to be collected under this part.  The recorded information shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(16)(a): the name, address, age, and gender of the recipient;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(16)(b): individual history of the recipient where significant, including disease state, known allergies and drug reactions, and a comprehensive list of medications and relevant devices;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(16)(c): the pharmacist's comments on the individual's drug therapy;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(16)(d): name of prescriber; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-303(16)(e): name of drug, dose, duration of therapy, and directions for use.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-304 Confidentiality of records.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-304(1): Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act Information obtained under this part shall be treated as confidential or controlled information under
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-304(2): 26B-3-304(16) The board shall establish procedures ensuring that the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-304(3): The board shall adopt and implement procedures designed to ensure the confidentiality of all information collected, stored, retrieved, assessed, or analyzed by the board, staff to the board, or contractors to the DUR program, that identifies individual physicians, pharmacists, or recipients.  The board may have access to identifying information for purposes of carrying out intervention activities, but that identifying information may not be released to anyone other than a member of the board.  The board may release cumulative nonidentifying information for research purposes.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-307 Retrospective and prospective DUR.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-307(1): The board, in cooperation with the division, shall include in its state plan the creation and implementation of a retrospective and prospective DUR program for Medicaid outpatient drugs to ensure that prescriptions are appropriate, medically necessary, and not likely to result in adverse medical outcomes.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-307(2): (3); (4) The retrospective and prospective DUR program shall be operated under guidelines established by the board under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-307(3): The retrospective DUR program shall be based on guidelines established by the board, using the mechanized drug claims processing and information retrieval system to analyze claims data in order to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-307(3)(a): identify patterns of fraud, abuse, gross overuse, and inappropriate or medically unnecessary care; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-307(3)(b): assess data on drug use against explicit predetermined standards that are based on the compendia and other sources for the purpose of monitoring:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-307(3)(b)(i): therapeutic appropriateness;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-307(3)(b)(ii): overutilization or underutilization;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-307(3)(b)(iii): therapeutic duplication;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-307(3)(b)(iv): drug-disease contraindications;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-307(3)(b)(v): drug-drug interactions;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-307(3)(b)(vi): incorrect drug dosage or duration of drug treatment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-307(3)(b)(vii): clinical abuse and misuse.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-307(4): The prospective DUR program shall be based on guidelines established by the board and shall provide that, before a prescription is filled or delivered, a review will be conducted by the pharmacist at the point of sale to screen for potential drug therapy problems resulting from:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-307(4)(a): therapeutic duplication;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-307(4)(b): drug-drug interactions;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-307(4)(c): incorrect dosage or duration of treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-307(4)(d): drug-allergy interactions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-307(4)(e): clinical abuse or misuse.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-307(5): In conducting the prospective DUR, a pharmacist may not alter the prescribed outpatient drug therapy without the consent of the prescribing physician or physician assistant.  This section does not effect the ability of a pharmacist to substitute a generic equivalent.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-310(1)(c): it is in the best interest of the state to encourage aging nursing care facilities with Medicaid certification to renovate the nursing care facilities' physical facilities so that the quality of life and clinical services for Medicaid residents are preserved.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311 Authorization to renew, transfer, or increase Medicaid certified programs -- Reimbursement methodology.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(1): 26B-3-313; 26B-3-310; 26B-3-312
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(1)(a): The division may renew Medicaid certification of a certified program if the program, without lapse in service to Medicaid recipients, has its nursing care facility program certified by the division at the same physical facility as long as the licensed and certified bed capacity at the facility has not been expanded, unless the director has approved additional beds in accordance with Subsection (5).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(1)(b): 26B-3-313; 26B-3-310; 26B-3-312 The division may renew Medicaid certification of a nursing care facility program that is not currently certified if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(1)(b)(i): 26B-3-313 since the day on which the program last operated with Medicaid certification:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(1)(b)(i)(A): the physical facility where the program operated has functioned solely and continuously as a nursing care facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(1)(b)(i)(B): 26B-3-313 the owner of the program has not, under this section or Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(1)(b)(ii): 26B-3-310; 26B-3-312 except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(2)(a): The division may issue a Medicaid certification for a new nursing care facility program if a current owner of the Medicaid certified program transfers its ownership of the Medicaid certification to the new nursing care facility program and the new nursing care facility program meets all of the following conditions:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(2)(a)(i): the new nursing care facility program operates at the same physical facility as the previous Medicaid certified program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(2)(a)(ii): the new nursing care facility program gives a written assurance to the director in accordance with Subsection (4);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(2)(a)(iii): the new nursing care facility program receives the Medicaid certification within one year of the date the previously certified program ceased to provide medical assistance to a Medicaid recipient; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(2)(a)(iv): the licensed and certified bed capacity at the facility has not been expanded, unless the director has approved additional beds in accordance with Subsection (5).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(2)(b): A nursing care facility program that receives Medicaid certification under the provisions of Subsection (2)(a) does not assume the Medicaid liabilities of the previous nursing care facility program if the new nursing care facility program:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(2)(b)(i): is not owned in whole or in part by the previous nursing care facility program; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(2)(b)(ii): is not a successor in interest of the previous nursing care facility program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(3): The division may issue a Medicaid certification to a nursing care facility program that was previously a certified program but now resides in a new or renovated physical facility if the nursing care facility program meets all of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(3)(a): the nursing care facility program met all applicable requirements for Medicaid certification at the time of closure;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(3)(b): the new or renovated physical facility is in the same county or within a five-mile radius of the original physical facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(3)(c): the time between which the certified program ceased to operate in the original facility and will begin to operate in the new physical facility is not more than three years, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(3)(c)(i): an emergency is declared by the president of the United States or the governor, affecting the building or renovation of the physical facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(3)(c)(ii): the director approves an exception to the three-year requirement for any nursing care facility program within the three-year requirement;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(3)(c)(iii): the provider submits documentation supporting a request for an extension to the director that demonstrates a need for an extension; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(3)(c)(iv): the exception does not extend for more than two years beyond the three-year requirement;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(3)(d): if Subsection (3)(c) applies, the certified program notifies the department within 90 days after ceasing operations in its original facility, of its intent to retain its Medicaid certification;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(3)(e): the provider gives written assurance to the director in accordance with Subsection (4) that no third party has a legitimate claim to operate a certified program at the previous physical facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(3)(f): the bed capacity in the physical facility has not been expanded unless the director has approved additional beds in accordance with Subsection (5).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(4)(a): The entity requesting Medicaid certification under Subsections (2) and (3) shall give written assurances satisfactory to the director or the director's designee that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(4)(a)(i): no third party has a legitimate claim to operate the certified program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(4)(a)(ii): the requesting entity agrees to defend and indemnify the department against any claims by a third party who may assert a right to operate the certified program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(4)(a)(iii): if a third party is found, by final agency action of the department after exhaustion of all administrative and judicial appeal rights, to be entitled to operate a certified program at the physical facility the certified program shall voluntarily comply with Subsection (4)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(4)(b): If a finding is made under the provisions of Subsection (4)(a)(iii):
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(4)(b)(i): the certified program shall immediately surrender its Medicaid certification and comply with division rules regarding billing for Medicaid and the provision of services to Medicaid patients; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(4)(b)(ii): the department shall transfer the surrendered Medicaid certification to the third party who prevailed under Subsection (4)(a)(iii).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5)(a): The director may approve additional nursing care facility programs for Medicaid certification, or additional beds for Medicaid certification within an existing nursing care facility program, if a nursing care facility or other interested party requests Medicaid certification for a nursing care facility program or additional beds within an existing nursing care facility program, and the nursing care facility program or other interested party complies with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5)(b): Except as provided under Subsection (5)(e), a nursing care facility or other interested party requesting Medicaid certification for a nursing care facility program or additional beds within an existing nursing care facility program under Subsection (5)(a) shall submit to the director:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5)(b)(i): proof of the following as reasonable evidence that bed capacity provided by Medicaid certified programs within the county or group of counties impacted by the requested additional Medicaid certification is insufficient:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5)(b)(i)(A): nursing care facility occupancy levels for all existing and proposed facilities will be at least 90% for the next three years;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5)(b)(i)(B): current nursing care facility occupancy is 90% or more; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5)(b)(i)(C): there is  no other nursing care facility within a 35-mile radius of the nursing care facility requesting the additional certification; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5)(b)(ii): an independent analysis demonstrating that at projected occupancy rates the nursing care facility's after-tax net income is sufficient for the facility to be financially viable.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5)(c): Any request for additional beds as part of a renovation project are limited to the maximum number of beds allowed in Subsection (7).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5)(d): The director shall determine whether to issue additional Medicaid certification by considering:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5)(d)(i): whether bed capacity provided by certified programs within the county or group of counties impacted by the requested additional Medicaid certification is insufficient, based on the information submitted to the director under Subsection (5)(b);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5)(d)(ii): whether the county or group of counties impacted by the requested additional Medicaid certification is underserved by specialized or unique services that would be provided by the nursing care facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5)(d)(iii): whether any Medicaid certified beds are subject to a claim by a previous certified program that may reopen under the provisions of Subsections (2) and (3);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5)(d)(iv): how additional bed capacity should be added to the long-term care delivery system to best meet the needs of Medicaid recipients;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5)(d)(v): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5)(d)(v)(A): whether the existing certified programs within the county or group of counties have provided services of sufficient quality to merit at least a two-star rating in the Medicare Five-Star Quality Rating System over the previous three-year period; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5)(d)(v)(B): information obtained under Subsection (9); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5)(d)(vi): subject to Subsection (5)(e), for a state-owned veterans nursing care facility, whether the facility has previously been approved for a Medicaid certified bed increase under this Subsection (5).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5)(e): For a state-owned veterans nursing care facility that has not previously been approved for a Medicaid certified bed increase under this Subsection (5):
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5)(e)(i): the facility is exempt from the requirements under Subsection (5)(b); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(5)(e)(ii): the director may approve, for that facility location only, up to five total Medicaid certified beds.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(6): The department shall adopt administrative rules in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to adjust the Medicaid nursing care facility property reimbursement methodology to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(6)(a): only pay that portion of the property component of rates, representing actual bed usage by Medicaid clients as a percentage of the greater of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(6)(a)(i): actual occupancy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(6)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(6)(a)(ii)(A): for a nursing care facility other than a facility described in Subsection (6)(a)(ii)(B), 85% of total bed capacity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(6)(a)(ii)(B): for a rural nursing care facility, 65% of total bed capacity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(6)(b): not allow for increases in reimbursement for property values without major renovation or replacement projects as defined by the department by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-311(7): 26B-3-310; 26B-3-312

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-313 Authorization to sell or transfer licensed Medicaid beds -- Duties of transferor -- Duties of transferee -- Duties of division.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-313(1): 26B-3-311 This section provides a method to transfer or sell the license for a Medicaid bed from a nursing care facility program to another entity that is in addition to the authorization to transfer under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-313(2): 26B-3-311; 26B-3-311; 26B-3-311
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-313(2)(a): 26B-3-311 A nursing care facility program may transfer or sell one or more of its licenses for Medicaid beds in accordance with Subsection (2)(b) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-313(2)(a)(i): at the time of the transfer, and with respect to the license for the Medicaid bed that will be transferred, the nursing care facility program that will transfer the Medicaid license meets all applicable regulations for Medicaid certification;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-313(2)(a)(ii): 26B-3-311 the nursing care facility program gives a written assurance, which is postmarked or has proof of delivery 30 days before the transfer, to the director and to the transferee in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-313(2)(a)(iii): the nursing care facility program that will transfer the license for a Medicaid bed notifies the division in writing, which is postmarked or has proof of delivery 30 days before the transfer, of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-313(2)(a)(iii)(A): the number of bed licenses that will be transferred;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-313(2)(a)(iii)(B): the date of the transfer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-313(2)(a)(iii)(C): the identity and location of the entity receiving the transferred licenses; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-313(2)(a)(iv): if the nursing care facility program for which the license will be transferred or purchased is located in an urban county with a nursing care facility average annual occupancy rate over the previous two years less than or equal to 75%, the nursing care facility program transferring or selling the license demonstrates to the satisfaction of the director that the sale or transfer:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-313(2)(a)(iv)(A): will not result in an excessive number of Medicaid certified beds within the county or group of counties that would be impacted by the transfer or sale; and
