Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1024 Legal recognition of electronic claims records.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Pursuant toUtah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1024(1): a claim submitted to the department for payment may not be denied legal effect, enforceability, or admissibility as evidence in any court in any civil action because it is in electronic form; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1024(2): a third party shall accept an electronic record of payments by the department for medical services on behalf of a recipient as evidence in support of the department's claim.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1025 Direct payment to the department by third party.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1025(1): Any third party required to make payment to the department pursuant to this part shall make the payment directly to the department or its designee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1025(2): (1) The department may negotiate a payment or payment instrument it receives in connection with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1026 Attorney general or county attorney to represent department.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The attorney general or a county attorney shall represent the department in any action commenced under this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1027 Department's right to attorney fees and costs.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In any action brought by the department under this part in which it prevails, the department shall recover along with the principal sum and interest, a reasonable attorney fee and costs incurred.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1028 Application of provisions contrary to federal law prohibited.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In no event shall any provision contained in this part be applied contrary to existing federal law.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(1): "Benefit" means the receipt of money, goods, or any other thing of pecuniary value.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(2): "Claim" means any request or demand for money or property:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(2)(a): made to any:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(2)(a)(i): employee, officer, or agent of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(2)(a)(ii): contractor with the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(2)(a)(iii): grantee or other recipient, whether or not under contract with the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(2)(b): if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(2)(b)(i): any portion of the money or property requested or demanded was issued from or provided by the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(2)(b)(ii): the state will reimburse the contractor, grantee, or other recipient for any portion of the money or property.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(3): "False statement" or "false representation" means a wholly or partially untrue statement or representation which is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(3)(a): knowingly made; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(3)(b): a material fact with respect to the claim.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(4): 26B-8-411 "Health care provider" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(5): 26B-3-1108(1); 26B-3-1109(1) "Knowing" and "knowingly":
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(5)(a): 26B-3-1108(1) for purposes of criminal prosecutions for violations of this part, is one of the culpable mental states described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(5)(b): 26B-3-1109(1) for purposes of civil prosecutions for violations of this part, is the required culpable mental state as defined in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(6): "Medical benefit" means a benefit paid or payable to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(6)(a): a health care provider; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(6)(b): a recipient or a provider under a program administered by the state under:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(6)(b)(i): Titles V and XIX of the federal Social Security Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(6)(b)(ii): Title X of the federal Public Health Services Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(6)(b)(iii): the federal Child Nutrition Act of 1966 as amended by Pub. L. No. 94-105; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(6)(b)(iv): any programs for medical assistance of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1101(7): "Person" means an individual, corporation, unincorporated association, professional corporation, partnership, or other form of business association.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1102 False statement or representation relating to medical benefits.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1102(1): A person may not make or cause to be made a false statement or false representation of a material fact in an application for medical benefits.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1102(2): A person may not make or cause to be made a false statement or false representation of a material fact for use in determining rights to a medical benefit.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1102(3): A person, who having knowledge of the occurrence of an event affecting the person's initial or continued right to receive a medical benefit or the initial or continued right of any other person on whose behalf the person has applied for or is receiving a medical benefit, may not conceal or fail to disclose that event with intent to obtain a medical benefit to which the person or any other person is not entitled or in an amount greater than that to which the person or any other person is entitled.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1103 Kickbacks or bribes prohibited.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1103(1): For purposes of this section, kickback or bribe:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1103(1)(a): includes rebates, compensation, or any other form of remuneration which is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1103(1)(a)(i): direct or indirect;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1103(1)(a)(ii): overt or covert; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1103(1)(a)(iii): in cash or in kind; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1103(1)(b): does not include a rebate paid to the state under 42 U.S.C. Sec. 1396r-8 or any state supplemental rebates.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1103(2): A person may not solicit, offer, pay, or receive a kickback or bribe in return for or to induce:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1103(2)(a): the purchasing, leasing, or ordering of any goods or services for which payment is or may be made in whole or in part pursuant to a medical benefit program; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1103(2)(b): the referral of an individual to another person for the furnishing of any goods or services for which payment is or may be made in whole or in part pursuant to a medical benefit program.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1104 False statements or false representations relating to qualification of health institution or facility prohibited -- Felony.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1104(1): A person may not knowingly, intentionally, or recklessly make, induce, or seek to induce, the making of a false statement or false representation of a material fact with respect to the conditions or operation of an institution or facility in order that the institution or facility may qualify, upon initial certification or upon recertification, as a hospital, skilled nursing facility, intermediate care facility, or home health agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1104(2): A person who violates this section is guilty of a second degree felony.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1105 Conspiracy to defraud prohibited.
------------------------------------------------------------------
A person may not enter into an agreement, combination, or conspiracy to defraud the state by obtaining or aiding another to obtain the payment or allowance of a false, fictitious, or fraudulent claim for a medical benefit.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106 False claims for medical benefits prohibited.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(1): A person may not make or present or cause to be made or presented to an employee or officer of the state a claim for a medical benefit:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(1)(a): which is wholly or partially false, fictitious, or fraudulent;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(1)(b): for services which were not rendered or for items or materials which were not delivered;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(1)(c): which misrepresents the type, quality, or quantity of items or services rendered;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(1)(d): representing charges at a higher rate than those charged by the provider to the general public;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(1)(e): for items or services which the person or the provider knew were not medically necessary in accordance with professionally recognized standards;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(1)(f): which has previously been paid;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(1)(g): for services also covered by one or more private sources when the person or provider knew of the private sources without disclosing those sources on the claim; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(1)(h): where a provider:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(1)(h)(i): unbundles a product, procedure, or group of procedures usually and customarily provided or performed as a single billable product or procedure into artificial components or separate procedures; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(1)(h)(ii): bills for each component of the product, procedure, or group of procedures:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(1)(h)(ii)(A): as if they had been provided or performed independently and at separate times; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(1)(h)(ii)(B): the aggregate billing for the components exceeds the amount otherwise billable for the usual and customary single product or procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(2): (1) In addition to the prohibitions in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(2)(a): fail to credit the state for payments received from other sources;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(2)(b): recover or attempt to recover payment in violation of the provider agreement from:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(2)(b)(i): a recipient under a medical benefit program; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(2)(b)(ii): the recipient's family;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(2)(c): falsify or alter with intent to deceive, any report or document required by state or federal law, rule, or Medicaid provider agreement;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(2)(d): retain any unauthorized payment as a result of acts described by this section; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1106(2)(e): aid or abet the commission of any act prohibited by this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1107 Knowledge of past acts not necessary to establish fact that false statement or representation knowingly made.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In prosecution under this part, it is not necessary to show that the person had knowledge of similar acts having been performed in the past on the part of persons acting on his behalf nor to show that the person had actual notice that the acts by the persons acting on his behalf occurred to establish the fact that a false statement or representation was knowingly made.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1108 Criminal penalties.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1108(1): (1)(b); 76-2-103; 26B-3-1103; 76-2-103
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1108(1)(a): (1)(b); 76-2-103 Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1108(1)(b): 26B-3-1103; 76-2-103 The culpable mental state required for a criminal violation of this part for kickbacks and bribes under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1108(2): 26B-3-1104 The punishment for a criminal violation of any provision of this part, except as provided under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1108(3): 26B-3-1104 Punishment for criminal violation of this part, except as provided under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1108(3)(a): a second degree felony if the value of the property or service is or exceeds $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1108(3)(b): a third degree felony if the value of the property or service is or exceeds $1,500 but is less than $5,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1108(3)(c): a class A misdemeanor if the value of the property or service is or exceeds $500 but is less than $1,500; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1108(3)(d): a class B misdemeanor if the value of the property or service is less than $500.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1109 Civil penalties.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1109(1): The culpable mental state required for a civil violation of this part is "knowing" or "knowingly" which:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1109(1)(a): means that person, with respect to information:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1109(1)(a)(i): has actual knowledge of the information;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1109(1)(a)(ii): acts in deliberate ignorance of the truth or falsity of the information; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1109(1)(a)(iii): acts in reckless disregard of the truth or falsity of the information; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1109(1)(b): does not require a specific intent to defraud.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1109(2): Any person who violates this part shall, in all cases, in addition to other penalties provided by law, be required to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1109(2)(a): make full and complete restitution to the state of all damages that the state sustains because of the person's violation of this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1109(2)(b): pay to the state its costs of enforcement of this part in that case, including the cost of investigators, attorneys, and other public employees, as determined by the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1109(2)(c): pay to the state a civil penalty equal to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1109(2)(c)(i): three times the amount of damages that the state sustains because of the person's violation of this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1109(2)(c)(ii): not less than $5,000 or more than $10,000 for each claim filed or act done in violation of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1109(3): (2) Any civil penalties assessed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1109(4): A criminal action need not be brought against a person in order for that person to be civilly liable under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1110 Revocation of license of assisted living facility -- Appointment of receiver.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1110(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1110(1)(a): If the license of an assisted living facility is revoked for violation of this part, the county attorney may bring a petition in a court with jurisdiction under Title 78A, Judiciary and Judicial Administration, for the appointment of a receiver.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1110(1)(b): Notwithstanding Title 78B, Chapter 3a, Venue for Civil Actions, the person shall bring the petition in the county in which the facility is located if the person brings the petition in the district court.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1110(2): The court shall issue an order to show cause why a receiver should not be appointed returnable within five days after the filing of the petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1110(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1110(3)(a): If the court finds that the facts warrant the granting of the petition, the court shall appoint a receiver to take charge of the facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1110(3)(b): The court may determine fair compensation for the receiver.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1110(4): A receiver appointed pursuant to this section shall have the powers and duties prescribed by the court.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1111 Presumption based on paid state warrant -- Value of medical benefits -- Repayment of benefits.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1111(1): In any civil or criminal action brought under this part, a paid state warrant, made payable to the order of a party, creates a presumption that the party received funds from the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1111(2): In any civil or criminal action brought under this part, the value of the benefits received shall be the ordinary or usual charge for similar benefits in the private sector.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1111(3): In any criminal action under this part, the repayment of funds or other benefits obtained in violation of the provisions of this part does not constitute a defense to, or grounds for dismissal of that action.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1112 Violation of other laws.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1112(1): The provisions of this part are:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1112(1)(a): not exclusive, and the remedies provided for in this part are in addition to any other remedies provided for under:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1112(1)(a)(i): any other applicable law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1112(1)(a)(ii): common law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1112(1)(b): to be liberally construed and applied to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1112(1)(b)(i): effectuate the chapter's remedial and deterrent purposes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1112(1)(b)(ii): serve the public interest.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1112(2): If any provision of this part or the application of this part to any person or circumstance is held unconstitutional:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1112(2)(a): the remaining provisions of this part are not affected; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1112(2)(b): the application of this part to other persons or circumstances are not affected.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1113 Medicaid fraud enforcement.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1113(1): This part shall be enforced in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1113(2): The department is responsible for:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1113(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1113(2)(a)(i): investigating and prosecuting suspected civil violations of this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1113(2)(a)(ii): referring suspected civil violations of this part to the attorney general for investigation and prosecution; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1113(2)(b): promptly referring suspected criminal violations of this part to the attorney general for criminal investigation and prosecution.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1113(3): The attorney general has:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1113(3)(a): concurrent jurisdiction with the department for investigating and prosecuting suspected civil violations of this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1113(3)(b): exclusive jurisdiction to investigate and prosecute all suspected criminal violations of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1113(4): The department and the attorney general share concurrent civil enforcement authority under this part and may enter into an interagency agreement regarding the investigation and prosecution of violations of this part in accordance with this section, the requirements of Title XIX of the federal Social Security Act, and applicable federal regulations.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1113(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1113(5)(a): Any violation of this part which comes to the attention of any state government officer or agency shall be reported to the attorney general or the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1113(5)(b): All state government officers and agencies shall cooperate with and assist in any prosecution for violation of this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114 Investigations -- Civil investigative demands.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(1): The attorney general may take investigative action under Subsection (2) if the attorney general has reason to believe that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(1)(a): a person has information or custody or control of documentary material relevant to the subject matter of an investigation of an alleged violation of this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(1)(b): a person is committing, has committed, or is about to commit a violation of this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(1)(c): it is in the public interest to conduct an investigation to ascertain whether or not a person is committing, has committed, or is about to commit a violation of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(2): In taking investigative action, the attorney general may:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(2)(a): require the person to file on a prescribed form a statement in writing, under oath or affirmation describing:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(2)(a)(i): the facts and circumstances concerning the alleged violation of this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(2)(a)(ii): other information considered necessary by the attorney general;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(2)(b): examine under oath a person in connection with the alleged violation of this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(2)(c): in accordance with Subsections (7) through (18), execute in writing, and serve on the person, a civil investigative demand requiring the person to produce the documentary material and permit inspection and copying of the material.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(3): The attorney general may not release or disclose information that is obtained under Subsection (2)(a) or (b), or any documentary material or other record derived from the information obtained under Subsection (2)(a) or (b), except:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(3)(a): by court order for good cause shown;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(3)(b): with the consent of the person who provided the information;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(3)(c): to an employee of the attorney general or the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(3)(d): to an agency of this state, the United States, or another state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(3)(e): to a special assistant attorney general representing the state in a civil action;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(3)(f): to a political subdivision of this state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(3)(g): to a person authorized by the attorney general to receive the information.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(4): The attorney general may use documentary material derived from information obtained under Subsection (2)(a) or (b), or copies of that material, as the attorney general determines necessary in the enforcement of this part, including presentation before a court.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(5)(a): If a person fails to file a statement as required by Subsection (2)(a) or fails to submit to an examination as required by Subsection (2)(b), the attorney general may bring in a court with jurisdiction under Title 78A, Judiciary and Judicial Administration, a complaint for an order to compel the person to within a period stated by court order:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(5)(a)(i): file the statement required by Subsection (2)(a); or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(5)(a)(ii): submit to the examination required by Subsection (2)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(5)(b): Failure to comply with an order entered under Subsection (5)(a) is punishable as contempt.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(6): A civil investigative demand shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(6)(a): state the rule or statute under which the alleged violation of this part is being investigated;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(6)(b): describe the:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(6)(b)(i): general subject matter of the investigation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(6)(b)(ii): class or classes of documentary material to be produced with reasonable specificity to fairly indicate the documentary material demanded;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(6)(c): designate a date within which the documentary material is to be produced; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(6)(d): identify an authorized employee of the attorney general to whom the documentary material is to be made available for inspection and copying.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(7): A civil investigative demand may require disclosure of any documentary material that is discoverable under the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(8): Service of a civil investigative demand may be made by:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(8)(a): delivering an executed copy of the demand to the person to be served or to a partner, an officer, or an agent authorized by appointment or by law to receive service of process on behalf of that person;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(8)(b): delivering an executed copy of the demand to the principal place of business in this state of the person to be served; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(8)(c): mailing by registered or certified mail an executed copy of the demand addressed to the person to be served:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(8)(c)(i): at the person's principal place of business in this state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(8)(c)(ii): if the person has no place of business in this state, to the person's principal office or place of business.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(9): Documentary material demanded in a civil investigative demand shall be produced for inspection and copying during normal business hours at the office of the attorney general or as agreed by the person served and the attorney general.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(10): The attorney general may not produce for inspection or copying or otherwise disclose the contents of documentary material obtained pursuant to a civil investigative demand except:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(10)(a): by court order for good cause shown;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(10)(b): with the consent of the person who produced the information;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(10)(c): to an employee of the attorney general or the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(10)(d): to an agency of this state, the United States, or another state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(10)(e): to a special assistant attorney general representing the state in a civil action;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(10)(f): to a political subdivision of this state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(10)(g): to a person authorized by the attorney general to receive the information.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(11)(a): With respect to documentary material obtained pursuant to a civil investigative demand, the attorney general shall prescribe reasonable terms and conditions allowing such documentary material to be available for inspection and copying by the person who produced the material or by an authorized representative of that person.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(11)(b): The attorney general may use such documentary material or copies of it as the attorney general determines necessary in the enforcement of this part, including presentation before a court.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(12): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(12)(a): A person may file a complaint, stating good cause, to extend the return date for the demand or to modify or set aside the demand.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(12)(b): A complaint under this Subsection (12) shall be filed in court before the earlier of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(12)(b)(i): the return date specified in the demand; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(12)(b)(ii): the 20th day after the date the demand is served.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(13): Except as provided by court order, a person who has been served with a civil investigative demand shall comply with the terms of the demand.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(14): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(14)(a): A person who has committed a violation of this part in relation to the Medicaid program in this state or to any other medical benefit program administered by the state has submitted to the jurisdiction of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(14)(b): Personal service of a civil investigative demand under this section may be made on the person described in Subsection (14)(a) outside of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(15): This section does not limit the authority of the attorney general to conduct investigations or to access a person's documentary materials or other information under another state or federal law, the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure, or the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(16): The attorney general may bring a complaint in a court with jurisdiction under Title 78A, Judiciary and Judicial Administration, for an order to enforce the civil investigative demand if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(16)(a): a person fails to comply with a civil investigative demand; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(16)(b): copying and reproduction of the documentary material demanded:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(16)(b)(i): cannot be satisfactorily accomplished; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(16)(b)(ii): the person refuses to surrender the documentary material.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(17): If a complaint is filed under Subsection (16), the court may determine the matter presented and may enter an order to enforce the civil investigative demand.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1114(18): Failure to comply with a final order entered under Subsection (17) is punishable by contempt.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1115 Limitation of actions -- Civil acts antedating this section -- Civil burden of proof -- Estoppel -- Joint civil liability -- Venue.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1115(1): An action under this part may not be brought after the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1115(1)(a): six years after the date on which the violation was committed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1115(1)(b): three years after the date an official of the state charged with responsibility to act in the circumstances discovers the violation, but in no event more than 10 years after the date on which the violation was committed.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1115(2): A civil action brought under this part may be brought for acts occurring prior to the effective date of this section if the limitations period set forth in Subsection (1) has not lapsed.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1115(3): In any civil action brought under this part the state shall be required to prove by a preponderance of evidence, all essential elements of the cause of action including damages.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1115(4): Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a final judgment rendered in favor of the state in any criminal proceeding under this part, whether upon a verdict after trial or upon a plea of guilty or nolo contendere, shall estop the defendant from denying the essential elements of the offense in any civil action under this part which involves the same transaction.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1115(5): Civil liability under this part shall be joint and several for a violation committed by two or more persons.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1115(6): A person shall bring an action under this part:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-3-1115(6)(a): in Salt Lake County; or

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-118 Permits for emergency medical service vehicles and nonemergency secured behavioral health transport vehicles.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-118(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-118(1)(a): To ensure that emergency medical service vehicles and nonemergency secured behavioral health transport vehicles are adequately staffed, safe, maintained, properly equipped, and safely operated, the committee shall establish permit requirements at levels it considers appropriate in the following categories:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-118(1)(a)(i): ambulance;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-118(1)(a)(ii): emergency medical response vehicle; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-118(1)(a)(iii): nonemergency secured behavioral health transport vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-118(1)(b): The permit requirements under Subsections (1)(a)(i) and (ii) shall include a requirement that every operator of an ambulance or emergency medical response vehicle annually provide proof of the successful completion of an emergency vehicle operator's course approved by the department for all ambulances and emergency medical response vehicle operators.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-118(2): The department shall, based on the requirements established in Subsection (1), issue permits to emergency medical service vehicles and nonemergency secured behavioral health transport vehicles.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-123 Out-of-state vehicles.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-123(1): 26B-4-118 An ambulance or emergency response vehicle from another state may not pick up a patient in Utah to transport that patient to another location in Utah or to another state without a permit issued under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-123(2): Notwithstanding Subsection (1), an ambulance or emergency response vehicle from another state may, without a permit or license:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-123(2)(a): transport a patient into Utah; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-123(2)(b): provide assistance in time of disaster.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-123(3): The department may enter into agreements with ambulance and paramedic providers and their respective licensing agencies from other states to assure the expeditious delivery of emergency medical services beyond what may be reasonably provided by licensed ambulance and paramedic providers, including the transportation of patients between states.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-201(40): 26B-4-203 "Nonresident patient" means an individual who:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202 Electronic verification system.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(1): The Department of Agriculture and Food, the department, the Department of Public Safety, and the Division of Technology Services shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(1)(a): enter into a memorandum of understanding in order to determine the function and operation of the state electronic verification system in accordance with Subsection (2);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(1)(b): coordinate with the Division of Purchasing, under Title 63G, Chapter 6a, Utah Procurement Code, to develop a request for proposals for a third-party provider to develop and maintain the state electronic verification system in coordination with the Division of Technology Services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(1)(c): select a third-party provider who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(1)(c)(i): meets the requirements contained in the request for proposals issued under Subsection (1)(b); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(1)(c)(ii): may not have any commercial or ownership interest in a cannabis production establishment or a medical cannabis pharmacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2): 26B-4-213; 4-41a-1101; 4-41a-103; 4-41a-1102 The Department of Agriculture and Food, the department, the Department of Public Safety, and the Division of Technology Services shall ensure that the state electronic verification system described in Subsection (1):
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(a): allows an individual to apply for a medical cannabis patient card or, if applicable, a medical cannabis guardian card, provided that the card may not become active until:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(a)(ii): for a medical cannabis card related to a limited medical provider's recommendation, the medical cannabis pharmacy completes the recording described in Subsection (2)(d);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(b): 26B-4-213 allows an individual to apply to renew a medical cannabis patient card or a medical cannabis guardian card in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(c): allows a qualified medical provider, or an employee described in Subsection (3) acting on behalf of the qualified medical provider, to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(c)(i): access dispensing and card status information regarding a patient:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(c)(i)(B): for whom the qualified medical provider has recommended or is considering recommending a medical cannabis card;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(c)(ii): electronically recommend treatment with cannabis in a medicinal dosage form or a cannabis product in a medicinal dosage form and optionally recommend dosing guidelines;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(c)(iii): electronically renew a recommendation to a medical cannabis patient cardholder or medical cannabis guardian cardholder:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(c)(iii)(A): using telehealth services, for the qualified medical provider who originally recommended a medical cannabis treatment during a face-to-face visit with the patient; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(c)(iii)(B): during a face-to-face visit with the patient, for a qualified medical provider who did not originally recommend the medical cannabis treatment during a face-to-face visit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(c)(iv): submit an initial application, renewal application, or application payment on behalf of an individual applying for any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(c)(iv)(A): a medical cannabis patient card;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(c)(iv)(B): a medical cannabis guardian card; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(c)(iv)(C): a medical cannabis caregiver card;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(d): 4-41a-1101 allows a medical cannabis pharmacy medical provider or medical cannabis pharmacy agent, in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(d)(i): access the electronic verification system to review the history within the system of a patient with whom the provider or agent is interacting, limited to read-only access for medical cannabis pharmacy agents unless the medical cannabis pharmacy's pharmacist in charge authorizes add and edit access;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(d)(ii): record a patient's recommendation from a limited medical provider, including any directions of use, dosing guidelines, or caregiver indications from the limited medical provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(d)(iii): record a limited medical provider's renewal of the provider's previous recommendation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(d)(iv): submit an initial application, renewal application, or application payment on behalf of an individual applying for any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(d)(iv)(A): a medical cannabis patient card;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(d)(iv)(B): a medical cannabis guardian card; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(d)(iv)(C): a medical cannabis caregiver card;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(e): 4-41a-103 connects with:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(e)(i)(D): the personally identifiable information of the medical cannabis cardholder who made the purchase; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(e)(ii): 4-41a-103 any commercially available inventory control system that a cannabis production establishment utilizes in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(f): provides access to:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(i): provides access to state or local law enforcement only to verify the validity of an individual's medical cannabis card for the administration of criminal justice and through a database used by law enforcement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(2)(j): creates a record each time a person accesses the system that identifies the person who accesses the system and the individual whose records the person accesses.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(3)(a): An employee of a qualified medical provider may access the electronic verification system for a purpose described in Subsection (2)(c) on behalf of the qualified medical provider if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(3)(a)(i): the qualified medical provider has designated the employee as an individual authorized to access the electronic verification system on behalf of the qualified medical provider;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(3)(a)(iii): the department grants to the employee access to the electronic verification system.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(3)(b): An employee of a business that employs a qualified medical provider may access the electronic verification system for a purpose described in Subsection (2)(c) on behalf of the qualified medical provider if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(3)(b)(i): the qualified medical provider has designated the employee as an individual authorized to access the electronic verification system on behalf of the qualified medical provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(3)(b)(ii): the qualified medical provider and the employing business jointly provide written notice to the department of the employee's identity and the designation described in Subsection (3)(b)(i); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(3)(b)(iii): the department grants to the employee access to the electronic verification system.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(4)(a): As used in this Subsection (4), "prescribing provider" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(4)(a)(i): a podiatrist licensed under Title 58, Chapter 5a, Podiatric Physician Licensing Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(4)(a)(ii): an advanced practice registered nurse licensed under Title 58, Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(4)(a)(iii): a physician licensed under Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act, or Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(4)(a)(iv): a physician assistant licensed under Title 58, Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(4)(b): A prescribing provider may access information in the electronic verification system regarding a patient the prescribing provider treats.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(5): 26B-4-222 The department may release limited data that the system collects for the purpose of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(5)(a): conducting medical and other department approved research;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(5)(b): 26B-4-222 providing the report required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(5)(c): other official department purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(6): The department shall make rules, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to establish:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(6)(a): the limitations on access to the data in the state electronic verification system as described in this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(6)(b): standards and procedures to ensure accurate identification of an individual requesting information or receiving information in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(7): Any person who negligently or recklessly releases any information in the state electronic verification system in violation of this section is guilty of a class C misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(8): Any person who obtains or attempts to obtain information from the state electronic verification system by misrepresentation or fraud is guilty of a third degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(9)(a): Except as provided in Subsections (9)(c) and (9)(e), a person may not knowingly and intentionally use, release, publish, or otherwise make available to any other person information obtained from the state electronic verification system for any purpose other than a purpose specified in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(9)(b): Each separate violation of this Subsection (9) is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(9)(b)(i): a third degree felony; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(9)(b)(ii): subject to a civil penalty not to exceed $5,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(9)(c): A law enforcement officer who uses the database used by law enforcement to access information in the electronic verification system for a reason that is not the administration of criminal justice is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(9)(d): The department shall determine a civil violation of this Subsection (9) in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(9)(e): Civil penalties assessed under this Subsection (9) shall be deposited into the General Fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(9)(f): This Subsection (9) does not prohibit a person who obtains information from the state electronic verification system under Subsection (2)(a), (c), or (f) from:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(9)(f)(i): including the information in the person's medical chart or file for access by a person authorized to review the medical chart or file;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(9)(f)(ii): providing the information to a person in accordance with the requirements of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-202(9)(f)(iii): discussing or sharing that information about the patient with the patient.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203 Qualifying condition.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(1): (2) By designating a particular condition under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(1)(a): current scientific evidence clearly supports the efficacy of a medical cannabis treatment for the condition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(1)(b): a medical cannabis treatment will treat, cure, or positively affect the condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2): 58-60-102; 58-31b-302(5)(g); 58-70a-501.1; 26B-4-213(5)(c); 26B-1-421 For the purposes of this part, each of the following conditions is a qualifying condition:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(a): HIV or acquired immune deficiency syndrome;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(b): Alzheimer's disease;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(c): amyotrophic lateral sclerosis;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(d): cancer;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(e): cachexia;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(f): persistent nausea that is not significantly responsive to traditional treatment, except for nausea related to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(f)(i): pregnancy;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(f)(ii): cannabis-induced cyclical vomiting syndrome; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(f)(iii): cannabinoid hyperemesis syndrome;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(g): Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(h): epilepsy or debilitating seizures;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(i): multiple sclerosis or persistent and debilitating muscle spasms;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(j): 58-60-102; 58-31b-302(5)(g); 58-70a-501.1 post-traumatic stress disorder that is being treated and monitored by a licensed mental health therapist, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(j)(i): has been diagnosed by a healthcare provider or mental health provider employed or contracted by the United States Veterans Administration, evidenced by copies of medical records from the United States Veterans Administration that are included as part of the qualified medical provider's pre-treatment assessment and medical record documentation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(j)(ii): 58-31b-302(5)(g); 58-70a-501.1 has been diagnosed or confirmed, through face-to-face or telehealth evaluation of the patient, by a provider who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(j)(ii)(A): a licensed board-eligible or board-certified psychiatrist;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(j)(ii)(B): a licensed psychologist with a master's-level degree;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(j)(ii)(C): a licensed clinical social worker with a master's-level degree;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(j)(ii)(D): 58-31b-302(5)(g) a licensed advanced practice registered nurse who is qualified to practice within the psychiatric mental health nursing specialty and who has completed the clinical practice requirements in psychiatric mental health nursing, including in psychotherapy, in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(j)(ii)(E): 58-70a-501.1 a licensed physician assistant who is qualified to specialize in mental health care under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(k): autism;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(l): a terminal illness when the patient's remaining life expectancy is less than six months;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(m): a condition resulting in the individual receiving hospice care;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(n): a rare condition or disease that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(n)(i): affects less than 200,000 individuals in the United States, as defined in Section 526 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(n)(ii): is not adequately managed despite treatment attempts using:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(n)(ii)(A): conventional medications other than opioids or opiates; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(n)(ii)(B): physical interventions;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(o): pain lasting longer than two weeks that is not adequately managed, in the qualified medical provider's opinion, despite treatment attempts using:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(o)(i): conventional medications other than opioids or opiates; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(o)(ii): physical interventions;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(p): 26B-4-213(5)(c) pain that is expected to last for two weeks or longer for an acute condition, including a surgical procedure, for which a medical professional may generally prescribe opioids for a limited duration, subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-203(2)(q): 26B-1-421 a condition that the Compassionate Use Board approves under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-204(2): 63J-1-504
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-204(2)(a): 63J-1-504 The department shall, within 15 days after the day on which the department receives an application from an individual, register and issue a qualified medical provider registration card to the individual if the individual:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-204(2)(a)(v): 63J-1-504 pays the department a fee in an amount that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-204(2)(a)(v)(A): 63J-1-504 the department sets, in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-204(2)(a)(v)(B): does not exceed $300 for an initial registration.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-204(2)(b): The department may not register an individual as a qualified medical provider if the individual is:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-204(3)(c)(v): best practices for recommending the form and dosage of medical cannabis based on the qualifying condition underlying a medical cannabis recommendation.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-207 Nondiscrimination for medical care or government employment -- Notice to prospective and current public employees -- No effect on private employers.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-207(1): For purposes of medical care, including an organ or tissue transplant, a patient's use, in accordance with this part, of cannabis in a medicinal dosage form or a cannabis product in a medicinal dosage form:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-207(1)(a): is considered the equivalent of the authorized use of any other medication used at the discretion of a physician; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-207(1)(b): does not constitute the use of an illicit substance or otherwise disqualify an individual from needed medical care.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-207(2): 67-21-3; 67-19a-101
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-207(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-207(2)(a)(i): A state employer or a political subdivision employer shall take the action described in Subsection (2)(a)(ii) before:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-207(2)(a)(i)(A): giving to a current employee an assignment or duty that arises from or directly relates to an obligation under this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-207(2)(a)(i)(B): hiring a prospective employee whose assignments or duties would include an assignment or duty that arises from or directly relates to an obligation under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-207(2)(a)(ii): The employer described in Subsection (2)(a)(i) shall give the employee or prospective employee described in Subsection (2)(a)(i) a written notice that notifies the employee or prospective employee:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-207(2)(a)(ii)(A): that the employee's or prospective employee's job duties may require the employee or prospective employee to engage in conduct which is in violation of the criminal laws of the United States; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-207(2)(a)(ii)(B): that in accepting a job or undertaking a duty described in Subsection (2)(a)(i), although the employee or prospective employee is entitled to the protections of Title 67, Chapter 21, Utah Protection of Public Employees Act, the employee may not object or refuse to carry out an assignment or duty that may be a violation of the criminal laws of the United States with respect to the manufacture, sale, or distribution of cannabis.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-207(2)(b): The Division of Human Resource Management shall create, revise, and publish the form of the notice described in Subsection (2)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-207(2)(c): 67-21-3 Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-207(2)(c)(i): claim in good faith that the employee's actions violate or potentially violate the laws of the United States with respect to the manufacture, sale, or distribution of cannabis; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-207(2)(c)(ii): refuse to carry out a directive that the employee reasonably believes violates the criminal laws of the United States with respect to the manufacture, sale, or distribution of cannabis.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-207(2)(d): 67-19a-101 An employer may not take retaliatory action as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-207(3): Nothing in this section requires a private employer to accommodate the use of medical cannabis or affects the ability of a private employer to have policies restricting the use of medical cannabis by applicants or employees.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-208 No insurance requirement.
---------------------------------------------------------
Nothing in this part requires an insurer, a third-party administrator, or an employer to pay or reimburse for cannabis, a cannabis product, or a medical cannabis device.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-209 No effect on use of hemp extract -- Cannabidiol -- Approved drugs.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-209(1): 4-41-402 Nothing in this part prohibits an individual from purchasing, selling, possessing, or using a cannabinoid product in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-209(2): Nothing in this part restricts or otherwise affects the prescription, distribution, or dispensing of a product that the United States Food and Drug Administration has approved.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-211 Analogous to prescribed controlled substances.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
When an employee, officer, or agent of the state or a political subdivision makes a finding, determination, or otherwise considers an individual's possession or use of cannabis, a cannabis product, or a medical cannabis device, the employee, officer, or agent may not consider the individual's possession or use any differently than the lawful possession or use of any prescribed controlled substance, if the individual's possession or use complies with:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-211(1): this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-211(2): Title 4, Chapter 41a, Cannabis Production Establishments and Pharmacies
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-211(3): 58-37-3.7(2); (3) Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212 Institutional review board -- Approved study of cannabis, a cannabinoid product, or an expanded cannabinoid product.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(1): 26B-1-420; 58-37-3.6; 58-37-3.6; 58-37-3.6 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(1)(a): "Approved study" means a medical research study:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(1)(a)(i): the purpose of which is to investigate the medical benefits and risks of cannabinoid products; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(1)(a)(ii): that is approved by an IRB.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(1)(b): 26B-1-420 "Board" means the Cannabis Research Review Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(1)(c): 58-37-3.6 "Cannabinoid product" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(1)(d): 58-37-3.6 "Cannabis" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(1)(e): 58-37-3.6 "Expanded cannabinoid product" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(1)(f): "Institutional review board" or "IRB" means an institutional review board that is registered for human subject research by the United States Department of Health and Human Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(2): A person conducting an approved study may, for the purposes of the study:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(2)(a): process a cannabinoid product or an expanded cannabinoid product;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(2)(b): possess a cannabinoid product or an expanded cannabinoid product; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(2)(c): administer a cannabinoid product, or an expanded cannabinoid product to an individual in accordance with the approved study.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(3): A person conducting an approved study may:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(3)(a): import cannabis, a cannabinoid product, or an expanded cannabinoid product from another state if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(3)(a)(i): the importation complies with federal law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(3)(a)(ii): the person uses the cannabis, cannabinoid product, or expanded cannabinoid product in accordance with the approved study; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(3)(b): obtain cannabis, a cannabinoid product, or an expanded cannabinoid product from the National Institute on Drug Abuse.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(4): A person conducting an approved study may distribute cannabis, a cannabinoid product, or an expanded cannabinoid product outside the state if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(4)(a): the distribution complies with federal law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-212(4)(b): the distribution is for the purposes of, and in accordance with, the approved study.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219 Pharmacy medical providers -- Registration -- Continuing education.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(1)(a): A medical cannabis pharmacy:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(1)(a)(i): shall employ a pharmacist who is licensed under Title 58, Chapter 17b, Pharmacy Practice Act, as a pharmacy medical provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(1)(a)(ii): may employ a physician who has the authority to write a prescription and is licensed under Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act, or Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act, as a pharmacy medical provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(1)(a)(iii): shall ensure that a pharmacy medical provider described in Subsection (1)(a)(i) works onsite during all business hours; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(1)(a)(iv): shall designate one pharmacy medical provider described in Subsection (1)(a)(i) as the pharmacist-in-charge to oversee the operation of and generally supervise the medical cannabis pharmacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(1)(b): The pharmacist-in-charge shall determine which cannabis and cannabis products the medical cannabis pharmacy maintains in the medical cannabis pharmacy's inventory.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(1)(c): An individual may not serve as a pharmacy medical provider unless the department registers the individual as a pharmacy medical provider in accordance with Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(2): 26B-1-310; 63J-1-504
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(2)(a): 26B-1-310; 63J-1-504 The department shall, within 15 days after the day on which the department receives an application from a medical cannabis pharmacy on behalf of a prospective pharmacy medical provider, register and issue a pharmacy medical provider registration card to the prospective pharmacy medical provider if the medical cannabis pharmacy:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(2)(a)(i): provides to the department:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(2)(a)(i)(A): the prospective pharmacy medical provider's name and address;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(2)(a)(i)(B): the name and location of the licensed medical cannabis pharmacy where the prospective pharmacy medical provider seeks to act as a pharmacy medical provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(2)(a)(i)(C): a report detailing the completion of the continuing education requirement described in Subsection (3); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(2)(a)(i)(D): evidence that the prospective pharmacy medical provider is a pharmacist who is licensed under Title 58, Chapter 17b, Pharmacy Practice Act, or a physician who has the authority to write a prescription and is licensed under Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act, or Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(2)(a)(ii): 26B-1-310; 63J-1-504 pays a fee to the department in an amount that, subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(2)(b): The department may not register a recommending medical provider as a pharmacy medical provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(3)(a): A pharmacy medical provider shall complete the continuing education described in this Subsection (3) in the following amounts:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(3)(a)(i): as a condition precedent to registration, four hours; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(3)(a)(ii): as a condition precedent to renewal of the registration, four hours every two years.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(3)(b): In accordance with Subsection (3)(a), the pharmacy medical provider shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(3)(b)(i): complete continuing education:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(3)(b)(i)(A): regarding the topics described in Subsection (3)(d); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(3)(b)(i)(B): offered by the department under Subsection (3)(c) or an accredited or approved continuing education provider that the department recognizes as offering continuing education appropriate for the medical cannabis pharmacy practice; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(3)(b)(ii): make a continuing education report to the department in accordance with a process that the department establishes by rule, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, and in collaboration with the Division of Professional Licensing and:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(3)(b)(ii)(A): for a pharmacy medical provider who is licensed under Title 58, Chapter 17b, Pharmacy Practice Act, the Board of Pharmacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(3)(b)(ii)(B): for a pharmacy medical provider licensed under Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act, the Physicians Licensing Board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(3)(b)(ii)(C): for a pharmacy medical provider licensed under Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act, the Osteopathic Physician and Surgeon's Licensing Board.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(3)(c): The department may, in consultation with the Division of Professional Licensing, develop the continuing education described in this Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(3)(d): The continuing education described in this Subsection (3) may discuss:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(3)(d)(i): the provisions of this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(3)(d)(ii): general information about medical cannabis under federal and state law;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(3)(d)(iii): the latest scientific research on the endocannabinoid system and medical cannabis, including risks and benefits;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(3)(d)(iv): recommendations for medical cannabis as it relates to the continuing care of a patient in pain management, risk management, potential addiction, and palliative care; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(3)(d)(v): best practices for recommending the form and dosage of medical cannabis based on the qualifying condition underlying a medical cannabis recommendation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(4): 26B-1-310; 63J-1-504
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(4)(a): A pharmacy medical provider registration card expires two years after the day on which the department issues or renews the card.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(4)(b): 26B-1-310; 63J-1-504 A pharmacy medical provider may renew the provider's registration card if the provider:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(4)(b)(i): is eligible for a pharmacy medical provider registration card under this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(4)(b)(ii): certifies to the department in a renewal application that the information in Subsection (2)(a) is accurate or updates the information;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(4)(b)(iii): submits a report detailing the completion of the continuing education requirement described in Subsection (3); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(4)(b)(iv): 26B-1-310; 63J-1-504 pays to the department a renewal fee in an amount that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(4)(b)(iv)(A): 26B-1-310; 63J-1-504 subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(4)(b)(iv)(B): may not exceed the cost of the relatively lower administrative burden of renewal in comparison to the original application process.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(5): 4-41a-109
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(5)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (5)(b), a person may not advertise that the person or another person dispenses medical cannabis.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(5)(b): 4-41a-109 Notwithstanding Subsection (5)(a) and Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(5)(b)(i): a green cross;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(5)(b)(ii): that the person is registered as a pharmacy medical provider and dispenses medical cannabis; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(5)(b)(iii): a scientific study regarding medical cannabis use.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(6)(a): The department may revoke a pharmacy medical provider's registration for a violation of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-219(6)(b): The department may inspect patient records held by a medical cannabis pharmacy to ensure a pharmacy medical provider is practicing in accordance with this chapter and applicable rules.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-222 Report.
---------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-222(1): By the November interim meeting each year, the department shall report to the Health and Human Services Interim Committee on:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-222(1)(a): the number of applications and renewal applications filed for medical cannabis cards;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-222(1)(b): the number of qualifying patients and designated caregivers;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-222(1)(c): the nature of the debilitating medical conditions of the qualifying patients;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-222(1)(d): the age and county of residence of cardholders;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-222(1)(e): the number of medical cannabis cards revoked;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-222(1)(f): the number of practitioners providing recommendations for qualifying patients;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-222(1)(g): the number of license applications and renewal license applications received;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-222(1)(h): the number of licenses the department has issued in each county;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-222(1)(i): the number of licenses the department has revoked;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-222(1)(j): the quantity of medical cannabis shipments that the state central patient portal facilitates;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-222(1)(k): the number of overall purchases of medical cannabis and medical cannabis products from each medical cannabis pharmacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-222(1)(l): the expenses incurred and revenues generated from the medical cannabis program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-222(1)(m): an analysis of product availability in medical cannabis pharmacies in consultation with the Department of Agriculture and Food.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-222(2): 53B-17-1402 The report shall include information provided by the Center for Medical Cannabis Research described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-222(3): The department may not include personally identifying information in the report described in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-222(4): 36-12-8.2 The department shall report to the working group described in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231 Partial filling -- Pharmacy medical provider directions of use.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231(1): As used in this section, "partially fill" means to provide less than the full amount of cannabis or cannabis product that the recommending medical provider recommends, if the recommending medical provider recommended specific dosing guidelines.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231(2): A pharmacy medical provider may partially fill a recommendation for a medical cannabis treatment at the request of the recommending medical provider who issued the medical cannabis treatment recommendation or the medical cannabis cardholder.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231(3): The department shall make rules, in collaboration with the Division of Professional Licensing and the Board of Pharmacy and in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, specifying how to record the date, quantity supplied, and quantity remaining of a partially filled medical cannabis treatment recommendation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231(4): 4-41a-1102; 4-41a-1102 A pharmacy medical provider who is a pharmacist may, upon the request of a medical cannabis cardholder, determine different dosing guidelines, subject to the dosing limits in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231(4)(a): 4-41a-1102 the pharmacy medical provider determined dosing guidelines for the partial fill under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231(4)(b): the medical cannabis cardholder reports that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231(4)(b)(i): the partial fill did not substantially affect the qualifying condition underlying the medical cannabis recommendation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231(4)(b)(ii): the patient experienced an adverse reaction to the partial fill or was otherwise unable to successfully use the partial fill.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231(5): If a recommending medical provider recommends treatment with medical cannabis but wishes for the pharmacy medical provider to determine directions of use and dosing guidelines:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231(5)(a): the recommending medical provider shall provide to the pharmacy medical provider, either through the state electronic verification system or through a medical cannabis pharmacy's recording of a recommendation under the order of a limited medical provider, any of the following information that the recommending medical provider feels would be needed to provide appropriate directions of use and dosing guidelines:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231(5)(a)(i): information regarding the qualifying condition underlying the recommendation;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231(5)(a)(ii): information regarding prior treatment attempts with medical cannabis; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231(5)(a)(iii): portions of the patient's current medication list; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231(5)(b): before the relevant medical cannabis cardholder may obtain medical cannabis, the pharmacy medical provider shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231(5)(b)(i): review pertinent medical records, including the recommending medical provider documentation described in Subsection (5)(a); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231(5)(b)(ii): after completing the review described in Subsection (5)(b)(i) and consulting with the recommending medical provider as needed, determine the best course of treatment through consultation with the cardholder regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231(5)(b)(ii)(A): the patient's qualifying condition underlying the recommendation from the recommending medical provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231(5)(b)(ii)(B): indications for available treatments;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231(5)(b)(ii)(C): directions of use and dosing guidelines; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-231(5)(b)(ii)(D): potential adverse reactions.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-236(1): Title 63G, Chapter 6a, Utah Procurement Code The department shall establish or contract to establish, in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-236(2)(c): 26B-4-230(4) if the cardholder's recommending medical provider recommended the use of medical cannabis without providing directions of use and dosing guidelines and the cardholder has not yet received the counseling or consultation required in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-236(2)(c)(ii): provide the cardholder with access to the contact information for each pharmacy medical provider;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-243 Guidance for treatment with medical cannabis.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department, in consultation with the Center for Medical Cannabis Research created in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 26B-4-243(1): develop evidence-based guidance for treatment with medical cannabis based on the latest medical research that shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-243(1)(a): for each qualifying condition, a summary of the latest medical research regarding the treatment of the qualifying condition with medical cannabis;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-243(1)(b): risks, contraindications, side effects, and adverse reactions that are associated with medical cannabis use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-243(1)(c): potential drug interactions between medical cannabis and medications that have been approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-243(2): (1)(a) educate recommending medical providers, pharmacy medical providers, medical cannabis cardholders, and the public regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-243(2)(a): (1)(a) the evidence-based guidance for treatment with medical cannabis described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-243(2)(b): relevant warnings and safety information related to medical cannabis use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-243(2)(c): other topics related to medical cannabis use as determined by the department.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-246 Denial or revocation of guardian card or caregiver card.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department may deny or revoke a medical cannabis guardian card or a medical cannabis caregiver card if the applicant or cardholder:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-246(1): violates the requirements of this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-246(2): unless the individual completes any imposed sentence two or more years before the day on which the individual submits the application, has been convicted of any of the following under state or federal law:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-246(2)(a): a drug distribution offense that is a felony within the preceding 10 years; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-246(2)(b): after December 3, 2018, a drug distribution offense that is a misdemeanor.
