Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-247(3): when appropriate, consult with the advisory board regarding issues that arise in the medical cannabis program.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(1): 26B-1-410 "Committee" means the Primary Care Grant Committee described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(2): "Community based organization":
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(2)(a): means a private entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(2)(b): includes for profit and not for profit entities.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(3): "Cultural competence" means a set of congruent behaviors, attitudes, and policies that come together in a system, agency, or profession and enables that system, agency, or profession to work effectively in cross-cultural situations.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(4): 63H-7a-103 "Emergency medical dispatch center" means a public safety answering point, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(5): "Health literacy" means the degree to which an individual has the capacity to obtain, process, and understand health information and services needed to make appropriate health decisions.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(6): "Institutional capacity" means the ability of a community based organization to implement public and private contracts.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(7): "Medically underserved population" means the population of an urban or rural area or a population group that the committee determines has a shortage of primary health care.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(8): "Office" means the Office of Emergency Medical Services and Preparedness within the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(9): "Pregnancy support services" means services that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(9)(a): encourage childbirth instead of voluntary termination of pregnancy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(9)(b): assist pregnant women, or women who may become pregnant, to choose childbirth whether they intend to parent or select adoption for the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(10): 26B-4-310 "Primary care grant" means a grant awarded by the department under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(11)(a): "Primary health care" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(11)(a)(i): basic and general health care services given when a person seeks assistance to screen for or to prevent illness and disease, or for simple and common illnesses and injuries; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(11)(a)(ii): care given for the management of chronic diseases.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(11)(b): "Primary health care" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(11)(b)(i): services of physicians, nurses, physician's assistants, and dentists licensed to practice in this state under Title 58, Occupations and Professions;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(11)(b)(ii): diagnostic and radiologic services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(11)(b)(iii): preventive health services including perinatal services, well-child services, and other services that seek to prevent disease or its consequences;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(11)(b)(iv): emergency medical services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(11)(b)(v): preventive dental services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-301(11)(b)(vi): pharmaceutical services.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-311 Content of primary care grant applications.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
An applicant for a grant under SectionUtah Code Annotated § 26B-4-311(1): a statement of specific, measurable objectives, and the methods the applicant will use to assess the achievement of those objectives;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-311(2): the precise boundaries of the area the applicant will serve, including a description of the medically underserved population the applicant will serve using the grant;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-311(3): the results of a need assessment that demonstrates that the population the applicant will serve has a need for the services provided by the applicant;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-311(4): a description of the personnel responsible for carrying out the activities of the grant along with a statement justifying the use of any grant funds for the personnel;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-311(5): evidence that demonstrates the applicant's existing financial and professional assistance and any attempts by the applicant to obtain financial and professional assistance;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-311(6): a list of services the applicant will provide;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-311(7): the schedule of fees, if any, the applicant will charge;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-311(8): the estimated number of individuals the applicant will serve with the grant award; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-311(9): any other information required by the department in consultation with the committee.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-314 Assistance to rural communities by department.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department shall assist rural communities in dealing with primary health care needs relating to recruiting health professionals, planning, and technical assistance. The department shall assist the communities, at their request, at any stage of development of new or expanded primary health care services and shall work with them to improve primary health care by providing information to increase the effectiveness of their systems, to decrease duplication and fragmentation of services, and to maximize community use of private gifts, and local, state, and federal grants and contracts.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-315 Responsibility of department for coordinating rural health programs.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department shall be the lead agency responsible for coordinating rural health programs and shall ensure that resources available for rural health are efficiently and effectively used.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-316 Rural health development initiatives.
---------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-316(2)(a): The area health education center program shall consist of a central program office at University of Utah Health.  The program office shall establish and operate a statewide, decentralized, regional program with emphasis on addressing rural health professions workforce education and training needs.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-318 Maternal and child health provided by department.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department shall, as funding permits, provide for maternal and child health services and services for children with a disability if the individual needs the services and the individual cannot reasonably obtain the services from other sources.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-320 Dental health programs -- Appointment of director.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department shall establish and promote programs to protect and improve the dental health of the public. The executive director shall appoint a director of the dental health program who shall be a dentist licensed in the state with at least one year of training in an accredited school of public health or not less than two years of experience in public health dentistry.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-324 Department to award grants for assistance to persons with bleeding disorders.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-324(1): As used in this section:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-324(1)(b): "Person with a bleeding disorder" means a person:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-324(1)(b)(i): who is medically diagnosed with hemophilia or a bleeding disorder;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-324(1)(b)(ii): who is not eligible for Medicaid or the Children's Health Insurance Program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-324(1)(b)(iii): who meets one or more of the following:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-324(1)(b)(iii)(D): the premiums for the person's private insurance coverage, or cost sharing under private coverage, are greater than a percentage of the person's annual adjusted gross income as established by the department by administrative rule.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-325(10)(c): an updated report before October 1 of each year that compares the indicators and population measures of the most recent year to the initial report described in Subsection (10)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-325(11): An inmate receiving comprehensive health care from the department remains in the custody of the Department of Corrections.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-326 Pregnancy support services.
-----------------------------------------------------------
The department shall, as funding permits and either directly or through one or more third parties, provide pregnancy support services, which may include:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-326(1): medical care and information, including pregnancy tests, sexually transmitted infection tests, pregnancy-related health screenings, ultrasound services, prenatal care, or birth planning and classes;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-326(2): nutritional services and education;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-326(3): housing, education, and employment assistance during pregnancy and up to one year following a birth;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-326(4): adoption education, planning, and services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-326(5): child care assistance, if necessary for the client to receive pregnancy support services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-326(6): parenting education and support services for up to one year following a birth;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-326(7): material items that are supportive of pregnancy and childbirth, including cribs, car seats, clothing, formula, and other safety devices; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-326(8): information regarding health care benefits, including Medicaid coverage for the client for pregnancy care that provides health coverage for the client's child upon birth.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(1): "Agent" means a coach, teacher, employee, representative, or volunteer.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(2)(a): "Amateur sports organization" means, except as provided in Subsection (2)(b):
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(2)(a)(i): a sports team;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(2)(a)(ii): a public or private school;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(2)(a)(iii): a public or private sports league;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(2)(a)(iv): a public or private sports camp; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(2)(a)(v): any other public or private organization that organizes, manages, or sponsors a sporting event for its members, enrollees, or attendees.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(2)(b): "Amateur sports organization" does not include a professional:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(2)(b)(i): team;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(2)(b)(ii): league; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(2)(b)(iii): sporting event.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(3): "Anaphylaxis" means a potentially life-threatening hypersensitivity to a substance.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(3)(a): Symptoms of anaphylaxis may include shortness of breath, wheezing, difficulty breathing, difficulty talking or swallowing, hives, itching, swelling, shock, or asthma.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(3)(b): Causes of anaphylaxis may include insect sting, food allergy, drug reaction, and exercise.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(4): "Asthma action plan" means a written plan:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(4)(a): developed with a school nurse, a student's parent or guardian, and the student's health care provider to help control the student's asthma; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(4)(b): signed by the student's:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(4)(b)(i): parent or guardian; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(4)(b)(ii): health care provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(5): "Asthma emergency" means an episode of respiratory distress that may include symptoms such as wheezing, shortness of breath, coughing, chest tightness, or breathing difficulty.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(6): "Child" means an individual who is under the age of 18.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(7): "Department health care provider" means a health care provider who is acting in the capacity of a health care provider during employment for the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(8): "Epinephrine auto-injector" means a portable, disposable drug delivery device that contains a measured, single dose of epinephrine that is used to treat a person suffering a potentially fatal anaphylactic reaction.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(9): 58-31b-302 "Health care provider" means an individual who is licensed as:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(9)(a): a physician under Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(9)(b): a physician under Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(9)(c): 58-31b-302 an advanced practice registered nurse under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(9)(d): a physician assistant under Title 58, Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(10): 58-17b-102 "Pharmacist" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(11): 58-17b-102 "Pharmacy intern" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(12): 58-67-102 "Physician" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(13): "Public school" means a district school or a charter school.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(14): 26B-4-407; 26B-4-408 "Qualified adult" means a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(14)(a): is at least 18 years old; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(14)(b): 26B-4-407; 26B-4-408
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(14)(b)(i): 26B-4-407 for purposes of administering an epinephrine auto-injector, has successfully completed the training program established in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(15)(b): includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(15)(b)(i): recreation camps;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(15)(b)(ii): an education facility, school, or university;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(15)(b)(iii): a day care facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(15)(b)(iv): youth sports leagues;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(15)(b)(v): amusement parks;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(15)(b)(vi): food establishments;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(15)(b)(vii): places of employment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(15)(b)(viii): recreation areas.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(16): "Qualified health care provider" means a health care provider who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(16)(a): is licensed under Title 58, Occupations and Professions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(16)(b): may evaluate and manage a concussion within the health care provider's scope of practice.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(17): "Qualified stock albuterol entity" means a public or private school that employs, contracts with, or has a similar relationship with a qualified adult who is likely to have contact with another person who may experience an asthma emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(18): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(18)(a): "Sporting event" means any of the following athletic activities that is organized, managed, or sponsored by an organization:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(18)(a)(i): a game;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(18)(a)(ii): a practice;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(18)(a)(iii): a sports camp;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(18)(a)(iv): a physical education class;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(18)(a)(v): a competition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(18)(a)(vi): a tryout.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(18)(b): "Sporting event" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(18)(b)(i): the issuance of a lift ticket or pass by a ski resort, the use of the ticket or pass, or a ski or snowboarding class or school at a ski resort, unless the skiing or snowboarding is part of a camp, team, or competition that is organized, managed, or sponsored by the ski resort;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(18)(b)(ii): as applied to a government entity, merely making available a field, facility, or other location owned, leased, or controlled by the government entity to an amateur sports organization or a child, regardless of whether the government entity charges a fee for the use; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(18)(b)(iii): free play or recess taking place during school hours.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(19): "Stock albuterol" means a prescription inhaled medication:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(19)(a): used to treat asthma; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(19)(b): that may be delivered through a device, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(19)(b)(i): an inhaler; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(19)(b)(ii): a nebulizer with a mouthpiece or mask.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(20): "Traumatic head injury" means an injury to the head arising from blunt trauma, an acceleration force, or a deceleration force, with one of the following observed or self-reported conditions attributable to the injury:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(20)(a): transient confusion, disorientation, or impaired consciousness;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(20)(b): dysfunction of memory;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(20)(c): loss of consciousness; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(20)(d): signs of other neurological or neuropsychological dysfunction, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(20)(d)(i): seizures;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(20)(d)(ii): irritability;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(20)(d)(iii): lethargy;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(20)(d)(iv): vomiting;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(20)(d)(v): headache;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(20)(d)(vi): dizziness; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-401(20)(d)(vii): fatigue.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-402 Plan for school health services.
----------------------------------------------------------------
The department shall establish a plan for school health services for pupils in elementary and secondary schools. The department shall cooperate with the State Board of Education and local health departments in developing such plan and shall coordinate activities between these agencies. The plan may provide for the delivery of health services by and through intermediate and local school districts and local health departments.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-403 Adoption and enforcement of concussion and head injury policy -- Notice of policy to parent or guardian.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Each amateur sports organization shall:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-403(1): 26B-4-404 adopt and enforce a concussion and head injury policy that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-403(1)(a): 26B-4-404 is consistent with the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-403(1)(b): describes the nature and risk of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-403(1)(b)(i): a concussion or a traumatic head injury; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-403(1)(b)(ii): continuing to participate in a sporting event after sustaining a concussion or a traumatic head injury;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-403(2): ensure that each agent of the amateur sports organization is familiar with, and has a copy of, the concussion and head injury policy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-403(3): before permitting a child to participate in a sporting event of the amateur sports organization:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-403(3)(a): provide a written copy of the concussion and head injury policy to a parent or legal guardian of a child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-403(3)(b): obtain the signature of a parent or legal guardian of the child, acknowledging that the parent or legal guardian has read, understands, and agrees to abide by, the concussion and head injury policy.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-404 Removal of child suspected of sustaining concussion or a traumatic head injury -- Medical clearance required before return to participation.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-404(1): (1)(a); (1)(b)(i) An amateur sports organization, and each agent of the amateur sports organization, shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-404(1)(a): immediately remove a child from participating in a sporting event of the amateur sports organization if the child is suspected of sustaining a concussion or a traumatic head injury; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-404(1)(b): (1)(a); (1)(b)(i) prohibit the child described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-404(1)(b)(i): is evaluated by a qualified health care provider who is trained in the evaluation and management of a concussion; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-404(1)(b)(ii): (1)(b)(i) provides the amateur sports organization with a written statement from the qualified health care provider described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-404(1)(b)(ii)(A): the qualified health care provider has, within three years before the day on which the written statement is made, successfully completed a continuing education course in the evaluation and management of a concussion; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-404(1)(b)(ii)(B): the child is cleared to resume participation in the sporting event of the amateur sports organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-404(2): This section does not create a new cause of action.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-405 School nurses evaluating student injuries.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-405(1): A school nurse may assess a child who is suspected of sustaining a concussion or a traumatic head injury during school hours on school property regardless of whether the nurse has received specialized training in the evaluation and management of a concussion.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-405(2): 26B-4-404(1)(b)(i); (1)(b)(ii)(A); (1); 26B-4-404(1)(b)(ii) A school nurse who does not meet the requirements of Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-405(2)(a): shall refer the child to a qualified health care provider who is trained in the evaluation and management of a concussion; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-405(2)(b): 26B-4-404(1)(b)(ii) may not provide a written statement permitting the child to resume participation in free play or physical education class under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-405(3): A school nurse shall undergo training in the evaluation and management of a concussion, as funding allows.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(1): "Controlled substance" means the same as that term is defined in Title 58, Chapter 37, Utah Controlled Substances Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(2): "Critical access hospital" means a critical access hospital that meets the criteria of 42 U.S.C. Sec. 1395i-4(c)(2) (1998).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(3): "Designated facility" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(3)(a): a freestanding urgent care center;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(3)(b): a general acute hospital; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(3)(c): a critical access hospital.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(4): 58-17b-102 "Dispense" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(5): 58-1-103 "Division" means the Division of Professional Licensing created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(6): "Emergency contraception" means the use of a substance, approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration, to prevent pregnancy after sexual intercourse.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(7): 59-12-801 "Freestanding urgent care center" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(8): 26B-2-201 "General acute hospital" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(9): "Health care facility" means a hospital, a hospice inpatient residence, a nursing facility, a dialysis treatment facility, an assisted living residence, an entity that provides home- and community-based services, a hospice or home health care agency, or another facility that provides or contracts to provide health care services, which facility is licensed under Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(10): 58-67-102; 58-31b-102; 58-70a-102; 58-69-102 "Health care provider" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(10)(a): 58-67-102 a physician, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(10)(b): 58-31b-102 an advanced practice registered nurse, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(10)(c): 58-70a-102 a physician assistant, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(10)(d): 58-69-102 an individual licensed to engage in the practice of dentistry, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(11): "Increased risk" means risk exceeding the risk typically experienced by an individual who is not using, and is not likely to use, an opiate.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(12): 58-37-2 "Opiate" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(13): "Opiate antagonist" means naloxone hydrochloride or any similarly acting drug that is not a controlled substance and that is approved by the federal Food and Drug Administration for the diagnosis or treatment of an opiate-related drug overdose.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(14): "Opiate-related drug overdose event" means an acute condition, including a decreased level of consciousness or respiratory depression resulting from the consumption or use of a controlled substance, or another substance with which a controlled substance was combined, and that a person would reasonably believe to require medical assistance.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(15): 26B-4-101; 26B-4-101; 26B-5-610; 26B-5-101; 26B-5-101 "Overdose outreach provider" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(15)(a): a law enforcement agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(15)(b): a fire department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(15)(c): 26B-4-101 an emergency medical service provider, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(15)(d): 26B-4-101 emergency medical service personnel, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(15)(e): an organization providing treatment or recovery services for drug or alcohol use;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(15)(f): an organization providing support services for an individual, or a family of an individual, with a substance use disorder;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(15)(g): 26B-5-610 a certified peer support specialist, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(15)(h): 26B-5-101; 26B-5-101 an organization providing substance use or mental health services under contract with a local substance abuse authority, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(15)(i): an organization providing services to the homeless;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(15)(j): a local health department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(15)(k): an individual licensed to practice under:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(15)(k)(i): Title 58, Chapter 17b, Pharmacy Practice Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(15)(k)(ii): Title 58, Chapter 60, Part 2, Social Worker Licensing Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(15)(k)(iii): Title 58, Chapter 60, Part 5, Substance Use Disorder Counselor Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(15)(l): an individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(16): 58-17b-102 "Patient counseling" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(17): 58-17b-102 "Pharmacist" means the same as that term is defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(20)(b): any other person who is permitted by law to prescribe emergency contraception.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(21): 58-17b-102 "Prescribe" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(22): 76-7-301
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(22)(a): "Self-administered hormonal contraceptive" means a self-administered hormonal contraceptive that is approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration to prevent pregnancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(22)(b): "Self-administered hormonal contraceptive" includes an oral hormonal contraceptive, a hormonal vaginal ring, and a hormonal contraceptive patch.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(22)(c): 76-7-301 "Self-administered hormonal contraceptive" does not include any drug intended to induce an abortion, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(23): "Sexual assault" means any criminal conduct described in Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses, that may result in a pregnancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-501(24): "Victim of sexual assault" means any person who presents to receive, or receives, medical care in consequence of being subjected to sexual assault.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502 Emergency contraception services for a victim of sexual assault.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(1): Except as provided in Subsection (2), a designated facility shall provide the following services to a victim of sexual assault:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(1)(a): provide the victim with written and oral medical information regarding emergency contraception that is unbiased, accurate, and generally accepted by the medical community as being scientifically valid;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(1)(b): orally inform the victim of sexual assault that the victim may obtain emergency contraception at the designated facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(1)(c): offer a complete regimen of emergency contraception to a victim of sexual assault;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(1)(d): provide, at the designated facility, emergency contraception to the victim of sexual assault upon her request;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(1)(e): maintain a protocol, prepared by a physician, for the administration of emergency contraception at the designated facility to a victim of sexual assault; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(1)(f): develop and implement a written policy to ensure that a person is present at the designated facility, or on-call, who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(1)(f)(i): has authority to dispense or prescribe emergency contraception, independently, or under the protocol described in Subsection (1)(e), to a victim of sexual assault; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(1)(f)(ii): is trained to comply with the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(2): A freestanding urgent care center is exempt from the requirements of Subsection (1) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(2)(a): there is a general acute hospital or a critical access hospital within 30 miles of the freestanding urgent care center; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(2)(b): an employee of the freestanding urgent care center provides the victim with:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(2)(b)(i): written and oral medical information regarding emergency contraception that is unbiased, accurate, and generally accepted by the medical community as being scientifically valid; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(2)(b)(ii): the name and address of the general acute hospital or critical access hospital described in Subsection (2)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(3): A practitioner shall comply with Subsection (4) with regard to a person who is a victim of sexual assault, if the person presents to receive medical care, or receives medical care, from the practitioner at a location that is not a designated facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(4): A practitioner described in Subsection (3) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(4)(a): provide the victim with written and oral medical information regarding emergency contraception that is unbiased, accurate, and generally accepted by the medical community as being scientifically valid; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(4)(b)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(4)(b)(i)(A): orally inform the victim of sexual assault that the victim may obtain emergency contraception at the facility where the practitioner is located; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(4)(b)(i)(B): provide emergency contraception to the victim of sexual assault, if she requests emergency contraception; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(4)(b)(ii): inform the victim of sexual assault of the nearest location where she may obtain emergency contraception.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(5): 26B-2-703
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(5)(a): The department may make rules, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to enforce the provisions of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(5)(b): The department shall, in an expeditious manner, investigate any complaint received by the department regarding the failure of a health care facility to comply with a requirement of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-502(5)(c): 26B-2-703 If the department finds a violation of this section or any rules adopted under this section, the department may take one or more of the actions described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-604(6): specify the content and timing of reports required from a qualified provider, including a report on actual and projected treatment outcomes for a qualified individual.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-701 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-701(1): "Accredited clinical education program" means a clinical education program for a health care profession that is accredited by the Accreditation Council on Graduate Medical Education.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-701(2): "Accredited clinical training program" means a clinical training program that is accredited by an entity recognized within medical education circles as an accrediting body for medical education, advanced practice nursing education, physician assistant education, doctor of pharmacy education, dental education, or registered nursing education.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-701(3): "Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services" means the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services within the United States Department of Health and Human Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-701(4): "Health care professionals in training" means medical students and residents, advanced practice nursing students, physician assistant students, doctor of pharmacy students, dental students, and registered nursing students.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-701(5): 26B-2-201 "Hospital" means a general acute hospital, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-701(6): "Physician" means a person:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-701(6)(a): licensed as a physician under Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-701(6)(b): licensed as a physician under Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-701(7): 17-50-501 "Rural county" means a county of the third, fourth, fifth, or sixth class under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-701(8): "Rural hospital" means a hospital located within a rural county.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-701(9): 26B-4-706 "UMEC" means the Utah Medical Education Council created in Section

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1)(a): "Eligible professional" means a geriatric professional or a health care professional who is eligible to participate in the program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1)(b): "Geriatric professional" means a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1)(b)(i): is a licensed:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1)(b)(i)(A): health care professional;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1)(b)(i)(B): social worker;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1)(b)(i)(C): occupational therapist;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1)(b)(i)(D): pharmacist;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1)(b)(i)(E): physical therapist; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1)(b)(i)(F): psychologist; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1)(b)(ii): is determined by the department to have adequate advanced training in geriatrics to prepare the person to provide specialized geriatric care within the scope of the person's profession.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1)(c): "Health care professional" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1)(c)(i): a licensed:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1)(c)(i)(A): physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1)(c)(i)(B): physician assistant;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1)(c)(i)(C): nurse;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1)(c)(i)(D): dentist; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1)(c)(i)(E): mental health therapist; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1)(c)(ii): another licensed health care professional designated by the department by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1)(d): "Program" means the Utah Health Care Workforce Financial Assistance Program created in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(1)(e): "Underserved area" means an area designated by the department as underserved by health care professionals, based upon the results of a needs assessment developed by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(2): There is created within the department the Utah Health Care Workforce Financial Assistance Program to provide, within funding appropriated by the Legislature for the following purposes:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(2)(a): professional education scholarships and loan repayment assistance to health care professionals who locate or continue to practice in underserved areas; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(2)(b): loan repayment assistance to geriatric professionals who locate or continue to practice in underserved areas.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(3): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the department shall make rules governing the administration of the program, including rules that address:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(3)(a): application procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(3)(b): eligibility criteria;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(3)(c): selection criteria;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(3)(d): service conditions, which at a minimum shall include professional service in an underserved area for a minimum period of time by any person receiving a scholarship or loan repayment assistance;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(3)(e): penalties for failure to comply with service conditions or other terms of a scholarship or loan repayment contract;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(3)(f): criteria for modifying or waiving service conditions or penalties in case of extreme hardship or other good cause; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(3)(g): administration of contracts entered into before the effective date of this act, between the department and scholarship or loan repayment recipients, as authorized by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(4): The department may provide education loan repayment assistance to an eligible professional if the eligible professional:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(4)(a): agrees to practice in an underserved area for the duration of the eligible professional's participation in the program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(4)(b): submits a written commitment from the health care facility employing the eligible professional that the health care facility will provide education loan repayment assistance to the eligible professional in an amount equal to 20% of the total award amount provided to the eligible professional.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(5): Funding for the program:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(5)(a): shall be a line item within the appropriations act;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(5)(b): shall be nonlapsing unless designated otherwise by the Legislature; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(5)(c): may be used to cover administrative costs of the program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-702(6): Refunds for loan repayment assistance, penalties for breach of contract, and other payments to the program are dedicated credits to the program.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-703 Rural Physician Loan Repayment Program -- Purpose -- Repayment limit -- Funding -- Reporting -- Rulemaking -- Advisory committee.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-703(1): There is created within the department the Rural Physician Loan Repayment Program to provide, within funding appropriated by the Legislature for this purpose, education loan repayment assistance to physicians in accordance with Subsection (2).

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-703(2)(c): the physician is otherwise eligible for assistance under administrative rules adopted under Subsection (6).

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-703(3)(c)(i): 26B-1-423 including administrative support provided to the Rural Physician Loan Repayment Program Advisory Committee created under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-703(3)(c)(ii): in an amount not exceeding 10% of funding for the program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-703(4): Refunds of loan repayment assistance, penalties for breach of contract, and other payments to the program are dedicated credits to the program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-703(5): Before November 2025 and every five years thereafter, the department shall provide a report of the program's revenues, expenditures, and outcomes for the preceding five years to the Social Services Appropriations Subcommittee.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704 Scope of telehealth practice -- Enforcement.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1): Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection; Title 58, Occupations and Professions; Chapter 2, Part 1, Human Services Programs and Facilities As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(a): "Asynchronous store and forward transfer" means the transmission of a patient's health care information from an originating site to a provider at a distant site.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(b): "Distant site" means the physical location of a provider delivering telemedicine services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(c): "Originating site" means the physical location of a patient receiving telemedicine services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(d): "Patient" means an individual seeking telemedicine services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(e)(i): "Patient-generated medical history" means medical data about a patient that the patient creates, records, or gathers.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(e)(ii): "Patient-generated medical history" does not include a patient's medical record that a healthcare professional creates and the patient personally delivers to a different healthcare professional.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(f): Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection; Title 58, Occupations and Professions; Chapter 2, Part 1, Human Services Programs and Facilities "Provider" means an individual who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(f)(i): Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(f)(ii): Title 58, Occupations and Professions licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(f)(iii): Chapter 2, Part 1, Human Services Programs and Facilities licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(g): "Synchronous interaction" means real-time communication through interactive technology that enables a provider at a distant site and a patient at an originating site to interact simultaneously through two-way audio and video transmission.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(h): "Telehealth services" means the transmission of health-related services or information through the use of electronic communication or information technology.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(i): "Telemedicine services" means telehealth services:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(i)(i): including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(i)(i)(A): clinical care;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(i)(i)(B): health education;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(i)(i)(C): health administration;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(i)(i)(D): home health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(i)(i)(E): facilitation of self-managed care and caregiver support; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(i)(i)(F): remote patient monitoring occurring incidentally to general supervision; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(i)(ii): provided by a provider to a patient through a method of communication that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(i)(ii)(A): uses asynchronous store and forward transfer or synchronous interaction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(1)(i)(ii)(B): meets industry security and privacy standards, including compliance with the federal Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996, Pub. L. No. 104-191, 110 Stat. 1936, as amended, and the federal Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act, Pub. L. No. 111-5, 123 Stat. 226, 467, as amended.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(2): Title 58, Occupations and Professions; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 26B-3-126 A provider offering telehealth services shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(2)(a): Title 58, Occupations and Professions at all times:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(2)(a)(i): Title 58, Occupations and Professions act within the scope of the provider's license under
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(2)(a)(ii): be held to the same standards of practice as those applicable in traditional health care settings;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(2)(b): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act if the provider does not already have a provider-patient relationship with the patient, establish a provider-patient relationship during the patient encounter in a manner consistent with the standards of practice, determined by the Division of Professional Licensing in rule made in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(2)(c): before providing treatment or prescribing a prescription drug, establish a diagnosis and identify underlying conditions and contraindications to a recommended treatment after:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(2)(c)(i): obtaining from the patient or another provider the patient's relevant clinical history; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(2)(c)(ii): documenting the patient's relevant clinical history and current symptoms;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-704(2)(d): be available to a patient who receives telehealth services from the provider for subsequent care related to the initial telemedicine services, in accordance with community standards of practice;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-708 Duties of UMEC.
-----------------------------------------------
UMEC shall:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-708(1): seek private and public contributions for the program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-708(2): determine the method for reimbursing institutions that sponsor health care professionals in training;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-708(3): determine the number and type of positions for health care professionals in training for which program money may be used;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-708(4): distribute program money for graduate medical education in a manner that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-708(4)(a): prepares postgraduate medical residents, as defined by the accreditation council on graduate medical education, for inpatient, outpatient, hospital, community, and geographically diverse settings;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-708(4)(b): encourages the coordination of interdisciplinary clinical training among health care professionals in training;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-708(4)(c): promotes stable funding for the clinical training of health care professionals in training; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-708(4)(d): only funds accredited clinical training programs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-708(5): advise on the implementation of the program.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711 Residency grant program.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(1)(a): "D.O. program" means an osteopathic medical program that prepares a graduate to obtain licensure as a doctor of osteopathic medicine upon completing a state's licensing requirements.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(1)(b): "M.D. program" means a medical education program that prepares a graduate to obtain licensure as a doctor of medicine upon completing a state's licensing requirements.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(1)(c): "Residency program" means a program that provides training for graduates of a D.O. program or an M.D. program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(2): UMEC shall develop a grant program where a sponsoring institution in Utah may apply for a grant to establish a new residency program or expand a current residency program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(3): An applicant for a grant shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(3)(a): provide the proposed specialty area for each grant funded residency position;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(3)(b): identify where the grant funded residency position will provide care;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(3)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(3)(c)(i): provide proof that the residency program is accredited by the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(3)(c)(ii): identify what actions need to occur for the proposed residency program to become accredited by the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(3)(d): identify how a grant funded residency position will be funded once the residency program exhausts the grant money;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(3)(e): agree to implement selection processes for a residency position that treat applicants from D.O. programs and applicants from M.D. programs equally;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(3)(f): agree to provide information identified by UMEC that relates to post-residency employment outcomes for individuals who work in grant funded residency positions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(3)(g): provide any other information related to the grant application UMEC deems necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(4): UMEC shall prioritize awarding grants to new or existing residency programs that will:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(4)(a): address a workforce shortage, occurring in Utah, for a specialty; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(4)(b): serve an underserved population, including a rural population.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(5)(a): An applicant that receives a grant under this section may apply, every two years, to renew the grant for two years.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(5)(b): An applicant to renew a grant under Subsection (5)(a) shall provide a statement that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(5)(b)(i): the applicant applied for federal funding and was not awarded federal funding in an amount that fully funds each grant funded residency position; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(5)(b)(ii): the funding the applicant described in Subsection (3)(d) is unavailable to the applicant.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(6): Each November 1 until November 2026 and then every three years thereafter, the Health Workforce Advisory Council, in consultation with UMEC, shall provide a written report to the Higher Education Appropriations Subcommittee and the Social Services Appropriations Subcommittee describing:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(6)(a): which sponsoring institutions received a grant;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(6)(b): the number of residency positions created; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(6)(c): for each residency position created:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(6)(c)(i): the type of specialty;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(6)(c)(ii): where the residency position provides care; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-711(6)(c)(iii): an estimated date of when a grant funded residency position will no longer need grant funding.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-712 Forensic psychiatrist fellowship grant.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-712(1): As used in this section, "forensic psychiatry" means the provision of services by an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-712(1)(a): is a licensed physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-712(1)(b): is board certified or board eligible for a psychiatry specialization recognized by the American Board of Medical Specialists or the American Osteopathic Association's Bureau of Osteopathic Specialists; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-712(1)(c): uses scientific and clinical expertise in legal contexts involving the mental health of individuals.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-712(2): UMEC shall establish a grant program that will facilitate the creation of a single forensic psychiatrist fellowship program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-712(3): An applicant for the grant shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-712(3)(a): demonstrate how the applicant is best suited for developing a forensic psychiatry fellowship program, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-712(3)(a)(i): a description of resources that would be available to the program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-712(3)(a)(ii): any resources or staff that need to be acquired for the program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-712(3)(b): identify what needs to occur for the proposed residency program to become accredited by the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-712(3)(c): provide an estimate of how many individuals would be trained in the program at any one time;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-712(3)(d): provide any information related to the grant application UMEC deems necessary for awarding the grant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-712(3)(e): if awarded the grant, agree to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-712(3)(e)(i): enter into a contract with the Department of Corrections that the applicant will provide for the provision of forensic psychiatry services to an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-712(3)(e)(i)(A): who needs psychiatric services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-712(3)(e)(i)(B): is under the Department of Corrections' jurisdiction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-712(3)(e)(ii): ensure that any individual hired to provide forensic psychiatry services will comply with all relevant:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-712(3)(e)(ii)(A): national licensing requirements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-712(3)(e)(ii)(B): state licensing requirements under Title 58, Occupations and Professions.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-803 Regulation of services during emergency.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-803(1): During an emergency, the department or a local health department may limit, restrict, or otherwise regulate:

Sec. 247d-7b, as amended;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-804(1)(d)(iii)(E): governmental entity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-804(1)(d)(iv): be designated by the department as a registration system for purposes of this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-806 No effect on credentialing and privileging.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-806(1): For purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-806(1)(a): "Credentialing" means obtaining, verifying, and assessing the qualifications of a health practitioner to provide treatment, care, or services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-806(1)(b): "Privileging" means the authorizing by an appropriate authority of a health practitioner to provide specific treatment, care, or services at a health facility subject to limits based on factors that include license, education, training, experience, competence, health status, and specialized skill.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-806(2): This part does not affect credentialing or privileging standards of a health facility, and does not preclude a health facility from waiving or modifying those standards during an emergency.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-4-812 Uniformity of application and construction.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
In applying and construing this part, consideration shall be given to the need to promote uniformity of the law with respect to its subject matter among states that enact it.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 26B - Chapter 5 - Health Care - Substance Use and Mental Health
*******************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101 Chapter definitions.
----------------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(1): "Criminal risk factors" means a person's characteristics and behaviors that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(1)(a): affect the person's risk of engaging in criminal behavior; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(1)(b): are diminished when addressed by effective treatment, supervision, and other support resources, resulting in reduced risk of criminal behavior.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(2): 26B-5-103 "Director" means the director appointed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(3): 26B-1-1202 "Division" means the Division of Integrated Healthcare created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(4): "Local mental health authority" means a county legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(5): "Local substance abuse authority" means a county legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(6): "Mental health crisis" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(6)(a): a mental health condition that manifests in an individual by symptoms of sufficient severity that a prudent layperson who possesses an average knowledge of mental health issues could reasonably expect the absence of immediate attention or intervention to result in:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(6)(a)(i): serious danger to the individual's health or well-being; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(6)(a)(ii): a danger to the health or well-being of others; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(6)(b): a mental health condition that, in the opinion of a mental health therapist or the therapist's designee, requires direct professional observation or intervention.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(7): "Mental health crisis response training" means community-based training that educates laypersons and professionals on the warning signs of a mental health crisis and how to respond.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(8): "Mental health crisis services" means an array of services provided to an individual who experiences a mental health crisis, which may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(8)(a): direct mental health services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(8)(b): on-site intervention provided by a mobile crisis outreach team;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(8)(c): the provision of safety and care plans;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(8)(d): prolonged mental health services for up to 90 days after the day on which an individual experiences a mental health crisis;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(8)(e): referrals to other community resources;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(8)(f): local mental health crisis lines; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(8)(g): the statewide mental health crisis line.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(9): 58-60-102 "Mental health therapist" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(10): "Mobile crisis outreach team" or "MCOT" means a mobile team of medical and mental health professionals that, in coordination with local law enforcement and emergency medical service personnel, provides mental health crisis services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(11): 26B-5-102 "Office" means the Office of Substance Use and Mental Health created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(12): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(12)(a): "Public funds" means federal money received from the department, and state money appropriated by the Legislature to the department, a county governing body, or a local substance abuse authority, or a local mental health authority for the purposes of providing substance abuse or mental health programs or services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(12)(b): "Public funds" include federal and state money that has been transferred by a local substance abuse authority or a local mental health authority to a private provider under an annual or otherwise ongoing contract to provide comprehensive substance abuse or mental health programs or services for the local substance abuse authority or local mental health authority. The money maintains the nature of "public funds" while in the possession of the private entity that has an annual or otherwise ongoing contract with a local substance abuse authority or a local mental health authority to provide comprehensive substance use or mental health programs or services for the local substance abuse authority or local mental health authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(12)(c): Public funds received for the provision of services under substance use or mental health service plans may not be used for any other purpose except those authorized in the contract between the local mental health or substance abuse authority and provider for the provision of plan services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(13): "Severe mental disorder" means schizophrenia, major depression, bipolar disorders, delusional disorders, psychotic disorders, and other mental disorders as defined by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(14): "Stabilization services" means in-home services provided to a child with, or who is at risk for, complex emotional and behavioral needs, including teaching the child's parent or guardian skills to improve family functioning.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(15): 26B-5-610 "Statewide mental health crisis line" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(16): "System of care" means a broad, flexible array of services and supports that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(16)(a): serve a child with or who is at risk for complex emotional and behavioral needs;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(16)(b): are community based;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(16)(c): are informed about trauma;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(16)(d): build meaningful partnerships with families and children;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(16)(e): integrate service planning, service coordination, and management across state and local entities;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(16)(f): include individualized case planning;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(16)(g): provide management and policy infrastructure that supports a coordinated network of interdepartmental service providers, contractors, and service providers who are outside of the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(16)(h): are guided by the type and variety of services needed by a child with or who is at risk for complex emotional and behavioral needs and by the child's family.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-101(17): "Targeted case management" means a service that assists Medicaid recipients in a target group to gain access to needed medical, social, educational, and other services.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102 Division of Integrated Healthcare -- Office of Substance Use and Mental Health -- Creation -- Responsibilities.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(1)(a): The Division of Integrated Healthcare shall exercise responsibility over the policymaking functions, regulatory and enforcement powers, rights, duties, and responsibilities outlined in state law that were previously vested in the Division of Substance Abuse and Mental Health within the department, under the administration and general supervision of the executive director.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(1)(b): The division is the substance abuse authority and the mental health authority for this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(1)(c): There is created the Office of Substance Use and Mental Health within the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(1)(d): The office shall exercise the responsibilities, powers, rights, duties, and responsibilities assigned to the office by the executive director.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2): 26B-5-313; 17-43-201; 17-43-301; 63M-7-102; 63M-7-204; 13-53-102 The division shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(a)(i): educate the general public regarding the nature and consequences of substance use by promoting school and community-based prevention programs;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(a)(ii): render support and assistance to public schools through approved school-based substance abuse education programs aimed at prevention of substance use;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(a)(iii): promote or establish programs for the prevention of substance use within the community setting through community-based prevention programs;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(a)(iv): cooperate with and assist treatment centers, recovery residences, and other organizations that provide services to individuals recovering from a substance use disorder, by identifying and disseminating information about effective practices and programs;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(a)(v): promote integrated programs that address an individual's substance use, mental health, and physical health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(a)(vi): establish and promote an evidence-based continuum of screening, assessment, prevention, treatment, and recovery support services in the community for individuals with a substance use disorder or mental illness;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(a)(vii): evaluate the effectiveness of programs described in this Subsection (2);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(a)(viii): consider the impact of the programs described in this Subsection (2) on:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(a)(viii)(A): emergency department utilization;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(a)(viii)(B): jail and prison populations;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(a)(viii)(C): the homeless population; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(a)(viii)(D): the child welfare system; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(a)(ix): promote or establish programs for education and certification of instructors to educate individuals convicted of driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs or driving with any measurable controlled substance in the body;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(b): 26B-5-313
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(b)(i): collect and disseminate information pertaining to mental health;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(b)(iii): make rules in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to educate families concerning mental illness and promote family involvement, when appropriate, and with patient consent, in the treatment program of a family member;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(b)(iv): 26B-5-313 make rules in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to direct that an individual receiving services through a local mental health authority or the Utah State Hospital be informed about and, if desired by the individual, provided assistance in the completion of a declaration for mental health treatment in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(b)(v): to the extent authorized and in accordance with statute, make rules in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(b)(v)(A): create a certification for targeted case management;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(b)(v)(B): establish training and certification requirements;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(b)(v)(C): specify the types of services each certificate holder is qualified to provide;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(b)(v)(D): specify the type of supervision under which a certificate holder is required to operate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(b)(v)(E): specify continuing education and other requirements for maintaining or renewing certification;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(c)(i): consult and coordinate with local substance abuse authorities and local mental health authorities regarding programs and services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(c)(ii): provide consultation and other assistance to public and private agencies and groups working on substance use and mental health issues;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(c)(iii): promote and establish cooperative relationships with courts, hospitals, clinics, medical and social agencies, public health authorities, law enforcement agencies, education and research organizations, and other related groups;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(c)(xiv): withhold funds from local substance abuse authorities, local mental health authorities, and public and private providers for contract noncompliance, failure to comply with division directives regarding the use of public funds, or for misuse of public funds or money;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-102(2)(d): ensure that the requirements of this part are met and applied uniformly by local substance abuse authorities and local mental health authorities across the state;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-106 Authority to assess fees.
---------------------------------------------------------
The division may, with the approval of the Legislature and the executive director, establish fee schedules and assess fees for services rendered by the division.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-107(1)(b): The formulas shall provide for allocation of funds based on need.  Determination of need shall be based on population unless the division establishes, by valid and accepted data, that other defined factors are relevant and reliable indicators of need.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-107(2)(a): funds that local substance abuse authorities and local mental health authorities receive from sources other than the division;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-107(2)(d): funds that local substance abuse authorities and local mental health authorities receive from the division for research projects.
