Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-112.5 Mobile Crisis Outreach Team Grant Program.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-112.5(1): 63C-18-202 As used in this section, "committee" means the Behavioral Health Crisis Response Committee established in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-112.5(2): The committee shall provide recommendations and the division shall award grants for the development of up to five mobile crisis outreach teams.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-112.5(3): A mobile crisis outreach team that is awarded a grant under Subsection (2) shall provide mental health crisis services 24 hours per day, seven days per week, and every day of the year.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-112.5(4): The division shall prioritize the award of a grant described in Subsection (2) to entities based on:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-112.5(4)(a): the outstanding need for crisis outreach services within the area the proposed mobile crisis outreach team will serve; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-112.5(4)(b): the capacity for implementation of the proposed mobile crisis outreach team in accordance with the division's established standards and requirements for mobile crisis outreach teams.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-112.5(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-112.5(5)(a): In consultation with the committee, the division shall make rules, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, for the application and award of the grants described in Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-112.5(5)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-112.5(5)(b)(i): The rules created under Subsection (5)(a) shall implement a funding structure for a mobile crisis outreach team developed using a grant awarded under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-112.5(5)(b)(ii): The funding structure described in Subsection (5)(b)(i) shall provide for tiers and phases of shared funding coverage between the state and counties.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-113 Medicaid reimbursement for school-based health services -- Report to Legislature.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-113(1): As used in this section, "individualized education program" or "IEP" means a written statement for a student with a disability that is developed, reviewed, and revised in accordance with the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, 20 U.S.C. Sec. 1400 et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-113(2): The division shall coordinate with the State Board of Education, the Department of Health, and stakeholders to address and develop recommendations related to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-113(2)(a): the expansion of Medicaid reimbursement for school-based health services, including how to expand Medicaid-eligible school-based services beyond the services for students with IEPs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-113(2)(b): other areas concerning Medicaid reimbursement for school-based health services, including the time threshold for medically necessary IEP services.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114 Behavioral Health Receiving Center Grant Program.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(1): 63C-18-202 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(1)(a): "Behavioral health receiving center" means a 23-hour nonsecure program or facility that is responsible for, and provides mental health crisis services to, an individual experiencing a mental health crisis.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(1)(b): 63C-18-202 "Committee" means the Behavioral Health Crisis Response Committee established in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(1)(c): "Project" means a behavioral health receiving center project described in Subsection (2) or (3)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(2): 17-50-501 Before July 1, 2020, the division shall issue a request for proposals in accordance with this section to award a grant to one or more counties of the first or second class, as classified in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(3)(a): Before July 1, 2023, the division shall issue a request for proposals in accordance with this section to award a grant to one county of the third class, as classified in Section 17-50- 501, to develop and implement a behavioral health receiving center.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(3)(b): Subject to appropriations by the Legislature, the division shall award grants under this Subsection (3) before December 31, 2023.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(3)(c): The committee shall provide recommendations to the division regarding the development and implementation of a behavioral health receiving center.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(4): The purpose of a project is to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(4)(a): increase access to mental health crisis services for individuals in the state who are experiencing a mental health crisis; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(4)(b): reduce the number of individuals in the state who are incarcerated or in a hospital emergency room while experiencing a mental health crisis.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(5): An application for a grant under this section shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(5)(a): identify the population to which the behavioral health receiving center will provide mental health crisis services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(5)(b): identify the type of mental health crisis services the behavioral health receiving center will provide;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(5)(c): explain how the population described in Subsection (5)(a) will benefit from the provision of mental health crisis services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(5)(d): provide details regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(5)(d)(i): how the proposed project plans to provide mental health crisis services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(5)(d)(ii): how the proposed project will ensure that consideration is given to the capacity of the behavioral health receiving center;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(5)(d)(iii): how the proposed project will ensure timely and effective provision of mental health crisis services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(5)(d)(iv): the cost of the proposed project;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(5)(d)(v): any existing or planned contracts or partnerships between the applicant and other individuals or entities to develop and implement the proposed project;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(5)(d)(vi): any plan to use funding sources in addition to a grant under this section for the proposed project;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(5)(d)(vii): the sustainability of the proposed project; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(5)(d)(viii): the methods the proposed project will use to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(5)(d)(viii)(A): protect the privacy of each individual who receives mental health crisis services from the behavioral health receiving center;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(5)(d)(viii)(B): collect nonidentifying data relating to the proposed project; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(5)(d)(viii)(C): provide transparency on the costs and operation of the proposed project; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(5)(e): provide other information requested by the division to ensure that the proposed project satisfies the criteria described in Subsection (7).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(6): A recipient of a grant under this section shall enroll as a Medicaid provider and meet minimum standards of care for behavioral health receiving centers established by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(7): In evaluating an application for the grant, the division shall consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(7)(a): the extent to which the proposed project will fulfill the purposes described in Subsection (4);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(7)(b): the extent to which the population described in Subsection (5)(a) is likely to benefit from the proposed project;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(7)(c): the cost of the proposed project;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(7)(d): the extent to which any existing or planned contracts or partnerships between the applicant and other individuals or entities to develop and implement the project, or additional funding sources available to the applicant for the proposed project, are likely to benefit the proposed project; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(7)(e): the viability and innovation of the proposed project.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(8)(a): In consultation with the committee, the division shall make rules, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, for the application and award of a grant under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(8)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(8)(b)(i): The rules created under Subsection (8)(a) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(8)(b)(i)(A): implement a funding structure for a behavioral health receiving center developed using a grant awarded under this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(8)(b)(i)(B): include implementation standards and minimum program requirements for a behavioral health receiving center developed using a grant awarded under this section, including minimum guidelines and standards of care, and minimum staffing requirements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(8)(b)(i)(C): require a behavioral health receiving center developed using a grant awarded under this section to operate 24 hours per day, seven days per week, and every day of the year.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(8)(b)(ii): The funding structure described in Subsection (8)(b)(i)(A) shall provide for tiers and phases of shared funding coverage between the state and counties.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(9): Before June 30, 2024, the division shall report to the Health and Human Services Interim Committee regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(9)(a): grants awarded under Subsection (3)(a); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(9)(b): the details of each project described in Subsection (3)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-114(10): Before June 30, 2026, the division shall provide a report to the Health and Human Services Interim Committee that includesdata gathered in relation to each project described in Subsection (3)(a).


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-115 Safety Net Initiative.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-115(1): As used in this section, "individuals in underserved communities" means individuals living in culturally isolated communities in the state who may lack access to public assistance and other government services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-115(2): There is created within the division the Safety Net Initiative to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-115(2)(a): implement strategies to increase awareness and reduce risk factors in order to improve the safety and well-being of individuals in underserved communities;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-115(2)(b): coordinate with government agencies, nonprofit organizations, and interested individuals to provide open communication with individuals in underserved communities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-115(2)(c): coordinate efforts to give individuals in underserved communities needed access to public assistance and other government services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-115(3): The division may employ or contract with individuals, entities, and support staff as necessary to administer the duties required by this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116 Suicide prevention technical assistance program.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(1): As used in this section, "technical assistance" means training for the prevention of suicide.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(2)(a): Before July 1, 2021, and each subsequent July 1, the division shall solicit applications from health care organizations to receive technical assistance provided by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(2)(b): The division shall approve at least one but not more than six applications each year.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(2)(c): The division shall determine which applicants receive the technical assistance before December 31 of each year.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(3): An application for technical assistance under this section shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(3)(a): identify the population to whom the health care organization will provide suicide prevention services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(3)(b): identify how the health care organization plans to implement the skills and knowledge gained from the technical assistance;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(3)(c): identify the health care organization's current resources used for the prevention of suicide;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(3)(d): explain how the population described in Subsection (3)(a) will benefit from the health care organization receiving technical assistance;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(3)(e): provide details regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(3)(e)(i): how the health care organization will provide timely and effective suicide prevention services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(3)(e)(ii): any existing or planned contracts or partnerships between the health care organization and other persons that are related to suicide prevention; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(3)(e)(iii): the methods the health care organization will use to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(3)(e)(iii)(A): protect the privacy of each individual to whom the health care organization provides suicide prevention services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(3)(e)(iii)(B): collect non-identifying data; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(3)(f): provide other information requested by the division for the division to evaluate the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(4): In evaluating an application for technical assistance, the division shall consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(4)(a): the extent to which providing technical assistance to the health care organization will fulfill the purpose of preventing suicides in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(4)(b): the extent to which the population described in Subsection (3)(a) is likely to benefit from the health care organization receiving the technical assistance;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(4)(c): the cost of providing the technical assistance to the health care organization; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(4)(d): the extent to which any of the following are likely to benefit the heath care organization's ability to assist in preventing suicides in the state:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(4)(d)(i): existing or planned contracts or partnerships between the applicant and other persons to develop and implement other initiatives; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-116(4)(d)(ii): additional funding sources available to the applicant for suicide prevention services.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-119 Forms.
--------------------------------------
The division shall furnish the clerks of the court with forms, blanks, warrants, and certificates, to enable judges, with regularity and facility, to comply with the provisions of this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-120 Virtual crisis outreach team grant program.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-120(1): 26B-5-610; 63C-18-202; 26B-5-609 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-120(1)(a): 26B-5-610 "Certified peer support specialist" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-120(1)(b): 63C-18-202 "Committee" means the Behavioral Health Crisis Response Committee established in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-120(1)(c): 26B-5-609 "Mobile crisis outreach team" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-120(1)(d): "Virtual crisis outreach program" means a program that provides the following real-time services 24 hours per day, seven days per week, and every day of the year:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-120(1)(d)(i): crisis support, by a qualified mental or behavioral health professional, to law enforcement officers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-120(1)(d)(ii): peer support services, by a certified peer support specialist, to individuals experiencing behavioral health crises.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-120(2): In consultation with the committee and in accordance with the requirements of this section, the division shall award a grant for the development of a virtual crisis outreach program that primarily serves counties of the third, fourth, fifth, or sixth class.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-120(3): The division shall prioritize the award of the grant described in Subsection (2) based on the extent to which providing the grant to the applicant will increase the provision of crisis support and peer support services in areas:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-120(3)(a): with frequent mental or behavioral health provider shortages; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-120(3)(b): where only one mobile crisis outreach team is available to serve multiple counties of the third, fourth, fifth, or sixth class.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-120(4): When not providing crisis support or peer support services to law enforcement or individuals in a county of the third, fourth, fifth, or sixth class, the virtual crisis outreach program developed using a grant under this section shall provide support services as needed to mobile crisis outreach teams in counties of the first or second class.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-120(5): In consultation with the committee, the division may make rules, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, for the application and award of the grant described in Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-120(6): Before June 30, 2024, the division shall submit a written report to the Health and Human Services Interim Committee regarding the virtual crisis outreach program developed using the grant awarded under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-120(7): Before June 30, 2026, the division shall submit a written report to the Health and Human Services Interim Committee regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-120(7)(a): data gathered in relation to the rural virtual crisis outreach team developed using the grant awarded under this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-120(7)(b): knowledge gained relating to the provision of virtual crisis outreach services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-120(7)(c): recommendations for the future use of virtual crisis outreach services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-120(7)(d): obstacles encountered in the provision of virtual crisis outreach services.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-201 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-201(1): 78A-6-103 "Juvenile substance use offender" means any minor who has committed a drug or alcohol related offense under the jurisdiction of the juvenile court in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-201(2): 17-43-201 "Local substance abuse authority" means a county legislative body designated to provide substance abuse services in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-201(3): 80-1-102 "Minor" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-201(4): "Teen substance use school" means any school established by the local substance abuse authority, in cooperation with the Board of Juvenile Court Judges, that provides an educational, interpersonal, skill-building experience for juvenile substance abuse offenders and their parents or legal guardians.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-202 Teen substance use schools -- Establishment.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
The division or a local substance abuse authority, in cooperation with the Board of Juvenile Court Judges, may establish teen substance use schools in the districts of the juvenile court.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-203 Court order to attend substance use school -- Assessments.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-203(1): 80-6-701 In addition to any other disposition ordered by the juvenile court under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-203(1)(a): a minor and the minor's parent or legal guardian to attend a teen substance use school; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-203(1)(b): payment of an assessment in addition to any other fine imposed.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-203(2): All assessments collected shall be forwarded to the county treasurer of the county where the minor resides, to be used exclusively for the operation of a teen substance use program.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-204 Commitment of minor to secure drug or alcohol facility or program -- Procedures -- Review.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-204(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-204(1)(a): "Approved treatment facility or program" means a public or private secure, inpatient facility or program that is licensed or operated by the department to provide drug or alcohol treatment or rehabilitation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-204(1)(b): "Drug or alcohol addiction" means that the person has a physical or psychological dependence on drugs or alcohol in a manner not prescribed by a physician.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-204(2): The parent or legal guardian of a minor under 18 years old may submit that child, without the child's consent, to an approved treatment facility or program for treatment or rehabilitation of drug or alcohol addiction, upon application to a facility or program, and after a careful diagnostic inquiry is made by a neutral and detached fact finder, in accordance with the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-204(3): The neutral fact finder who conducts the inquiry:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-204(3)(a): shall be either a physician, psychologist, marriage and family therapist, psychiatric and mental health nurse specialist, or social worker licensed to practice in this state, who is trained and practicing in the area of substance use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-204(3)(b): may not profit, financially or otherwise, from the commitment of the child and may not be employed by the proposed facility or program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-204(4): The review by a neutral fact finder may be conducted on the premises of the proposed treatment facility or program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-204(5): The inquiry conducted by the neutral fact finder shall include a private interview with the child, and an evaluation of the child's background and need for treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-204(6): The child may be committed to the approved treatment facility or program if it is determined by the neutral fact finder that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-204(6)(a): the child is addicted to drugs or alcohol and because of that addiction poses a serious risk of harm to himself or others;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-204(6)(b): the proposed treatment or rehabilitation is in the child's best interest; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-204(6)(c): there is no less restrictive alternative that would be equally as effective, from a clinical standpoint, as the proposed treatment facility or program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-204(7): (6) Any approved treatment facility or program that receives a child under this section shall conduct a periodic review, at intervals not to exceed 30 days, to determine whether the criteria described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-204(8): A minor committed under this section shall be released from the facility or program upon the request of his parent or legal guardian.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-204(9): Commitment of a minor under this section terminates when the minor reaches the age of 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-204(10): Nothing in this section requires a program or facility to accept any person for treatment or rehabilitation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-204(11): The parent or legal guardian who requests commitment of a minor under this section is responsible to pay any fee associated with the review required by this section and any necessary charges for commitment, treatment, or rehabilitation for a minor committed under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-204(12): The child shall be released from commitment unless the report of the neutral fact finder is submitted to the juvenile court within 72 hours of commitment and approved by the court.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-207 DUI -- Legislative policy -- Rehabilitation treatment and evaluation -- Use of victim impact panels.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Legislature finds that drivers impaired by alcohol or drugs constitute a major problem in this state and that the problem demands a comprehensive detection, intervention, education, and treatment program including emergency services, outpatient treatment, detoxification, residential care, inpatient care, medical and psychological care, social service care, vocational rehabilitation, and career counseling through public and private agencies.  It is the policy of this state to provide those programs at the expense of persons convicted of driving while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or drugs. It is also the policy of this state to utilize victim impact panels to assist persons convicted of driving under the influence of intoxicating liquor or drugs to gain a full understanding of the severity of their offense.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-210 Policy -- Alternatives to incarceration.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is the policy of this state to provide adequate and appropriate health and social services as alternatives to incarceration for public intoxication.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part,Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(1): "Adult" means an individual 18 years old or older.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(2): 26B-5-102(2)(j) "Approved treatment facility or program" means a mental health or substance use treatment provider that meets the goals and measurements described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(5): "Attorney-in-fact" means an adult properly appointed under this part to make mental health treatment decisions for a declarant under a declaration for mental health treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(6): "Commitment to the custody of a local mental health authority" means that an adult is committed to the custody of the local mental health authority that governs the mental health catchment area where the adult resides or is found.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(7): "Community mental health center" means an entity that provides treatment and services to a resident of a designated geographical area, that operates by or under contract with a local mental health authority, and that complies with state standards for community mental health centers.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(8): "Designated examiner" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(8)(a): a licensed physician, preferably a psychiatrist, who is designated by the division as specially qualified by training or experience in the diagnosis of mental or related illness; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(8)(b): a licensed mental health professional designated by the division as specially qualified by training and who has at least five years' continual experience in the treatment of mental illness.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(9): 17-43-304 "Designee" means a physician who has responsibility for medical functions including admission and discharge, an employee of a local mental health authority, or an employee of a person that has contracted with a local mental health authority to provide mental health services under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(10): "Essential treatment" and "essential treatment and intervention" mean court-ordered treatment at a local substance abuse authority or an approved treatment facility or program for the treatment of an adult's substance use disorder.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(11): 76-5-406(2)(a); (l) "Harmful sexual conduct" means the following conduct upon an individual without the individual's consent, including the nonconsensual circumstances described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(11)(a): sexual intercourse;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(11)(b): penetration, however slight, of the genital or anal opening of the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(11)(c): any sexual act involving the genitals or anus of the actor or the individual and the mouth or anus of either individual, regardless of the gender of either participant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(11)(d): any sexual act causing substantial emotional injury or bodily pain.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(12): "Informed waiver" means the patient was informed of a right and, after being informed of that right and the patient's right to waive the right, expressly communicated his or her intention to waive that right.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(13): Title 75, Utah Uniform Probate Code "Incapable" means that, in the opinion of the court in a guardianship proceeding under

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(17): "Mental health officer" means an individual who is designated by a local mental health authority as qualified by training and experience in the recognition and identification of mental illness, to:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(18): "Mental illness" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(18)(a): a psychiatric disorder that substantially impairs an individual's mental, emotional, behavioral, or related functioning; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(18)(b): the same as that term is defined in:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(18)(b)(i): the current edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders published by the American Psychiatric Association; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(18)(b)(ii): the current edition of the International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(19): "Mental health treatment" means convulsive treatment, treatment with psychoactive medication, or admission to and retention in a facility for a period not to exceed 17 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(20): "Patient" means an individual who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(20)(a): under commitment to the custody or to the treatment services of a local mental health authority; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(20)(b): undergoing essential treatment and intervention.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(21): Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act "Physician" means an individual who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(21)(a): Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act licensed as a physician under
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(21)(b): Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act licensed as a physician under
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(22): "Serious bodily injury" means bodily injury that involves a substantial risk of death, unconsciousness, extreme physical pain, protracted and obvious disfigurement, or protracted loss or impairment of the function of a bodily member, organ, or mental faculty.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(23): 26B-5-302 "State hospital" means the Utah State Hospital established in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(24): "Substantial danger" means that due to mental illness, an individual is at serious risk of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(24)(a): suicide;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(24)(b): serious bodily self-injury;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(24)(c): serious bodily injury because the individual is incapable of providing the basic necessities of life, including food, clothing, or shelter;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(24)(d): causing or attempting to cause serious bodily injury to another individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(24)(e): engaging in harmful sexual conduct; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(24)(f): if not treated, suffering severe and abnormal mental, emotional, or physical distress that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(24)(f)(i): is associated with significant impairment of judgment, reason, or behavior; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(24)(f)(ii): causes a substantial deterioration of the individual's previous ability to function independently.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-301(25): "Treatment" means psychotherapy, medication, including the administration of psychotropic medication, or other medical treatments that are generally accepted medical or psychosocial interventions for the purpose of restoring the patient to an optimal level of functioning in the least restrictive environment.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-302 Utah State Hospital.
----------------------------------------------------
The Utah State Hospital is established and located in Provo, in Utah county.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-302.5 Study concerning civil commitment and the Utah State Hospital.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-302.5(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-302.5(1)(a): The Utah Substance Use and Mental Health Advisory Committee shall study and make recommendations concerning the need for expanded civil commitment capacity in the state, including an analysis of the anticipated impact that any changes to civil commitment standards made during the 2024 General Session will have on the number of individuals subject to civil commitment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-302.5(1)(b): The study and recommendations described in Subsection (1)(a) shall also address the role of the Utah State Hospital in serving patients who are subject to court-ordered treatment, including civil commitment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-302.5(1)(c): The study and recommendations described in Subsection (1)(a) shall also address any additional resources or services needed to decrease the likelihood that individuals who are subject to court-ordered treatment, including civil commitment, will enter or reenter the Utah State Hospital or another inpatient facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-302.5(2): The Utah Substance Use and Mental Health Advisory Committee shall provide a report on the study and recommendations described in Subsection (1) to the Judiciary Interim Committee at or before the committee's October 2024 interim meeting.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-303 Administration of state hospital -- Division -- Authority.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-303(1): The division shall administer the state hospital as part of the state's comprehensive mental health program and, to the fullest extent possible, shall, as the state hospital's administrator, coordinate with local mental health authority programs.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-303(2): The division has the same powers, duties, rights, and responsibilities as, and shall perform the same functions that by law are conferred or required to be discharged or performed by, the state hospital.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-303(3): Supervision and administration of security responsibilities for the state hospital is vested in the division. The executive director shall designate, as special function officers, individuals with peace officer authority to perform special security functions for the state hospital.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-303(4): 76-8-311.1 A director of a mental health facility that houses an involuntary patient or a patient committed by judicial order may establish secure areas, as provided in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-304 Appointment of superintendent -- Qualifications -- Powers and responsibilities.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-304(1): The director, with the consent of the executive director, shall appoint a superintendent of the state hospital, who shall hold office at the will of the director.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-304(2): The superintendent shall have a bachelor's degree from an accredited university or college, be experienced in administration, and be knowledgeable in matters concerning mental health.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-304(3): The superintendent has general responsibility for the buildings, grounds, and property of the state hospital.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-304(4): The superintendent shall appoint, with the approval of the director, as many employees as necessary for the efficient and economical care and management of the state hospital, and shall fix the employees' compensation and administer personnel functions according to the standards of the Division of Human Resource Management.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-305 Clinical director -- Appointment -- Conditions and procedure -- Duties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-305(1): Whenever the superintendent is not qualified to be the clinical director of the state hospital under this section, the superintendent shall, with the approval of the director of the division, appoint a clinical director who is licensed to practice medicine and surgery in this state, and who has had at least three years' training in a psychiatric residency program approved by the American Board of Psychiatry and Neurology, Inc., and who is eligible for certification by that board.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-305(2): The salary of the clinical director of the state hospital shall be fixed by the standards of the Division of Finance, to be paid in the same manner as the salaries of other employees.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-305(3): The clinical director shall perform such duties as directed by the superintendent and prescribed by the rules of the board, and shall prescribe and direct the treatment of patients and adopt sanitary measures for their welfare.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-305(4): If the superintendent is qualified to be the clinical director, the superintendent may assume the duties of the clinical director.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-306 Objectives of state hospital and other facilities -- Persons who may be admitted to state hospital.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-306(1): The objectives of the state hospital and other mental health facilities shall be to care for all persons within this state who are subject to the provisions of this chapter; and to furnish them with the proper attendance, medical treatment, seclusion, rest, restraint, amusement, occupation, and support that is conducive to their physical and mental well-being.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-306(2): Part 4, Commitment of Persons under Age 18; Title 77, Chapter 16a, Commitment and Treatment of Individuals with a Mental Condition; 77-16a-302; 77-15-6; Title 77, Utah Code of Criminal Procedure; 26B-5-372 Only the following persons may be admitted to the state hospital:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-306(2)(a): persons 18 years old and older who meet the criteria necessary for commitment under this part and who have severe mental disorders for whom no appropriate, less restrictive treatment alternative is available;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-306(2)(b): Part 4, Commitment of Persons under Age 18 persons under 18 years old who meet the criteria necessary for commitment under
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-306(2)(c): Title 77, Chapter 16a, Commitment and Treatment of Individuals with a Mental Condition persons adjudicated and found to be guilty with a mental condition under

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-307 Additional powers of director -- Reports and records of division.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-307(1): In addition to specific authority granted by other provisions of this part, the director has authority to prescribe the form of applications, records, reports, and medical certificates provided for under this part, and the information required to be contained therein, and to adopt rules that are not inconsistent with the provisions of this part that the director finds to be reasonably necessary for the proper and efficient commitment of persons with a mental illness.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-307(2): The division shall require reports relating to the admission, examination, diagnosis, release, or discharge of any patient and investigate complaints made by any patient or by any person on behalf of a patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-307(3): A local mental health authority shall keep a record of the names and current status of all persons involuntarily committed to it under this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-308 Standards for care and treatment.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Every patient is entitled to humane care and treatment and to medical care and treatment in accordance with the prevailing standards accepted in medical practice, psychiatric nursing practice, social work practice, and the practice of clinical psychology.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-309 Mechanical restraints and medication -- Clinical record.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-309(1): Mechanical restraints may not be applied to a patient unless it is determined by the director or his designee to be required by the needs of the patient. Every use of a mechanical restraint and the reasons therefor shall be made a part of the patient's clinical record, under the signature of the director or his designee, and shall be reviewed regularly.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-309(2): In no event shall medication be prescribed for a patient unless it is determined by a physician to be required by the patient's medical needs. Every use of a medication and the reasons therefor shall be made a part of the patient's clinical record.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-310 Restrictions and limitations -- Civil rights and privileges.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-310(1): Subject to the general rules of the division, and except to the extent that the director or his designee determines that it is necessary for the welfare of the patient to impose restrictions, every patient is entitled to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-310(1)(a): communicate, by sealed mail or otherwise, with persons, including official agencies, inside or outside the facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-310(1)(b): receive visitors; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-310(1)(c): exercise all civil rights, including the right to dispose of property, execute instruments, make purchases, enter contractual relationships, and vote, unless the patient has been adjudicated to be incompetent and has not been restored to legal capacity.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-310(2): When any right of a patient is limited or denied, the nature, extent, and reason for that limitation or denial shall be entered in the patient's treatment record. Any continuing denial or limitation shall be reviewed every 30 days and shall also be entered in that treatment record. Notice of that continuing denial in excess of 30 days shall be sent to the division, the appropriate local mental health authority, the appropriate local substance abuse authority, or an approved treatment facility or program, whichever is most applicable to the patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-310(3): Notwithstanding any limitations authorized under this section on the right of communication, each patient is entitled to communicate by sealed mail with the appropriate local mental health authority, the appropriate local substance abuse authority, an approved treatment facility or program, the division, the patient's attorney, and the court, if any, that ordered the patient's commitment or essential treatment. In no case may the patient be denied a visit with the legal counsel or clergy of the patient's choice.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-310(4): Local mental health authorities, local substance abuse authorities, and approved treatment facilities or programs shall provide reasonable means and arrangements for informing involuntary patients of their right to release as provided in this chapter, and for assisting them in making and presenting requests for release.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-310(5): Mental health facilities, local substance abuse authorities, and approved treatment facilities or programs shall post a statement, created by the division, describing a patient's rights under Utah law.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-310(6): 53B-17-303 Notwithstanding Section


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-311 Habeas corpus.
----------------------------------------------
Any individual detained pursuant to this part is entitled to the writ of habeas corpus upon proper petition by themselves or a friend, to the court in the county in which the individual is detained.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-312 Confidentiality of information and records -- Exceptions -- Penalty.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-312(1): 53-10-208.1 All certificates, applications, records, and reports made for the purpose of this part, including those made on judicial proceedings for involuntary commitment, that directly or indirectly identify a patient or former patient or an individual whose commitment has been sought under this part, shall be kept confidential and may not be disclosed by any person except insofar as:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-312(1)(a): the individual identified or his legal guardian, if any, or, if a minor, his parent or legal guardian shall consent;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-312(1)(b): 53-10-208.1 disclosure may be necessary to carry out the provisions of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-312(1)(b)(i): this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-312(1)(b)(ii): 53-10-208.1 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-312(1)(c): a court may direct, upon its determination that disclosure is necessary for the conduct of proceedings before it, and that failure to make the disclosure would be contrary to the public interest.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-312(2): A person who knowingly or intentionally discloses any information not authorized by this section is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-313 Declaration for mental health treatment.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-313(1): An adult who is not incapable may make a declaration of preferences or instructions regarding the adult's mental health treatment. The declaration may include, but is not limited to, consent to or refusal of specified mental health treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-313(2): A declaration for mental health treatment shall designate a capable adult to act as attorney-in-fact to make decisions about mental health treatment for the declarant. An alternative attorney-in-fact may also be designated to act as attorney-in-fact if the original designee is unable or unwilling to act at any time. An attorney-in-fact who has accepted the appointment in writing may make decisions about mental health treatment on behalf of the declarant only when the declarant is incapable. The decisions shall be consistent with any instructions or desires the declarant has expressed in the declaration.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-313(3): 26B-5-314(6) A declaration is effective only if it is signed by the declarant and two capable adult witnesses. The witnesses shall attest that the declarant is known to them, signed the declaration in their presence, appears to be of sound mind and is not under duress, fraud, or undue influence. Persons specified in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-313(4): A declaration becomes operative when it is delivered to the declarant's physician or other mental health treatment provider and remains valid until it expires or is revoked by the declarant. The physician or provider is authorized to act in accordance with an operative declaration when the declarant has been found to be incapable. The physician or provider shall continue to obtain the declarant's informed consent to all mental health treatment decisions if the declarant is capable of providing informed consent or refusal.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-313(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-313(5)(a): An attorney-in-fact does not have authority to make mental health treatment decisions unless the declarant is incapable.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-313(5)(b): An attorney-in-fact is not, solely as a result of acting in that capacity, personally liable for the cost of treatment provided to the declarant.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-313(5)(c): Except to the extent that a right is limited by a declaration or by any federal law, an attorney-in-fact has the same right as the declarant to receive information regarding the proposed mental health treatment and to receive, review, and consent to disclosure of medical records relating to that treatment. This right of access does not waive any evidentiary privilege.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-313(5)(d): In exercising authority under the declaration, the attorney-in-fact shall act consistently with the instructions and desires of the declarant, as expressed in the declaration.  If the declarant's desires are unknown, the attorney-in-fact shall act in what the attorney-in-fact, in good faith, believes to be the best interest of the declarant.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-313(5)(e): An attorney-in-fact is not subject to criminal prosecution, civil liability, or professional disciplinary action for any action taken in good faith pursuant to a declaration for mental health treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-313(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-313(6)(a): A declaration for mental health treatment remains effective for a period of three years or until revoked by the declarant. If a declaration for mental health treatment has been invoked and is in effect at the expiration of three years after its execution, the declaration remains effective until the declarant is no longer incapable.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-313(6)(b): The authority of a named attorney-in-fact and any alternative attorney-in-fact continues in effect as long as the declaration appointing the attorney-in-fact is in effect or until the attorney-in-fact has withdrawn.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-313(7): A person may not be required to execute or to refrain from executing a declaration as a criterion for insurance, as a condition for receiving mental or physical health services, or as a condition of discharge from a facility.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-314 Physician and provider responsibilities -- Provision of services contrary to declaration -- Revocation.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-314(1): Upon being presented with a declaration, a physician shall make the declaration a part of the declarant's medical record. When acting under authority of a declaration, a physician shall comply with it to the fullest extent possible, consistent with reasonable medical practice, the availability of treatments requested, and applicable law. If the physician or other provider is unwilling at any time to comply with the declaration, the physician or provider shall promptly notify the declarant and the attorney-in-fact, and document the notification in the declarant's medical record.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-314(2): A physician or provider may subject a declarant to intrusive treatment in a manner contrary to the declarant's wishes, as expressed in a declaration for mental health treatment if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-314(2)(a): the declarant has been committed to the custody of a local mental health authority in accordance with this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-314(2)(b): in cases of emergency endangering life or health.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-314(3): A declaration does not limit any authority provided in this part, to take a person into custody, or admit or retain a person in the custody of a local mental health authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-314(4): A declaration may be revoked in whole or in part by the declarant at any time so long as the declarant is not incapable. That revocation is effective when the declarant communicates the revocation to the attending physician or other provider. The attending physician or other provider shall note the revocation as part of the declarant's medical record.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-314(5): A physician who administers or does not administer mental health treatment according to and in good faith reliance upon the validity of a declaration is not subject to criminal prosecution, civil liability, or professional disciplinary action resulting from a subsequent finding that a declaration is invalid.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-314(6): None of the following persons may serve as an attorney-in-fact or as witnesses to the signing of a declaration:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-314(6)(a): the declarant's attending physician or mental health treatment provider, or an employee of that physician or provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-314(6)(b): an employee of the division; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-314(6)(c): an employee of a local mental health authority or any organization that contracts with a local mental health authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-314(7): An attorney-in-fact may withdraw by giving notice to the declarant.  If a declarant is incapable, the attorney-in-fact may withdraw by giving notice to the attending physician or provider.  The attending physician shall note the withdrawal as part of the declarant's medical record.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-315 Declaration for mental health treatment -- Form.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A declaration for mental health treatment shall be in substantially the following form:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-315(1): this document allows you to make decisions in advance about three types of mental health treatment: psychoactive medication, convulsive therapy, and short-term (up to 17 days) admission to a mental health facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-315(2): the instructions that you include in this declaration will be followed only if a court or two physicians believe that you are incapable of otherwise making treatment decisions.  Otherwise, you will be considered capable to give or withhold consent for treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-315(3): you may also appoint a person as your attorney-in-fact to make these treatment decisions for you if you become incapable. The person you appoint has a duty to act consistently with your desires as stated in this document or, if not stated, to make decisions in accordance with what that person believes, in good faith, to be in your best interest. For the appointment to be effective, the person you appoint must accept the appointment in writing.  The person also has the right to withdraw from acting as your attorney-in-fact at any time;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-315(4): this document will continue in effect for a period of three years unless you become incapable of participating in mental health treatment decisions. If this occurs, the directive will continue in effect until you are no longer incapable;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-315(5): you have the right to revoke this document in whole or in part, or the appointment of an attorney-in-fact, at any time you have not been determined to be incapable.  YOU MAY NOT REVOKE THE DECLARATION OR APPOINTMENT WHEN YOU ARE CONSIDERED INCAPABLE  BY A COURT OR TWO PHYSICIANS.  A revocation is effective when it is communicated to your attending physician or other provider; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-315(6): if there is anything in this document that you do not understand, you should ask an attorney to explain it to you.  This declaration is not valid unless it is signed by two qualified witnesses who are personally known to you and who are present when you sign or acknowledge your signature.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-316 Responsibility for cost of care.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-316(1): The division shall estimate and determine, as nearly as possible, the actual expense per annum of caring for and maintaining a patient in the state hospital, and that amount or portion of that amount shall be assessed to and paid by the applicant, patient, spouse, parents, child or children who are of sufficient financial ability to do so, or by the guardian of the patient who has funds of the patient that may be used for that purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-316(2): In addition to the expenses described in Subsection (1), parents are responsible for the support of their child while the child is in the care of the state hospital in accordance with Title 26B, Chapter 9, Recovery Services and Administration of Child Support, and Title 81, Chapter 6, Child Support.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-317 Expenses of voluntary patients.
---------------------------------------------------------------
The expense for the care and treatment of voluntary patients shall be assessed to and paid in the same manner and to the same extent as is provided for involuntary patients under the provisions of Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-318 Liability of estate of person with a mental illness.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The provisions made in this part for the support of persons with a mental illness at public expense do not release the estates of those persons from liability for their care and treatment, and the division is authorized and empowered to collect from the estates of those persons any sums paid by the state in their behalf.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-319 Receipt of gift and personal property related to the transfer of persons from other institutions.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-319(1): The division may take and hold by gift, devise, or bequest real and personal property required for the use of the state hospital.  With the approval of the governor the division may convert that property that is not suitable for the state hospital's use into money or property that is suitable for the state hospital's use.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-319(2): The state hospital is authorized to receive from any other institution within the department an individual committed to that institution, when a careful evaluation of the treatment needs of the individual and of the treatment programs available at the state hospital indicates that the transfer would be in the interest of that individual.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-319(3)(c)(ii): Single expenditures exceeding $5,000 must be preapproved by the superintendent and the division director.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-320 Trespass -- Disturbance -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Any person who, without permission, enters any of the buildings or enclosures appropriated to the use of patients, or makes any attempt to do so, or enters anywhere upon the premises belonging to or used by the division, a local mental health authority, or the state hospital and commits, or attempts to commit, any trespass or depredation thereon, or any person who, either from within or without the enclosures, willfully annoys or disturbs the peace or quiet of the premises or of any patient therein, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-321 Abduction of patient -- Penalty.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Any person who abducts a patient who is in the custody of a local mental health authority, or induces any patient to elope or escape from that custody, or attempts to do so, or aids or assists therein, is guilty of a class B misdemeanor, in addition to liability for damages, or subject to other criminal charges.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-322 Criminal's escape -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Any person committed to the state hospital under the provisions of

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-323 Violations of this part -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Any person who willfully and knowingly violates any provision of this part, except where another penalty is provided by law, is guilty of a class C misdemeanor.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-324(1): Each local mental health authority has responsibility for supervision and treatment of persons with a mental illness who have been committed to its custody under the provisions of this part, whether residing in the state hospital or elsewhere.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-326(2)(b)(i): on July 1, 2011, to restore the number of beds allocated to 212 beds as funding permits; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-326(2)(b)(ii): on July 1, 2011, and every three years after July 1, 2011, according to the state's population.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-326(2)(c): All population figures utilized shall reflect the most recent available population estimates from the Utah Population Committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-326(3): (2) The formula established under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-326(3)(a): the percentage of the state's adult population located within a mental health catchment area; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-326(3)(b): a differential to compensate for the additional demand for hospital beds in mental health catchment areas that are located in urban areas.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-326(4): A local mental health authority may sell or loan its allocation of beds to another local mental health authority.

If a local mental health authority is unable to access a bed allocated to it under the formula established under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-327 Allocation of pediatric state hospital beds -- Formula.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-327(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-327(1)(a): "Mental health catchment area" means a county or group of counties governed by a local mental health authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-327(1)(b): "Pediatric beds" means the total number of patient beds located in the children's unit and the youth units at the state hospital, as determined by the superintendent of the state hospital.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-327(2): On July 1, 1996, 72 pediatric beds shall be allocated to local mental health authorities under this section. The division shall review and adjust the number of pediatric beds as necessary every three years according to the state's population of persons under 18 years old. All population figures utilized shall reflect the most recent available population estimates from the Governor's Office of Planning and Budget.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-327(3): The allocation of beds shall be based on the percentage of the state's population of persons under 18 years old located within a mental health catchment area. Each community mental health center shall be allocated at least one bed.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-327(4): A local mental health authority may sell or loan its allocation of beds to another local mental health authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-327(5): The division shall allocate 72 pediatric beds at the state hospital to local mental health authorities for their use in accordance with the formula established under this section.  If a local mental health authority is unable to access a bed allocated to it under that formula, the division shall provide that local mental health authority with funding equal to the reasonable, average daily cost of an acute care bed purchased by the local mental health authority.

---------------------------------------------------------------------
