Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331 Temporary commitment -- Requirements and procedures -- Rights.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(1): An adult shall be temporarily, involuntarily committed to a local mental health authority upon:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(1)(a): a written application that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(1)(a)(i): is completed by a responsible individual who has reason to know, stating a belief that the adult, due to mental illness, is likely to pose substantial danger to self or others if not restrained and stating the personal knowledge of the adult's condition or circumstances that lead to the individual's belief; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(1)(a)(ii): includes a certification by a licensed physician, licensed physician assistant, licensed nurse practitioner, or designated examiner stating that the physician, physician assistant, nurse practitioner, or designated examiner has examined the adult within a three-day period immediately preceding the certification, and that the physician, physician assistant, nurse practitioner, or designated examiner is of the opinion that, due to mental illness, the adult poses a substantial danger to self or others; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(1)(b): a peace officer or a mental health officer:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(1)(b)(i): observing an adult's conduct that gives the peace officer or mental health officer probable cause to believe that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(1)(b)(i)(A): the adult has a mental illness; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(1)(b)(i)(B): because of the adult's mental illness and conduct, the adult poses a substantial danger to self or others; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(1)(b)(ii): completing a temporary commitment application that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(1)(b)(ii)(A): is on a form prescribed by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(1)(b)(ii)(B): states the peace officer's or mental health officer's belief that the adult poses a substantial danger to self or others;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(1)(b)(ii)(C): states the specific nature of the danger;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(1)(b)(ii)(D): provides a summary of the observations upon which the statement of danger is based; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(1)(b)(ii)(E): provides a statement of the facts that called the adult to the peace officer's or mental health officer's attention.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(2): If at any time a patient committed under this section no longer meets the commitment criteria described in Subsection (1), the local mental health authority or the local mental health authority's designee shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(2)(a): document the change and release the patient; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(2)(b): if the patient was admitted under Subsection (1)(b), notify the peace officer or mental health officer of the patient's release.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(3): 26B-5-332; 26B-5-332 A patient committed under this section may be held for a maximum of 72 hours after commitment, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(3)(a): 26B-5-332; 26B-5-332 as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(3)(b): the patient makes a voluntary application for admission.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(4): 26B-4-119; 53-2d-101 Upon a written application described in Subsection (1)(a) or the observation and belief described in Subsection (1)(b)(i), the adult shall be:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(4)(a): taken into a peace officer's protective custody, by reasonable means, if necessary for public safety; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(4)(b): 26B-4-119; 53-2d-101 transported for temporary commitment to a facility designated by the local mental health authority, by means of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(4)(b)(i): 26B-4-119 an ambulance, if the adult meets any of the criteria described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(4)(b)(ii): an ambulance, if a peace officer is not necessary for public safety, and transportation arrangements are made by a physician, physician assistant, nurse practitioner, designated examiner, or mental health officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(4)(b)(iii): the city, town, or municipal law enforcement authority with jurisdiction over the location where the adult is present, if the adult is not transported by ambulance;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(4)(b)(iv): the county sheriff, if the designated facility is outside of the jurisdiction of the law enforcement authority described in Subsection (4)(b)(iii) and the adult is not transported by ambulance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(4)(b)(v): 53-2d-101 nonemergency secured behavioral health transport as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(5): Notwithstanding Subsection (4):
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(5)(a): an individual shall be transported by ambulance to an appropriate medical facility for treatment if the individual requires physical medical attention;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(5)(b): if an officer has probable cause to believe, based on the officer's experience and de-escalation training that taking an individual into protective custody or transporting an individual for temporary commitment would increase the risk of substantial danger to the individual or others, a peace officer may exercise discretion to not take the individual into custody or transport the individual, as permitted by policies and procedures established by the officer's law enforcement agency and any applicable federal or state statute, or case law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(5)(c): if an officer exercises discretion under Subsection (4)(b) to not take an individual into protective custody or transport an individual, the officer shall document in the officer's report the details and circumstances that led to the officer's decision.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(6)(a): The local mental health authority shall inform an adult patient committed under this section of the reason for commitment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(6)(b): An adult patient committed under this section has the right to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(6)(b)(i): within three hours after arrival at the local mental health authority, make a telephone call, at the expense of the local mental health authority, to an individual of the patient's choice; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(6)(b)(ii): see and communicate with an attorney.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(7)(a): Title 63G, Chapter 7, Governmental Immunity Act of Utah, applies to this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(7)(b): This section does not create a special duty of care.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(8)(a): A local mental health authority shall provide discharge instructions to each individual committed under this section at or before the time the individual is discharged from the local mental health authority's custody, regardless of whether the individual is discharged by being released, taken into a peace officer's protective custody, transported to a medical facility or other facility, or other circumstances.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(8)(b): Discharge instructions provided under Subsection (8)(a) shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(8)(b)(i): a summary of why the individual was committed to the local mental health authority;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(8)(b)(ii): detailed information about why the individual is being discharged from the local mental health authority's custody;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(8)(b)(iii): a safety plan for the individual based on the individual's mental illness or mental or emotional state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(8)(b)(iv): notification to the individual's primary care provider, if applicable;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(8)(b)(v): if the individual is discharged without food, housing, or economic security, a referral to appropriate services, if such services exist in the individual's community;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(8)(b)(vi): the phone number to call or text for a crisis services hotline, and information about the availability of peer support services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(8)(b)(vii): a copy of any psychiatric advance directive presented to the local mental health authority, if applicable;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(8)(b)(viii): information about how to establish a psychiatric advance directive if one was not presented to the local mental health authority;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(8)(b)(ix): as applicable, information about medications that were changed or discontinued during the commitment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(8)(b)(x): a list of any screening or diagnostic tests conducted during the commitment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(8)(b)(xi): a summary of therapeutic treatments provided during the commitment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(8)(b)(xii): any laboratory work, including blood samples or imaging, that was completed or attempted during the commitment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(8)(b)(xiii): information about how to contact the local mental health authority if needed.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(8)(c): If an individual's medications were changed, or if an individual was prescribed new medications while committed under this section, discharge instructions provided under Subsection (8)(a) shall include a clinically appropriate supply of medications, as determined by a licensed health care provider, to allow the individual time to access another health care provider or follow-up appointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(8)(d): If an individual refuses to accept discharge instructions, the local mental health authority shall document the refusal in the individual's medical record.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(8)(e): If an individual's discharge instructions include referrals to services under Subsection (8)(b)(v), the local mental health authority shall document those referrals in the individual's medical record.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-331(8)(f): The local mental health authority shall attempt to follow up with a discharged individual at least 48 hours after discharge, and may use peer support professionals when performing follow-up care or developing a continuing care plan.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332 Involuntary commitment under court order -- Examination -- Hearing -- Power of court -- Findings required -- Costs.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(1): A responsible individual who has credible knowledge of an adult's mental illness and the condition or circumstances that have led to the adult's need to be involuntarily committed may initiate an involuntary commitment court proceeding by filing, in the court in the county where the proposed patient resides or is found, a written application that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(1)(a): unless the court finds that the information is not reasonably available, the proposed patient's:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(1)(a)(i): name;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(1)(a)(ii): date of birth; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(1)(a)(iii): social security number;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(1)(b)(i): a certificate of a licensed physician or a designated examiner stating that within the seven-day period immediately preceding the certification, the physician or designated examiner examined the proposed patient and is of the opinion that the proposed patient has a mental illness and should be involuntarily committed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(1)(b)(ii): a written statement by the applicant that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(1)(b)(ii)(A): the proposed patient has been requested to, but has refused to, submit to an examination of mental condition by a licensed physician or designated examiner;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(1)(b)(ii)(B): is sworn to under oath; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(1)(b)(ii)(C): states the facts upon which the application is based; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(1)(c): a statement whether the proposed patient has previously been under an assisted outpatient treatment order, if known by the applicant.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(2): Before issuing a judicial order, the court:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(2)(a): shall require the applicant to consult with the appropriate local mental health authority at or before the hearing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(2)(b): may direct a mental health professional from the local mental health authority to interview the applicant and the proposed patient to determine the existing facts and report the existing facts to the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(3): 26B-5-334 The court may issue an order, directed to a mental health officer or peace officer, to immediately place a proposed patient in the custody of a local mental health authority or in a temporary emergency facility, as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(3)(a): the court finds from the application, any other statements under oath, or any reports from a mental health professional that there is a reasonable basis to believe that the proposed patient has a mental illness that poses a danger to self or others and requires involuntary commitment pending examination and hearing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(3)(b): the proposed patient refuses to submit to an interview with a mental health professional as directed by the court or to go to a treatment facility voluntarily.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(4)(a): The court shall provide notice of commencement of proceedings for involuntary commitment, setting forth the allegations of the application and any reported facts, together with a copy of any official order of detention, to a proposed patient before, or upon, placement of the proposed patient in the custody of a local mental health authority or, with respect to any proposed patient presently in the custody of a local mental health authority whose status is being changed from voluntary to involuntary, upon the filing of an application for that purpose with the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(4)(b): The place of detention shall maintain a copy of the order of detention.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(5)(a): The court shall provide notice of commencement of proceedings for involuntary commitment as soon as practicable to the applicant, any legal guardian, any immediate adult family members, legal counsel for the parties involved, the local mental health authority or the local mental health authority's designee, and any other persons whom the proposed patient or the court designates.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(5)(b): Except as provided in Subsection (5)(c), the notice under Subsection (5)(a) shall advise the persons that a hearing may be held within the time provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(5)(c): If the proposed patient refuses to permit release of information necessary for provisions of notice under this subsection, the court shall determine the extent of notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(6): Proceedings for commitment of an individual under 18 years old to a local mental health authority may be commenced in accordance with Part 4, Commitment of Persons Under Age 18.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(7)(a): The court may, in the court's discretion, transfer the case to any other district court within this state, if the transfer will not be adverse to the interest of the proposed patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(7)(b): If a case is transferred under Subsection (7)(a), the parties to the case may be transferred and the local mental health authority may be substituted in accordance with Utah Rules of Civil Procedure, Rule 25.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(8): Within 24 hours, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays, of the issuance of a judicial order, or after commitment of a proposed patient to a local mental health authority or the local mental health authority's designee under court order for detention or examination, the court shall appoint two designated examiners:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(8)(a): who did not sign the civil commitment application nor the civil commitment certification under Subsection (1);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(8)(b): one of whom is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(8)(b)(i): a licensed physician; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(8)(b)(ii): a psychiatric mental health nurse practitioner or a psychiatric mental health clinical nurse specialist who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(8)(b)(ii)(A): is nationally certified;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(8)(b)(ii)(B): is doctorally trained; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(8)(b)(ii)(C): has at least two years of inpatient mental health experience, regardless of the license the individual held at the time of that experience; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(8)(c): one of whom may be designated by the proposed patient or the proposed patient's counsel, if that designated examiner is reasonably available.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(9): The court shall schedule a hearing to be held within 10 calendar days after the day on which the designated examiners are appointed.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(10): 26B-5-360
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(10)(a): 26B-5-360 The designated examiners shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(10)(a)(i): conduct the examinations separately;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(10)(a)(ii): conduct the examinations at the home of the proposed patient, at a hospital or other medical facility, or at any other suitable place, including through telehealth, that is not likely to have a harmful effect on the proposed patient's health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(10)(a)(iii): inform the proposed patient, if not represented by an attorney:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(10)(a)(iii)(A): that the proposed patient does not have to say anything;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(10)(a)(iii)(B): of the nature and reasons for the examination;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(10)(a)(iii)(C): that the examination was ordered by the court;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(10)(a)(iii)(D): that any information volunteered could form part of the basis for the proposed patient's involuntary commitment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(10)(a)(iii)(E): that findings resulting from the examination will be made available to the court; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(10)(a)(iii)(F): that the designated examiner may, under court order, obtain the proposed patient's mental health records; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(10)(a)(iv): 26B-5-360 within 24 hours of examining the proposed patient, report to the court, orally or in writing, whether the proposed patient is mentally ill, has agreed to voluntary commitment, as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(10)(b): If a designated examiner reports orally under Subsection (10)(a), the designated examiner shall immediately send a written report to the clerk of the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(11): If a designated examiner is unable to complete an examination on the first attempt because the proposed patient refuses to submit to the examination, the court shall fix a reasonable compensation to be paid to the examiner.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(12): If the local mental health authority, the local mental health authority's designee, or a medical examiner determines before the court hearing that the conditions justifying the findings leading to a commitment hearing no longer exist, the local mental health authority, the local mental health authority's designee, or the medical examiner shall immediately report the determination to the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(13): 26B-5-360; 26B-5-351 The court may terminate the proceedings and dismiss the application at any time, including before the hearing, if the designated examiners or the local mental health authority or the local mental health authority's designee informs the court that the proposed patient:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(13)(a): does not meet the criteria in Subsection (16);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(13)(b): 26B-5-360 has agreed to voluntary commitment, as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(13)(c): has acceptable options for treatment programs that are available without court proceedings; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(13)(d): 26B-5-351 meets the criteria for assisted outpatient treatment described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(14): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(14)(a): Before the hearing, the court shall provide the proposed patient an opportunity to be represented by counsel, and if neither the proposed patient nor others provide counsel, the court shall appoint counsel and allow counsel sufficient time to consult with the proposed patient before the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(14)(b): In the case of an indigent proposed patient, the county in which the proposed patient resides or is found shall make payment of reasonable attorney fees for counsel, as determined by the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(15): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(15)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(15)(a)(i): The court shall afford the proposed patient, the applicant, and any other person to whom notice is required to be given an opportunity to appear at the hearing, to testify, and to present and cross-examine witnesses.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(15)(a)(ii): The court may, in the court's discretion, receive the testimony of any other person.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(15)(a)(iii): The court may allow a waiver of the proposed patient's right to appear for good cause, which cause shall be set forth in the record, or an informed waiver by the patient, which shall be included in the record.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(15)(b): The court is authorized to exclude any person not necessary for the conduct of the proceedings and may, upon motion of counsel, require the testimony of each designated examiner to be given out of the presence of any other designated examiners.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(15)(c): The court shall conduct the hearing in as informal a manner as may be consistent with orderly procedure, and in a physical setting that is not likely to have a harmful effect on the mental health of the proposed patient, while preserving the due process rights of the proposed patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(15)(d): The court shall consider any relevant historical and material information that is offered, subject to the rules of evidence, including reliable hearsay under Utah Rules of Evidence, Rule 1102.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(15)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(15)(e)(i): A local mental health authority or the local mental health authority's designee or the physician in charge of the proposed patient's care shall, at the time of the hearing, provide the court with the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(15)(e)(i)(A): the detention order;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(15)(e)(i)(B): admission notes;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(15)(e)(i)(C): the diagnosis;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(15)(e)(i)(D): any doctors' orders;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(15)(e)(i)(E): progress notes;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(15)(e)(i)(F): nursing notes;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(15)(e)(i)(G): medication records pertaining to the current commitment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(15)(e)(i)(H): whether the proposed patient has previously been civilly committed or under an order for assisted outpatient treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(15)(e)(ii): The information described in Subsection (15)(e)(i) shall also be supplied to the proposed patient's counsel at the time of the hearing, and at any time prior to the hearing upon request.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(16): 26B-5-351; 26B-5-351; 26B-5-351; 26B-5-351
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(16)(a): The court shall order commitment of an adult proposed patient to a local mental health authority if, upon completion of the hearing and consideration of the information presented, the court finds by clear and convincing evidence that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(16)(a)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(16)(a)(i)(A): the proposed patient has a mental illness;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(16)(a)(i)(B): because of the proposed patient's mental illness the proposed patient poses a substantial danger to self or others;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(16)(a)(i)(C): the proposed patient lacks the ability to engage in a rational decision-making process regarding the acceptance of mental treatment as demonstrated by evidence of inability to weigh the possible risks of accepting or rejecting treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(16)(a)(i)(D): there is no appropriate less-restrictive alternative to a court order of commitment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(16)(a)(i)(E): the local mental health authority can provide the proposed patient with treatment that is adequate and appropriate to the proposed patient's conditions and needs; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(16)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(16)(a)(ii)(A): the proposed patient has been charged with a criminal offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(16)(a)(ii)(B): with respect to the charged offense, the proposed patient is found incompetent to proceed as a result of a mental illness;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(16)(a)(ii)(C): the proposed patient has a mental illness;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(16)(a)(ii)(D): the proposed patient has a persistent unawareness of their mental illness and the negative consequences of that illness, or within the preceding six months has been requested or ordered to undergo mental health treatment but has unreasonably refused to undergo that treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(16)(a)(ii)(E): there is no appropriate less-restrictive alternative to a court order of commitment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(16)(a)(ii)(F): the local mental health authority can provide the proposed patient with treatment that is adequate and appropriate to the proposed patient's conditions and needs.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(17)(b)(v): If, after reexamination under Subsection (17)(b)(iii), the local mental health authority or the local mental health authority's designee determines that the conditions justifying commitment continue to exist, the court shall immediately appoint two designated examiners and proceed under Subsections (8) through (14).

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(17)(c)(ii): If the local mental health authority or the local mental health authority's designee determines that the conditions justifying commitment no longer exist, the local mental health authority or the local mental health authority's designee shall discharge the patient from the local mental health authority's or the local mental health authority designee's custody and immediately report the discharge to the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(17)(c)(iii): If the local mental health authority or the local mental health authority's designee determines that the conditions justifying commitment continue to exist, the local mental health authority or the local mental health authority's designee shall send a written report of the findings to the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(17)(c)(iv): A patient and the patient's counsel of record shall be notified in writing that the involuntary commitment will be continued under Subsection (17)(c)(iii), the reasons for the decision to continue, and that the patient has the right to a review hearing by making a request to the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-332(17)(c)(v): Upon receiving a request under Subsection (17)(c)(iv), the court shall immediately appoint two designated examiners and proceed under Subsections (8) through (14).

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-333 Circumstances under which conditions justifying initial involuntary commitment shall be considered to continue to exist.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-333(1): 26B-5-332(16); 26B-5-332(17); 26B-5-337 When an individual is involuntarily committed to the custody of a local mental health authority under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-333(1)(a): the patient is still mentally ill;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-333(1)(b): there is no appropriate less restrictive alternative to a court order of involuntary commitment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-333(1)(c): absent an order of involuntary commitment, the patient will likely pose a substantial danger to self or others.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-333(2): 26B-5-351(14); 26B-5-332(16); 26B-5-332(17); 26B-5-337 When an individual has been ordered to assisted outpatient treatment under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-333(2)(a): the patient is still mentally ill;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-333(2)(b): there is no appropriate less-restrictive alternative to a court order of involuntary commitment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-333(2)(c): based upon the patient's conduct and statements during the preceding six months, or the patient's failure to comply with treatment recommendations during the preceding six months, the court finds that absent an order of involuntary commitment, the patient is likely to pose a substantial danger to self or others.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-333(3): A patient whose treatment is continued or who is conditionally released under the terms of this section shall be maintained in the least restrictive environment available that can provide the patient with treatment that is adequate and appropriate.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-334 Detention pending placement in custody.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Pending commitment to a local mental health authority, a patient taken into custody or ordered to be committed pursuant to this part may be detained in the patient's home, a licensed foster home, or any other suitable facility under reasonable conditions prescribed by the local mental health authority. Except in an extreme emergency, the patient may not be detained in a nonmedical facility used for the detention of individuals charged with or convicted of criminal offenses. The local mental health authority shall take reasonable measures, including provision of medical care, as may be necessary to assure proper care of an individual temporarily detained pursuant to this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-335 Notice of commitment.
-----------------------------------------------------
Whenever a patient has been temporarily, involuntarily committed to a local mental health authority under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-336 Periodic review -- Discharge.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Each local mental health authority or its designee shall, as frequently as practicable, examine or cause to be examined every person who has been committed to it. Whenever the local mental health authority or its designee determines that the conditions justifying involuntary commitment no longer exist, it shall discharge the patient. If the patient has been committed through judicial proceedings, a report describing that determination shall be sent to the clerk of the court where the proceedings were held.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-339 Designated examiners.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-339(1): A designated examiner shall consider a proposed patient's mental health history when evaluating a proposed patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-339(2): A designated examiner may request a court order to obtain a proposed patient's mental health records if a proposed patient refuses to share this information with the designated examiner.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-339(3): A designated examiner, when evaluating a proposed patient for civil commitment, shall consider whether:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-339(3)(a): a proposed patient has been under a court order for assisted outpatient treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-339(3)(b): the proposed patient complied with the terms of the assisted outpatient treatment order, if any; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-339(3)(c): whether assisted outpatient treatment is sufficient to meet the proposed patient's needs.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-339(4): A designated examiner shall be allowed a reasonable fee by the county legislative body of the county in which the proposed patient resides or is found, unless the designated examiner is otherwise paid.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-342 Attempt to commit person contrary to requirements -- Penalty.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any person who attempts to place another person in the custody of a local mental health authority contrary to the provisions of this part is guilty of a class B misdemeanor, in addition to liability in an action for damages, or subject to other criminal charges.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351 Assisted outpatient treatment proceedings.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(1): A responsible individual who has credible knowledge of an adult's mental illness and the condition or circumstances that have led to the adult's need for assisted outpatient treatment may file, in the court in the county where the proposed patient resides or is found, a written application that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(1)(a): unless the court finds that the information is not reasonably available, the proposed patient's:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(1)(a)(i): name;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(1)(a)(ii): date of birth; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(1)(a)(iii): social security number; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(1)(b)(i): a certificate of a licensed physician or a designated examiner stating that within the seven-day period immediately preceding the certification, the physician or designated examiner examined the proposed patient and is of the opinion that the proposed patient has a mental illness and should be involuntarily committed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(1)(b)(ii): a written statement by the applicant that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(1)(b)(ii)(A): the proposed patient has been requested to, but has refused to, submit to an examination of mental condition by a licensed physician or designated examiner;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(1)(b)(ii)(B): is sworn to under oath; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(1)(b)(ii)(C): states the facts upon which the application is based.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(2): (2)(b); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(2)(a): (2)(b) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(2)(b): (2)(a) The consultation described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(2)(b)(i): may take place at or before the hearing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(2)(b)(ii): is required if the local mental health authority appears at the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(3): (2)(a); (8); 26B-5-334 If the proposed patient refuses to submit to an interview described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(4): Notice of commencement of proceedings for assisted outpatient treatment, setting forth the allegations of the application and any reported facts, together with a copy of any official order of detention, shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(4)(a): be provided by the court to a proposed patient before, or upon, placement into the custody of a local mental health authority or, with respect to any proposed patient presently in the custody of a local mental health authority;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(4)(c): be provided by the court as soon as practicable to the applicant, any legal guardian, any immediate adult family members, legal counsel for the parties involved, the local mental health authority or its designee, and any other person whom the proposed patient or the court shall designate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(4)(d): advise that a hearing may be held within the time provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(5): The court may, in its discretion, transfer the case to any other court within this state, provided that the transfer will not be adverse to the interest of the proposed patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(6): (1) Within 24 hours, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays, of the issuance of a judicial order, or after commitment of a proposed patient to a local mental health authority or its designee under court order for detention in order to complete an examination, the court shall appoint two designated examiners:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(6)(a): (1) who did not sign the assisted outpatient treatment application nor the certification described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(6)(b): one of whom is a licensed physician; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(6)(c): one of whom may be designated by the proposed patient or the proposed patient's counsel, if that designated examiner is reasonably available.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(7): The court shall schedule a hearing to be held within 10 calendar days of the day on which the designated examiners are appointed.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(8): The designated examiners shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(8)(a): conduct their examinations separately;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(8)(b): conduct the examinations at the home of the proposed patient, at a hospital or other medical facility, or at any other suitable place that is not likely to have a harmful effect on the proposed patient's health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(8)(c): inform the proposed patient, if not represented by an attorney:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(8)(c)(i): that the proposed patient does not have to say anything;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(8)(c)(ii): of the nature and reasons for the examination;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(8)(c)(iii): that the examination was ordered by the court;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(8)(c)(iv): that any information volunteered could form part of the basis for the proposed patient to be ordered to receive assisted outpatient treatment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(8)(c)(v): that findings resulting from the examination will be made available to the court; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(8)(d): within 24 hours of examining the proposed patient, report to the court, orally or in writing, whether the proposed patient is mentally ill. If the designated examiner reports orally, the designated examiner shall immediately send a written report to the clerk of the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(9): If a designated examiner is unable to complete an examination on the first attempt because the proposed patient refuses to submit to the examination, the court shall fix a reasonable compensation to be paid to the examiner.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(10): If the local mental health authority, its designee, or a medical examiner determines before the court hearing that the conditions justifying the findings leading to an assisted outpatient treatment hearing no longer exist, the local mental health authority, its designee, or the medical examiner shall immediately report that determination to the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(11): (14) The court may terminate the proceedings and dismiss the application at any time, including prior to the hearing, if the designated examiners or the local mental health authority or its designee informs the court that the proposed patient does not meet the criteria in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(12): Before the hearing, an opportunity to be represented by counsel shall be afforded to the proposed patient, and if neither the proposed patient nor others provide counsel, the court shall appoint counsel and allow counsel sufficient time to consult with the proposed patient before the hearing. In the case of an indigent proposed patient, the payment of reasonable attorney fees for counsel, as determined by the court, shall be made by the county in which the proposed patient resides or is found.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(13): (13)(e)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(13)(a): All persons to whom notice is required to be given shall be afforded an opportunity to appear at the hearing, to testify, and to present and cross-examine witnesses. The court may, in its discretion, receive the testimony of any other individual. The court may allow a waiver of the proposed patient's right to appear for good cause, which cause shall be set forth in the record, or an informed waiver by the patient, which shall be included in the record.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(13)(b): The court is authorized to exclude all individuals not necessary for the conduct of the proceedings and may, upon motion of counsel, require the testimony of each examiner to be given out of the presence of any other examiners.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(13)(c): The hearing shall be conducted in as informal a manner as may be consistent with orderly procedure, and in a physical setting that is not likely to have a harmful effect on the mental health of the proposed patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(13)(d): The court shall consider all relevant historical and material information that is offered, subject to the rules of evidence, including reliable hearsay under Rule 1102, Utah Rules of Evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(13)(e): (13)(e)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(13)(e)(i): A local mental health authority or its designee, or the physician in charge of the proposed patient's care shall, at the time of the hearing, provide the court with the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(13)(e)(i)(A): the detention order, if any;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(13)(e)(i)(B): admission notes, if any;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(13)(e)(i)(C): the diagnosis, if any;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(13)(e)(i)(D): doctor's orders, if any;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(13)(e)(i)(E): progress notes, if any;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(13)(e)(i)(F): nursing notes, if any; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(13)(e)(i)(G): medication records, if any.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(13)(e)(ii): (13)(e)(i) The information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(13)(e)(ii)(A): at the time of the hearing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(13)(e)(ii)(B): at any time prior to the hearing, upon request.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(14): The court shall order a proposed patient to assisted outpatient treatment if, upon completion of the hearing and consideration of the information presented, the court finds by clear and convincing evidence that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(14)(a): the proposed patient has a mental illness;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(14)(b): there is no appropriate less-restrictive alternative to a court order for assisted outpatient treatment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(14)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(14)(c)(i): the proposed patient lacks the ability to engage in a rational decision-making process regarding the acceptance of mental health treatment, as demonstrated by evidence of inability to weigh the possible risks of accepting or rejecting treatment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-351(14)(c)(ii): the proposed patient needs assisted outpatient treatment in order to prevent relapse or deterioration that is likely to result in the proposed patient posing a substantial danger to self or others.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365 Interstate Compact on Mental Health -- Compact provisions.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Interstate Compact on Mental Health is hereby enacted and entered into with all other jurisdictions that legally join in the compact, which is, in form, substantially as follows:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(1): "After-care" means care, treatment, and services provided to a patient on convalescent status or conditional release.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(2): "Institution" means any hospital, program, or facility maintained by a party state or political subdivision for the care and treatment of persons with a mental illness.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(3): "Mental illness" means a psychiatric disorder as defined by the current Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, that substantially impairs a person's mental, emotional, behavioral, or related functioning to such an extent that he requires care and treatment for his own welfare, the welfare of others, or the community.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(4): "Patient" means any person subject to or eligible, as determined by the laws of the sending state, for institutionalization or other care, treatment, or supervision pursuant to the provisions of this compact and constitutional due process requirements.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(5): "Receiving state" means a party state to which a patient is transported pursuant to the provisions of the compact or to which it is contemplated that a patient may be sent.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(6): "Sending state" means a party state from which a patient is transported pursuant to the provisions of the compact or from which it is contemplated that a patient may be sent.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(7): (1); (2); (1) "State" means any state, territory, or possession of the United States, the District of Columbia, and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(7)(a): given advance notice of its intent to send the patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(7)(b): furnished all available medical and other pertinent records concerning the patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(7)(c): given the qualified medical or other appropriate clinical authorities of the receiving state an opportunity to examine the patient; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(7)(d): (1) determined that the receiving state agrees to accept the patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(7)(d)(1): No person may be deemed a patient of more than one institution at any given time.  Completion of transfer of any patient to an institution in a receiving state has the effect of making the person a patient of the institution in the receiving state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(7)(d)(2): The sending state shall pay all costs of and incidental to the transportation of any patient pursuant to this compact, but any two or more party states may, by making a specific agreement for that purpose, arrange for a different allocation of costs among themselves.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(7)(d)(3): No provision of this compact may be construed to alter or affect any internal relationships among the departments, agencies, and officers of a party state, or between a party state and its subdivisions, as to the payment of costs or responsibilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(7)(d)(4): Nothing in this compact may be construed to prevent any party state or any of its subdivisions from asserting any right against any person, agency, or other entity with regard to costs for which that party state or its subdivision may be responsible under this compact.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(7)(d)(5): (1) Nothing in this compact may be construed to invalidate any reciprocal agreement between a party state and a nonparty state relating to institutionalization, care, or treatment of the mentally ill, or any statutory authority under which those agreements are made.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(7)(d)(5)(1): Nothing in this compact may be construed to abridge, diminish, or in any way impair the rights, duties, and responsibilities of any patient's guardian on his own behalf or with respect to any patient for whom he serves, except that when the transfer of a patient to another jurisdiction makes advisable the appointment of a supplemental or substitute guardian, a court of competent jurisdiction in the receiving state may make supplemental or substitute appointments.  In that case, the court that appointed the previous guardian shall, upon being advised of the new appointment and upon the satisfactory completion of accounting and other acts as the court may require, relieve the previous guardian of power and responsibility to whatever extent is appropriate in the circumstances.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(7)(d)(5)(2): (1) The term "guardian" as used in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(7)(d)(5)(3): The compact administrator shall cooperate with all governmental departments, agencies, and officers in this state and its subdivisions in facilitating the proper administration of the compact and any supplementary agreement or agreements entered into by this state under the compact.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(7)(d)(5)(4): The compact administrator is hereby authorized and empowered to enter into supplementary agreements with appropriate officials of other states pursuant to Articles VII and XI of this compact.  In the event that supplementary agreements require or contemplate the use of any institution or facility of this state or require or contemplate the provision of any service by this state, that agreement shall have no force unless approved by the director of the department or agency under whose jurisdiction the institution or facility is operated, or whose department or agency will be charged with the rendering of services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-365(7)(d)(5)(5): The compact administrator may make or arrange for any payments necessary to discharge financial obligations imposed upon this state by the compact or by any supplementary agreement entered into under the compact.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-366 Interstate compact on mental health -- Requirement of conformity with this chapter.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
All actions and proceedings taken under authority of this compact shall be in accordance with the procedures and constitutional requirements described in this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-367 Severability.
---------------------------------------------
If any one or more provision, section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or word of this part, or the application thereof to any person or circumstance, is found to be unconstitutional the same is hereby declared to be severable and the balance of this part shall remain effective notwithstanding that unconstitutionality. The Legislature hereby declares that it would have passed this part, and each provision, section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or word thereof, irrespective of the fact that any one or more provision, section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or word be declared unconstitutional.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-370 Establishment of the Utah Forensic Mental Health Facility.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Utah Forensic Mental Health Facility is hereby established and shall be located on state land on the campus of the Utah State Hospital in Provo, Utah County.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382 HOME Court Pilot Program -- Requirements -- Funding -- Reporting.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(1): As used in this section, "pilot program" means the HOME Court Pilot Program established in Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(2): Subject to appropriations from the Legislature and the assignment of a judge to preside over the proceedings, the Third Judicial District Court of Salt Lake County shall establish and administer a HOME Court Pilot Program beginning October 1, 2024, and ending June 30, 2029, that provides for comprehensive and individualized, court-supervised treatment and services to individuals with mental illness.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(3): 26B-5-351; 26B-5-351 The pilot program shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(3)(a): allow a person to petition the court for an order requiring an individual's participation in the pilot program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(3)(b): require the court to substitute the local mental health authority as the petitioner if the initial petitioner is not the local mental health authority;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(3)(c): provide an opportunity for the parties to enter into an agreement regarding an individual's participation in the pilot program, including a treatment plan, prior to a court order under Subsection (3)(e);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(3)(d): provide for a hearing at which information is presented to determine whether an individual qualifies for court-ordered participation in the pilot program as provided in Subsection (3)(e);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(3)(e): 26B-5-351 require the court to order an individual to participate in the pilot program if, upon completion of the hearing described in Subsection (3)(d), the court finds by clear and convincing evidence that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(3)(e)(i): the individual resides or may be presently found within Salt Lake County;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(3)(e)(ii): the individual has a mental illness;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(3)(e)(iii): 26B-5-351 because of the individual's mental illness, the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(3)(e)(iii)(A): is unlikely to survive or remain safe without supervision, assistance, or services; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(3)(e)(iii)(B): 26B-5-351 meets the criteria described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(3)(e)(iv): there is no appropriate less-restrictive alternative to a court order for participation in the pilot program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(3)(e)(v): the individual is likely to benefit from participation in the pilot program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(3)(e)(vi): there is adequate capacity within the pilot program to meet the individual's need for services described in Subsection (3)(f);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(3)(f): upon the court's order for an individual to participate in the pilot program, require the local mental health authority to prepare a comprehensive and individualized treatment plan, for approval by the court, that includes the following components for the individual to successfully achieve the purposes of the pilot program:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(3)(g)(ii): require the court to conduct regular review hearings as deemed necessary to evaluate the individual's progress in completing the treatment plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(3)(h): 26B-5-351 operate in a manner that is consistent with the procedures for ordering assisted outpatient treatment under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(4)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(4)(a)(i): If a individual participating in the pilot program has an outstanding warrant or pending criminal matter in another Utah court, the Third Judicial District Court of Salt Lake County may notify the other court in which the individual has an outstanding warrant or pending criminal matter regarding the individual's participation in the pilot program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(4)(a)(ii): Upon receiving notice of an individual's participation in the pilot program under Subsection (4)(a)(i), the other court may, if deemed appropriate, recall the warrant or stay the case in which the individual is involved unless the warrant or case involves a felony charge.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(4)(a)(iii): In determining whether to recall a warrant or stay a case under Subsection (4)(a)(ii), the other court shall consider the likelihood of the individual's successful completion of the pilot program, the severity of the pending charges, the impact on victims' rights, and the impact on the government's ability and right to prosecute the case.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(4)(b)(i): If an individual described in Subsection (4)(a)(i) successfully completes the pilot program, the Third Judicial District Court of Salt Lake County may notify the other court in which the individual has an outstanding warrant or pending criminal matter regarding the individual's successful completion of the pilot program.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(5)(b)(iv): conduct an annual audit and review of the local mental health authority, and any contracted provider, regarding the use of funds appropriated for the pilot program.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(5)(d): Subject to appropriation by the Legislature, Salt Lake County may:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(5)(d)(i): apply to the division to receive funds to cover the county's costs under the pilot program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(5)(d)(ii): pay county contributions to the nonfederal share of Medicaid expenditures with funds appropriated for the pilot program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-382(6): 35A-16-204 The department shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-401 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
In addition to the definitions in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 26B-5-401(1): "Child" means a person under 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-401(2): "Commit" and "commitment" mean the transfer of physical custody in accordance with the requirements of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-401(3): "Legal custody" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-401(3)(a): the right to determine where and with whom the child shall live;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-401(3)(b): the right to participate in all treatment decisions and to consent or withhold consent for treatment in which a constitutionally protected liberty or privacy interest may be affected, including antipsychotic medication, electroshock therapy, and psychosurgery; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-401(3)(c): the right to authorize surgery or other extraordinary medical care.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-401(4): "Physical custody" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-401(4)(a): placement of a child in any residential or inpatient setting;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-401(4)(b): the right to physical custody of a child;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-401(4)(c): the right and duty to protect the child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-401(4)(d): the duty to provide, or insure that the child is provided with, adequate food, clothing, shelter, and ordinary medical care.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-401(5): "Residential" means any out-of-home placement made by a local mental health authority, but does not include out-of-home respite care.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-401(6): "Respite care" means temporary, periodic relief provided to parents or guardians from the daily care of children with serious emotional disorders for the limited time periods designated by the division.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-402 Treatment and commitment of minors in the public mental health system.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A child is entitled to due process proceedings, in accordance with the requirements of this part, whenever the child:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-402(1): may receive or receives services through the public mental health system and is placed, by a local mental health authority, in a physical setting where his liberty interests are restricted, including residential and inpatient placements; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-402(2): receives treatment in which a constitutionally protected privacy or liberty interest may be affected, including the administration of antipsychotic medication, electroshock therapy, and psychosurgery.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403 Residential and inpatient settings -- Commitment proceeding -- Child in physical custody of local mental health authority.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(1): A child may receive services from a local mental health authority in an inpatient or residential setting only after a commitment proceeding, for the purpose of transferring physical custody, has been conducted in accordance with the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(2): That commitment proceeding shall be initiated by a petition for commitment, and shall be a careful, diagnostic inquiry, conducted by a neutral and detached fact finder, pursuant to the procedures and requirements of this section. If the findings described in Subsection (4) exist, the proceeding shall result in the transfer of physical custody to the appropriate local mental health authority, and the child may be placed in an inpatient or residential setting.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(3): The neutral and detached fact finder who conducts the inquiry:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(3)(a): shall be a designated examiner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(3)(b): may not profit, financially or otherwise, from the commitment or physical placement of the child in that setting.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(4): Upon determination by a fact finder that the following circumstances clearly exist, the fact finder may order that the child be committed to the physical custody of a local mental health authority:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(4)(a): the child has a mental illness;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(4)(b): the child demonstrates a reasonable fear of the risk of substantial danger to self or others;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(4)(c): the child will benefit from care and treatment by the local mental health authority; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(4)(d): there is no appropriate less-restrictive alternative.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(5)(a): The commitment proceeding before the neutral and detached fact finder shall be conducted in as informal manner as possible and in a physical setting that is not likely to have a harmful effect on the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(5)(b): The child, the child's parent or legal guardian, the petitioner, and a representative of the appropriate local mental health authority:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(5)(b)(i): shall receive informal notice of the date and time of the proceeding; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(5)(b)(ii): may appear and address the petition for commitment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(5)(c): The neutral and detached fact finder may, in the fact finder's discretion, receive the testimony of any other person.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(5)(d): The fact finder may allow a child to waive the child's right to be present at the commitment proceeding, for good cause shown. If that right is waived, the purpose of the waiver shall be made a matter of record at the proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(5)(e): At the time of the commitment proceeding, the appropriate local mental health authority, its designee, or the psychiatrist who has been in charge of the child's care prior to the commitment proceeding, shall provide the neutral and detached fact finder with the following information, as it relates to the period of current admission:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(5)(e)(i): the petition for commitment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(5)(e)(ii): the admission notes;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(5)(e)(iii): the child's diagnosis;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(5)(e)(iv): physicians' orders;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(5)(e)(v): progress notes;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(5)(e)(vi): nursing notes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(5)(e)(vii): medication records.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(5)(f): The information described in Subsection (5)(e) shall also be provided to the child's parent or legal guardian upon written request.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(5)(g): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(5)(g)(i): The neutral and detached fact finder's decision of commitment shall state the duration of the commitment. Any commitment to the physical custody of a local mental health authority may not exceed 180 days. Prior to expiration of the commitment, and if further commitment is sought, a hearing shall be conducted in the same manner as the initial commitment proceeding, in accordance with the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(5)(g)(ii): At the conclusion of the hearing and subsequently in writing, when a decision for commitment is made, the neutral and detached fact finder shall inform the child and the child's parent or legal guardian of that decision and of the reasons for ordering commitment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(5)(g)(iii): The neutral and detached fact finder shall state in writing the basis of the decision, with specific reference to each of the criteria described in Subsection (4), as a matter of record.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(6): 26B-5-331 A child may be temporarily committed for a maximum of 72 hours, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays, to the physical custody of a local mental health authority in accordance with the procedures described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(7): A local mental health authority shall have physical custody of each child committed to it under this section. The parent or legal guardian of a child committed to the physical custody of a local mental health authority under this section, retains legal custody of the child, unless legal custody has been otherwise modified by a court of competent jurisdiction. In cases when the Division of Child and Family Services or the Division of Juvenile Justice and Youth Services has legal custody of a child, that division shall retain legal custody for purposes of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(8): The cost of caring for and maintaining a child in the physical custody of a local mental health authority shall be assessed to and paid by the child's parents, according to their ability to pay. For purposes of this section, the Division of Child and Family Services or the Division of Juvenile Justice and Youth Services shall be financially responsible, in addition to the child's parents, if the child is in the legal custody of either of those divisions at the time the child is committed to the physical custody of a local mental health authority under this section, unless Medicaid regulation or contract provisions specify otherwise. The Office of Recovery Services shall assist those divisions in collecting the costs assessed pursuant to this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(9): Whenever application is made for commitment of a minor to a local mental health authority under any provision of this section by a person other than the child's parent or guardian, the local mental health authority or its designee shall notify the child's parent or guardian. The parents shall be provided sufficient time to prepare and appear at any scheduled proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(10)(a): Each child committed pursuant to this section is entitled to an appeal within 30 days after any order for commitment. The appeal may be brought on the child's own petition or on petition of the child's parent or legal guardian, to the juvenile court in the district where the child resides or is currently physically located. With regard to a child in the custody of the Division of Child and Family Services or the Division of Juvenile Justice and Youth Services, the attorney general's office shall handle the appeal, otherwise the appropriate county attorney's office is responsible for appeals brought pursuant to this Subsection (10)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(10)(b): Upon receipt of the petition for appeal, the court shall appoint a designated examiner previously unrelated to the case, to conduct an examination of the child in accordance with the criteria described in Subsection (4), and file a written report with the court.  The court shall then conduct an appeal hearing to determine whether the findings described in Subsection (4) exist by clear and convincing evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(10)(c): Prior to the time of the appeal hearing, the appropriate local mental health authority, its designee, or the mental health professional who has been in charge of the child's care prior to commitment, shall provide the court and the designated examiner for the appeal hearing with the following information, as it relates to the period of current admission:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(10)(c)(i): the original petition for commitment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(10)(c)(ii): admission notes;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(10)(c)(iii): diagnosis;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(10)(c)(iv): physicians' orders;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(10)(c)(v): progress notes;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(10)(c)(vi): nursing notes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(10)(c)(vii): medication records.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(10)(d): Both the neutral and detached fact finder and the designated examiner appointed for the appeal hearing shall be provided with an opportunity to review the most current information described in Subsection (10)(c) prior to the appeal hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(10)(e): The child, the child's parent or legal guardian, the person who submitted the original petition for commitment, and a representative of the appropriate local mental health authority shall be notified by the court of the date and time of the appeal hearing. Those persons shall be afforded an opportunity to appear at the hearing. In reaching its decision, the court shall review the record and findings of the neutral and detached fact finder, the report of the designated examiner appointed pursuant to Subsection (10)(b), and may, in its discretion, allow or require the testimony of the neutral and detached fact finder, the designated examiner, the child, the child's parent or legal guardian, the person who brought the initial petition for commitment, or any other person whose testimony the court deems relevant. The court may allow the child to waive the right to appear at the appeal hearing, for good cause shown. If that waiver is granted, the purpose shall be made a part of the court's record.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(11): Each local mental health authority has an affirmative duty to conduct periodic evaluations of the mental health and treatment progress of every child committed to its physical custody under this section, and to release any child who has sufficiently improved so that the criteria justifying commitment no longer exist.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(12): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(12)(a): A local mental health authority or its designee, in conjunction with the child's current treating mental health professional may release an improved child to a less restrictive environment, as they determine appropriate. Whenever the local mental health authority or its designee, and the child's current treating mental health professional, determine that the conditions justifying commitment no longer exist, the child shall be discharged and released to the child's parent or legal guardian. With regard to a child who is in the physical custody of the State Hospital, the treating psychiatrist or clinical director of the State Hospital shall be the child's current treating mental health professional.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(12)(b): A local mental health authority or its designee, in conjunction with the child's current treating mental health professional, is authorized to issue a written order for the immediate placement of a child not previously released from an order of commitment into a more restrictive environment, if the local authority or its designee and the child's current treating mental health professional has reason to believe that the less restrictive environment in which the child has been placed is exacerbating the child's mental illness, or increasing the risk of harm to self or others.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(12)(c): The written order described in Subsection (12)(b) shall include the reasons for placement in a more restrictive environment and shall authorize any peace officer to take the child into physical custody and transport the child to a facility designated by the appropriate local mental health authority in conjunction with the child's current treating mental health professional. Prior to admission to the more restrictive environment, copies of the order shall be personally delivered to the child, the child's parent or legal guardian, the administrator of the more restrictive environment, or the administrator's designee, and the child's former treatment provider or facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(12)(d): If the child has been in a less restrictive environment for more than 30 days and is aggrieved by the change to a more restrictive environment, the child or the child's representative may request a review within 30 days of the change, by a neutral and detached fact finder as described in Subsection (3). The fact finder shall determine whether:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(12)(d)(i): the less restrictive environment in which the child has been placed is exacerbating the child's mental illness or increasing the risk of harm to self or others; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(12)(d)(ii): the less restrictive environment in which the child has been placed is not exacerbating the child's mental illness or increasing the risk of harm to self or others, in which case the fact finder shall designate that the child remain in the less restrictive environment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(12)(e): Nothing in this section prevents a local mental health authority or its designee, in conjunction with the child's current mental health professional, from discharging a child from commitment or from placing a child in an environment that is less restrictive than that designated by the neutral and detached fact finder.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(13): 26B-5-405 Each local mental health authority or its designee, in conjunction with the child's current treating mental health professional shall discharge any child who, in the opinion of that local authority, or its designee, and the child's current treating mental health professional, no longer meets the criteria specified in Subsection (4), except as provided by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-403(14): 26B-5-404 Even though a child has been committed to the physical custody of a local mental health authority under this section, the child is still entitled to additional due process proceedings, in accordance with Section

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-404(1): For purposes of this section, "invasive treatment" means treatment in which a constitutionally protected liberty or privacy interest may be affected, including antipsychotic medication, electroshock therapy, and psychosurgery.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-404(2): The requirements of this section apply to all children receiving services or treatment from a local mental health authority, its designee, or its provider regardless of whether a local mental health authority has physical custody of the child or the child is receiving outpatient treatment from the local authority, its designee, or provider.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-404(3)(a)(ii): (3) with regard to psychosurgery and electroshock therapy, a due process proceeding shall be conducted pursuant to the procedures established under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-404(3)(a)(iii): (3) other possible invasive treatments may be conducted unless either the parent or child disagrees with the treatment, in which case a due process proceeding shall be conducted pursuant to the procedures established under this Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-405(1): (1)(b); 26B-5-332; 26B-5-403

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-405(2): The juvenile court shall order commitment to the physical custody of a local mental health authority if, upon completion of the hearing and consideration of the record, the juvenile court finds by clear and convincing evidence that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-405(2)(a): the child has a mental illness;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-405(2)(b): the child demonstrates a risk of harm to the child or others;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-405(2)(c): the child is experiencing significant impairment in the child's ability to perform socially;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-405(5): If a child is committed to the custody of a local mental health authority, or the local mental health authority's designee, by the juvenile court, the local mental health authority, or the local mental health authority's designee, shall give the juvenile court written notice of the intention to release the child not fewer than five days before the day on which the child is released.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-406 Parent advocate.
------------------------------------------------
The division shall establish the position of a parent advocate to assist parents of children with a mental illness who are subject to the procedures required by this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-407 Confidentiality of information and records -- Exceptions -- Penalty.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-407(1): Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act Notwithstanding the provisions of
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-407(1)(a): the individual identified consents after reaching 18 years old;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-407(1)(b): the child's parent or legal guardian consents;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-407(1)(c): disclosure is necessary to carry out any of the provisions of this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-407(1)(d): a court may direct, upon its determination that disclosure is necessary for the conduct of proceedings before it, and that failure to make the disclosure would be contrary to the public interest.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-407(2): A person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-408 Mechanical restraints -- Clinical record.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Mechanical restraints may not be applied to a child unless it is determined, by the local mental health authority or its designee in conjunction with the child's current treating mental health professional, that they are required by the needs of that child. Every use of a mechanical restraint and the reasons for that use shall be made a part of the child's clinical record, under the signature of the local mental health authority, its designee, and the child's current treating mental health professional.
