Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-410 Restrictions and limitations -- Civil rights and privileges.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-410(1): 26B-5-403 Subject to the specific rules of the division, and except to the extent that the local mental health authority or its designee, in conjunction with the child's current treating mental health professional, determines that it is necessary for the welfare of the person to impose restrictions, every child committed to the physical custody of a local mental health authority under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-410(1)(a): communicate, by sealed mail or otherwise, with persons, including official agencies, inside or outside of the facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-410(1)(b): receive visitors; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-410(1)(c): exercise his civil rights.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-410(2): When any right of a child is limited or denied, the nature, extent, and reason for that limitation or denial shall be entered in the child's treatment record. Any continuing denial or limitation shall be reviewed every 30 days and shall also be entered in that treatment record.  Notice of that continuing denial in excess of 30 days shall be sent to the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-410(3): Notwithstanding any limitations authorized under this section on the right of communication, each child committed to the physical custody of a local mental health authority is entitled to communicate by sealed mail with his attorney, the local mental health authority, its designee, his current treating mental health professional, and the court, if commitment was court ordered. In no case may the child be denied a visit with the legal counsel or clergy of his choice.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-410(4): Each local mental health authority shall provide appropriate and reasonable means and arrangements for informing children and their parents or legal guardians of their rights as provided in this part, and for assisting them in making and presenting requests for release.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-410(5): All local mental health facilities shall post a statement, promulgated by the division, describing patient's rights under Utah law.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-411 Standards for care and treatment.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Every child is entitled to humane care and treatment and to medical care and treatment in accordance with the prevailing standards accepted in medical practice, psychiatric nursing practice, social work practice, and the practice of clinical psychology.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-412 Responsibilities of the division.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-412(1): The division shall ensure that the requirements of this part are met and applied uniformly by local mental health authorities across the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-412(2): 26B-5-102 Because the division must, under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-412(2)(a): require each local mental health authority to submit its plan to the division by May 1 of each year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-412(2)(b): conduct an annual program audit and review of each local mental health authority in the state, and its contract provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-412(3): (2)(b) The annual audit and review described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-412(3)(a): public funds allocated to local mental health authorities are consistent with services rendered and outcomes reported by it or its contract provider; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-412(3)(b): each local mental health authority is exercising sufficient oversight and control over public funds allocated for mental health programs and services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-412(4): The Legislature may refuse to appropriate funds to the division if the division fails to comply with the procedures and requirements of this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-413 Contracts with local mental health authorities -- Provisions.

When the division contracts with a local mental health authority to provide mental health programs and services in accordance with the provisions of this chapter andUtah Code Annotated § 26B-5-413(1): Title 51, Chapter 2a, Accounting Reports from Political Subdivisions, Interlocal Organizations, and Other Local Entities Act that an independent auditor shall conduct any audit of the local mental health authority or its contract provider's programs or services, pursuant to the provisions of

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-413(2)(b): may prescribe specific items to be addressed by that audit, depending upon the particular needs or concerns relating to the local mental health authority or contract provider at issue;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-501 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
In addition to the definitions in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 26B-5-501(1): "Emergency, life saving treatment" means treatment that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-501(1)(a): provided at a licensed health care facility or licensed human services program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-501(1)(b): provided by a licensed health care professional;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-501(1)(c): necessary to save the life of the patient; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-501(1)(d): required due to the patient's:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-501(1)(d)(i): use of an illegal substance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-501(1)(d)(ii): excessive use or misuse of a prescribed medication.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-501(2): "Essential treatment examiner" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-501(2)(a): a licensed physician, preferably a psychiatrist, who is designated by the division as specifically qualified by training or experience in the diagnosis of substance use disorder; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-501(2)(b): a licensed mental health professional designated by the division as specially qualified by training and who has at least five years' continual experience in the treatment of substance use disorder.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-501(3): "Relative" means an adult who is a spouse, parent, stepparent, grandparent, child, or sibling of an individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-501(4): "Serious harm" means the individual, due to substance use disorder, is at serious risk of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-501(4)(a): drug overdose;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-501(4)(b): suicide;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-501(4)(c): serious bodily self-injury;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-501(4)(d): serious bodily injury because the individual is incapable of providing the basic necessities of life, including food, clothing, or shelter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-501(4)(e): causing or attempting to cause serious bodily injury to another individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-501(5): "Substance use disorder" means the same as that term is defined in the current edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders published by the American Psychiatric Association.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-502 Statement of legislative intent.
----------------------------------------------------------------
To address the serious public health crisis of substance use disorder related deaths and life-threatening opioid addiction, and to allow and enable caring relatives to seek essential treatment and intervention, as may be necessary, on behalf of a sufferer of a substance use disorder, the Legislature enacts the Essential Treatment and Intervention Act.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-503 Petition for essential treatment -- Contents -- Commitment to pay.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-503(1): A relative seeking essential treatment and intervention for a sufferer of a substance use disorder may file a petition with the court of the county in which the sufferer of the substance use disorder resides or is found.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-503(2): (2)(d) The petition shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-503(2)(a): the respondent's:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-503(2)(a)(i): legal name;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-503(2)(a)(ii): date of birth, if known;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-503(2)(a)(iii): social security number, if known; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-503(2)(a)(iv): residence and current location, if known;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-503(2)(b): the petitioner's relationship to the respondent;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-503(2)(c): the name and residence of the respondent's legal guardian, if any and if known;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-503(2)(d): a statement that the respondent:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-503(2)(d)(i): is suffering from a substance use disorder; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-503(2)(d)(ii): if not treated for the substance use disorder presents a serious harm to self or others;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-503(2)(e): (2)(d) the factual basis for the statement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-503(2)(f): at least one specified local substance abuse authority or approved treatment facility or program where the respondent may receive essential treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-503(3): Any petition filed under this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-503(3)(a): may be accompanied by proof of health insurance to provide for the respondent's essential treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-503(3)(b): shall be accompanied by a binding commitment to pay, signed by the petitioner or another individual, obligating the petitioner or other individual to pay all treatment costs beyond those covered by the respondent's health insurance policy for court-ordered essential treatment for the respondent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-503(3)(c): may be accompanied by documentation of emergency, life saving treatment provided to the respondent.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-503(4): Nothing in this section alters the contractual relationship between a health insurer and an insured individual.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-504 Criteria for essential treatment and intervention.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A court shall order an individual to undergo essential treatment for a substance use disorder when the court determines by clear and convincing evidence that the individual:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-504(1): suffers from a substance use disorder;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-504(2): can reasonably benefit from the essential treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-504(3): is unlikely to substantially benefit from a less-restrictive alternative treatment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-504(4): presents a serious harm to self or others.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505 Proceeding for essential treatment -- Duties of court -- Disposition.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(1): 26B-5-503 A court shall review the assertions contained in the verified petition described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(2): (2)(b)(vi) If the court determines that the assertions, if true, are sufficient to order the respondent to undergo essential treatment, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(2)(a): set an expedited date for a time-sensitive hearing to determine whether the court should order the respondent to undergo essential treatment for a substance use disorder;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(2)(b): provide notice of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(2)(b)(i): the contents of the petition, including all assertions made;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(2)(b)(ii): a copy of any order for detention or examination;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(2)(b)(iii): the date of the hearing;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(2)(b)(iv): the purpose of the hearing;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(2)(b)(v): the right of the respondent to be represented by legal counsel; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(2)(b)(vi): the right of the respondent to request a preliminary hearing before submitting to an order for examination;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(2)(c): provide notice to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(2)(c)(i): the respondent;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(2)(c)(ii): the respondent's guardian, if any; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(2)(c)(iii): the petitioner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(2)(d): (2)(b)(vi) subject to the right described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(2)(d)(i): by two essential treatment examiners; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(2)(d)(ii): by one essential treatment examiner, if documentation before the court demonstrates that the respondent received emergency, life saving treatment:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(2)(d)(ii)(A): within 30 days before the day on which the petition for essential treatment and intervention was filed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(2)(d)(ii)(B): during the pendency of the petition for essential treatment and intervention.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(3): 26B-5-504 An essential treatment examiner shall examine the respondent to determine:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(3)(a): 26B-5-504 whether the respondent meets each of the criteria described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(3)(b): the severity of the respondent's substance use disorder, if any;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(3)(c): what forms of treatment would substantially benefit the respondent, if the examiner determines that the respondent has a substance use disorder; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(3)(d): the appropriate duration for essential treatment, if essential treatment is recommended.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(4): An essential treatment examiner shall certify the examiner's findings to the court within 24 hours after completion of the examination.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(5): The court may, based upon the findings of an essential treatment examiner, terminate the proceedings and dismiss the petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(6): The parties may, at any time, make a binding stipulation to an essential treatment plan and submit that plan to the court for court order.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(7): At the hearing, the petitioner and the respondent may testify and may cross-examine witnesses.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(8): 26B-5-504; 26B-5-507 If, upon completion of the hearing, the court finds that the criteria in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(8)(a): 26B-5-507 does not exceed 360 days, subject to periodic review as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(8)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(8)(b)(i): is recommended by an essential treatment examiner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(8)(b)(ii): is otherwise agreed to at the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(9): The court shall designate the facility for the essential treatment, as:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(9)(a): described in the petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(9)(b): recommended by an essential treatment examiner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(9)(c): agreed to at the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(10): The court shall issue an order that includes the court's findings and the reasons for the court's determination.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-505(11): The court may order the petitioner to be the respondent's personal representative, as described in 45 C.F.R. Sec. 164.502(g), for purposes of the respondent's essential treatment.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-507 Periodic review -- Discharge.
-------------------------------------------------------------
A local substance abuse authority or an approved treatment facility or program that provides essential treatment shall:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-507(1): at least every 90 days after the day on which a patient is admitted, unless a court orders otherwise, examine or cause to be examined a patient who has been ordered to receive essential treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-507(2): notify the patient and the patient's personal representative or guardian, if any, of the substance and results of the examination;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-507(3): discharge an essential treatment patient if the examination determines that the conditions justifying essential treatment and intervention no longer exist; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-507(4): after discharging an essential treatment patient, send a report describing the reasons for discharge to the clerk of the court where the proceeding for essential treatment was held and to the patient's personal representative or guardian, if any.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-508 Seventy-two-hour emergency treatment pending a final court order.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-508(1): 26B-5-504 A court may order a respondent to be hospitalized for up to 72 hours if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-508(1)(a): 26B-5-504 an essential treatment examiner has examined the respondent and certified that the respondent meets the criteria described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-508(1)(b): the court finds by clear and convincing evidence that the respondent presents an imminent threat of serious harm to self or others as a result of a substance use disorder.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-508(2): An individual who is admitted to a hospital under this section shall be released from the hospital within 72 hours after admittance, unless a treating physician or essential treatment examiner determines that the individual continues to pose an imminent threat of serious harm to self or others.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-508(3): (2) If a treating physician or essential treatment examiner makes the determination described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-508(4): A treating physician or an essential treatment examiner shall, as frequently as practicable, examine an individual hospitalized under this section and release the individual if it is determined that a threat of imminent serious harm no longer exists.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509 Emergency, life saving treatment -- Temporary personal representative.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(1): When an individual receives emergency, life saving treatment:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(1)(a): a licensed health care professional, at the health care facility where the emergency, life saving treatment is provided, may ask the individual who, if anyone, may be contacted and informed regarding the individual's treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(1)(b): a treating physician may hold the individual in the health care facility for up to 48 hours, if the treating physician determines that the individual poses a serious harm to self or others; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(1)(c): a relative of the individual may petition a court to be designated as the individual's personal representative, described in 45 C.F.R. Sec. 164.502(g), for the limited purposes of the individual's medical and mental health care related to a substance use disorder.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(2): (1)(c); (2)(d) The petition described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(2)(a): the respondent's:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(2)(a)(i): legal name;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(2)(a)(ii): date of birth, if known;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(2)(a)(iii): social security number, if known; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(2)(a)(iv): residence and current location, if known;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(2)(b): the petitioner's relationship to the respondent;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(2)(c): the name and residence of the respondent's legal guardian, if any and if known;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(2)(d): a statement that the respondent:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(2)(d)(i): is suffering from a substance use disorder; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(2)(d)(ii): has received, within the last 72 hours, emergency, life saving treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(2)(e): (2)(d) the factual basis for the statement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(2)(f): the name of any other individual, if any, who may be designated as the respondent's personal representative.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(3): A court shall grant a petition for designation as a personal representative, ex parte, if it appears from the petition for designation as a court-designated personal representative that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(3)(a): the respondent is suffering from a substance use disorder;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(3)(b): the respondent received emergency, life saving treatment within 10 days before the day on which the petition for designation as a personal representative is filed;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(3)(c): the petitioner is a relative of the respondent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(3)(d): no other individual is otherwise designated as the respondent's personal representative.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(4): When a court grants, ex parte, a petition for designation as a personal representative, the court:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(4)(a): shall provide notice to the respondent;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(4)(b): shall order the petitioner to be the respondent's personal representative for 10 days after the day on which the court designates the petitioner as the respondent's personal representative; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(4)(c): may extend the duration of the order:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(4)(c)(i): for good cause shown, after the respondent has been notified and given a proper and sufficient opportunity to respond; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-509(4)(c)(ii): if the respondent consents to an extension.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-510 Confidentiality.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-510(1): The purpose of this part is to provide a process for essential treatment and intervention to save lives, preserve families, and reduce substance use disorder, including opioid addiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-510(2): An essential treatment petition and any other document filed in connection with the petition for essential treatment is confidential and protected.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-510(3): 26B-5-505(3); 26B-5-505(2)(c) A hearing on an essential treatment petition is closed to the public, and only the following individuals and their legal counsel may be admitted to the hearing:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-510(3)(a): parties to the petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-510(3)(b): 26B-5-505(3) the essential treatment examiners who completed the court-ordered examination under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-510(3)(c): individuals who have been asked to give testimony; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-510(3)(d): 26B-5-505(2)(c) individuals to whom notice of the hearing is required to be given under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-510(4): Testimony, medical evaluations, the petition, and other documents directly related to the adjudication of the petition and presented to the court in the interest of the respondent may not be construed or applied as an admission of guilt to a criminal offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-510(5): A court may, if applicable, enforce a previously existing warrant for a respondent or a warrant for a charge that is unrelated to the essential treatment petition filed under this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-511 Essential treatment for substance use disorder -- Rights of patient.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
All applicable rights guaranteed to a patient by Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601(1): "211" means the abbreviated dialing code assigned by the Federal Communications Commission for consumer access to community information and referral services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601(2): "ACT team personnel" means a licensed psychiatrist or mental health therapist, or another individual, as determined by the division, who is part of an ACT team.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601(3): "Approved 211 service provider" means a public or nonprofit agency or organization designated by the department to provide 211 services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601(4)(a): "Assertive community treatment" means mental health services and on-site intervention that a person renders to an individual with a mental illness.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601(4)(b): "Assertive community treatment" includes the provision of assessment and treatment plans, rehabilitation, support services, and referrals to other community resources.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601(5): "Assertive community treatment team" or "ACT team" means a mobile team of medical and mental health professionals that provides assertive community outreach treatment and, based on the individual circumstances of each case, coordinates with other medical providers and appropriate community resources.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601(6): 58-60-102 "Mental health therapist" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601(7): 26B-5-301 "Mental illness" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601(8): Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act "Psychiatrist" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601(8)(a): Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act is licensed as a physician under
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601(8)(b): is board eligible for a psychiatry specialization recognized by the American Board of Medical Specialists or the American Osteopathic Association's Bureau of Osteopathic Specialists.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601(9)(a): "Utah 211" means an information and referral system that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601(9)(a)(i): maintains a database of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601(9)(a)(i)(A): providers of health and human services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601(9)(a)(i)(B): volunteer opportunities and coordinators throughout the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601(9)(a)(ii): assists individuals, families, and communities at no cost in identifying, understanding, and accessing the providers of health and human services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601(9)(a)(iii): works collaboratively with state agencies, local governments, community-based organizations, not-for-profit organizations, organizations active in disaster relief, and faith-based organizations.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-601(9)(b): "Utah 211" does not mean service provided by 911 and first responders.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-602 Designated approved 211 service provider -- Department responsibilities.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-602(1): The department shall designate an approved 211 service provider to provide information to Utah citizens about health and human services available in the citizen's community.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-602(2): Only a service provider approved by the department may provide 211 telephone services in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-602(3): The department shall approve a 211 service provider after considering the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-602(3)(a): the ability of the proposed 211 service provider to meet the national 211 standards recommended by the Alliance of Information and Referral Systems;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-602(3)(b): the financial stability of the proposed 211 service provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-602(3)(c): the community support for the proposed 211 service provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-602(3)(d): the relationship between the proposed 211 service provider and other information and referral services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-602(3)(e): other criteria as the department considers appropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-602(4): The department shall coordinate with the approved 211 service provider and other state and local agencies to ensure the joint development and maintenance of a statewide information database for use by the approved 211 service provider.

---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-603(1): 26B-5-601 The designated 211 service provider described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-603(2)(a)(ii): abide by the key standards for 211 programs, as specified in the Standards for Professional Information and Referral Requirements for Alliance of Information Systems Accreditation and Operating 211 systems; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-603(2)(a)(iii): be a point of entry for disaster-related information and referral;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-603(2)(c): develop, coordinate, and implement a statewide information and referral system that integrates existing community-based structures with state and local agencies;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-603(2)(g): host meetings on a quarterly basis until calendar year 2014, and on a biannual basis beginning in 2014, to seek input and guidance from state agencies, local governments, community-based organizations, not-for-profit organizations, and faith-based organizations.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-604 Other state agencies and local governments.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-604(1): A state agency or local government institution that provides health and human services, or a public or private entity receiving state-appropriated funds to provide health and human services, shall provide Utah 211 with information, in a form determined by Utah 211, about the services the agency or entity provides for inclusion in the statewide information and referral system.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-604(2): A state agency or local government institution that provides health and human services may not establish a new public telephone line or hotline, other than an emergency first responder hotline, to provide information or referrals unless the agency or institution first:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-604(2)(a): consults with Utah 211 about using the existing 211 to provide access to the information or referrals; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-604(2)(b): assesses whether a new line or the existing 211 program would be more cost effective.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-604(3): Nothing in this section prohibits a state agency or local government institution from starting a public telephone line or hotline in an emergency situation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-604(4): State agencies, local governments, community-based organizations, not-for-profit organizations, faith-based organizations, and businesses that engage in providing human services may contract with Utah 211 to provide specialized projects, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-604(4)(a): public health campaigns;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-604(4)(b): seasonal community services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-604(4)(c): expanded point of entry services.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-605 Immunity from liability.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-605(1): (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-605(1)(a): developing, adopting, implementing, maintaining, or operating the Utah 211 system;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-605(1)(b): making Utah 211 available for use by the public; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-605(1)(c): providing 211 services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-605(2): Utah 211, its employees, directors, officers, and information specialists shall be liable to any person in a civil action for an injury or loss resulting from willful or wanton misconduct.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-606 Division duties -- ACT team license creation.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-606(1): To promote the availability of assertive community treatment, the division shall make rules, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, that create a certificate for ACT team personnel and ACT teams, that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-606(1)(a): the standards the division establishes under Subsection (2); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-606(1)(b): guidelines for:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-606(1)(b)(i): required training and experience of ACT team personnel; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-606(1)(b)(ii): the coordination of assertive community treatment and other community resources.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-606(2): The division shall,in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, make rules that establish standards that an applicant is required to meet to qualify for the certifications described in Subsection (1).


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-607 Grants for development of an ACT team.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-607(1): The division shall award grants for the development of one or more ACT teams to provide assertive community treatment to individuals in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-607(2): (1) The division shall prioritize the award of a grant described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-607(2)(a): the number of individuals the proposed ACT team will serve;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-607(2)(b): the ability of the entity to provide housing to individuals served under the program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-607(2)(c): the ability of the entity to provide evidence of probable future program sustainability; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-607(2)(d): the percentage of matching funds the entity will provide to develop the proposed ACT team.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609 Department and division duties -- MCOT license creation.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(1): 63C-18-202; 26B-4-101; 26B-4-101; 58-60-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(1)(a): 63C-18-202 "Committee" means the Behavioral Health Crisis Response Committee created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(1)(b): 26B-4-101 "Emergency medical service personnel" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(1)(c): 26B-4-101 "Emergency medical services" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(1)(d): "MCOT certification" means the certification created in this part for MCOT personnel and mental health crisis outreach services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(1)(e): "MCOT personnel" means a licensed mental health therapist or other mental health professional, as determined by the division, who is a part of a mobile crisis outreach team.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(1)(f): "Mental health crisis" means a mental health condition that manifests itself by symptoms of sufficient severity that a prudent layperson who possesses an average knowledge of mental health issues could reasonably expect the absence of immediate attention or intervention to result in:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(1)(f)(i): serious jeopardy to the individual's health or well-being; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(1)(f)(ii): a danger to others.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(1)(g): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(1)(g)(i): "Mental health crisis services" means mental health services and on-site intervention that a person renders to an individual suffering from a mental health crisis.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(1)(g)(ii): "Mental health crisis services" includes the provision of safety and care plans, stabilization services offered for a minimum of 60 days, and referrals to other community resources.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(1)(h): 58-60-102 "Mental health therapist" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(1)(i): "Mobile crisis outreach team" or "MCOT" means a mobile team of medical and mental health professionals that provides mental health crisis services and, based on the individual circumstances of each case, coordinates with local law enforcement, emergency medical service personnel, and other appropriate state or local resources.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(2): 26B-5-331 To promote the availability of comprehensive mental health crisis services throughout the state, the division shall make rules, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, that create a certificate for MCOT personnel and MCOTs, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(2)(a): the standards the division establishes under Subsection (3); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(2)(b): 26B-5-331 guidelines for:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(2)(b)(i): credit for training and experience; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(2)(b)(ii): 26B-5-331 the coordination of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(2)(b)(ii)(A): emergency medical services and mental health crisis services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(2)(b)(ii)(B): law enforcement, emergency medical service personnel, and mobile crisis outreach teams; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(2)(b)(ii)(C): 26B-5-331 temporary commitment in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(3)(a): The division shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(3)(a)(i): in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, make rules that establish standards that an applicant is required to meet to qualify for the MCOT certification described in Subsection (2); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(3)(a)(ii): create a statewide MCOT plan that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(3)(a)(ii)(A): identifies statewide mental health crisis services needs, objectives, and priorities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(3)(a)(ii)(B): identifies the equipment, facilities, personnel training, and other resources necessary to provide mental health crisis services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-609(3)(b): The division shall take the action described in Subsection (3)(a) with recommendations from the committee.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610 Contracts for statewide mental health crisis line and statewide warm line -- Crisis worker and certified peer support specialist qualification or certification -- Operational standards.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(1): 63C-18-202; 26B-5-609; 58-60-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(1)(a): "Certified peer support specialist" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(1)(a)(i): meets the standards of qualification or certification that the division sets, in accordance with Subsection (3); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(1)(a)(ii): staffs the statewide warm line under the supervision of at least one mental health therapist.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(1)(b): 63C-18-202 "Committee" means the Behavioral Health Crisis Response Committee created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(1)(c): "Crisis worker" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(1)(c)(i): meets the standards of qualification or certification that the division sets, in accordance with Subsection (3); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(1)(c)(ii): staffs the statewide mental health crisis line, the statewide warm line, or a local mental health crisis line under the supervision of at least one mental health therapist.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(1)(d): "Local mental health crisis line" means a phone number or other response system that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(1)(d)(i): accessible within a particular geographic area of the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(1)(d)(ii): intended to allow an individual to contact and interact with a qualified mental or behavioral health professional.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(1)(e): 26B-5-609 "Mental health crisis" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(1)(f): 58-60-102 "Mental health therapist" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(1)(g): "Statewide mental health crisis line" means a statewide phone number or other response system that allows an individual to contact and interact with a qualified mental or behavioral health professional 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(1)(h): "Statewide warm line" means a statewide phone number or other response system that allows an individual to contact and interact with a qualified mental or behavioral health professional or a certified peer support specialist.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(2)(a): The division shall enter into a new contract or modify an existing contract to manage and operate, in accordance with this part, the statewide mental health crisis line and the statewide warm line.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(2)(b)(i): Through the contracts described in Subsection (2)(a), the division shall set standards of care and practice for:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(2)(b)(i)(A): the mental health therapists and crisis workers who staff the statewide mental health crisis line; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(2)(b)(i)(B): the mental health therapists, crisis workers, and certified peer support specialists who staff the statewide warm line.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(2)(b)(ii): The division shall set the standards described in Subsection (2)(b)(i) in consultation with the committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(3)(a): The division shall establish training and minimum standards for the qualification or certification of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(3)(a)(i): crisis workers who staff the statewide mental health crisis line, the statewide warm line, and local mental health crisis lines; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(3)(a)(ii): certified peer support specialists who staff the statewide warm line.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(3)(b): The division may make rules, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, necessary to establish the training and minimum standards described in Subsection (3)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(4)(a): The division shall ensure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(4)(a)(i): the following individuals are available to staff and answer calls to the statewide mental health crisis line 24 hours per day, 365 days per calendar year:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(4)(a)(i)(A): mental health therapists; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(4)(a)(i)(B): crisis workers;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(4)(a)(ii): a sufficient amount of staff is available to ensure that when an individual calls the statewide mental health crisis line, regardless of the time, date, or number of individuals trying to simultaneously access the statewide mental health crisis line, an individual described in Subsection (4)(a)(i) answers the call without the caller first:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(4)(a)(ii)(A): waiting on hold; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(4)(a)(ii)(B): being screened by an individual other than a mental health therapist or crisis worker;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(4)(a)(iii): the statewide mental health crisis line has capacity to accept all calls that local mental health crisis lines route to the statewide mental health crisis line;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(4)(a)(iv): the following individuals are available to staff and answer calls to the statewide warm line during the hours and days of operation set by the division under Subsection (5):
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(4)(a)(iv)(A): mental health therapists;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(4)(a)(iv)(B): crisis workers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(4)(a)(iv)(C): certified peer support specialists;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(4)(a)(v): when an individual calls the statewide mental health crisis line, the individual's call may be transferred to the statewide warm line if the individual is not experiencing a mental health crisis; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(4)(a)(vi): when an individual calls the statewide warm line, the individual's call may be transferred to the statewide mental health crisis line if the individual is experiencing a mental health crisis.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(4)(b): The division shall take the actions described in Subsection (4)(a) in consultation with the committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-610(5): The division shall make rules, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to establish the hours and days of operation for the statewide warm line.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611 Suicide prevention -- Reporting requirements.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(1): 53-10-201; 26B-5-702; 26B-1-325 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(1)(a): 53-10-201 "Bureau" means the Bureau of Criminal Identification created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(1)(b): "Coalition" means the Statewide Suicide Prevention Coalition created under Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(1)(c): 26B-5-702 "Commission" means the Utah Behavioral Health Commission created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(1)(d): "Coordinator" means the state suicide prevention coordinator appointed under Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(1)(e): 26B-1-325 "Fund" means the Governor's Suicide Prevention Fund created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(1)(f): "Intervention" means an effort to prevent a person from attempting suicide.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(1)(g): "Legal intervention" means an incident in which an individual is shot by another individual who has legal authority to use deadly force.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(1)(h): "Postvention" means intervention after a suicide attempt or a suicide death to reduce risk and promote healing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(1)(i): "Shooter" means an individual who uses a gun in an act that results in the death of the actor or another individual, whether the act was a suicide, homicide, legal intervention, act of self-defense, or accident.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(2): The division shall appoint a state suicide prevention coordinator to, under the direction of the commission, administer a state suicide prevention program composed of suicide prevention, intervention, and postvention programs, services, and efforts.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(3): The coordinator shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(3)(a): establish a Statewide Suicide Prevention Committee with membership from public and private organizations and Utah citizens; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(3)(b): appoint a chair and co-chair from among the membership of the coalition to lead the coalition.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(4): The state suicide prevention program may include the following components:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(4)(a): delivery of resources, tools, and training to community-based coalitions;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(4)(b): evidence-based suicide risk assessment tools and training;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(4)(c): town hall meetings for building community-based suicide prevention strategies;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(4)(d): suicide prevention gatekeeper training;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(4)(e): training to identify warning signs and to manage an at-risk individual's crisis;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(4)(f): evidence-based intervention training;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(4)(g): intervention skills training;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(4)(h): postvention training; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(4)(i): a public education campaign to improve public awareness about warning signs of suicide and suicide prevention resources.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(5): 53G-9-702 The coordinator shall coordinate with the following to gather statistics, among other duties:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(5)(a): local mental health and substance abuse authorities;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(5)(b): 53G-9-702 the State Board of Education, including the public education suicide prevention coordinator described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(5)(c): applicable divisions and offices within the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(5)(d): health care providers, including emergency rooms;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(5)(e): federal agencies, including the Federal Bureau of Investigation;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(5)(f): other unbiased sources; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(5)(g): other public health suicide prevention efforts.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(6): 26B-5-102 The coordinator shall, in consultation with the bureau, implement and manage the operation of the firearm safety program described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(7): 26B-5-110; 26B-5-102; 26B-5-102 In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the division shall make rules:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(7)(a): governing the implementation of the state suicide prevention program, consistent with this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-611(7)(b): 26B-5-110; 26B-5-102; 26B-5-102 in conjunction with the bureau, defining the criteria for employers to apply for grants under the Suicide Prevention Education Program described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-612(4)(d): the sustainability and reliability of the local mental health authority's proposed project.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-612(5)(c): recommendations for expanding a project statewide.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-701 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-701(1): 26B-5-702 "Commission" means the Utah Behavioral Health Commission created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-701(2): "Master plan" means the Utah Behavioral Health Assessment and Master Plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-701(3): "Mental disorder" means the same as that term is defined in the current edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders published by the American Psychiatric Association.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-701(4): "Substance use disorder" means the same as that term is defined in the current edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders published by the American Psychiatric Association.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702 Utah Behavioral Health Commission -- Creation -- Members -- Chair.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(1): There is created within the department the Utah Behavioral Health Commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(2): The commission is composed of the following 11 members:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(2)(a): one individual who has lived experience with a substance use disorder, appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the Senate;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(2)(b): one individual who has lived experience with a mental disorder, appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the Senate;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(2)(c): one individual who represents families of individuals with behavioral health issues, appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the Senate;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(2)(d): one individual who represents state behavioral health agencies, appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the Senate;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(2)(e): one individual who represents major healthcare systems, appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the Senate;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(2)(f): one individual who represents private acute care providers, appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the Senate;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(2)(g): one individual who represents private outpatient providers, appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the Senate;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(2)(h): one individual who represents county behavioral health authorities, appointed by the chair of the Utah Behavioral Healthcare Committee with the advice and consent of the Senate;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(2)(i): one individual who represents rural communities, appointed by the speaker of the House of Representatives;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(2)(j): one individual who represents large employers, appointed by the president of the Senate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(2)(k): one individual who represents historically underrepresented populations, appointed by the joint minority caucus leaders.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(3)(a): After all 11 members of the commission have been appointed, the governor shall appoint the chair of the commission from among the membership of the commission to serve a two-year term.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(3)(b): A commission member may not serve as chair of the commission for more than two consecutive terms.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(4)(a): A member appointed by the governor shall serve a four-year term, except as provided in Subsection (4)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(4)(b): The governor shall stagger the initial terms of appointees so that approximately half of the members appointed by the governor are appointed every two years.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(4)(c): The terms of members appointed under Subsections (2)(h) through (k) shall be staggered so that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(4)(c)(i): members appointed under Subsections (2)(h) and (i) shall serve four-year terms;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(4)(c)(ii): the initial members appointed under Subsections (2)(j) and (k) shall serve an initial two-year term; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(4)(c)(iii): after the initial members appointed under Subsections (2)(j) and (k) serve an initial two-year term, members appointed under Subsections (2)(j) and (k) shall serve four-year terms.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(4)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(4)(d)(i): The commission may remove a member of the commission for cause by a majority vote of the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(4)(d)(ii): The person who appointed a member of the commission may remove that member for cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(4)(e): If a vacancy occurs in the membership of the commission for any reason, a replacement shall be appointed for the unexpired term in the same manner as the original appointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(5)(a): A majority of the members of the commission constitutes a quorum.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(5)(b): The action of a majority of a quorum of the commission constitutes the action of the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(6): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 A member of the commission may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service, but may receive per diem and travel expenses in accordance with:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-702(7): Consistent with the provisions of this part, the commission may adopt bylaws to govern the commission's operation.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703 Purpose -- Duties -- Reporting.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(1): The purpose of the commission is to be the central authority for coordinating behavioral health initiatives between state and local governments, health systems, and other interested persons, to ensure that Utah's behavioral health systems are comprehensive, aligned, effective, and efficient.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(2): 26B-5-611 To fulfill the commission's purpose, the commission shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(2)(a): establish a shared vision across public and private sectors for improving Utah's behavioral health systems;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(2)(b): make recommendations, including policy recommendations, and advise the governor, executive branch agencies, and the Legislature on matters pertaining to behavioral health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(2)(c): provide feedback on proposed bills, rules, policies, and budgets relating to behavioral health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(2)(d): encourage participation in the commission's work by individuals and populations directly impacted by behavioral health issues, including family members of individuals with behavioral health issues;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(2)(e): engage private sector payers, providers, and business and employer groups in the commission's work;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(2)(f): continually review and revise the master plan as appropriate;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(2)(g): identify priorities and lead efforts to implement and advance those priorities by coordinating and collaborating closely with public and private persons throughout the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(2)(h): identify areas where innovation is necessary to improve behavioral health access and care;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(2)(i): cooperate with the Utah System of Higher Education, the State Board of Education, the Division of Professional Licensing, the Utah Health Workforce Advisory Council, and the department to oversee the creation and implementation of behavioral health workforce initiatives for the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(2)(j): collaborate with the Utah State Hospital, the Department of Corrections, county jails, and the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(2)(k): 26B-5-611 oversee coordination for the funding, implementation, and evaluation of suicide prevention efforts described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(2)(l): develop methods or models for implementing and coherently communicating cross-sector strategies;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(2)(m): hold the state's behavioral health systems accountable for clear, measurable outcomes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(2)(n): maintain independence from the department and the governor such that the commission and its committees are able to provide independent advice and recommendations, especially regarding proposed bills and policy considerations.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(3): 52-4-204; 52-4-205
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(3)(a): The commission shall meet at least quarterly, but may meet at other times as scheduled by the chair.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(3)(b): The chair of the commission shall set the agenda for each commission meeting with input from commission members and staff.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(3)(c): Notice of the time and place of a commission meeting shall be given to each member and to the public in compliance with Title 52, Chapter 4, Open and Public Meetings Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(3)(d): 52-4-204; 52-4-205 A commission meeting is open to the public unless the meeting or a portion of a meeting is closed by the commission pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(4): On or before December 31, 2024, the commission shall provide a report to the Legislature that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(4)(a): recommendations for behavioral health measures and targets to be included in the next update to the master plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(4)(b): recommendations for consolidating into the commission other commissions, committees, subcommittees, task forces, working groups, or other bodies pertaining to behavioral health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(4)(c): recommendations on the next steps for reviewing and potentially redefining state law and program options regarding county-based behavioral health services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(4)(d): recommendations on key budget priorities and key legislative policies for the 2025 General Session and thereafter.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(5): 26B-5-705; 26B-5-705
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(5)(a): 26B-5-705 Beginning in 2025, by no later than September 30 of each year, the commission shall provide a report to the Health and Human Services Interim Committee that describes the commission's work during the preceding year and includes, in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(5)(b): 26B-5-705 Before the commission submits a legislative recommendation to the Health and Human Services Interim Committee or the Legislature, the Legislative Policy Committee created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-703(6): Neither the commission nor a committee of the commission may obtain any individual's health or medical information, whether identifiable or deidentified, without first obtaining the consent of the individual or the individual's legal representative.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705 Legislative Policy Committee -- Creation -- Duties -- Staff.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(1): As used in this section, "committee" means the Legislative Policy Committee created in Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(2): Under the commission, there is created the Legislative Policy Committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(3)(a): The committee is composed of five legislators, appointed as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(3)(a)(i): the speaker of the House of Representatives shall appoint one member of the House of Representatives;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(3)(a)(ii): the minority leader of the House of Representatives shall appoint one member of the House of Representatives;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(3)(a)(iii): the president of the Senate shall appoint one member of the Senate;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(3)(a)(iv): the minority leader of the Senate shall appoint one member of the Senate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(3)(a)(v): the speaker of the House of Representatives and the president of the Senate shall jointly appoint one legislator.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(3)(b): The speaker, president, and minority leaders:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(3)(b)(i): shall make the appointments described in Subsection (3)(a) after consulting with the chairs of the Health and Human Services Interim Committee and the chairs of the Social Services Appropriations Subcommittee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(3)(b)(ii): are encouraged but not required to appoint to the committee legislators who are members of one or more of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(3)(b)(ii)(A): the Health and Human Services Interim Committee; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(3)(b)(ii)(B): the Social Services Appropriations Subcommittee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(4): The speaker of the House of Representatives and the president of the Senate shall each designate one of their appointees as a co-chair of the committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(5): The individual who appoints a member of the committee may change the appointment at any time.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(6): The committee shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(6)(a): assist the commission and any of the commission's other committees with developing policy and legislative recommendations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(6)(b): review any legislative recommendation proposed by the commission before the legislative recommendation is provided to the Health and Human Services Interim Committee or the Legislature.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(7): The committee may:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(7)(a): submit its own proposed legislation to the commission for consideration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(7)(b): provide other services as requested by the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(8)(a): A majority of the members of the committee constitutes a quorum.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(8)(b): The action of a majority of a quorum constitutes the action of the committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-705(9): The Office of Legislative Research and General Counsel shall provide staff support to the committee.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803 Duties of council.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1): 26B-5-702; 26B-5-802; 32B-2-306 Under the direction of the Utah Behavioral Health Commission created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(a): provide leadership and generate unity for Utah's ongoing efforts to reduce and eliminate the impact of substance use and mental health disorders in Utah through a comprehensive and evidence-based prevention, treatment, and justice strategy;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(b): recommend and coordinate the creation, dissemination, and implementation of statewide policies to address substance use and mental health disorders;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(c): facilitate planning for a balanced continuum of substance use and mental health disorder prevention, treatment, and justice services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(d): promote collaboration and mutually beneficial public and private partnerships;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(e): 26B-5-802 coordinate recommendations made by any subcommittee created under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(f): analyze and provide an objective assessment of all proposed legislation concerning substance use, mental health, forensic mental health, and related issues;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(g): 32B-2-306 comply with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(h): advise the Department of Health and Human Services regarding the state hospital admissions policy for individuals in the custody of the Department of Corrections;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(i): regarding the interaction between an individual with a mental illness or an intellectual disability and the civil commitment system, criminal justice system, or juvenile justice system:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(i)(i): promote communication between and coordination among all agencies interacting with the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(i)(ii): study, evaluate, and recommend changes to laws and procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(i)(iii): identify and promote the implementation of specific policies and programs to deal fairly and efficiently with the individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(i)(iv): promote judicial education;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(j): study the long-term need for adult patient staffed beds at the state hospital, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(j)(i): the total number of staffed beds currently in use at the state hospital;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(j)(ii): the current staffed bed capacity at the state hospital;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(j)(iii): the projected total number of staffed beds needed in the adult general psychiatric unit of the state hospital over the next three, five, and 10 years based on:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(j)(iii)(A): the state's current and projected population growth;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(j)(iii)(B): current access to mental health resources in the community; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(j)(iii)(C): any other factors the committee finds relevant to projecting the total number of staffed beds; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(j)(iv): the cost associated with the projected total number of staffed beds described in Subsection (1)(j)(iii); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(1)(k): each year report on whether the pay of the state hospital's employees is adequate based on market conditions.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(2): The committee shall meet quarterly or more frequently as determined necessary by the chair.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(3): The committee shall report:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(3)(a): with the assistance and staff support from the state hospital, regarding the items described in Subsections (1)(j) and (k), including any recommendations, to the Utah Behavioral Health Commission on or before July 31 of each year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-5-803(3)(b): any other recommendations annually to the commission, the governor, the Legislature, and the Judicial Council.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-101 Chapter definitions.
----------------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-101(1): Part 4, Division of Services for People with Disabilities; Chapter 5, Health Care - Substance Use and Mental Health "Adult" or "high risk adult" means a person 18 years old or older who experiences a condition:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-101(1)(a): that places the person at a high risk of being unable to care for themselves:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-101(1)(a)(i): as determined by assessment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-101(1)(a)(ii): due to the onset of a physical or cognitive impairment or frailty; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-101(1)(b): Part 4, Division of Services for People with Disabilities; Chapter 5, Health Care - Substance Use and Mental Health for which the person is not eligible to receive services under:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-101(1)(b)(i): Part 4, Division of Services for People with Disabilities
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-101(1)(b)(ii): Chapter 5, Health Care - Substance Use and Mental Health
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-101(2): "Aging" and "aged" means a person 60 years old or older.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-101(3): "Area agency" means an area agency that provides services to the aged, high risk adults, or both within a planning and service area.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-101(4): (4)(a) "Area agency on aging" means a public or private nonprofit agency or office designated by the division to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-101(4)(a): operate within a planning and service area of the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-101(4)(b): (4)(a) develop and implement a broad range of services for the aged in the area described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-101(5): (5)(a) "Area agency on high risk adults" means a public or private nonprofit agency or office designated by the division to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-101(5)(a): operate within a planning and service area of the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-101(5)(b): (5)(a) develop and implement services for high risk adults in the area described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-102 Division created.
-------------------------------------------------
There is created a Division of Aging and Adult Services within the department, under the administration and general supervision of the executive director.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-103 Director of division -- Appointment -- Qualifications.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-103(1): The director of the division shall be appointed by the executive director with the concurrence of the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-103(2): The director shall have a bachelor's degree from an accredited university or college, be experienced in administration, and be knowledgeable in matters concerning the aging and adult populations.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-103(3): The director is the administrative head of the division.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-104 Authority of division.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-104(1)(b): develop and administer a state plan under the policy direction of the board; and

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-106 Contracts for services.
-------------------------------------------------------
When an area agency has established a plan to provide services authorized by this chapter, and those services meet standards fixed by rules of the board, the area agency may enter into a contract with the division for services to be furnished by that area agency for an agreed compensation to be paid by the division.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-109 Eligibility criteria.
-----------------------------------------------------
Eligibility for services provided by the division directly or through contractual arrangements shall be determined by criteria established by the division and approved by the board.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-112 Allocation of funds to acquire facilities.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-112(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-112(1)(a): The board may make grants to local area agencies on aging to acquire facilities to provide community-based services for aged persons.  Grants under this section shall be made solely from appropriations made to the division for implementation of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-112(1)(b): Acquisition of a facility may include acquisition of real property, construction of a new facility, acquisition of an existing facility, or alteration, renovation, or improvement of an existing facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-112(1)(c): The local area agency may allocate grants received under this section to a local nonprofit or governmental agency that owns or operates a facility to provide community-based services for aged persons.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-112(2): A local area agency on aging or the local nonprofit or governmental agency that owns or operates the facility and receives grant money from the area agency shall provide a matching contribution of at least 25% of the grant funds it receives under this section.  A matching contribution may include funds, services, property, or other in-kind contributions.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-112(3): In making grants under this section, the board may consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-112(3)(a): the extent and availability of public and private funding to operate programs in the facility to be acquired and to provide for maintenance of that facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-112(3)(b): the need for community-based services in the geographical area served by the area agency on aging;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-112(3)(c): the availability of private and local funds to assist in acquisition, alteration, renovation, or improvement of the facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-112(3)(d): the extent and level of support for acquisition of the facility from local government officials, private citizens, interest groups, and others.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-112(4): 26B-6-104(8) Grants to local area agencies on aging and any local nonprofit or governmental agency that owns or operates a facility and receives grant money from the area agency under this section are subject to the oversight and control by the division described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-112(5): It is the intent of the Legislature that the grants made under this section serve the statewide purpose of providing support for senior citizens throughout the state, and that the grants shall be made to serve as effectively as possible the facilities in greatest need of assistance.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-113 Allocation of funds to local area agencies -- Formulas.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-113(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-113(1)(a): The board shall establish by rule formulas for allocating funds to local area agencies through contracts to provide programs and services in accordance with this part based on need.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-113(1)(b): Determination of need shall be based on the number of eligible persons located in the local area which the division is authorized to serve, unless federal regulations require otherwise or the board establishes, by valid and accepted data, that other defined factors are relevant and reliable indicators of need.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-113(1)(c): Formulas established by the board shall include a differential to compensate for additional costs of providing services in rural areas.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-113(2): (1) Formulas established under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-113(2)(a): funds that local area agencies receive from sources other than the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-113(2)(b): funds that local area agencies receive from the division to operate a specific program within its jurisdiction which is available to all residents of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-113(2)(c): funds that a local area agency receives from the division to meet a need that exists only within that local area; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-113(2)(d): funds that a local area agency receives from the division for research projects.
