Adjudicative proceedings held by, or relating to, the division or the board shall comply with the procedures and requirements of

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(1): "Abandonment" means any knowing or intentional action or failure to act, including desertion, by a person acting as a caretaker for a vulnerable adult that leaves the vulnerable adult without the means or ability to obtain necessary food, clothing, shelter, or medical or other health care.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(2): 76-5-111 "Abuse" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(2)(a): knowingly or intentionally:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(2)(a)(i): attempting to cause harm;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(2)(a)(ii): causing harm; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(2)(a)(iii): placing another in fear of harm;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(2)(b): unreasonable or inappropriate use of physical restraint, medication, or isolation that causes or is likely to cause harm to a vulnerable adult;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(2)(c): emotional or psychological abuse;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(2)(d): a sexual offense as described in Title 76, Chapter 5, Offenses Against the Individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(2)(e): 76-5-111 deprivation of life sustaining treatment, or medical or mental health treatment, except:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(2)(e)(i): as provided in Title 75A, Chapter 3, Health Care Decisions; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(2)(e)(ii): 76-5-111 when informed consent, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(3): "Adult" means an individual who is 18 years old or older.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(4): "Adult protection case file" means a record, stored in any format, contained in a case file maintained by Adult Protective Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(5): "Adult Protective Services" means the unit within the division responsible to investigate abuse, neglect, and exploitation of vulnerable adults and provide appropriate protective services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(6): "Capacity to consent" means the ability of an individual to understand and communicate regarding the nature and consequences of decisions relating to the individual, and relating to the individual's property and lifestyle, including a decision to accept or refuse services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(7): "Caretaker" means a person or public institution that is entrusted with or assumes the responsibility to provide a vulnerable adult with care, food, shelter, clothing, supervision, medical or other health care, resource management, or other necessities for pecuniary gain, by contract, or as a result of friendship, or who is otherwise in a position of trust and confidence with a vulnerable adult, including a relative, a household member, an attorney-in-fact, a neighbor, a person who is employed or who provides volunteer work, a court-appointed or voluntary guardian, or a person who contracts or is under court order to provide care.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(8): "Counsel" means an attorney licensed to practice law in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(9): 26B-6-210 "Database" means the statewide database maintained by the division under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(10)(a): "Dependent adult" means an individual 18 years old or older, who has a physical or mental impairment that restricts the individual's ability to carry out normal activities or to protect the individual's rights.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(10)(b): "Dependent adult" includes an individual who has physical or developmental disabilities or whose physical or mental capacity has substantially diminished because of age.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(11): "Elder abuse" means abuse, neglect, or exploitation of an elder adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(12): "Elder adult" means an individual 65 years old or older.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(13): "Emergency" means a circumstance in which a vulnerable adult is at an immediate risk of death, serious physical injury, or serious physical, emotional, or financial harm.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(14): "Emergency protective services" means measures taken by Adult Protective Services under time-limited, court-ordered authority for the purpose of remediating an emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(15): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(15)(a): "Emotional or psychological abuse" means knowing or intentional verbal or nonverbal conduct directed at a vulnerable adult that results in the vulnerable adult suffering mental anguish, emotional distress, fear, humiliation, degradation, agitation, or confusion.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(15)(b): "Emotional or psychological abuse" includes intimidating, threatening, isolating, coercing, or harassing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(15)(c): "Emotional or psychological abuse" does not include verbal or non-verbal conduct by a vulnerable adult who lacks the capacity to intentionally or knowingly:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(15)(c)(i): engage in the conduct; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(15)(c)(ii): cause mental anguish, emotional distress, fear, humiliation, degradation, agitation, or confusion.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(16): 76-5-111.3; 76-5-111.4; 76-5b-202 "Exploitation" means an offense described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(17): "Harm" means pain, mental anguish, emotional distress, hurt, physical or psychological damage, physical injury, serious physical injury, suffering, or distress inflicted knowingly or intentionally.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(18): "Inconclusive" means a finding by the division that there is not a reasonable basis to conclude that abuse, neglect, or exploitation occurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(19): "Intimidation" means communication through verbal or nonverbal conduct which threatens deprivation of money, food, clothing, medicine, shelter, social interaction, supervision, health care, or companionship, or which threatens isolation or abuse.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(20): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(20)(a): "Isolation" means knowingly or intentionally preventing a vulnerable adult from having contact with another person, unless the restriction of personal rights is authorized by court order, by:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(20)(a)(i): preventing the vulnerable adult from communicating, visiting, interacting, or initiating interaction with others, including receiving or inviting visitors, mail, or telephone calls, contrary to the expressed wishes of the vulnerable adult, or communicating to a visitor that the vulnerable adult is not present or does not want to meet with or talk to the visitor, knowing that communication to be false;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(20)(a)(ii): physically restraining the vulnerable adult in order to prevent the vulnerable adult from meeting with a visitor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(20)(a)(iii): making false or misleading statements to the vulnerable adult in order to induce the vulnerable adult to refuse to receive communication from visitors or other family members.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(20)(b): "Isolation" does not include an act:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(20)(b)(i): intended in good faith to protect the physical or mental welfare of the vulnerable adult; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(20)(b)(ii): performed pursuant to the treatment plan or instructions of a physician or other professional advisor of the vulnerable adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(21): 76-5-111.4 "Lacks capacity to consent" is as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(22): Title 75A, Chapter 3, Health Care Decisions
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(22)(a): "Neglect" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(22)(a)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(22)(a)(i)(A): failure of a caretaker to provide necessary care, including nutrition, clothing, shelter, supervision, personal care, or dental, medical, or other health care for a vulnerable adult, unless the vulnerable adult is able to provide or obtain the necessary care without assistance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(22)(a)(i)(B): failure of a caretaker to provide protection from health and safety hazards or maltreatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(22)(a)(ii): failure of a caretaker to provide care to a vulnerable adult in a timely manner and with the degree of care that a reasonable person in a like position would exercise;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(22)(a)(iii): a pattern of conduct by a caretaker, without the vulnerable adult's informed consent, resulting in deprivation of food, water, medication, health care, shelter, cooling, heating, or other services necessary to maintain the vulnerable adult's well being;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(22)(a)(iv): knowing or intentional failure by a caretaker to carry out a prescribed treatment plan that causes or is likely to cause harm to the vulnerable adult;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(22)(a)(v): self-neglect by the vulnerable adult; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(22)(a)(vi): abandonment by a caretaker.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(22)(b): Title 75A, Chapter 3, Health Care Decisions "Neglect" does not include conduct, or failure to take action, that is permitted or excused under
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(23): 76-5-111 "Physical injury" includes the damage and conditions described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(24): "Protected person" means a vulnerable adult for whom the court has ordered protective services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(25): "Protective services" means services to protect a vulnerable adult from abuse, neglect, or exploitation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(26): "Self-neglect" means the failure of a vulnerable adult to provide or obtain food, water, medication, health care, shelter, cooling, heating, safety, or other services necessary to maintain the vulnerable adult's well being when that failure is the result of the adult's mental or physical impairment.  Choice of lifestyle or living arrangements may not, by themselves, be evidence of self-neglect.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(27): 76-5-111 "Serious physical injury" is as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(28): "Supported" means a finding by the division that there is a reasonable basis to conclude that abuse, neglect, or exploitation occurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(29): "Undue influence" occurs when a person:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(29)(a): uses influence to take advantage of a vulnerable adult's mental or physical impairment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(29)(b): uses the person's role, relationship, or power:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(29)(b)(i): to exploit, or knowingly assist or cause another to exploit, the trust, dependency, or fear of a vulnerable adult; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(29)(b)(ii): to gain control deceptively over the decision making of the vulnerable adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(30): "Vulnerable adult" means an elder adult, or a dependent adult who has a mental or physical impairment which substantially affects that person's ability to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(30)(a): provide personal protection;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(30)(b): provide necessities such as food, shelter, clothing, or mental or other health care;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(30)(c): obtain services necessary for health, safety, or welfare;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(30)(d): carry out the activities of daily living;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(30)(e): manage the adult's own financial resources; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(30)(f): comprehend the nature and consequences of remaining in a situation of abuse, neglect, or exploitation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-201(31): "Without merit" means a finding that abuse, neglect, or exploitation did not occur.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-202 Purpose of Adult Protective Services Program.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Subject to the rules made by the division under SectionUtah Code Annotated § 26B-6-202(1): shall investigate or cause to be investigated reports of alleged abuse, neglect, or exploitation of vulnerable adults;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-202(2): shall, where appropriate, provide short-term, limited protective services with the permission of the affected vulnerable adult or the guardian or conservator of the vulnerable adult;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-202(3): 26B-6-217 shall, subject to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-202(4): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act may make rules, in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-202(4)(a): reporting and investigating incidents of abuse, neglect, or exploitation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-202(4)(b): providing protective services to the extent that funds are appropriated by the Legislature for this purpose.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203 Powers and duties of Adult Protective Services.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In addition to all other powers and duties that Adult Protective Services is given under this part, Adult Protective Services:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(1): shall maintain an intake system for receiving and screening reports;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(2): shall investigate referrals that meet the intake criteria;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(3): shall conduct assessments of vulnerability and functional capacity as it relates to an allegation of abuse, neglect, or exploitation of an adult who is the subject of a report;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(4): shall perform assessments based on protective needs and risks for a vulnerable adult who is the subject of a report;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(5): may address any protective needs by making recommendations to and coordinating with the vulnerable adult or by making referrals to community resources;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(6): may provide short-term, limited services to a vulnerable adult when family or community resources are not available to provide for the protective needs of the vulnerable adult;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(7): shall have access to facilities licensed by, or contracted with, the department for the purpose of conducting investigations;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(8): shall be given access to, or provided with, written statements, documents, exhibits, and other items related to an investigation, including private, controlled, or protected medical or financial records of a vulnerable adult who is the subject of an investigation if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(8)(a): for a vulnerable adult who has the capacity to consent, the vulnerable adult signs a release of information; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(8)(b): an administrative subpoena is issued by Adult Protective Services:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(8)(b)(i): for a vulnerable adult who has limited capacity to consent;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(8)(b)(ii): for a vulnerable adult whose legal guardian refuses to consent;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(8)(b)(iii): to a custodian of records or other items for a vulnerable adult, if the custodian refuses to allow access to the records or items without a subpoena; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(8)(b)(iv): when the records or other items sought are reasonably necessary for Adult Protective Services to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(8)(b)(iv)(A): investigate the alleged abuse, neglect, or exploitation of a vulnerable adult; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(8)(b)(iv)(B): protect the vulnerable adult who may be the victim of abuse, neglect, or exploitation;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(9): may initiate proceedings in a court of competent jurisdiction to seek relief necessary to carry out the provisions of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(10): 26B-6-217 shall, subject to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(11): may require all persons, including family members of a vulnerable adult and any caretaker, to cooperate with Adult Protective Services in carrying out its duties under this chapter, including the provision of statements, documents, exhibits, and other items that assist Adult Protective Services in conducting investigations and providing protective services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(12): may require all officials, agencies, departments, and political subdivisions of the state to assist and cooperate within their jurisdictional power with the court, the division, and Adult Protective Services in furthering the purposes of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(13): may conduct studies and compile data regarding abuse, neglect, and exploitation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-203(14): may issue reports and recommendations.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-204 Cooperation by caretaker.
---------------------------------------------------------
A caretaker, facility, or other institution shall, regardless of the confidentiality standards of the caretaker, facility, or institution:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-204(1): report abuse, neglect, or exploitation of a vulnerable adult in accordance with this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-204(2): cooperate with any Adult Protective Services investigation;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-204(3): provide Adult Protective Services with access to records or documents relating to the vulnerable adult who is the subject of an investigation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-204(4): provide evidence in any judicial or administrative proceeding relating to a vulnerable adult who is the subject of an investigation.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205 Reporting requirements -- Investigation -- Exceptions -- Immunity -- Penalties -- Nonmedical healing.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(1): Except as provided in Subsection (4), if an individual has reason to believe that a vulnerable adult is, or has been, the subject of abuse, neglect, or exploitation, the individual shall immediately report the suspected abuse, neglect, or exploitation to Adult Protective Services or to the nearest peace officer or law enforcement agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(2)(a): If a peace officer or a law enforcement agency receives a report under Subsection (1), the peace officer or the law enforcement agency shall immediately notify Adult Protective Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(2)(b): Adult Protective Services and the peace officer or the law enforcement agency shall coordinate, as appropriate, efforts to investigate the report under Subsection (1) and to provide protection to the vulnerable adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(3): When a report under Subsection (1), or a subsequent investigation by Adult Protective Services, indicates that a criminal offense may have occurred against a vulnerable adult:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(3)(a): Adult Protective Services shall notify the nearest local law enforcement agency regarding the potential offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(3)(b): the law enforcement agency shall initiate an investigation in cooperation with Adult Protective Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(4): Subject to Subsection (5), the reporting requirement described in Subsection (1) does not apply to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(4)(a): a member of the clergy, with regard to any confession made to the member of the clergy while functioning in the ministerial capacity of the member of the clergy and without the consent of the individual making the confession, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(4)(a)(i): the perpetrator made the confession directly to the member of the clergy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(4)(a)(ii): the member of the clergy is, under canon law or church doctrine or practice, bound to maintain the confidentiality of that confession; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(4)(b): an attorney, or an individual employed by the attorney, if knowledge of the suspected abuse, neglect, or exploitation of a vulnerable adult arises from the representation of a client, unless the attorney is permitted to reveal the suspected abuse, neglect, or exploitation of the vulnerable adult to prevent reasonably certain death or substantial bodily harm in accordance with Utah Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 1.6.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(5)(a): When a member of the clergy receives information about abuse, neglect, or exploitation of a vulnerable adult from any source other than confession of the perpetrator, the member of the clergy is required to report that information even though the member of the clergy may have also received information about abuse, neglect, or exploitation from the confession of the perpetrator.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(5)(b): Exemption of the reporting requirement for an individual described in Subsection (4) does not exempt the individual from any other efforts required by law to prevent further abuse, neglect, or exploitation of a vulnerable adult by the perpetrator.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(6)(a): As used in this Subsection (6), "physician" means an individual licensed to practice as a physician or osteopath in this state under Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act, or Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(6)(b): The physician-patient privilege does not:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(6)(b)(i): excuse a physician from reporting suspected abuse, neglect, or exploitation of a vulnerable adult under Subsection (1); or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(6)(b)(ii): constitute grounds for excluding evidence regarding a vulnerable adult's injuries, or the cause of the vulnerable adult's injuries, in any judicial or administrative proceeding resulting from a report under Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(7): 26B-2-238
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(7)(a): An individual who in good faith makes a report under Subsection (1), or who otherwise notifies Adult Protective Services or a peace officer or law enforcement agency, is immune from civil and criminal liability in connection with the report or notification.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(7)(b): 26B-2-238 A covered provider or covered contractor, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(7)(c): This Subsection (7) does not provide immunity with respect to acts or omissions of a governmental employee except as provided in Title 63G, Chapter 7, Governmental Immunity Act of Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(8): 80-2-603; 58-60-102; 53-13-103; 53E-6-102 If Adult Protective Services has substantial grounds to believe that an individual has knowingly failed to report suspected abuse, neglect, or exploitation of a vulnerable adult in accordance with this section, Adult Protective Services shall file a complaint with:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(8)(a): 80-2-603; 58-60-102 the Division of Professional Licensing if the individual is a health care provider, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(8)(b): 53-13-103 the appropriate law enforcement agency if the individual is a law enforcement officer, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(8)(c): 53E-6-102 the State Board of Education if the individual is an educator, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(9)(a): An individual is guilty of a class B misdemeanor if the individual willfully fails to report suspected abuse, neglect, or exploitation of a vulnerable adult to Adult Protective Services, or to the nearest peace officer or law enforcement agency under Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(9)(b): If an individual is convicted under Subsection (9)(a), the court may order the individual, in addition to any other sentence the court imposes, to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(9)(b)(i): complete community service hours; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(9)(b)(ii): complete a program on preventing abuse, neglect, and exploitation of vulnerable adults.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(9)(c): In determining whether it would be appropriate to charge an individual with a violation of Subsection (9)(a), the prosecuting attorney shall take into account whether a reasonable individual would not have reported suspected abuse, neglect, or exploitation of a vulnerable adult because reporting would have placed the individual in immediate danger of death or serious bodily injury.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(9)(d): Notwithstanding any contrary provision of law, a prosecuting attorney may not use an individual's violation of Subsection (9)(a) as the basis for charging the individual with another offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(9)(e): A prosecution for failure to report under Subsection (9)(a) shall be commenced within two years after the day on which the individual had knowledge of the suspected abuse, neglect, or exploitation and willfully failed to report.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(10): 76-8-508; 76-8-508.7 Under circumstances not amounting to a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-205(11): An adult is not considered abused, neglected, or a vulnerable adult for the reason that the adult has chosen to rely solely upon religious, nonmedical forms of healing in lieu of medical care.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-206 Photographing, video, and audio taping.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Law enforcement or Adult Protective Services investigators may collect evidence regarding alleged abuse, neglect, or exploitation of a vulnerable adult by taking, or causing to be taken, photographs, video tape recordings, or audio or video tape accounts of a vulnerable adult, if the vulnerable adult:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-206(1): consents to the taking of the photographs, video tape recordings, or audio or video tape accounts; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-206(2): (1) lacks the capacity to give the consent described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-207 Peace officer's authority to transport -- Notification.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-207(1): A peace officer may remove and transport, or cause to have transported, a vulnerable adult to an appropriate medical or shelter facility, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-207(1)(a): the officer has probable cause to believe that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-207(1)(a)(i): by reason of abuse, neglect, or exploitation there exist exigent circumstances; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-207(1)(a)(ii): the vulnerable adult will suffer serious physical injury or death if not immediately placed in a safe environment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-207(1)(b): the vulnerable adult refuses to consent or lacks capacity to consent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-207(1)(c): there is not time to notify interested parties or to apply for a warrant or other court order.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-207(2): (1) A peace officer described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-207(2)(a): notify Adult Protective Services intake; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-207(2)(b): request that Adult Protective Services or the division file a petition with the court for an emergency protective order.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-208 Enforcement by division -- Duty of county or district attorney.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-208(1): 17-18a-202; 17-18a-203 It is the duty of the county or district attorney, as appropriate under Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-208(1)(a): assist and represent the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-208(1)(b): initiate legal proceedings to protect vulnerable adults; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-208(1)(c): take appropriate action to prosecute the alleged offenders.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-208(2): If the county or district attorney fails to act upon the request of the division to provide legal assistance within five business days after the day on which the request is made:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-208(2)(a): the division may request the attorney general to act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-208(2)(b): the attorney general may, in the attorney general's discretion, assume the responsibilities and carry the action forward in place of the county or district attorney.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-209 Requests for records.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-209(1): Requests for records maintained by Adult Protective Services shall be made in writing to Adult Protective Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-209(2): Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act Classification and disclosure of records shall be made in accordance with


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-210 Statewide database -- Restricted use and access.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-210(1): The division shall maintain a database for reports of vulnerable adult abuse, neglect, or exploitation made pursuant to this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-210(2): The database shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-210(2)(a): the names and identifying data of the alleged abused, neglected, or exploited vulnerable adult and the alleged perpetrator;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-210(2)(b): information regarding whether or not the allegation of abuse, neglect, or exploitation was found to be:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-210(2)(b)(i): supported;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-210(2)(b)(ii): inconclusive;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-210(2)(b)(iii): without merit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-210(2)(b)(iv): for reports for which the finding is made before May 5, 2008:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-210(2)(b)(iv)(A): substantiated; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-210(2)(b)(iv)(B): unsubstantiated; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-210(2)(c): any other information that may be helpful in furthering the purposes of this part, as determined by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-210(3): Information obtained from the database may be used only:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-210(3)(a): for statistical summaries compiled by the department that do not include names or other identifying data;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-210(3)(b): where identification of an individual as a perpetrator may be relevant in a determination regarding whether to grant or deny a license, privilege, or approval made by:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-210(3)(b)(i): the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-210(3)(b)(ii): the Division of Professional Licensing;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-210(3)(b)(iii): the Division of Licensing and Background Checks within the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-210(3)(b)(iv): the Bureau of Emergency Medical Services , within the Department of Public Safety;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-213 Private right of action -- Estate asset -- Attorney fees.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-213(1): A vulnerable adult who suffers harm or financial loss as a result of exploitation has a private right of action against the perpetrator.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-213(2): Upon the death of a vulnerable adult, any cause of action under this section shall constitute an asset of the estate of the vulnerable adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-213(3): If the plaintiff prevails in an action brought under this section, the court may order that the defendant pay the costs and reasonable attorney fees of the plaintiff.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-213(4): If the defendant prevails in an action brought under this section, the court may order that the plaintiff pay the costs and reasonable attorney fees of the defendant, if the court finds that the action was frivolous, unreasonable, or taken in bad faith.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-214 Protective services voluntary unless court ordered.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-214(1): Vulnerable adults who receive protective services under this part shall do so knowingly or voluntarily or upon district court order.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-214(2): Protective services may be provided without a court order for a vulnerable adult who has the capacity to consent and who requests or knowingly or voluntarily consents to those services.  Protective services may also be provided for a vulnerable adult whose guardian or conservator with authority to consent does consent to those services.  When short-term, limited protective services are provided, the division and the recipient, or the recipient's guardian or conservator, shall execute a written agreement setting forth the purposes and limitations of the services to be provided.  If consent is subsequently withdrawn by the recipient, the recipient's guardian or conservator, or the court, services, including any investigation, shall cease.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-214(3): 26B-6-217 A court may order emergency  protective services to be provided to a vulnerable adult who does not consent or who lacks capacity to consent to protective services in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-215 Costs incurred in providing of protective services.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Costs incurred in providing protective services are the responsibility of the vulnerable adult when:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-215(1): 26B-6-214 the vulnerable adult is financially able to pay for those services, according to rates established by the division, and that payment is provided for as part of the written agreement for services described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-215(2): the vulnerable adult to be protected is eligible for those services from another governmental agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-215(3): the court appoints a guardian or conservator and orders that the costs be paid from the vulnerable adult's estate.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-216 Venue for protective services proceedings.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Venue for all proceedings related to protective services and emergency protective services under this part is in the county where the vulnerable adult resides or is present.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-217 Emergency protective services -- Forcible entry.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-217(1): Adult Protective Services shall, immediately upon court order, provide emergency protective services to a court-designated vulnerable adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-217(2): A court may, without notice, order emergency protective services immediately upon receipt of a petition for emergency protective services when a court finds that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-217(2)(a): the subject of the petition is a vulnerable adult;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-217(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-217(2)(b)(i): the vulnerable adult does not have a court-appointed guardian or conservator; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-217(2)(b)(ii): the guardian or conservator is not effectively performing the guardian's or conservator's duties;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-217(2)(c): an emergency exists; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-217(2)(d): the welfare, safety, or best interests of the vulnerable adult requires emergency protective services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-217(3): An emergency protective services order shall specifically designate the services that are approved and the facts that support the provision of those services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-217(4): Services authorized in an emergency protective services order may include hospitalization, nursing, custodial care, or a change in residence.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-217(5): 75-5-310 An emergency protective services order expires five business days after the day on which the court issues the order unless an appropriate party petitions for temporary guardianship pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-217(6): If a petition for guardianship or an additional emergency protective services petition is filed within five business days after the day on which the court issues the original emergency protective services order, a court may extend the duration of the original order an additional 15 business days after the day on which the subsequent petition is filed to allow for a court hearing on the petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-217(7): To implement an emergency protective services order, a court may authorize forcible entry by a peace officer into the premises where the vulnerable adult may be found.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-218 Petition for injunctive relief when caretaker refuses to allow protective services.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-218(1): When a vulnerable adult is in need of protective services and the caretaker refuses to allow the provision of those services, the division may petition the court for injunctive relief prohibiting the caretaker from interfering with the provision of protective services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-218(2): (1) The division's petition under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-218(3): The court may, on appropriate findings and conclusions in accordance with Rule 65A, Utah Rules of Civil Procedure, issue an order enjoining the caretaker from interfering with the provision of protective services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-218(4): (1); 26B-6-217 The petition under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-302 Office of Public Guardian -- Creation.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-302(1): There is created within the department the Office of Public Guardian which has the powers and duties provided in this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-302(2): The office is under the administrative and general supervision of the executive director.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-303 Director of the office -- Appointment -- Qualifications.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-303(1): The director of the office shall be appointed by the executive director.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-303(2): The director shall have a bachelor's degree from an accredited university or college, be experienced in administration, and be knowledgeable in matters concerning guardianship and conservatorship.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-303(3): The director is the administrative head of the office.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304 Powers and duties of the office.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(1): 63I-5-401 The office shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(1)(a): develop and operate a statewide program to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(1)(a)(i): educate the public about the role and function of guardians and conservators;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(1)(a)(ii): educate guardians and conservators on:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(1)(a)(ii)(A): the duties of a guardian and a conservator; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(1)(a)(ii)(B): standards set by the National Guardianship Association for guardians and conservators; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(1)(a)(iii): serve as a guardian, conservator, or both for a ward upon appointment by a court when no other person is able and willing to do so and the office petitioned for or agreed in advance to the appointment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(1)(b): possess and exercise all the powers and duties specifically given to the office by virtue of being appointed as guardian or conservator of a ward, including the power to access a ward's records;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(1)(c): review and monitor the personal and, if appropriate, financial status of each ward for whom the office has been appointed to serve as guardian or conservator;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(1)(d): train and monitor each employee and volunteer, and monitor each contract provider to whom the office has delegated a responsibility for a ward;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(1)(e): retain all court-delegated powers and duties for a ward;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(1)(f): report on the personal and financial status of a ward as required by a court in accordance with Title 75, Chapter 5, Protection of Persons Under Disability and Their Property;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(1)(g): handle a ward's funds in accordance with the department's trust account system;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(1)(h): 63I-5-401 request that the department's audit plan, established pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(1)(i): maintain accurate records concerning each ward, the ward's property, and office services provided to the ward;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(1)(j): make reasonable and continuous efforts to find a family member, friend, or other person to serve as a ward's guardian or conservator; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(1)(k): after termination as guardian or conservator, distribute a ward's property in accordance with Title 75, Chapter 5, Protection of Persons Under Disability and Their Property.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(2): 26B-6-305; 26B-6-305 The office may:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(2)(a): 26B-6-305 petition a court pursuant to Title 75, Chapter 5, Protection of Persons Under Disability and Their Property, to be appointed an incapacitated person's guardian, conservator, or both after conducting a prepetition assessment under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(2)(b): develop and operate a statewide program to recruit, train, supervise, and monitor volunteers to assist the office in providing guardian and conservator services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(2)(c): 26B-6-305 delegate one or more responsibilities for a ward to an employee, volunteer, or contract provider, except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(2)(d): solicit and receive private donations to provide guardian and conservator services under this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(2)(e): adopt rules, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(2)(e)(i): effectuate policy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-304(2)(e)(ii): carry out the office's role as guardian and conservator of wards as provided in this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-305 Prepetition assessment and plan.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-305(1): Before the office may file a petition in court to be appointed guardian or conservator of a person, the office shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-305(1)(a): conduct a face-to-face needs assessment, by someone other than a volunteer, to determine whether the person suffers from a mental or physical impairment that renders the person substantially incapable of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-305(1)(a)(i): caring for his personal safety;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-305(1)(a)(ii): managing his financial affairs; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-305(1)(a)(iii): attending to and providing for such necessities as food, shelter, clothing, and medical care, to the extent that physical injury or illness may result;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-305(1)(b): assess the financial resources of the person based on information supplied to the office at the time of assessment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-305(1)(c): inquire and, if appropriate, search to determine whether any other person may be willing and able to serve as the person's guardian or conservator; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-305(1)(d): determine the form of guardianship or conservatorship to request of a court, if any, giving preference to the least intensive form of guardianship or conservatorship, consistent with the best interests of the person.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-305(2): The office shall prepare an individualized guardianship or conservator plan for each ward within 60 days of appointment.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-308 Court, legal, and other costs.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-308(1): The office may not be appointed as the guardian or conservator of a person unless the office petitioned for or agreed in advance to the appointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-308(2): (4) Except as provided in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-308(5): Under no circumstances may court costs or attorney fees be assessed to the office.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-309 Duty of the county attorney or district attorney.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-309(1): The attorney general shall advise the office on legal matters and represent the office in legal proceedings.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-309(2): Upon the request of the attorney general, a county attorney may represent the office in connection with the filing of a petition for appointment as guardian or conservator of an incapacitated person and with routine, subsequent appearances.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-402 Division of Services for People with Disabilities -- Creation -- Authority -- Direction -- Provision of services.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-402(1): There is created within the department the Division of Services for People with Disabilities, under the administrative direction of the executive director of the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-402(2): In accordance with this part, the division has the responsibility to plan and deliver an appropriate array of services and supports to persons with disabilities and their families in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-402(3): Within appropriations from the Legislature, the division shall provide services to any individual with a disability who is eligible to receive division services.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-404 Director -- Qualifications -- Responsibilities.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-404(1): The director of the division shall be appointed by the executive director.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-404(2): The director shall have a bachelor's degree from an accredited university or college, be experienced in administration, and be knowledgeable in developmental disabilities, intellectual disabilities, and other disabilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-404(3): The director is the administrative head of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-404(4): The director shall appoint the superintendent of the developmental center and the necessary and appropriate administrators for other facilities operated by the division with the concurrence of the executive director.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405 Division responsibilities -- Policy mediation.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(1): The division shall establish its rules in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(1)(a): the policy of the Legislature as set forth by this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(1)(b): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(2): 26B-6-411 The division shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(2)(a): establish program policy for the division, the developmental center, and programs and facilities operated by or under contract with the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(2)(b): establish rules for the assessment and collection of fees for programs within the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(2)(c): 26B-6-411 no later than July 1, 2003, establish a graduated fee schedule based on ability to pay and implement the schedule with respect to service recipients and their families where not otherwise prohibited by federal law or regulation or not otherwise provided for in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(2)(d): establish procedures to ensure that private citizens, consumers, private contract providers, allied state and local agencies, and others are provided with an opportunity to comment and provide input regarding any new policy or proposed revision to an existing policy;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(2)(e): provide a mechanism for systematic and regular review of existing policy and for consideration of policy changes proposed by the persons and agencies described under Subsection (2)(d);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(2)(f): establish and periodically review the criteria used to determine who may receive services from the division and how the delivery of those services is prioritized within available funding;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(2)(g): review implementation and compliance by the division with policies established by the board to ensure that the policies established by the Legislature in this chapter are carried out;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(2)(h): annually report to the executive director; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(2)(i): upon request by a legislator or a legislative committee, provide a report detailing actions the division has taken to enhance the quality of life for individuals with disabilities, including how the division has:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(2)(i)(i): provided services and support in the most person-centered way, reflecting the unique desires, assessed competencies, and limitations of each individual, and in the least restrictive environment best suited to each individual's needs;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(2)(i)(ii): ensured opportunities to access employment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(2)(i)(iii): enabled reasonable personal choice in selecting services and support that promotes:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(2)(i)(iii)(A): independence;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(2)(i)(iii)(B): productivity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(2)(i)(iii)(C): integration in community life.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(3): The division may not make, amend, or repeal a rule or policy if the effect of making, amending, or repealing the rule or policy would be to reduce or eliminate day program services, supported employment services, or employment preparation services for individuals with disabilities, unless the division:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(3)(a): provides notice of the proposed rule or policy change to all persons who would be affected by the change at least 30 days before the proposed change becomes effective;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(3)(b): holds a public hearing on the proposed rule or policy change:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(3)(b)(i): before the proposed change becomes effective; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(3)(b)(ii): no less than seven days nor more than 30 days after the division satisfies the notice requirement in Subsection (3)(b)(i); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(3)(c): appropriately funds a reasonably equivalent service for individuals served by the reduced or eliminated day program services, supported employment services, or employment preparation services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(4): In accordance with the federal directive to provide services and supports in a setting and manner that is person-centered, and to empower individuals whose circumstances and disabilities make it unlikely for them to find suitable competitive integrated employment, the division shall support providers by permitting the providers maximum flexibility in creating and implementing employment preparation programs and additional personally meaningful services and supports.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-405(5): The executive director shall mediate any differences which arise between the policies of the division and those of any other policy board or division in the department.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-406 Powers of other state agencies -- Severability.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Nothing in this part shall be construed to supersede or limit the authority granted by law to any other state agency.  If any provision of this part, or the application of any provision to the person or circumstance, is held invalid, the remainder of this part shall not be affected.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-407 Program for provision of supported employment services.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-407(1): There is established a program for the provision of supported employment services to be administered by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-407(2): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The division shall make rules, in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-407(3): (4) In accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-407(3)(a): is eligible to receive services from the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-407(3)(b): has applied for, and is waiting to, receive services from the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-407(3)(c): is not receiving other ongoing services from the division;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-409 Employment first emphasis on the provision of services.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-409(1)(b): establish self-sufficiency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-409(1)(c): exercise economic control of the person's life.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-409(2): (1); (1) The division shall develop a written plan to implement the policy described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-409(2)(a): assessing the strengths and needs of a person with a disability;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-409(2)(b): customizing strength-based approaches to obtaining employment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-409(2)(c): expecting, encouraging, providing, and rewarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-409(2)(c)(i): integrated employment in the workplace at competitive wages and benefits; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-409(2)(c)(ii): self-employment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-409(2)(d): developing partnerships with potential employers;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-409(2)(e): maximizing appropriate employment training opportunities;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-409(2)(f): coordinating services with other government agencies and community resources;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-409(2)(g): (1) to the extent possible, eliminating practices and policies that interfere with the policy described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-409(2)(h): arranging sub-minimum wage work or volunteer work when employment at market rates cannot be obtained.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-409(3): (1); (2); (2) The division shall, on an annual basis:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-411 Parent liable for cost and support of minor -- Guardian liable for costs.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-411(1): Parents of a person who receives services or support from the division, who are financially responsible, are liable for the cost of the actual care and maintenance of that person and for the support of the child in accordance with Title 81, Chapter 6, Child Support, and Chapter 9, Part 1, Office of Recovery Services, until the person reaches 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-411(2): 26B-6-412 A guardian of a person who receives services or support from the division is liable for the cost of actual care and maintenance of that person, regardless of his age, where funds are available in the guardianship estate established on his behalf for that purpose. However, if the person who receives services is a beneficiary of a trust created in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-411(3): If, at the time a person who receives services or support from the division is discharged from a facility or program owned or operated by or under contract with the division, or after the death and burial of a resident of the developmental center, there remains in the custody of the division or the superintendent any money paid by a parent or guardian for the support or maintenance of that person, it shall be repaid upon demand.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-412 Discretionary trust for an individual with a disability -- Impact on state services.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-412(1): 26B-3-101 For purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-412(1)(a): "Discretionary trust for an individual with a disability" means a trust:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-412(1)(a)(i): that is established for the benefit of an individual who, at the time the trust is created, is under 65 years old and has a disability, as defined in 42 U.S.C. Sec. 1382c;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-412(1)(a)(ii): under which the trustee has discretionary power to determine distributions;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-412(1)(a)(iii): under which the individual may not control or demand payments unless an abuse of the trustee's duties or discretion is shown;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-412(1)(a)(iv): that contains the assets of the individual and is established for the benefit of the individual by the individual, a court, or a parent, grandparent, or legal guardian of the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-412(1)(a)(v): that is irrevocable, except that the trust document may provide that the trust be terminated if the individual no longer has a disability, as defined in 42 U.S.C. Sec. 1382c;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-412(1)(a)(vi): that is invalid as to any portion funded by property that is or may be subject to a lien by the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-412(1)(a)(vii): that provides that, upon the death of the individual, the state will receive all amounts remaining in the trust, up to an amount equal to the total medical assistance paid on behalf of the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-412(1)(b): 26B-3-101 "Medical assistance" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-412(2): (1)(a)(v) A state agency providing services or support to an individual with a disability may:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-412(2)(a): (1)(a)(v) waive application of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-412(2)(b): define, by rule, what constitutes "undue hardship" for purposes of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-412(3): (1)(a)(vi) A discretionary trust for an individual with a disability is not liable for reimbursement or payment to the state or any state agency, for financial aid or services provided to that individual except:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-412(3)(a): to the extent that the trust property has been distributed directly to or is otherwise under the control of the beneficiary with a disability; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-412(3)(b): (1)(a)(vi) as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-412(4): Property, goods, and services that are purchased or owned by a discretionary trust for an individual with a disability and that are used or consumed by a beneficiary with a disability shall not be considered trust property that is distributed to or under the control of the beneficiary.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-412(5): The benefits that an individual with a disability is otherwise legally entitled to may not be reduced, impaired, or diminished in any way because of contribution to a discretionary trust for that individual.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413 Scope of home based services -- Purpose --  Principles -- Services for individuals younger than 11 years old.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(1): The purpose of this section is to provide support to families in their role as primary caregivers for family members with disabilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(2)(a): To enable a person with a disability and the person's family to select services and supports that best suit their needs and preferences, the division shall, within appropriations from the Legislature, provide services and supports under this part by giving direct financial assistance to the parent or guardian of a person with a disability who resides at home.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(2)(b): The dollar value of direct financial assistance is determined by the division based on:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(2)(b)(i): appropriations from the Legislature; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(2)(b)(ii): the needs of the person with a disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(2)(c): In determining whether to provide direct financial assistance to the family, the division shall consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(2)(c)(i): the family's preference; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(2)(c)(ii): the availability of approved providers in the area where the family resides.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(2)(d): If the division provides direct financial assistance, the division:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(2)(d)(i): shall require the family to account for the use of that financial assistance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(2)(d)(ii): shall tell the person with a disability or the person's parent or guardian how long the direct financial assistance is intended to provide services and supports before additional direct financial assistance is issued.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(2)(e): Except for eligibility determination services directly connected to the provision of direct financial assistance, service coordination is not provided under this part by the division unless the person with a disability or the person's parent or guardian uses the direct financial assistance to purchase such services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(3): (3)(c)(i) The following principles shall be used as the basis for supporting families who care for family members with disabilities:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(3)(a): all children, regardless of disability, should reside in a family-like environment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(3)(b): families should receive the support they need to care for their children at home;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(3)(c): (3)(c)(i) services should:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(3)(c)(i): focus on the person with a disability;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(3)(c)(ii): (3)(c)(i) take into consideration the family of the person described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(3)(c)(iii): be sensitive to the unique needs, preferences, and strengths of individual families; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(3)(c)(iv): complement and reinforce existing sources of help and support that are available to each family.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(4): (5) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(5): (4) The prohibition of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(5)(a): for persons in the custody of the Division of Child and Family Services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(5)(b): under a plan for home-based services, including respite and temporary residential care or services provided by a professional parent under contract with the division; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-413(5)(c): after a written finding by the director that out-of-home residential placement is the most appropriate way to meet the needs of the person with disabilities and his family.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-414 Respite care services.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-414(1): As used in this section, "respite care services" means temporary, periodic relief provided to parents or guardians from the care of an individual who is eligible to receive division services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-414(2): The division may, as funding permits and either directly or through one or more third parties who are under contract with the division, provide overnight respite care services and, concurrent with the respite care services, services for the individual who is eligible to receive division services, such as recreational therapy, community-based programs, therapeutic recreation, educational programs, transportation, or vocational rehabilitation.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-502 Utah State Developmental Center.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-502(1): The intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability located in American Fork City, Utah County, shall be known as the "Utah State Developmental Center."
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-502(2): (3) Within appropriations authorized by the Legislature, the role and function of the developmental center is to:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-502(2)(b): provide the following services and support to persons with disabilities who do not reside at the developmental center:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-502(2)(b)(ii): specialized medical treatment and evaluation;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-502(2)(b)(iii): specialized dental treatment and evaluation;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-502(2)(b)(iv): family and client special intervention;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-502(2)(b)(v): crisis management;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-502(2)(b)(vi): occupational, physical, speech, and audiology services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-502(2)(b)(vii): professional services, such as education, evaluation, and consultation, for families, public organizations, providers of community and family support services, and courts.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-502(3): (6); Part 6, Admission to an Intermediate Care Facility for People with an Intellectual Disability; (2)(b) Except as provided in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-502(3)(b): (2)(b) persons who receive services and supports under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-503 Developmental center within division.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
The programs and facilities of the developmental center are within the division, and under the policy direction of the division.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-504 Operation, maintenance, and repair of developmental center buildings and grounds.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-504(1): The division shall operate, maintain, and repair the buildings, grounds, and physical properties of the developmental center.  However, the roads and driveways on the grounds of the  developmental center shall be maintained by the Department of Transportation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-504(2): The division has authority to make improvements to the buildings, grounds, and physical properties of the developmental center, as it deems necessary for the care and safety of the residents.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-505 State Board of Education -- Education of children at developmental center.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-505(1): The State Board of Education is responsible for the education of school-aged children at the developmental center.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-505(2): (1) In order to fulfill its responsibility under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-505(3): Medical, residential, and other services that are not the responsibility of the State Board of Education or other state agencies are the responsibility of the division.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-506 Powers and duties of division.
--------------------------------------------------------------
The powers and duties of the division, with respect to the developmental center are as follows:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-506(1): to establish rules, not inconsistent with law, for the government of the developmental center;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-506(2): to establish rules governing the admission and discharge of persons with an intellectual disability in accordance with state law;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-506(3): to employ necessary medical and other professional personnel to assist in establishing rules relating to the developmental center and to the treatment and training of persons with an intellectual disability at the center;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-506(4): Part 6, Admission to an Intermediate Care Facility for People with an Intellectual Disability to transfer a person who has been committed to the developmental center under
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-506(5): 26B-6-502(3) the developmental center may receive a person who meets the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-506(6): to manage funds for a person residing in the developmental center, upon request by that person's parent or guardian, or upon administrative or court order;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-506(7): to charge and collect a fair and equitable fee from developmental center residents, parents who have the ability to pay, or guardians where funds for that purpose are available; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-506(8): supervision and administration of security responsibilities for the developmental center is vested in the division.  The executive director may designate, as special function officers, individuals to perform special security functions for the developmental center that require peace officer authority.  Those special function officers may not become or be designated as members of the Public Safety Retirement System.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-509 Powers and duties of superintendent.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The chief administrative officer of the developmental center is the superintendent, and has the following powers and duties:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-509(1): to manage the developmental center and administer the division's rules governing the developmental center;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-601 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
The definitions in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-602 Division responsibility.
--------------------------------------------------------
The division is responsible:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-602(1): for the supervision, care, and treatment of persons with an intellectual disability in this state who are committed to the division's jurisdiction under the provisions of this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-602(2): to evaluate and determine the most appropriate, least restrictive setting for an individual with an intellectual disability.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-603 Residency requirements -- Transportation of person to another state.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-603(1): A person with an intellectual disability who has a parent or guardian residing in this state may be admitted to an intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability in accordance with the provisions of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-603(2): If a person with an intellectual disability enters Utah from another state, the division may have that person transported to the home of a relative or friend located outside of this state, or to an appropriate facility in the state where the person with the intellectual disability is domiciled.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-603(3): This section does not prevent a person with an intellectual disability who is temporarily located in this state from being temporarily admitted or committed to an intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability in this state.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-604(1)(a): 26B-6-607 an emergency commitment in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-604(3)(b): A juvenile court shall proceed with the written petition in the same manner and with the same authority as the district court.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-604(4): If an individual who is under 18 years old is committed to the custody of the Utah State Developmental Center by the juvenile court, the director or the director's designee shall give the juvenile court written notice of the intention to release the individual not fewer than five days before the day on which the individual is released.
