Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-606 Involuntary commitment.
-------------------------------------------------------
An individual may not be involuntarily committed to an intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability except in accordance with Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607 Temporary emergency commitment -- Observation and evaluation.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(1): The director of the division or his designee may temporarily commit an individual to the division and therefore, as a matter of course, to an intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability for observation and evaluation upon:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(1)(a): written application by a responsible person who has reason to know that the individual is in need of commitment, stating:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(1)(a)(i): a belief that the individual has an intellectual disability and is likely to cause serious injury to self or others if not immediately committed;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(1)(a)(ii): personal knowledge of the individual's condition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(1)(a)(iii): the circumstances supporting that belief; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(1)(b): certification by a licensed physician or designated intellectual disability professional stating that the physician or designated intellectual disability professional:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(1)(b)(i): has examined the individual within a three-day period immediately preceding the certification; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(1)(b)(ii): is of the opinion that the individual has an intellectual disability, and that because of the individual's intellectual disability is likely to injure self or others if not immediately committed.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(2): If the individual in need of commitment is not placed in the custody of the director or the director's designee by the person submitting the application, the director's or the director's designee may certify, either in writing or orally that the individual is in need of immediate commitment to prevent injury to self or others.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(3): Upon receipt of the application required by Subsection (1)(a) and the certifications required by Subsections (1)(b) and (2), a peace officer may take the individual named in the application and certificates into custody, and may transport the individual to a designated intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(4): 26B-6-608; 26B-6-608
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(4)(a): 26B-6-608 An individual committed under this section may be held for a maximum of 72 hours, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays.  At the expiration of that time, the individual shall be released unless proceedings for involuntary commitment have been commenced under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(4)(b): 26B-6-608 After proceedings for involuntary commitment have been commenced the individual shall be released unless an order of detention is issued in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(5): If an individual is committed to the division under this section on the application of any person other than the individual's legal guardian, spouse, parent, or next of kin, the director or his designee shall immediately give notice of the commitment to the individual's legal guardian, spouse, parent, or next of kin, if known.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(6)(a): The division or an intermediate care facility shall provide discharge instructions to each individual committed under this section at or before the time the individual is discharged from the custody of the division or intermediate care facility, regardless of whether the individual is discharged by being released or under other circumstances.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(6)(b): Discharge instructions provided under Subsection (6)(a) shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(6)(b)(i): a summary of why the individual was committed;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(6)(b)(ii): detailed information about why the individual is being discharged;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(6)(b)(iii): a safety plan for the individual based on the individual's intellectual disability and condition;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(6)(b)(iv): notification to the individual's primary care provider, if applicable;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(6)(b)(v): if the individual is discharged without food, housing, or economic security, a referral to appropriate services, if such services exist in the individual's community;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(6)(b)(vi): the phone number to call or text for a crisis services hotline, and information about the availability of peer support services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(6)(b)(vii): a copy of any advance directive presented to the local mental health authority, if applicable;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(6)(b)(viii): information about how to establish an advance directive if one was not presented to the division or intermediate care facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(6)(b)(ix): as applicable, information about medications that were changed or discontinued during the commitment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(6)(b)(x): a list of any screening or diagnostic tests conducted during the commitment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(6)(b)(xi): a summary of therapeutic treatments provided during the commitment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(6)(b)(xii): any laboratory work, including blood samples or imaging, that was completed or attempted during the commitment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(6)(b)(xiii): information about how to contact the division or intermediate care facility if needed.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(6)(c): If an individual's medications were changed, or if an individual was prescribed new medications while committed under this section, discharge instructions provided under Subsection (6)(a) shall include a clinically appropriate supply of medications, as determined by a licensed health care provider, to allow the individual time to access another health care provider or follow-up appointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(6)(d): If an individual refuses to accept discharge instructions, the division or intermediate care facility shall document the refusal in the individual's medical record.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(6)(e): If an individual's discharge instructions include referrals to services under Subsection (6)(b)(v), the division or intermediate care facility shall document those referrals in the individual's medical record.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-607(6)(f): The division shall attempt to follow up with a discharged individual at least 48 hours after discharge, and may use peer support professionals when performing follow-up care or developing a continuing care plan.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608 Involuntary commitment -- Procedures -- Necessary findings -- Periodic review.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(1): Any responsible person who has reason to know that an individual is in need of commitment, who has a belief that the individual has an intellectual disability, and who has personal knowledge of the conditions and circumstances supporting that belief, may commence proceedings for involuntary commitment by filing a written petition with the district court, or if the subject of the petition is less than 18 years old with the juvenile court, of the county in which the individual to be committed is physically located at the time the petition is filed.  The application shall be accompanied by:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(1)(a): a certificate of a licensed physician or a designated intellectual disability professional, stating that within a seven-day period immediately preceding the certification, the physician or designated intellectual disability professional examined the individual and believes that the individual has an intellectual disability and is in need of involuntary commitment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(1)(b): a written statement by the petitioner that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(1)(b)(i): states that the individual was requested to, but refused to, submit to an examination for an intellectual disability by a licensed physician or designated intellectual disability professional, and that the individual refuses to voluntarily go to the division or an intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability recommended by the division for treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(1)(b)(ii): is under oath; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(1)(b)(iii): sets forth the facts on which the statement is based.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(2): Before issuing a detention order, the court may require the petitioner to consult with personnel at the division or at an intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability and may direct a designated intellectual disability professional to interview the petitioner and the individual to be committed, to determine the existing facts, and to report them to the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(3): The court may issue a detention order and may direct a peace officer to immediately take the individual to an intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability to be detained for purposes of an examination if the court finds from the petition, from other statements under oath, or from reports of physicians or designated intellectual disability professionals that there is a reasonable basis to believe that the individual to be committed:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(3)(a): poses an immediate danger of physical injury to  self or others;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(3)(b): requires involuntary commitment pending examination and hearing;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(3)(c): the individual was requested but refused to submit to an examination by a licensed physician or designated intellectual disability professional; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(3)(d): the individual refused to voluntarily go to the division or to an intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability recommended by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(4)(a): If the court issues a detention order based on an application that did not include a certification by a designated intellectual disability professional or physician in accordance with Subsection (1)(a), the director or his designee shall within 24 hours after issuance of the detention order, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays, examine the individual, report the results of the examination to the court and inform the court:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(4)(a)(i): whether the director or his designee believes that the individual has an intellectual disability; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(4)(a)(ii): whether appropriate treatment programs are available and will be used by the individual without court proceedings.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(4)(b): If the report of the director or his designee is based on an oral report of the examiner, the examiner shall immediately send the results of the examination in writing to the clerk of the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(5): 26B-6-607 Immediately after an individual is involuntarily committed under a detention order or under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(6)(a): Immediately after commencement of proceedings for involuntary commitment, the court shall give notice of commencement of the proceedings to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(6)(a)(i): the individual to be committed;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(6)(a)(ii): the applicant;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(6)(a)(iii): any legal guardian of the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(6)(a)(iv): adult members of the individual's immediate family;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(6)(a)(v): legal counsel of the individual to be committed, if any;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(6)(a)(vi): the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(6)(a)(vii): any other person to whom the individual requests, or the court designates, notice to be given.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(6)(b): If an individual cannot or refuses to disclose the identity of persons to be notified, the extent of notice shall be determined by the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(7): That notice shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(7)(a): set forth the allegations of the petition and all supporting facts;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(7)(b): be accompanied by a copy of any detention order issued under Subsection (3); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(7)(c): state that a hearing will be held within the time provided by law, and give the time and place for that hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(8): The court may transfer the case and the custody of the individual to be committed to any other district court within the state, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(8)(a): there are no appropriate facilities for persons with an intellectual disability within the judicial district; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(8)(b): the transfer will not be adverse to the interests of the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(9)(a): Within 24 hours, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays, after any order or commitment under a detention order, the court shall appoint two designated intellectual disability professionals to examine the individual.  If requested by the individual's counsel, the court shall appoint a reasonably available, qualified person designated by counsel to be one of the examining designated intellectual disability professionals.  The examinations shall be conducted:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(9)(a)(i): separately;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(9)(a)(ii): at the home of the individual to be committed, a hospital, an intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability, or any other suitable place not likely to have a harmful effect on the individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(9)(a)(iii): within a reasonable period of time after appointment of the examiners by the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(9)(b): The court shall set a time for a hearing to be held within 10 court days of the appointment of the examiners.  However, the court may immediately terminate the proceedings and dismiss the application if, prior to the hearing date, the examiners, the director, or his designee informs the court that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(9)(b)(i): the individual does not have an intellectual disability; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(9)(b)(ii): treatment programs are available and will be used by the individual without court proceedings.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(10)(a): Each individual has the right to be represented by counsel at the commitment hearing and in all preliminary proceedings.  If neither the individual nor others provide counsel,  the court shall appoint counsel and allow sufficient time for counsel to consult with the individual prior to any hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(10)(b): If the individual is indigent, the county in which the individual was physically located when taken into custody shall pay reasonable attorney fees as determined by the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(11): The division or a designated intellectual disability professional in charge of the individual's care shall provide all documented information on the individual to be committed and to the court at the time of the hearing.  The individual's attorney shall have access to all documented information on the individual at the time of and prior to the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(12): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(12)(a): The court shall provide an opportunity to the individual, the petitioner, and all other persons to whom notice is required to be given to appear at the hearing, to testify, and to present and cross-examine witnesses.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(12)(b): The court may, in its discretion:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(12)(b)(i): receive the testimony of any other person;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(12)(b)(ii): allow a waiver of the right to appear only for good cause shown;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(12)(b)(iii): exclude from the hearing all persons not necessary to conduct the proceedings; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(12)(b)(iv): upon motion of counsel, require the testimony of each examiner to be given out of the presence of any other examiner.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(12)(c): The hearing shall be conducted in as informal a manner as may be consistent with orderly procedure, and in a physical setting that is not likely to have a harmful effect on the individual.  The Utah Rules of Evidence apply, and the hearing shall be a matter of court record.  A verbatim record of the proceedings shall be maintained.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(13): The court may order commitment if, upon completion of the hearing and consideration of the record, it finds by clear and convincing evidence that all of the following conditions are met:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(13)(a): the individual to be committed has an intellectual disability;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(13)(b): because of the individual's intellectual disability one or more of the following conditions exist:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(13)(b)(i): the individual poses an immediate danger of physical injury to self or others;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(13)(b)(ii): the individual lacks the capacity to provide the basic necessities of life, such as food, clothing, or shelter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(13)(b)(iii): the individual is in immediate need of habilitation, rehabilitation, care, or treatment to minimize the effects of the condition which poses a threat of serious physical or psychological injury to the individual, and the individual lacks the capacity to engage in a rational decision-making process concerning the need for habilitation, rehabilitation, care, or treatment, as evidenced by an inability to weigh the possible costs and benefits of the care or treatment and the alternatives to it;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(13)(c): there is no appropriate, less restrictive alternative reasonably available; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(13)(d): the division or the intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability recommended by the division in which the individual is to be committed can provide the individual with treatment, care, habilitation, or rehabilitation that is adequate and appropriate to the individual's condition and needs.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(14): In the absence of any of the required findings by the court, described in Subsection (13), the court shall dismiss the proceedings.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(15): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(15)(a): The order of commitment shall designate the period for which the individual will be committed.  An initial commitment may not exceed six months.  Before the end of the initial commitment period, the administrator of the intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability shall commence a review hearing on behalf of the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(15)(b): At the conclusion of the review hearing, the court may issue an order of commitment for up to a one-year period.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(16): An individual committed under this part has the right to a rehearing, upon filing a petition with the court within 30 days after entry of the court's order.  If the petition for rehearing alleges error or mistake in the court's findings, the court shall appoint one impartial licensed physician and two impartial designated intellectual disability professionals who have not previously been involved in the case to examine the individual.  The rehearing shall, in all other respects, be conducted in accordance with this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(17): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(17)(a): The court shall maintain a current list of all individuals under its orders of commitment.  That list shall be reviewed in order to determine those patients who have been under an order of commitment for the designated period.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(17)(b): At least two weeks prior to the expiration of the designated period of any commitment order still in effect, the court that entered the original order shall inform the director of the division of the impending expiration of the designated commitment period.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(17)(c): The staff of the division shall immediately:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(17)(c)(i): reexamine the reasons upon which the order of commitment was based and report the results of the examination to the court;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(17)(c)(ii): discharge the resident from involuntary commitment if the conditions justifying commitment no longer exist; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(17)(c)(iii): immediately inform the court of any discharge.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(17)(d): If the director of the division reports to the court that the conditions justifying commitment no longer exist, and the administrator of the intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability does not discharge the individual at the end of the designated period, the court shall order the immediate discharge of the individual, unless involuntary commitment proceedings are again commenced in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(17)(e): If the director of the division, or the director's designee reports to the court that the conditions designated in Subsection (13) still exist, the court may extend the commitment order for up to one year.  At the end of any extension, the individual must be reexamined in accordance with this section, or discharged.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(18): When a resident is discharged under this subsection, the division shall provide any further support services available and required to meet the resident's needs.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(19): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(19)(a): The division or an intermediate care facility shall provide discharge instructions to each individual committed under this section at or before the time the individual is discharged from the custody of the division or intermediate care facility, regardless of whether the individual is discharged by being released or under other circumstances.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(19)(b): Discharge instructions provided under Subsection (19)(a) shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(19)(b)(i): a summary of why the individual was committed;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(19)(b)(ii): detailed information about why the individual is being discharged;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(19)(b)(iii): a safety plan for the individual based on the individual's intellectual disability and condition;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(19)(b)(iv): notification to the individual's primary care provider, if applicable;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(19)(b)(v): if the individual is discharged without food, housing, or economic security, a referral to appropriate services, if such services exist in the individual's community;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(19)(b)(vi): the phone number to call or text for a crisis services hotline, and information about the availability of peer support services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(19)(b)(vii): a copy of any advance directive presented to the local mental health authority, if applicable;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(19)(b)(viii): information about how to establish an advance directive if one was not presented to the division or intermediate care facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(19)(b)(ix): as applicable, information about medications that were changed or discontinued during the commitment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(19)(b)(x): a list of any screening or diagnostic tests conducted during the commitment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(19)(b)(xi): a summary of therapeutic treatments provided during the commitment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(19)(b)(xii): any laboratory work, including blood samples or imaging, that was completed or attempted during the commitment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(19)(b)(xiii): information about how to contact the division or intermediate care facility if needed.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(19)(c): If an individual's medications were changed, or if an individual was prescribed new medications while committed under this section, discharge instructions provided under Subsection (19)(a) shall include a clinically appropriate supply of medications, as determined by a licensed health care provider, to allow the individual time to access another health care provider or follow-up appointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(19)(d): If an individual refuses to accept discharge instructions, the division or intermediate care facility shall document the refusal in the individual's medical record.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(19)(e): If an individual's discharge instructions include referrals to services under Subsection (19)(b)(v), the division or intermediate care facility shall document those referrals in the individual's medical record.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-608(19)(f): The division shall attempt to follow up with a discharged individual at least 48 hours after discharge, and may use peer support professionals when performing follow-up care or developing a continuing care plan.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-609 Transfer -- Procedures.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-609(1): The director of the division, or the director's designee, may place an involuntarily committed resident in appropriate care or treatment outside the intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability.  During that placement, the order of commitment shall remain in effect, until the resident is discharged or the order is terminated.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-609(2): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act If the resident, or the resident's parent or guardian, objects to a proposed placement under this section, the resident may appeal the decision to the executive director or the executive director's designee.  Those appeals shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures and requirements of

-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-610(1): 26B-6-608 A resident committed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-610(2): 26B-6-608 Upon receipt of that petition, the court shall conduct proceedings under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-611 Temporary detention.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-611(1): Pending removal to an intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability, an individual taken into custody or ordered to be committed under this part may be detained in the individual's home, or in some other suitable facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-611(2): The individual shall not, however, be detained in a nonmedical facility used for detention of individuals charged with or convicted of penal offenses, except in a situation of extreme emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-611(3): The division shall take reasonable measures, as may be necessary, to assure proper care of an individual temporarily detained under this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-612 Authority to transfer resident.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-612(1): The administrator of an intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability, or the administrator's designee, may transfer or authorize the transfer of a resident to another intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability if, before the transfer, the administrator conducts a careful evaluation of the resident and the resident's treatment needs, and determines that a transfer would be in the best interest of that resident.  If a resident is transferred, the administrator shall give immediate notice of the transfer to the resident's spouse, guardian, parent, or advocate or, if none of those persons are known, to the resident's nearest known relative.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-612(2): If a resident, or the resident's parent or guardian, objects to a proposed transfer under this section, the administrator shall conduct a hearing on the objection before a committee composed of persons selected by the administrator.  That committee shall hear all evidence and make a recommendation to the administrator concerning the proposed transfer.  The transfer may not take effect until the committee holds that hearing and the administrator renders a final decision on the proposed transfer.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-613 Involuntary treatment with medication -- Committee -- Findings.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-613(1): If, after commitment, a resident elects to refuse treatment with medication, the director, the administrator of the intermediate care facility for people with an intellectual disability, or a designee, shall submit documentation regarding the resident's proposed treatment to a committee composed of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-613(1)(a): a licensed physician experienced in treating persons with an intellectual disability, who is not directly involved in the resident's treatment or diagnosis, and who is not biased toward any one facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-613(1)(b): a psychologist who is a designated intellectual disability professional who is not directly involved in the resident's treatment or diagnosis; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-613(1)(c): another designated intellectual disability professional of the facility for persons with an intellectual disability, or a designee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-613(2): 26B-6-608(13) Based upon the court's finding, under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-613(2)(a): the proposed treatment is in the medical best interest of the resident, taking into account the possible side effects as well as the potential benefits of the medication; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-613(2)(b): the proposed treatment is in accordance with prevailing standards of accepted medical practice.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-613(3): (2) In making the determination described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-613(4): Any authorization of involuntary treatment under this section shall be periodically reviewed in accordance with rules promulgated by the division.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-701 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
In addition to the definitions in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 26B-6-701(1): "Complainant" means a person who initiates a complaint.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-701(2): "Complaint" means a complaint initiated with the ombudsman identifying a person who has violated the rights and privileges of an individual with a disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-701(3): 26B-6-702 "Ombudsman" means the ombudsman appointed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-701(4): 26B-6-802(1); (3) "Rights and privileges of an individual with a disability" means the rights and privileges of an individual with a disability described in Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-702 Disability ombudsman -- Purpose -- Appointment -- Qualifications -- Staff.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-702(1): There is created within the department the position of disability ombudsman for the purpose of promoting, advocating, and ensuring the rights and privileges of an individual with a disability are upheld.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-702(2): The director shall appoint an ombudsman who has:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-702(2)(a): recognized executive and administrative capacity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-702(2)(b): experience in laws and policies regarding individuals with a disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-702(3): The ombudsman may hire staff as necessary to carry out the duties of the ombudsman under this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-703 Powers and duties of ombudsman.
---------------------------------------------------------------
The ombudsman shall:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-703(1): develop and maintain expertise in laws and policies governing the rights and privileges of an individual with a disability;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-703(2): provide training and information to private citizens, civic groups, governmental entities, and other interested parties across the state regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-703(2)(a): the role and duties of the ombudsman;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-703(2)(b): the rights and privileges of an individual with a disability; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-703(2)(c): services available in the state to an individual with a disability;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-703(3): develop a website to provide the information described in Subsection (2) in a form that is easily accessible;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-703(4): receive, process, and investigate complaints in accordance with this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-703(5): review periodically the procedures of state entities that serve individuals with a disability;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-703(6): 26B-2-303; 80-2-1104 cooperate and coordinate with governmental entities and other organizations in the community in exercising the duties under this section, including the long-term care ombudsman program, created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-703(7): as appropriate, make recommendations to the division regarding rules to be made in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, that the ombudsman considers necessary to carry out the ombudsman's duties under this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-703(8): perform other duties required by law.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-704 Investigation of complaints -- Procedures -- Rulemaking.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-704(1): (3) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-704(2): An ombudsman's investigation of a complaint may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-704(2)(a): a referral to a governmental entity or other services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-704(2)(b): the collection of facts, information, or documentation;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-704(2)(c): holding an investigatory hearing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-704(2)(d): an inspection of the premises of the person named in the complaint.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-704(3):

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-704(3)(b): If the ombudsman declines to investigate a complaint, the ombudsman shall notify the complainant and the division of the declination.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-705 Confidentiality of materials relating to complaints or investigations -- Rulemaking.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-705(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The division shall establish procedures by rule made in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-705(2): The identity of a complainant or a party named in the complaint may not be disclosed by the ombudsman unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-705(2)(a): the complainant or a legal representative of the complainant consents to the disclosure;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-705(2)(b): disclosure is ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-705(2)(c): the disclosure is approved by the ombudsman and is made, as part of an investigation involving the complainant, to an agency or entity in the community that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-705(2)(c)(i): has statutory responsibility for the complainant, over the action alleged in the complaint, or another party named in the complaint;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-705(2)(c)(ii): is able to assist the ombudsman to achieve resolution of the complaint; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-705(2)(c)(iii): is able to provide expertise that would benefit the complainant.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-705(3): Neither the ombudsman nor the ombudsman's designee may be required to testify in court with respect to confidential matters, except as the court finds necessary to enforce this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(1): "Disability" has the same meaning as defined in 42 U.S.C. Sec. 12102 of the Americans With Disabilities Act of 1990, as may be amended in the future, and 28 C.F.R. Sec. 36.104 of the Code of Federal Regulations, as may be amended in the future.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(2): "Informed consent" means consent that is voluntary and based on an understanding by the person to be sterilized of the nature and consequences of sterilization, the reasonably foreseeable risks and benefits of sterilization, and the available alternative methods of contraception.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(3): 10-9a-103; 17-27a-103 "Institutionalized" means residing in the Utah State Developmental Center, the Utah State Hospital, a residential facility for persons with a disability as defined in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4)(a): "Service animal" includes any dog that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4)(a)(i): is trained, or is in training, to do work or perform tasks for the benefit of an individual with a disability, including a physical, sensory, psychiatric, intellectual, or other mental disability; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4)(a)(ii): performs work or tasks, or is in training to perform work or tasks, that are directly related to the individual's disability, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4)(a)(ii)(A): assisting an individual who is blind or has low vision with navigation or other tasks;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4)(a)(ii)(B): alerting an individual who is deaf or hard of hearing to the presence of people or sounds;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4)(a)(ii)(C): providing non-violent protection or rescue work;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4)(a)(ii)(D): pulling a wheelchair;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4)(a)(ii)(E): assisting an individual during a seizure;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4)(a)(ii)(F): alerting an individual to the presence of an allergen;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4)(a)(ii)(G): retrieving an item for the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4)(a)(ii)(H): providing physical support and assistance with balance and stability; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4)(a)(ii)(I): helping an individual with a psychiatric or neurological disability by preventing or interrupting impulsive or destructive behaviors.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4)(b): "Service animal" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4)(b)(i): an animal other than a dog, whether wild or domestic, trained or untrained; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4)(b)(ii): an animal used solely to provide:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4)(b)(ii)(A): a crime deterrent;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4)(b)(ii)(B): emotional support;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4)(b)(ii)(C): well-being;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4)(b)(ii)(D): comfort; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(4)(b)(ii)(E): companionship.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(5): "Sterilization" means any medical procedure, treatment, or operation rendering an individual permanently incapable of procreation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-801(6): "Support animal" means an animal, other than a service animal, that qualifies as a reasonable accommodation under federal law for an individual with a disability.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-802 Rights and privileges of an individual with a disability.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-802(1): An individual with a disability has the same rights and privileges in the use of highways, streets, sidewalks, walkways, public buildings, public facilities, and other public areas as an individual who is not an individual with a disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-802(2): An individual with a disability has equal rights to accommodations, advantages, and facilities offered by common carriers, including air carriers, railroad carriers, motor buses, motor vehicles, water carriers, and all other modes of public conveyance in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-802(3): An individual with a disability has equal rights to accommodations, advantages, and facilities offered by hotels, motels, lodges, and all other places of public accommodation in this state, and to places of amusement or resort to which the public is invited.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-802(4): 26B-6-803
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-802(4)(a): An individual with a disability has equal rights and access to public and private housing accommodations offered for rent, lease, or other compensation in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-802(4)(b): This chapter does not require a person renting, leasing, or selling private housing or real property to modify the housing or property in order to accommodate an individual with a disability or to provide a higher degree of care for that individual than for someone who is not an individual with a disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-802(4)(c): 26B-6-803 A person renting, leasing, or selling private housing or real property to an individual with a disability shall comply with the provisions of Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-804 Policy of state to employ individuals with a disability.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is the policy of this state that an individual with a disability is employed in the state service, the service of the political subdivisions of the state, in the public schools, and in all other employment supported in whole or in part by public funds on the same terms and conditions as an individual who is not an individual with a disability, unless it is shown that the particular disability prevents the performance of the work involved.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-805 Interference with rights provided in this part -- Misrepresentation of rights under this part.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-805(1): Any individual, or agent of any individual, who denies or interferes with the rights provided in this chapter is guilty of a class C misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-805(2): An individual is guilty of a class C misdemeanor if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-805(2)(a): the individual intentionally and knowingly falsely represents to another person that an animal is a service animal or a support animal;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-805(2)(b): the individual knowingly and intentionally misrepresents a material fact to a health care provider for the purpose of obtaining documentation from the health care provider necessary to designate an animal as a service animal or a support animal; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-805(2)(c): the individual, except for an individual with a disability, uses an animal to gain treatment or benefits only provided for an individual with a disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-805(3): 76-6-501(2) This section does not affect the enforceability of any criminal law, including Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-805(4): (2) An agent of a protection and advocacy agency, acting in the agent's professional capacity and in compliance with 29 U.S.C. Sec. 794e et seq., 42 U.S.C. Sec. 15041 et seq., and 42 U.S.C. Sec. 1801 et seq., is not criminally liable under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-806 Sterilization of persons 18 years old or older.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-806(1): It is lawful for a physician to sterilize a person who is 18 years old or older and who has the capacity to give informed consent.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-806(2): 26B-6-811 It is unlawful for a physician to sterilize a person who is 18 years old or older and who is institutionalized, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-806(2)(a): the physician, through careful examination and counseling, ensures that the person is capable of giving informed consent and that no undue influence or coercion to consent has been placed on that person by nature of the fact that he is institutionalized; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-806(2)(b): 26B-6-811 the person is not capable of giving informed consent, a petition has been filed in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-806(3): 26B-6-811 It is unlawful for a physician to sterilize a person who is 18 years old or older and who is not capable of giving informed consent unless a petition has been filed in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-807 Sterilization of persons under 18 years old.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is unlawful for a physician to sterilize a person who is under 18 years old unless:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-807(1): the person is married or otherwise emancipated and the physician, through careful examination and counseling, ensures that the person is capable of giving informed consent.  If that person is institutionalized, the physician shall also ensure that no undue influence or coercion to consent has been placed on the person by nature of the fact that the person is institutionalized; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-807(2): 26B-6-811 a petition has been filed in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-808 Emergency -- Medical necessity.
---------------------------------------------------------------
If an emergency situation exists that prevents compliance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-809 Persons who may give informed consent.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
For purposes of this part, the following persons may give informed consent to sterilization:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-809(1): a person who is the subject of sterilization, if the person is capable of giving informed consent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-809(2): a person appointed by the court to give informed consent on behalf of a subject of sterilization who is incapable of giving informed consent.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-810 Declaration of capacity to give informed consent -- Hearing.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-810(1): A person who desires sterilization but whose capacity to give informed consent is questioned by any interested party may file a petition for declaration of capacity to give informed consent.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-810(2): If, after hearing all the relevant evidence, the court finds by a preponderance of the evidence that the person is capable of giving informed consent, the court shall enter an order declaring that the person has the capacity to give informed consent.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-811 Petition for order authorizing sterilization.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-811(1): A petition for an order authorizing sterilization may be filed by a person who desires sterilization, or by the person's parent, spouse, guardian, custodian, or other interested party.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-811(2): 26B-6-812 The court shall adjudicate the petition for sterilization in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812 Factors to be considered by court -- Evaluations -- Interview -- Findings of fact.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(1): If the court finds that the subject of sterilization is not capable of giving informed consent, the court shall consider, but not by way of limitation, the following factors concerning that person:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(1)(a): the nature and degree of the person's mental impairment, and the likelihood that the condition is permanent;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(1)(b): the level of the person's understanding regarding the concepts of reproduction and contraception, and whether the person's ability to understand those concepts is likely to improve;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(1)(c): the person's capability for procreation or reproduction, with a rebuttable presumption that the ability to procreate and reproduce exists in a person of normal physical development;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(1)(d): the potentially injurious physical and psychological effects from sterilization, pregnancy, childbirth, and parenthood;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(1)(e): the alternative methods of birth control presently available including, but not limited to, drugs, intrauterine devices, education and training, and the feasibility of one or more of those methods as an alternative to sterilization;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(1)(f): the likelihood that the person will engage in sexual activity or could be sexually abused or exploited;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(1)(g): the method of sterilization that is medically advisable, and least intrusive and destructive of the person's rights to bodily and psychological integrity;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(1)(h): the advisability of postponing sterilization until a later date; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(1)(i): the likelihood that the person could adequately care and provide for a child.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(2)(a): The court may require that independent medical, psychological, and social evaluations of the subject of sterilization be made prior to ruling on a petition for sterilization.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(2)(b): The court may appoint experts to perform those examinations and evaluations and may require the petitioner, to the extent of the petitioner's ability, to bear the costs incurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(3)(a): The court shall interview the subject of sterilization to determine the person's understanding of and desire for sterilization.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(3)(b): The expressed preference of the person shall be made a part of the record, and shall be considered by the court in rendering its decision.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(3)(c): The court is not bound by the expressed preference of the subject of sterilization; however, if the person expresses a preference not to be sterilized, the court shall deny the petition unless the petitioner proves beyond a reasonable doubt that the person will suffer serious physical or psychological injury if the petition is denied.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(4)(a): When adjudicating a petition for sterilization the court shall determine, on the basis of all the evidence, what decision regarding sterilization would have been made by the subject of sterilization, if the person were capable of giving informed consent to sterilization.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(4)(b): The decision regarding sterilization shall be in the best interest of the person to be sterilized.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-812(5): If the court grants a petition for sterilization, the court shall make appropriate findings of fact in support of its order.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-813 Advanced hearing.
-------------------------------------------------
On motion by the person seeking sterilization or by any other party to the proceeding, the court may advance hearing on the petition.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-814 Notice of hearing -- Service.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-814(1): A copy of the petition and notice of the hearing shall be served personally on the person to be sterilized not less than 20 days before the hearing date.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-814(2): The notice shall state the date, time, and place of the hearing, and shall specifically state that the hearing is to adjudicate either a petition for declaration of capacity to give informed consent to sterilization or a petition for sterilization.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-814(3): Notice shall be served on that person's parents, spouse, guardian, or custodian and on his attorney by the clerk of the court, by certified mail, not less than 10 days before the hearing date.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-815 Guardian ad litem -- Procedural rights.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-815(1): The court shall appoint an attorney to act as guardian ad litem to defend the rights and interests of the person to be sterilized.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-815(2): The person to be sterilized is entitled to appear and testify at the hearing, to examine and cross examine witnesses, and to compel the attendance of witnesses.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-815(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-815(3)(a): The person who is the subject of a sterilization proceeding may, on motion to the court and for good cause shown, waive the right to be present at the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-815(3)(b): If the court grants that motion, the person shall be represented by a guardian ad litem at the hearing.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-816 Jury -- Rules of evidence -- Transcript -- Burden of proof.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-816(1): The petitioner is entitled to request a jury to hear the petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-816(2): The rules of evidence apply in any hearing on a petition for sterilization.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-816(3): A transcript shall be made of the hearing and shall be made a permanent part of the record.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-816(4): The burden of producing evidence and the burden of proof shall be upon the petitioner to prove by clear and convincing evidence that the petition for or order authorizing sterilization should be granted.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-817 Appeal to Supreme Court -- Stay.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-817(1): Any party to a proceeding under this chapter may file a notice of appeal from any adverse decision with the Supreme Court in accordance with Rule 73, Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-817(2): The pendency of an appeal in the Supreme Court shall stay the proceedings until the appeal is finally determined.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-818 Treatment for therapeutic reasons unaffected.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent the medical or surgical treatment, for sound therapeutic reasons, of any person by a physician or surgeon licensed by this state, which treatment may incidentally involve destruction of reproductive functions.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-819 Immunity.
-----------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-819(1): A physician, assistant, or any other person acting pursuant to an order authorizing sterilization, as provided in this part, is not civilly or criminally liable for participation in or assistance to sterilization.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-819(2): This section does not apply to negligent acts committed in the performance of sterilization.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-820 Unauthorized sterilization -- Criminal penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Except as authorized by this part, any person who intentionally performs, encourages, assists in, or otherwise promotes the performance of a sterilization procedure for the purpose of destroying the power to procreate the human species, with knowledge that the provisions of this part have not been met, is guilty of a third degree felony.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-6-821 Annual "White Cane Safety Day" proclaimed.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Each year the governor shall take notice of October 15 as White Cane Safety Day.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-102 Director of family health services programs.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
The executive director may appoint a director of family health services programs who shall be a board certified pediatrician or obstetrician with at least two years experience in public health programs.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-103 State plan for maternal and child health services.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department shall prepare and submit a state plan for maternal and child health services as required by Title II of the Public Health Services Act. The plan shall be the official state plan for the state and shall be used as the basis for administration of Title V programs within the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-104 Child literacy -- Distribution of information kits.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-104(1): The Legislature recognizes that effective child literacy programs can have a dramatic long-term impact on each child's ability to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-104(1)(a): succeed in school;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-104(1)(b): successfully compete in a global society; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-104(1)(c): become a productive, responsible citizen.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-104(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-104(2)(a): To help further this end, the department may make available to parents of new-born infants, as a resource, an information kit regarding child development, the development of emerging literacy skills, and activities which promote and enhance emerging literacy skills, including reading aloud to the child on a regular basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-104(2)(b): The department shall seek private funding to help support this program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-104(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-104(3)(a): The department may seek assistance from the State Board of Education and local hospitals in making the information kit available to parents on a voluntary basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-104(3)(b): The department may also seek assistance from private entities in making the kits available to parents.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-108 Rules for sale of drugs, cosmetics, and medical devices.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department shall establish and enforce rules for the sale or distribution of human drugs, cosmetics, and medical devices.  The rules adopted under this section shall be no more stringent than those established by federal law.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-109 Director of community health nursing appointed by executive director.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The executive director shall appoint a director of community health nursing who shall develop, implement, monitor, and evaluate community health nursing standards and services and participate in the formulation of policies for administration of health services.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-110 Duty to establish program to reduce deaths and other harm from prescription opiates used for chronic noncancer pain.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-110(1): As used in this section, "opiate" means any drug or other substance having an addiction-forming or addiction-sustaining liability similar to morphine or being capable of conversion into a drug having addiction-forming or addiction-sustaining liability.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-110(2): 26B-1-202; 58-37f-201; 58-37f-201 In addition to the duties listed in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-110(2)(b): study the risks, warning signs, and solutions to the risks associated with prescription opiate medications for chronic pain, including risks and prevention of misuse and diversion of those medications;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-110(2)(c): provide education to health care providers, patients, insurers, and the general public on the appropriate management of chronic pain, including the effective use of medical treatment and quality care guidelines that are scientifically based and peer reviewed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-110(2)(d): 58-37f-201 educate the public regarding:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-111(3)(c): establish a method for apportioning money in the program fund to multiple local health departments when the total amount of concurrent requests for reimbursement by multiple local health departments exceeds the balance in the program fund; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-111(3)(d): establish by rule other provisions that the department considers necessary or advisable to implement the program.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-113 Identification of major risk factors by department -- Education of public -- Establishment of programs.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department shall identify the major risk factors contributing to injury, sickness, death, and disability within the state and where it determines that a need exists, educate the public regarding these risk factors, and the department may establish programs to reduce or eliminate these factors except that such programs may not be established if adequate programs exist in the private sector.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114 Office of Health Equity -- Duties.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(1)(a): "Multicultural or minority health issue" means a health issue, including a mental and oral health issue, of particular interest to cultural, ethnic, racial, or other subpopulations, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(1)(a)(i): disparities in:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(1)(a)(i)(A): disease incidence, prevalence, morbidity, mortality, treatment, and treatment response; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(1)(a)(i)(B): access to care; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(1)(a)(ii): cultural competency in the delivery of health care.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(1)(b): "Office" means the Office of Health Equity created in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(2): There is created within the department the Office of Health Equity.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(3): The office shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(3)(a): promote and coordinate the research, data production, dissemination, education, and health promotion activities of the following that relate to a multicultural or minority health issue:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(3)(a)(i): the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(3)(a)(ii): local health departments;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(3)(a)(iii): local mental health authorities;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(3)(a)(iv): public schools;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(3)(a)(v): community-based organizations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(3)(a)(vi): other organizations within the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(3)(b): assist in the development and implementation of one or more programs to address a multicultural or minority health issue;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(3)(c): promote the dissemination and use of information on a multicultural or minority health issue by minority populations, health care providers, and others;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(3)(d): seek federal funding and other resources to accomplish the office's mission;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(3)(e): provide technical assistance to organizations within the state seeking funding to study or address a multicultural or minority health issue;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(3)(f): develop and increase the capacity of the office to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(3)(f)(i): ensure the delivery of qualified timely culturally appropriate translation services across department programs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(3)(f)(ii): provide, when appropriate, linguistically competent translation and communication services for limited English proficiency individuals;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(3)(g): provide staff assistance to any advisory committee created by the department to study a multicultural or minority health issue; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-114(3)(h): annually report to the Legislature on its activities and accomplishments.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-115 Utah Registry of Autism and Developmental Disabilities.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-115(1): As used in this section, "URADD" means the Utah Registry of Autism and Developmental Disabilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-115(2): The department may enter into an agreement with:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-115(2)(a): the University of Utah or another person for the operation of URADD; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-115(2)(b): a person to conduct a public education campaign to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-115(2)(b)(i): improve public awareness of the early warning signs of autism spectrum disorders and developmental disabilities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-115(2)(b)(ii): promote the early identification of autism spectrum disorders and developmental disabilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-115(3): URADD shall consist of a database that collects information on people in the state who have an autism spectrum disorder or a developmental disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-115(4): The purpose of URADD is to assist health care providers to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-115(4)(a): determine the risk factors and causes of autism spectrum disorders and developmental disabilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-115(4)(b): plan for and develop resources, therapies, methods of diagnoses, and other services for people with an autism spectrum disorder or a developmental disability;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-115(4)(c): facilitate measuring and tracking of treatment outcomes;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-115(4)(d): gather statistics relating to autism spectrum disorders and developmental disabilities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-115(4)(e): improve coordination and cooperation between agencies and other programs that provide services to people with an autism spectrum disorder or a developmental disability.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-116 Radon awareness campaign.
---------------------------------------------------------
The department shall, in consultation with the Division of Waste Management and Radiation Control, develop a statewide electronic awareness campaign to educate the public regarding:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-116(1): the existence and prevalence of radon gas in buildings and structures;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-116(2): the health risks associated with radon gas;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-116(3): options for radon gas testing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-116(4): options for radon gas remediation.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117 Syringe exchange and education.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(1): 26B-5-101 The following may operate a syringe exchange program in the state to prevent the transmission of disease and reduce morbidity and mortality among individuals who inject drugs, and those individuals' contacts:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(1)(a): 26B-5-101 a government entity, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(1)(a)(i): the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(1)(a)(ii): a local health department; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(1)(a)(iii): 26B-5-101 a local substance abuse authority, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(1)(b): a nongovernment entity, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(1)(b)(i): a nonprofit organization; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(1)(b)(ii): a for-profit organization; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(1)(c): any other entity that complies with Subsections (2) and (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(2): An entity operating a syringe exchange program in the state shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(2)(a): facilitate the exchange of an individual's used syringe for one or more new syringes in sealed sterile packages;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(2)(b): ensure that a recipient of a new syringe is given verbal and written instruction on:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(2)(b)(i): methods for preventing the transmission of blood-borne diseases, including hepatitis C and human immunodeficiency virus; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(2)(b)(ii): options for obtaining:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(2)(b)(ii)(A): services for the treatment of a substance use disorder;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(2)(b)(ii)(B): testing for a blood-borne disease; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(2)(b)(ii)(C): an opiate antagonist; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(2)(c): report annually to the department the following information about the program's activities:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(2)(c)(i): the number of individuals who have exchanged syringes;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(2)(c)(ii): the number of used syringes exchanged for new syringes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(2)(c)(iii): the number of new syringes provided in exchange for used syringes.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-117(3): The department shall make rules, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, specifying how and when an entity operating a syringe exchange program shall make the report required by Subsection (2)(c).

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-119 Hepatitis C Outreach Pilot Program.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-119(1): As used in this section, "Hepatitis C outreach organization" means a private nonprofit organization that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-119(1)(a): has an established relationship with individuals who are at risk of acquiring acute Hepatitis C;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-119(1)(b): helps individuals who need Hepatitis C treatment, but who do not qualify for payment of the treatment by the Medicaid program or another health insurer, to obtain treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-119(1)(c): has the infrastructure necessary for conducting Hepatitis C assessment, testing, and diagnosis, including clinical staff with the training and ability to provide:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-119(1)(c)(i): specimen collection for Hepatitis C testing;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-119(1)(c)(ii): clinical assessments;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-119(1)(c)(iii): consultation regarding blood-borne diseases; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-119(1)(c)(iv): case management services for patient support during Hepatitis C treatment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-119(1)(d): has a partnership with a health care facility that can provide clinical follow-up and medical treatment following Hepatitis C rapid antibody testing and confirmatory testing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-119(2): There is created within the department the Hepatitis C Outreach Pilot Program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-119(3): Before September 1, 2020, the department shall, as funding permits, make grants to Hepatitis C outreach organizations in accordance with criteria established by the department under Subsection (4).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-119(4): Before July 1, 2020, the department shall make rules, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-119(4)(a): create application requirements for a grant from the program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-119(4)(b): establish criteria for determining:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-119(4)(b)(i): whether a grant is awarded, including criteria that ensure grants are awarded to areas of the state, including rural areas, that would benefit most from the grant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-119(4)(b)(ii): the amount of a grant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-119(4)(c): specify reporting requirements for the recipient of a grant under this section.
