Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-122(3)(a)(i): the benefits of strong communication skills, particularly between a minor and the minor's parent or guardian; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-122(3)(a)(ii): the harms associated with poor communication or a lack of communication; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-122(3)(b): promote:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-122(3)(b)(i): the destigmatization of mental health issues;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-122(3)(b)(ii): the personal and community benefits of effective communication;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-122(3)(b)(iii): tips and advice on how to effectively communicate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-122(3)(b)(iv): resources to support minors if they are struggling with mental illness.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-122(4): The CHAT campaign shall include a branding strategy around the CHAT campaign to increase public awareness.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-122(5): The request for proposals described in Subsection (3) shall be open to an institution of higher education.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-122(6): Within available funds, the department shall enter into an agreement with the selected proposer to implement the CHAT campaign selected through the request for proposal process on a statewide basis through June 30, 2029.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-122(7): The department may accept donations and use those funds to support the implementation of the CHAT campaign.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-123 Report on CHAT campaign.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-123(1): The department shall determine metrics to measure the success of the CHAT campaign and regularly reevaluate those metrics.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-123(2): No later than September 1, 2028, the department shall create a report on:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-123(2)(a): the implementation of the CHAT campaign;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-123(2)(b): the results of the CHAT campaign; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-123(2)(c): recommendations for the continuance or the suspension of the CHAT campaign.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-123(3): The department shall deliver the report described in Subsection (2) to the Health and Human Services Interim Committee, no later than October 1, 2028.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-124 Rules for public cold baths.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-124(1): As used in this section, "public cold bath" means a tub or tank that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-124(1)(a): is used by:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-124(1)(a)(i): the general public, regardless of whether there is a charge or payment for use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-124(1)(a)(ii): one bather at a time;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-124(1)(b): contains chilled water that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-124(1)(b)(i): maintained at a temperature lower than 60 degrees Fahrenheit;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-124(1)(b)(ii): no more than 180 gallons in volume; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-124(1)(b)(iii): at a depth that allows the bather to maintain the bather's head above the water while in a seated position; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-124(1)(c): continuously filters and sanitizes the chilled water.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-124(2): The department may not adopt a rule that restricts, limits, or imposes requirements on the operation of a public cold bath.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(1): 26B-2-201 "Ambulatory surgical center" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(2): "Carrier" means an infected individual or animal who harbors a specific infectious agent in the absence of discernible clinical disease and serves as a potential source of infection for man.  The carrier state may occur in an individual with an infection that is inapparent throughout its course, commonly known as healthy or asymptomatic carrier, or during the incubation period, convalescence, and postconvalescence of an individual with a clinically recognizable disease, commonly known as incubatory carrier or convalescent carrier.  Under either circumstance the carrier state may be of short duration, as a temporary or transient carrier, or long duration, as a chronic carrier.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(3): "Communicable disease" means illness due to a specific infectious agent or its toxic products which arises through transmission of that agent or its products from a reservoir to a susceptible host, either directly, as from an infected individual or animal, or indirectly, through an intermediate plant or animal host, vector, or the inanimate environment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(4): "Communicable period" means the time or times during which an infectious agent may be transferred directly or indirectly from an infected individual to another individual, from an infected animal to a human, or from an infected human to an animal, including arthropods.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(5): "Contact" means an individual or animal having had association with an infected individual, animal, or contaminated environment so as to have had an opportunity to acquire the infection.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(6): 26B-2-201 "End stage renal disease facility" is as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(7)(a): "Epidemic" means the occurrence or outbreak in a community or region of cases of an illness clearly in excess of normal expectancy and derived from a common or propagated source.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(7)(b): The number of cases indicating an epidemic will vary according to the infectious agent, size, and type of population exposed, previous experience or lack of exposure to the disease, and time and place of occurrence.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(7)(c): Epidemicity is considered to be relative to usual frequency of the disease in the same area, among the specified population, at the same season of the year.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(8): 26B-2-201 "General acute hospital" is as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(9): "Incubation period" means the time interval between exposure to an infectious agent and appearance of the first sign or symptom of the disease in question.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(10): "Infected individual" means an individual who harbors an infectious agent and who has manifest disease or inapparent infection.  An infected individual is one from whom the infectious agent can be naturally acquired.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(11): "Infection" means the entry and development or multiplication of an infectious agent in the body of man or animals.  Infection is not synonymous with infectious disease; the result may be inapparent or manifest.  The presence of living infectious agents on exterior surfaces of the body, or upon articles of apparel or soiled articles, is not infection, but contamination of such surfaces and articles.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(12): "Infectious agent" means an organism such as a virus, rickettsia, bacteria, fungus, protozoan, or helminth that is capable of producing infection or infectious disease.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(13): "Infectious disease" means a disease of man or animals resulting from an infection.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(14): "Isolation" means the separation, for the period of communicability, of infected individuals or animals from others, in such places and under such conditions as to prevent the direct or indirect conveyance of the infectious agent from those infected to those who are susceptible or who may spread the agent to others.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(15): 4-1-109 "Local food" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(16): 26B-7-301 "Order of constraint" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(17): "Quarantine" means the restriction of the activities of well individuals or animals who have been exposed to a communicable disease during its period of communicability to prevent disease transmission.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(18): "School" means a public, private, or parochial nursery school, licensed or unlicensed day care center, child care facility, family care home, Head Start program, kindergarten, elementary, or secondary school through grade 12.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(19): "Sexually transmitted disease" means those diseases transmitted through sexual intercourse or any other sexual contact.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-201(20): 26B-2-201 "Specialty hospital" is as defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202 Authority to investigate and control epidemic infections and communicable disease.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(1): Subject to Subsection (4) and the restrictions in this title, the department has authority to investigate and control the causes of epidemic infections and communicable disease, and shall provide for the detection, reporting, prevention, and control of communicable diseases and epidemic infections or any other health hazard which may affect the public health.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(2): 26B-7-301 This part does not authorize the department to control the production, processing, distribution, or sale price of local food in response to a public health emergency, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(3)(a): As part of the requirements of Subsection (1), the department shall distribute to the public and to health care professionals:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(3)(a)(i): medically accurate information about sexually transmitted diseases that may cause infertility and sterility if left untreated, including descriptions of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(3)(a)(i)(A): the probable side effects resulting from an untreated sexually transmitted disease, including infertility and sterility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(3)(a)(i)(B): medically accepted treatment for sexually transmitted diseases;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(3)(a)(i)(C): the medical risks commonly associated with the medical treatment of sexually transmitted diseases; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(3)(a)(i)(D): suggested screening by a private physician or physician assistant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(3)(a)(ii): information about:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(3)(a)(ii)(A): public services and agencies available to assist individuals with obtaining treatment for the sexually transmitted disease;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(3)(a)(ii)(B): medical assistance benefits that may be available to the individual with the sexually transmitted disease; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(3)(a)(ii)(C): abstinence before marriage and fidelity after marriage being the surest prevention of sexually transmitted disease.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(3)(b): The information described in Subsection (3)(a):
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(3)(b)(i): shall be distributed by the department and by local health departments free of charge;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(3)(b)(ii): shall be relevant to the geographic location in which the information is distributed by:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(3)(b)(ii)(A): listing addresses and telephone numbers for public clinics and agencies providing services in the geographic area in which the information is distributed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(3)(b)(ii)(B): providing the information in English as well as other languages that may be appropriate for the geographic area.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(3)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(3)(c)(i): Except as provided in Subsection (3)(c)(ii), the department shall develop written material that includes the information described in this Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(3)(c)(ii): In addition to the written materials described in Subsection (3)(c)(i), the department may distribute the information described in this Subsection (3) by any other methods the department determines is appropriate to educate the public, excluding public schools, including websites, toll free telephone numbers, and the media.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(3)(c)(iii): If the information described in Subsection (3)(b)(ii)(A) is not included in the written pamphlet developed by the department, the written material shall include either a website, or a 24-hour toll free telephone number that the public may use to obtain that information.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(4)(a): The Legislature may at any time terminate by joint resolution an order of constraint issued by the department as described in this section in response to a declared public health emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-202(4)(b): A county governing body may at any time terminate by majority vote an order of constraint issued by the relevant local health department as described in this section in response to a declared public health emergency.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-205 Willful introduction of communicable disease a misdemeanor.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any person who willfully or knowingly introduces any communicable or infectious disease into any county, municipality, or community is guilty of a class A misdemeanor, except as provided in Section

The following shall report to the department or the local health department regarding any individual suffering from or suspected of having a disease that is communicable, as required by department rule:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-206(1): 78B-3-403 health care providers as defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-206(6): nursing homes and other care facilities;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-207 Designation of communicable diseases by department -- Establishment of rules for detection, reporting, investigation, prevention, and control.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department may designate those diseases which are communicable, of concern to the public health, and reportable; and establish rules for the detection, reporting, investigation, prevention, and control of communicable diseases, epidemic infections, and other health hazards that affect the public health.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-208 Tuberculosis -- Duty of department to investigate, control, and monitor.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-208(1): The department shall conduct or oversee the investigation, control, and monitoring of suspected or confirmed tuberculosis infection and disease within the state.  Local health departments shall investigate, control, and monitor suspected or confirmed tuberculosis infection and disease within their respective jurisdictions.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-208(2): A health care provider who treats an individual with suspected or confirmed tuberculosis shall treat the individual according to guidelines established by the department.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-209 Tuberculosis -- Testing of high risk individuals.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Individuals at high risk for tuberculosis shall be tested as required by department rule, which:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-209(1): shall establish criteria to identify individuals who are at high risk for tuberculosis; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-209(2): may establish who is responsible for the costs of the testing.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-210 Rabies or other animal disease -- Investigation and order of quarantine.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-210(1): As used in this section, "quarantine" means strict confinement upon the private premises of the owners, under restraint by leash, closed cage or paddock of all animals specified by the order.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-210(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-210(2)(a): Whenever rabies or any other animal disease dangerous to the health of human beings is reported, the department shall investigate to determine whether such  disease exists, and the probable area of the state in which man or beast is thereby endangered.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-210(2)(b): If the department finds that such disease exists, a quarantine may be declared against all animals designated in the quarantine order and within the area specified in the order.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-210(2)(c): If the quarantine is for the purpose of preventing the spread of rabies or hydrophobia, the order shall contain a warning to the owners of dogs within the quarantined area to confine or muzzle all dogs to prevent biting.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-210(2)(d): Any dog not muzzled found running at large in a quarantined area or any dog known to have been removed from or escaped from such area, may be killed by any person without liability therefor.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-210(3): Following the order of quarantine the department shall make a thorough investigation as to the extent of the disease, the probable number of persons and beasts exposed, and the area involved.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-210(4): During the period any quarantine order is in force all peace officers may kill or capture and hold for further action by the department all animals in a quarantined area not held in restraint on private premises.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any person in possession of any animal being held in violation of Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-212 Sexually transmitted infections declared dangerous to public health.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Syphilis, gonorrhea, lymphogranuloma inguinale (venereum) and chancroid are hereby declared to be contagious, infectious, communicable and dangerous to the public health.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-213 Sexually transmitted infections -- Examinations by authorities -- Treatment of infected persons.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
State, county, and municipal health officers within their respective jurisdictions may make examinations of persons reasonably suspected of being infected with sexually transmitted infections. Persons infected with sexually transmitted infections shall be required to report for treatment to either a reputable physician or physician assistant and continue treatment until cured or to submit to treatment provided at public expense until cured.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-214 Sexually transmitted infections -- Consent of minor to treatment.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-214(1): A consent to medical care or services by a hospital or public clinic or the performance of medical care or services by a licensed physician or physician assistant executed by a minor who is or professes to be afflicted with a sexually transmitted disease, shall have the same legal effect upon the minor and the same legal obligations with regard to the giving of consent as a consent given by a person of full legal age and capacity, the infancy of the minor and any contrary provision of law notwithstanding.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-214(2): The consent of the minor is not subject to later disaffirmance by reason of minority at the time it was given and the consent of no other person or persons shall be necessary to authorize hospital or clinical care or services to be provided to the minor by a licensed physician or physician assistant.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-214(3): The provisions of this section shall apply also to minors who profess to be in need of hospital or clinical care and services or medical care or services provided by a physician or physician assistant for suspected sexually transmitted disease, regardless of whether such professed suspicions are subsequently substantiated on a medical basis.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-215 Sexually transmitted infections -- Examination and treatment of persons in prison or jail.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-215(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-215(1)(a): All persons confined in any state, county, or city prison or jail shall be examined, and if infected, treated for sexually transmitted infections by the health authorities.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-215(1)(b): The prison authorities of every state, county, or city prison or jail shall make available to the health authorities such portion of the prison or jail as may be necessary for a clinic or hospital wherein all persons suffering with sexually transmitted infections at the time of the expiration of their terms of imprisonment, shall be isolated and treated at public expense until cured.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-215(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-215(2)(a): The department may require persons suffering with sexually transmitted infections at the time of the expiration of their terms of imprisonment to report for treatment to a licensed physician or physician assistant or submit to treatment provided at public expense in lieu of isolation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-215(2)(b): Nothing in this section shall interfere with the service of any sentence imposed by a court as a punishment for the commission of crime.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-216 Serological testing of pregnant or recently delivered women.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-216(1): As used in this section, a "standard serological test" means a test for syphilis approved by the department and made at an approved laboratory.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-216(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-216(2)(a): Every licensed physician, surgeon, or physician assistant attending a pregnant or recently delivered woman for conditions relating to her pregnancy shall take or cause to be taken a sample of blood of the woman at the time of first examination or within 10 days thereafter.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-216(2)(b): The blood sample shall be submitted to an approved laboratory for a standard serological test for syphilis.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-216(2)(c): The provisions of this section do not apply to any female who objects thereto on the grounds that she is a bona fide member of a specified, well recognized religious organization whose teachings are contrary to the tests.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-216(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-216(3)(a): Every other person attending a pregnant or recently delivered woman, who is not permitted by law to take blood samples, shall within 10 days from the time of first attendance cause a sample of blood to be taken by a licensed physician or physician assistant.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-216(3)(b): The blood sample shall be submitted to an approved laboratory for a standard serological test for syphilis.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-216(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-216(4)(a): An approved laboratory is a laboratory approved by the department according to its rules governing the approval of laboratories for the purpose of this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-216(4)(b): In submitting the sample to the laboratory the physician or physician assistant shall designate whether it is a prenatal test or a test following recent delivery.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-216(5): The laboratory shall transmit a detailed report of the standard serological test, showing the result thereof to the physician or physician assistant.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-227 Chronic disease control -- Establishing a prevention program -- Detection, monitoring, and community education.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-227(1): As used in this section, "chronic disease" means an impairment or deviation from the normal functioning of the human body having one or more of the following characteristics:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-227(1)(a): is permanent;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-227(1)(b): leaves residual disability;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-227(1)(c): is caused by nonreversible pathological alterations;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-227(1)(d): requires special patient education and instruction for rehabilitation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-227(1)(e): may require a long period of supervision, observation and care.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-227(2): The department shall establish and operate reasonable programs to prevent, delay, and detect the onset of chronic diseases including cancer, diabetes, cardiovascular and pulmonary diseases, genetic diseases, and such other chronic diseases as the department determines are important in promoting, protecting, and maintaining the public's health.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-227(3): (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-227(3)(a): The department shall develop and maintain a system for detecting and monitoring chronic diseases within the state and shall investigate and determine the epidemiology of those conditions which contributed to preventable and premature sickness, or both, and to death and disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-227(3)(b): (3)(a) The department shall consider the disease known as "lupus" a chronic disease subject to the detection and monitoring provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-227(4): The department shall establish programs of community and professional education relevant to the detection, prevention, and control of chronic diseases.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(1): "Bioterrorism" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(1)(a): the intentional use of any microorganism, virus, infectious substance, or biological product to cause death, disease, or other biological malfunction in a human, an animal, a plant, or another living organism in order to influence, intimidate, or coerce the conduct of government or a civilian population; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(1)(b): includes anthrax, botulism, small pox, plague, tularemia, and viral hemorrhagic fevers.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(2): "Dangerous public health condition" means any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(2)(a): cholera;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(2)(b): pneumonic plague;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(2)(c): severe acute respiratory syndrome;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(2)(d): smallpox;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(2)(e): tuberculosis;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(2)(f): any viral hemorrhagic fever;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(2)(g): measles; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(2)(h): any infection:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(2)(h)(i): that is new, drug resistant, or reemerging;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(2)(h)(ii): that evidence suggests is likely to cause either high mortality or morbidity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(2)(h)(iii): only if the relevant legislative body of the county where the infection is located approves as needing containment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(3): "Diagnostic information" means a clinical facility's record of individuals who present for treatment, including the reason for the visit, chief complaint, presenting diagnosis, final diagnosis, and any pertinent lab results.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(4): "Epidemic or pandemic disease":
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(4)(a): means the occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness clearly in excess of normal expectancy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(4)(b): includes diseases designated by the department which have the potential to cause serious illness or death.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(5): "Exigent circumstances" means a significant change in circumstances following the expiration of a public health emergency declared in accordance with this title that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(5)(a): substantially increases the danger to public safety or health relative to the circumstances in existence when the public health emergency expired;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(5)(b): poses an imminent danger to public safety or health; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(5)(c): was not known or foreseen and could not have been known or foreseen at the time the public health emergency expired.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(6): 53-13-103; 26B-4-101 "First responder" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(6)(a): 53-13-103 a law enforcement officer as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(6)(b): 26B-4-101 emergency medical service personnel as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(6)(c): firefighters; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(6)(d): public health personnel having jurisdiction over the location where an individual subject to an order of restriction is found.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(7): 78B-3-403 "Health care provider" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(8): 53-2a-203 "Legislative emergency response committee" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(9): 4-1-109 "Local food" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(10)(a): "Order of constraint" means an order, rule, or regulation issued in response to a declared public health emergency under this part, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(10)(a)(i): applies to all or substantially all:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(10)(a)(i)(A): individuals or a certain group of individuals; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(10)(a)(i)(B): public places or certain types of public places; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(10)(a)(ii): for the protection of the public health and in response to the declared public health emergency:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(10)(a)(ii)(A): establishes, maintains, or enforces isolation or quarantine;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(10)(a)(ii)(B): establishes, maintains, or enforces a stay-at-home order;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(10)(a)(ii)(C): exercises physical control over property or individuals;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(10)(a)(ii)(D): requires an individual to perform a certain action or engage in certain behavior; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(10)(a)(ii)(E): closes theaters, schools, or other public places or prohibits gatherings of people to protect the public health.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(10)(b): "Order of constraint" includes a stay-at-home order.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(11): "Order of restriction" means an order issued by a department or a district court which requires an individual or group of individuals who are subject to restriction to submit to an examination, treatment, isolation, or quarantine.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(12): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(12)(a): "Public health emergency" means an occurrence or imminent credible threat of an illness or health condition, caused by bioterrorism, epidemic or pandemic disease, or novel and highly fatal infectious agent or biological toxin, that poses a substantial risk of a significant number of human fatalities or incidents of permanent or long-term disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(12)(b): "Public health emergency" includes an illness or health condition resulting from a natural disaster.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(13): "Public health official" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(13)(a): the executive director or the executive director's authorized representative; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(13)(b): the executive director of a local health department or the executive director's authorized representative.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(14): "Reportable emergency illness and health condition" includes the diseases, conditions, or syndromes designated by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(15): "Stay-at-home order" means an order of constraint that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(15)(a): restricts movement of the general population to suppress or mitigate an epidemic or pandemic disease by directing individuals within a defined geographic area to remain in their respective residences; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(15)(b): may include exceptions for certain essential tasks.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(16): "Threat to public health" means a situation where a dangerous public health condition could spread to other individuals.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-301(17): "Subject to restriction" as applied to an individual, or a group of individuals, means the individual or group of individuals could create a threat to public health.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-302 Executive director -- Power to order abatement of public health hazard -- Limitation on power to control local food.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-302(1): If the executive director finds that a condition of filth, sanitation, or other health hazard exists which creates a clear present hazard to the public health and which requires immediate action to protect human health or safety, the executive director with the concurrence of the governor may order persons causing or contributing to the condition to reduce, discontinue, or ameliorate it to the extent that the public health hazard is eliminated.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-302(2): This part does not authorize the executive director to control the production, processing, distribution, or sale price of local food in response to a public health emergency.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304 Order of restriction.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(1): 26B-1-202; 26A-1-114; 26B-7-304; 26B-7-314 Subject to Subsection (5), the department or a local health department having jurisdiction over the location where an individual or a group of individuals who are subject to restriction are found may:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(1)(a): 26B-1-202; 26A-1-114; 26B-7-304; 26B-7-314 issue a written order of restriction for the individual or group of individuals pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(1)(b): issue a verbal order of restriction for an individual or group of individuals pursuant to Subsection (2)(c).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(2): 26B-7-307; 26B-7-307
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(2)(a): A department or local health department's determination to issue an order of restriction shall be based upon the totality of circumstances reported to and known by the department or local health department, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(2)(a)(i): observation;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(2)(a)(ii): information that the department or local health department determines is credible and reliable information; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(2)(a)(iii): knowledge of current public health risks based on medically accepted guidelines as may be established by the department by administrative rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(2)(b): 26B-7-307 An order of restriction issued by the department or a local health department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(2)(b)(i): in the opinion of the public health official, be for the shortest reasonable period of time necessary to protect the public health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(2)(b)(ii): use the least intrusive method of restriction that, in the opinion of the department or local health department, is reasonable based on the totality of circumstances known to the department or local health department issuing the order of restriction;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(2)(b)(iii): be in writing unless the provisions of Subsection (2)(c) apply; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(2)(b)(iv): 26B-7-307 contain notice of an individual's rights as required in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(2)(c): 26B-7-307
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(2)(c)(i): The department or a local health department may issue a verbal order of restriction, without prior notice to the individual or group of individuals if the delay in imposing a written order of restriction would significantly jeopardize the department or local health department's ability to prevent or limit a threat to public health.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(2)(c)(ii): 26B-7-307 A verbal order of restriction issued under Subsection (2)(c)(i):
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(2)(c)(ii)(A): is valid for 24 hours from the time the order of restriction is issued;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(2)(c)(ii)(B): may be verbally communicated to the individuals or group of individuals subject to restriction by a first responder;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(2)(c)(ii)(C): may be enforced by the first responder until the department or local health department is able to establish and maintain the place of restriction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(2)(c)(ii)(D): 26B-7-307 may only be continued beyond the initial 24 hours if a written order of restriction is issued pursuant to the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(3): 26B-7-307; 26B-7-311 Pending issuance of a written order of restriction under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(4): The department or local health department that issued the order of restriction shall take reasonable measures, including the provision of medical care, as may be necessary to assure proper care related to the reason for the involuntary examination, treatment, isolation, or quarantine of an individual ordered to submit to an order of restriction.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(5)(a): The Legislature may at any time terminate by joint resolution an order of restriction issued by the department or local health department as described in this section in response to a declared public health emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-304(5)(b): A county governing body may at any time terminate by majority vote an order of restriction issued by the relevant local health department under this section issued in response to a declared public health emergency.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-305 Consent to order of restriction -- Periodic review.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-305(1): 26B-7-309; 26B-7-311; (1)(b)(iv)(B); 26B-7-306
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-305(1)(a): 26B-7-309; 26B-7-311 The department or a local health department shall either seek judicial review of an order of restriction under Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-305(1)(b): (1)(b)(iv)(B); 26B-7-306 If the department or a local health department obtains consent, the consent shall be in writing and shall inform the individual or group of individuals:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-305(1)(b)(i): of the terms and duration of the order of restriction;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-305(1)(b)(ii): of the importance of complying with the order of restriction to protect the public's health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-305(1)(b)(iii): that each individual has the right to agree to the order of restriction, or refuse to agree to the order of restriction and seek a judicial review of the order of restriction;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-305(1)(b)(iv): (1)(b)(iv)(B) that for any individual who consents to the order of restriction:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-305(1)(b)(iv)(A): (1)(b)(iv)(B) the order of restriction will not be reviewed by the court unless the individual withdraws consent to the order of restriction in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-305(1)(b)(iv)(B): the individual shall notify the department or local health department in writing, with at least five business day's notice, if the individual intends to withdraw consent to the order of restriction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-305(1)(b)(v): 26B-7-306 that a breach of a consent agreement prior to the end of the order of restriction may subject the individual to an involuntary order of restriction under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-305(2): 26B-7-309; 26B-7-311
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-305(2)(a): The department or local health department responsible for the care of an individual who has consented to the order of restriction shall periodically reexamine the reasons upon which the order of restriction was based.  This reexamination shall occur at least once every six months.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-305(2)(b): 26B-7-309; 26B-7-311
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-305(2)(b)(i): If at any time, the department or local health department determines that the conditions justifying the order of restriction for either a group or an individual no longer exist, the department or local health department shall immediately discharge the individual or group from the order of restriction.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-305(2)(b)(ii): If the department or local health department determines that the conditions justifying the order of restriction continue to exist, the department or local health department shall send to the individual a written notice of:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-305(2)(b)(ii)(B): the individual's right to a judicial review of the order of restriction by the court if requested by the individual.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307 Contents of notice of order of restriction -- Rights of individuals.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(1): A written order of restriction issued by a department or local health department shall include the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(1)(a): the identity of the individual or a description of the group of individuals subject to the order of restriction;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(1)(b): the identity or location of any premises that may be subject to restriction;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(1)(c): the date and time for which the restriction begins and the expected duration of the restriction;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(1)(d): the suspected dangerous public health condition that poses a threat to public health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(1)(e): the requirements for termination of the order of restriction, such as necessary laboratory reports, the expiration of an incubation period, or the completion of treatment for the communicable disease;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(1)(f): any conditions on the restriction, such as limitation of visitors or requirements for medical monitoring;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(1)(g): the medical or scientific information upon which the restriction is based;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(1)(h): a statement advising of the right to a judicial review of the order of restriction by the court; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(1)(i): pursuant to Subsection (2), the rights of each individual subject to restriction.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(2): 26B-7-309 An individual subject to restriction has the following rights:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(2)(a): 26B-7-309 the right to be represented by legal counsel in any judicial review of the order of restriction in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(2)(b): the right to be provided with prior notice of the date, time, and location of any hearing concerning the order of restriction;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(2)(c): the right to participate in any hearing, in a manner established by the court based on precautions necessary to prevent additional exposure to communicable or possibly communicable diseases or to protect the public health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(2)(d): the right to respond and present evidence and arguments on the individual's own behalf in any hearing;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(2)(e): the right to cross examine witnesses; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(2)(f): the right to review and copy all records in the possession of the department that issued the order of restriction which relate to the subject of the written order of restriction.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(3)(a): Notwithstanding the provisions of Subsection (1), if the department or a local health department issues an order of restriction for a group of individuals, the department or local health department may modify the method of providing notice to the group or modify the information contained in the notice, if the public health official determines the modification of the notice is necessary to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(3)(a)(i): protect the privacy of medical information of individuals in the group; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(3)(a)(ii): provide notice to the group in a manner that will efficiently and effectively notify the individuals in the group within the period of time necessary to protect the public health.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(3)(b): When the department or a local health department modifies notice to a group of individuals under Subsection (3)(a), the department or local health department shall provide each individual in the group with notice that complies with the provisions of Subsection (1) as soon as reasonably practical.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(4)(a): In addition to the rights of an individual described in Subsections (1) and (2), an individual subject to an order of restriction may not be terminated from employment if the reason for termination is based solely on the fact that the individual is or was subject to an order of restriction.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(4)(b): The department or local health department issuing the order of restriction shall give the individual subject to the order of restriction notice of the individual's employment rights under Subsection (4)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-307(4)(c): An employer in the state, including an employer who is the state or a political subdivision of the state, may not violate the provisions of Subsection (4)(a).

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-309(5): All persons to whom notice is required to be given may attend the hearings.  The court may exclude from the hearing all persons not necessary for the conduct of the proceedings.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-309(6): All hearings shall be conducted in as informal a manner as may be consistent with orderly procedure, and in a physical setting that is not likely to have a harmful effect on the health of the individual or others required to participate in the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-309(7): The court shall receive all relevant and material evidence which is offered, subject to Utah Rules of Evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-309(8): The court may order law enforcement to assist the petitioner in locating the individuals subject to restriction and enforcing the order of restriction.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-311(6)(a)(iv)(D): other relevant factors as determined by the court.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-313 Transportation of individuals subject to temporary or court-ordered restriction.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Transportation of an individual subject to an order of restriction to court, or to a place for examination, quarantine, isolation, or treatment pursuant a temporary order issued by a department or local health department, or pursuant to a court order, shall be conducted by the county sheriff where the individual is located.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-317 Authorization to report -- Declaration of a public health emergency -- Termination of a public health emergency -- Order of constraint.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-317(1): A health care provider is authorized to report to the department any case of a reportable emergency illness or health condition in any person when:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-317(1)(a): the health care provider knows of a confirmed case; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-317(1)(b): the health care provider believes, based on the health care provider's professional judgment that a person likely harbors a reportable emergency illness or health condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-317(2): A report pursuant to this section shall include, if known:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-317(2)(c): the date and time of visit;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-317(2)(f): the reportable illness or condition detected or suspected;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-317(2)(g): diagnostic information and, if available, diagnostic codes assigned to the visit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-317(2)(h): whether the patient was admitted to the hospital.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-317(3): (3)(b); (4); (3)(b)(i); (3)(b)(i)

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-317(3)(b)(ii): (3)(b)(i); (3)(b)(i) The department:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(1): 78B-4-512 "Agritourism" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(2): 78B-4-512 "Agritourism activity" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(3): "Agritourism food establishment" means a non-commercial kitchen facility where food is handled, stored, or prepared to be offered for sale on a farm in connection with an agritourism activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(4): "Agritourism food establishment permit" means a permit issued by a local health department to the operator for the purpose of operating an agritourism food establishment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(5): "Back country food service establishment" means a federal or state licensed back country guiding or outfitting business that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(5)(a): provides food services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(5)(b): meets department recognized federal or state food service safety regulations for food handlers.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(6): "Body art facility" means a facility where an individual practices or instructs:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(6)(a): body piercing;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(6)(b): branding;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(6)(c): permanent cosmetics;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(6)(d): scarification; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(6)(e): tattooing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(7)(a): "Body piercing" means any method of piercing the skin or mucosa to place jewelry through the skin or mucosa.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(7)(b): "Body piercing" does not include ear piercing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(8): "Branding" means the process in which a mark is burned, with or without heated metal, into human tissue with the intention of leaving a permanent mark.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(9): 26B-7-412 "Certified food safety manager" means a manager of a food service establishment who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(9)(a): passes successfully a department-approved examination;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(9)(b): successfully completes, every three years, renewal requirements established by department rule consistent with original certification requirements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(9)(c): 26B-7-412 submits to the appropriate local health department the documentation required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(10): "Ear piercing" means the puncturing of the lobe of the ear with piercing equipment to insert stud-and-clasp jewelry according to the directions provided by the piercing equipment's manufacturer.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(11): "Farm" means a working farm, ranch, or other commercial agricultural, aquacultural, horticultural, or forestry operation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(12): "Food" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(12)(a): a raw, cooked, or processed edible substance, ice, nonalcoholic beverage, or ingredient used or intended for use or for sale, in whole or in part, for human consumption; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(12)(b): chewing gum.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(13): 26B-7-410 "Food service establishment" means any place or area within a business or organization where potentially hazardous foods, as defined by the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(14): "Microblading" means a procedure where a hand tool with a blade formed of tiny needles implants permanent or semi-permanent pigment, resembling hair, into the skin of the eyebrow area with fine and short strokes.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(15): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(15)(a): "Microenterprise home kitchen" means a non-commercial kitchen facility located in a private home and operated by a resident of the home where ready-to-eat food is handled, stored, prepared, or offered for sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(15)(b): "Microenterprise home kitchen" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(15)(b)(i): a catering operation;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(15)(b)(ii): a cottage food operation;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(15)(b)(iii): a food truck;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(15)(b)(iv): an agritourism food establishment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(15)(b)(v): a bed and breakfast; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(15)(b)(vi): a residence-based group care facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(16): "Microenterprise home kitchen permit" means a permit issued by a local health department to the operator for the purpose of operating a microenterprise home kitchen.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(17): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(17)(a): "Permanent cosmetics" means a permanent or semi-permanent tattoo:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(17)(a)(i): to the eyebrows, eyelids, lips, or other parts of the body for beauty marks, hair imitation, lash enhancement, or areola repigmentation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(17)(a)(ii): performed by an individual not licensed under Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act, or Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(18): "Ready-to-eat" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(18)(a): raw animal food that is cooked;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(18)(b): raw fruits and vegetables that are washed;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(18)(e): a bakery item for which further cooking is not required for food safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(19): "Scarification" means the process in which a mark is cut into human skin tissue with the intent of leaving a permanent mark.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-401(20): "Time or temperature control food" means food that requires time or temperature controls for safety to limit pathogenic microorganism growth or toxin formation.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department shall establish and enforce, or provide for the enforcement of minimum rules of sanitation necessary to protect the public health, including rules necessary for the design, construction, operation, maintenance, or expansion of:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-402(1): a restaurant or a place where food or drink is handled, sold, or served to the public;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-402(2): a public swimming pool;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-402(3): a public bath, including a sauna, spa, or massage facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-402(4): a public bathing beach;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-402(5): a public or private school;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-402(6): a recreational resort, camp, or other vehicle park;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-402(7): an amusement park or other center or place used for public gatherings;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-402(8): a mobile home park and highway rest stop;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-402(9): a construction or labor camp;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-402(10): a jail, prison, or other place of incarceration or confinement;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-402(11): a hotel or motel;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-402(12): a lodging house or boarding house;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-402(13): a service station;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-402(14): 58-11a-304 a barber shop or beauty shop, including a facility in which one or more individuals are engaged in:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-402(14)(a): any of the practices licensed under Title 58, Chapter 11a, Cosmetology and Associated Professions Licensing Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-402(14)(b): 58-11a-304 styling hair in accordance with the exemption from licensure described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-402(15): an office of a physician, physician assistant, or dentist;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-405 Rules for controlling vector-borne diseases and pests.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-405(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-405(1)(a): "Pest" means a noxious, destructive, or troublesome organism whether plant or animal, when found in and around places of human occupancy, habitation, or use which threatens the public health or well-being of the people within the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-405(1)(b): "Vector" means any organism, such as insects or rodents, that transmits a pathogen that can affect public health.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-405(2): The department shall adopt rules to provide for the protection of the public health by controlling or preventing the spread of vector-borne diseases and infections and to control or reduce pests by the elimination of insanitary conditions which may include but not be limited to breeding areas, shelter, harborage or sources of food associated with such diseases or pests.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-408 Procurement and use of a blood product is a service and not a sale -- Blood donation by a minor.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-408(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-408(1)(a): "Blood" means human blood.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-408(1)(b): "Blood product" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-408(1)(b)(i): whole blood;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-408(1)(b)(ii): blood plasma;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-408(1)(b)(iii): a blood derivative;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-408(1)(b)(iv): blood platelets; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-408(1)(b)(v): blood clotting agents.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-408(2): The following are considered to be the rendition of a service by each participant and are not considered to be a sale:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-408(2)(a): the procurement, processing, distribution, or use of a blood product for the purpose of injecting or transfusing the blood product into the human body; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-408(2)(b): the process of injecting or transfusing a blood product.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-408(3): A minor who is at least 16 years old may donate blood to a voluntary, noncompensatory blood donation program if a parent or legal guardian of the minor consents to the donation.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-412 Certified food safety manager.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-412(1): Before a person may manage a food service establishment as a certified food safety manager, that person shall submit documentation in the format prescribed by the department to the appropriate local health department indicating a passing score on a department-approved examination.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-412(2): To continue to manage a food service establishment, a certified food safety manager shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-412(2)(a): successfully complete, every three years, renewal requirements established by department rule which are consistent with original certification requirements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-412(2)(b): submit documentation in the format prescribed by the department within 30 days of the completion of renewal requirements to the appropriate local health department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-412(3): (1); (2) A local health department may deny, revoke, or suspend the authority of a certified food safety manager to manage a food service establishment or require the completion of additional food safety training courses for any one of the following reasons:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-412(3)(a): (1); (2) submitting information required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-412(3)(b): repeated violations of department or local health department food safety rules; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-412(3)(c): operating a food service establishment in a way that causes or creates a health hazard or otherwise threatens the public health, safety, or welfare.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-412(4): (3); 26B-7-410(4) A determination of a local health department made pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-412(5): No person may use the title "certified food safety manager," or any other similar title, unless the person has satisfied the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-412(6): (1); (2); (1); (2); (1); (2) A local health department:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-412(6)(c): (1); (2) shall allow an individual to submit the documentation described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-412(7): Certified food safety managers shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-412(7)(a): establish and monitor compliance with practices and procedures in the food service establishments where they are employed to maintain compliance with department and local health department food safety rules; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-412(7)(b): perform such other duties that may be necessary to ensure food safety in the food service establishments where they are employed.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-412(8): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413 Requirements for food handlers -- Training program and testing requirements for permit -- Rulemaking -- Exceptions.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(1)(a): "Approved food handler training program" means a training program described by this section and approved by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(1)(b): "Food handler" means a person who works with unpackaged food, food equipment or utensils, or food-contact surfaces for a food service establishment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(1)(c): "Food handler permit" means a permit issued by a local health department to allow a person to work as a food handler.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(1)(d): "Instructor" means an individual who is qualified to instruct an approved food handler program on behalf of a provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(1)(e): "Provider" means a person or entity that provides an approved food handler training program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(2): A person may not work as a food handler for a food service establishment unless the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(2)(a): successfully completes an approved food handler training program within 14 days after the day on which the person begins employment that includes food handler services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(2)(b): obtains a food handler permit within 30 days after the day on which the person begins employment that includes food handler services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(3): (11); (3); (11) An approved food handler training program shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(3)(a): at least 75 minutes of training time;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(3)(b): (11) an exam, which requires a passing score of 75% and, except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(3)(b)(i): 40 multiple-choice questions developed by the department, in consultation with local health departments; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(3)(b)(ii): four content sections designated by rule of the department with 10 randomly selected questions for each content section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(3)(c): (3); (11) upon completion, the awarding of a certificate of completion that is valid with any local health department in the state for 30 days after the day on which the certificate is issued:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(3)(c)(i): (3); (11) to a student who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(3)(c)(i)(A): completes the training; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(3)(c)(i)(B): (3); (11) passes the exam described in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(3)(c)(ii): which certificate of completion:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(3)(c)(ii)(A): includes student identifying information determined by department rule; and

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(5)(b): within 30 days of initial employment with a food service establishment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(5)(c): within seven days of the expiration of an existing food handler permit.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(6):

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(12)(c)(ix): if the approved food handler training program provider learns that a certificate of completion does not accurately reflect the identity of the individual who took the online course or certification exam, an approved food handler training program provider invalidates the certificate of completion.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(13): An instructor is not required to satisfy any additional training requirements if the instructor:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(13)(a): is an educator in a public or private school; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(13)(b): teaches a food program that includes food safety in a public or private school in which the instructor is an educator.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(14): (2); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; (14)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(14)(a): (2) This section does not apply to an individual who handles food:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(14)(a)(i): at an event sponsored by a charitable organization where the organization provides food to a disadvantaged group free of charge; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-413(14)(a)(ii): (2) in compliance with rules established by the department under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-414 Impoundment of adulterated food products authorized.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department and local health departments may impound any food products found in places where food or drink is handled, sold, or served to the public that is intended for but found to be adulterated and unfit for human consumption; and, upon five days' notice and reasonable opportunity for a hearing to the interested parties, to condemn and destroy the same if deemed necessary for the protection of the public health.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415 Agritourism food establishment permits --  Permit requirements -- Inspections.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(1): As used in this section, "operator" means a person who owns, manages, or controls, or who has the duty to manage or control, the farm.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(2)(a): A farm may not operate an agritourism food establishment unless the farm obtains a permit from the local health department that has jurisdiction over the area in which the farm is located.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(3)(b): Nothing in this section prevents a local health department from revoking an agritourism food establishment permit issued by the local health department if the operation of the agritourism food establishment violates the terms of the permit or the requirements of this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(4)(b): (4)(a) meat not described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(4)(c): a kitchen facility used to prepare food for the agritourism food establishment meets the requirements established by the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(4)(d): the farm operates the agritourism food establishment for no more than 14 consecutive days at a time; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(4)(e): the farm complies with the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(5): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The department shall, in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(6)(c): document the reason for any inspection after the permitting inspection, keep a copy of that documentation on file with the agritourism food establishment's permit, and provide a copy of that documentation to the operator.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(7): An agritourism food establishment shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(7)(a): take steps to avoid any potential contamination to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(7)(a)(i): food;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(7)(a)(ii): equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(7)(a)(iii): utensils; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(7)(a)(iv): unwrapped single-service and single-use articles; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(7)(b): prevent an individual from entering the food preparation area while food is being prepared if the individual is known to be suffering from:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(7)(b)(i): symptoms associated with acute gastrointestinal illness; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(7)(b)(ii): a communicable disease that is transmissible through food.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8): (5); 26B-7-413 When making the rules described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(a): hand washing facilities, except to require that a hand washing station supplied with warm water, soap, and disposable hand towels is conveniently located;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(b): kitchen sinks, kitchen sink compartments, and dish sanitation, except to require that the kitchen sink has hot and cold water, a sanitizing agent, is fully operational, and that dishes are sanitized between each use;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(c): the individuals allowed access to the food preparation areas, food storage, and washing areas, except during food preparation;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(d): display guards, covers, or containers for display foods, except to require that any food on display that is not protected from the direct line of a consumer's mouth by an effective means is not served or sold to any subsequent consumer;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(e): outdoor display and sale of food, except to require that food is maintained at proper holding temperatures;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(f): reuse by an individual of drinking cups and tableware for multiple portions;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(g): utensils and equipment, except to require that utensils and equipment used in the home kitchen:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(g)(i): retain their characteristic qualities under normal use conditions;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(g)(ii): are properly sanitized after use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(g)(iii): are maintained in a sanitary manner between uses;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(h): food contact surfaces, except to require that food contact surfaces are smooth, easily cleanable, in good repair, and properly sanitized between tasks;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(i): non-food contact surfaces, if those surfaces are made of materials ordinarily used in residential settings, except to require that those surfaces are kept clean from the accumulation of residue and debris;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(j): clean-in-place equipment, except to require that the equipment is cleaned and sanitized between uses;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(k): ventilation, except to require that gases, odors, steam, heat, grease, vapors, and smoke are able to escape the kitchen;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(l): fixed temperature measuring devices or product mimicking sensors for the holding equipment for time or temperature controlled food, except to require non-fixed temperature measuring devices for hot and cold holding of food during storage, serving, and cooling;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(m): fixed floor-mounted and table-mounted equipment except to require that floor-mounted and table-mounted equipment be in good repair and sanitized between uses;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(n): dedicated laundry facilities, except to require that linens used for the agritourism food establishment are stored and laundered separately from household laundry and that soiled laundry is stored to prevent contamination of food and equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(o): water, plumbing, drainage, and waste, except to require that sinks be supplied with hot water;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(p): the number of and path of access to toilet facilities, except to require that toilet facilities are equipped with proper handwashing stations;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(q): lighting, except to require that food preparation areas are well lit by natural or artificial light whenever food is being prepared;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(r): designated dressing areas and storage facilities, except to require that items not ordinarily found in a home kitchen are placed or stored away from food preparation areas, that dressing takes place outside of the kitchen facility, and that food items are stored in a manner that does not allow for contamination;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(s): the presence and handling of animals, except to require that all animals are kept outside of food preparation and service areas during food service and food preparation;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(t): food storage, floor, wall, ceiling, and toilet surfaces, except to require that surfaces are smooth, of durable construction, easily cleanable, and kept clean and free of debris;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(u): kitchen facilities open to living areas, except to require that food is only prepared, handled, or stored in kitchen and food storage areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(v): submission of plans and specifications before construction or remodel of a kitchen facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(w): the number and type of time or temperature controlled food offered for sale;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(x): approved food sources, except those required by 9 C.F.R. Sec. 303.1;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(y): the use of an open air barbeque, grill, or outdoor wood-burning oven; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-415(8)(z): 26B-7-413 food safety certification, except any individual who is involved in the preparation, storage, or service of food in the agritourism food establishment shall hold a food handler permit as defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-501 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-506 Regulation of tobacco retailers.
----------------------------------------------------------------
The regulation of a tobacco retailer is an exercise of the police powers of the state, and through delegation, to other governmental entities.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-507 Permitting requirement.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-507(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-507(1)(a): A tobacco retailer shall hold a valid tobacco retail permit issued in accordance with this part by the local health department with jurisdiction over the physical location where the tobacco retailer operates.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-507(1)(b): A tobacco retailer without a valid permit may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-507(1)(b)(i): place a tobacco product, an electronic cigarette product, or a nicotine product in public view;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-507(1)(b)(ii): display any advertisement related to a tobacco product, an electronic cigarette product, or a nicotine product that promotes the sale, distribution, or use of those products; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-507(1)(b)(iii): sell, offer for sale, or offer to exchange for any form of consideration, tobacco, a tobacco product, an electronic cigarette product, or a nicotine product.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-507(2): A local health department may issue a permit under this part for a tobacco retailer in the classification of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-507(2)(a): a general tobacco retailer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-507(2)(b): a retail tobacco specialty business.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-507(3): A permit under this part is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-507(3)(a): valid only for one physical location, including a vending machine;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-507(3)(b): valid only at one fixed business address; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-507(3)(c): if multiple tobacco retailers are at the same address, separately required for each tobacco retailer.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-509 Permit term and fees.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-509(1):

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-509(1)(b): The term of a permit issued to a general tobacco retailer is two years.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-509(2): (2)(a); 26B-7-506; 26B-7-521; (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-509(2)(a): A local health department may not issue a permit until the applicant has paid a permit fee to the local health department of:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-509(2)(a)(ii): $20 for a permit renewal; or
