Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-522 Tobacco and nicotine cessation services for minors.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-522(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-522(1)(a): "Minor" means an individual who is younger than 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-522(1)(b): "Tobacco and nicotine cessation services" means a program that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-522(1)(b)(i): is specifically designed for minors who use tobacco products, electronic cigarette products, or nicotine products;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-522(1)(b)(ii): is operated by the department, a local health department, or a contractor that is approved by the department or a local health department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-522(1)(b)(iii): provides general information about the services offered by the department, the local health department, or a contractor that is approved by the department or the local health department before the minor's registration and participation in the program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-522(1)(b)(iv): provides the minor with access to any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-522(1)(b)(iv)(A): assessment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-522(1)(b)(iv)(B): web-based resources; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-522(1)(b)(iv)(C): coaching through technology-based communication tools; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-522(1)(b)(v): does not provide:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-522(1)(b)(v)(A): any form of nicotine replacement therapy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-522(1)(b)(v)(B): any other service not described in Subsection (1)(b)(iii) or (iv).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-522(2): Consent to tobacco and nicotine cessation services executed by a minor who is or professes to be afflicted with nicotine dependence shall have the same legal effect upon the minor and the same legal obligations with regard to the giving of consent as consent given by an individual of full legal age and capacity.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-522(3): A person providing tobacco and nicotine cessation services shall actively encourage a minor to inform the minor's parent or guardian for support.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-7-522(4): 53E-9-203 Nothing in this section authorizes a violation of Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(3): "Certified nurse midwife" means an individual who:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(3)(b): has completed an education program regarding the completion of a certificate of death developed by the department by rule made in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(4)(b): has custody of a dead body.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(5): "Dead body" means a human body or parts of a human body from the condition of which it reasonably may be concluded that death occurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(6): "Decedent" means the same as a dead body.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(7): 76-7-301 "Dead fetus" means a product of human conception, other than those circumstances described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(7)(a): of 20 weeks' gestation or more, calculated from the date the last normal menstrual period began to the date of delivery; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(7)(b): that was not born alive.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(8): "Declarant father" means a male who claims to be the genetic father of a child, and, along with the biological mother, signs a voluntary declaration of paternity to establish the child's paternity.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(9): 58-9-602 "Dispositioner" means:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(19): "Nurse practitioner" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(19)(a): is licensed to practice as an advanced practice registered nurse under Title 58, Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(19)(b): has completed an education program regarding the completion of a certificate of death developed by the department by administrative rule made in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(20): "Office" means the Office of Vital Records and Statistics within the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(21): "Physician" means a person licensed to practice as a physician or osteopath in this state under Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act, or Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(22): "Physician assistant" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(22)(a): is licensed to practice as a physician assistant under Title 58, Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(22)(b): has completed an education program regarding the completion of a certificate of death developed by the department by administrative rule made in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(23): 78B-15-102 "Presumed father" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(24): "Registration" or "register" means acceptance by the local or state registrar of a certificate and incorporation of the certificate into the permanent records of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(25): 26B-8-102 "State registrar" means the state registrar of vital records appointed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(26): "Vital records" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(26)(a): registered certificates or reports of birth, death, fetal death, marriage, divorce, dissolution of marriage, or annulment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(26)(b): amendments to any of the registered certificates or reports described in Subsection (26)(a);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(26)(c): an adoption document; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(26)(d): other similar documents.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-101(27): "Vital statistics" means the data derived from registered certificates and reports of birth, death, fetal death, induced termination of pregnancy, marriage, divorce, dissolution of marriage, or annulment.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103 Content and form of certificates and reports.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(1)(a): "Additional information" means information that is beyond the information necessary to comply with federal standards or state law for registering a birth.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(1)(b): "Diacritical mark" means a mark on a letter from the ISO basic Latin alphabet used to indicate a special pronunciation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(1)(c): "Diacritical mark" includes accents, tildes, graves, umlauts, and cedillas.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(2): Except as provided in Subsection (8), to promote and maintain nationwide uniformity in the vital records system, the forms of certificates, certification, reports, and other documents and records required by this part or the rules implementing this part shall include as a minimum the items recommended by the federal agency responsible for national vital statistics, subject to approval, additions, and modifications by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(3): Certificates, certifications, forms, reports, other documents and records, and the form of communications between persons required by this part shall be prepared in the format prescribed by department rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(4): All vital records shall include the date of filing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(5): Certificates, certifications, forms, reports, other documents and records, and communications between persons required by this part may be signed, filed, verified, registered, and stored by photographic, electronic, or other means as prescribed by department rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(6)(a): An individual may use a diacritical mark in an application for a vital record.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(6)(b): The office shall record a diacritical mark on a vital record as indicated on the application for the vital record.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(7): The absence of a diacritical mark on a vital record does not render the document invalid or affect any constructive notice imparted by proper recordation of the document.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(8)(a): The state:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(8)(a)(i): may collect the Social Security number of a deceased individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(8)(a)(ii): may not include the Social Security number of an individual on a certificate of death.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(8)(b): For registering a birth, the department may not require an individual to provide additional information.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(8)(c): The department may request additional information if the department provides a written statement that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(8)(c)(i): discloses that providing the additional information is voluntary;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(8)(c)(ii): discloses how the additional information will be used and the duration of use;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(8)(c)(iii): describes how the department prevents the additional information from being used in a manner different from the disclosure given under Subsection (8)(c)(ii); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(8)(c)(iv): includes a notice that the individual is consenting to the department's use of the additional information by providing the additional information.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(8)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(8)(d)(i): Beginning July 1, 2022, an individual may submit a written request to the department to de-identify the individual's additional information contained in the department's databases.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(8)(d)(ii): Upon receiving the written request, the department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(8)(d)(ii)(A): de-identify the additional information; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(8)(d)(ii)(B): for additional information that is inherently identifying, delete the inherently identifying additional information.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-103(8)(e): The department shall de-identify or delete additional information contained in the department's databases before the additional information is held by the department for longer than six years.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104 Birth registrations -- Execution and registration requirements.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(1): 26B-2-201; 26B-2-201 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(1)(a): 26B-2-201; 26B-2-201 "Birthing facility" means a:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(1)(a)(i): 26B-2-201 general acute hospital as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(1)(a)(ii): 26B-2-201 birthing center as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(1)(b): "Designated administrator" means an individual who has been designated by a birthing facility to submit a birth registration on behalf of the birthing facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(2)(a): The office shall register a birth if a birth registration is completed and filed in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(2)(b): Once a birth is registered, the office shall provide a birth certificate upon request in accordance with all state laws.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(3)(a): For each live birth that occurs in a birthing facility, the designated administrator, attending physician, or nurse midwife shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(3)(a)(i): obtain and enter the information required under this part in the electronic birth registration system no later than 10 days from the day on which the birth occurred;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(3)(a)(ii): provide the parent the opportunity to review the information to ensure accuracy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(3)(a)(iii): submit the birth registration.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(3)(b)(i): The date, time, place of birth, and required medical information shall be certified by the designated administrator.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(3)(b)(ii): The designated administrator shall enter the attending physician's, physician assistant's, or nurse midwife's name and transmit the birth registration to the local registrar for each birth that occurs in a birth facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(3)(b)(iii): The information contained in the birth registration about the parents shall be provided and certified by the mother or father or, in their incapacity or absence, by a person with knowledge of the facts.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(4)(a): For a live birth that occurs outside a birthing facility, the birth registration shall be completed and filed by the physician, physician assistant, nurse, nurse practitioner, certified nurse midwife, or other person primarily responsible for providing assistance to the mother at the birth no later than 10 days from the day on which the birth occurred. If the birth occurred without assistance from an individual described in Subsection (4)(a)(i), the presumed or declarant father or the mother of the child shall complete and file the birth registration.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(4)(b): The birth registration shall be completed as fully as possible and shall include the date, time, and place of birth, and the mother's name.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(5): 78B-15-302
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(5)(a): 78B-15-302 For each live birth to an unmarried mother that occurs in a birthing facility, the designated administrator shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(5)(a)(i): provide the birth mother and declarant father, if present, with:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(5)(a)(i)(A): a voluntary declaration of paternity form published by the state registrar;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(5)(a)(i)(B): oral and written notice to the birth mother and declarant father of the alternatives to, the legal consequences of, and the rights and responsibilities that arise from signing the declaration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(5)(a)(i)(C): the opportunity to sign the declaration;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(5)(a)(ii): 78B-15-302 witness the signature of a birth mother or declarant father in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(5)(a)(iii): enter the declarant father's information on the original birth certificate, but only if the mother and declarant father have signed a voluntary declaration of paternity or a court or administrative agency has issued an adjudication of paternity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(5)(a)(iv): file the completed declaration with the original birth certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(5)(b): If there is a presumed father, the voluntary declaration will only be valid if the presumed father also signs the voluntary declaration.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(5)(c): The state registrar shall file the information provided on the voluntary declaration of paternity form with the original birth certificate and may provide certified copies of the declaration of paternity as otherwise provided under Title 78B, Chapter 15, Utah Uniform Parentage Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(6)(a): The state registrar shall publish a form for the voluntary declaration of paternity, a description of the process for filing a voluntary declaration of paternity, and of the rights and responsibilities established or effected by that filing, in accordance with Title 78B, Chapter 15, Utah Uniform Parentage Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(6)(b): Information regarding the form and services related to voluntary paternity establishment shall be made available to birthing facilities and to any other entity or individual upon request.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(7): The name of a declarant father may only be included on the birth certificate of a child of unmarried parents if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(7)(a): the mother and declarant father have signed a voluntary declaration of paternity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(7)(b): a court or administrative agency has issued an adjudication of paternity.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(8): 26B-9-104 Voluntary declarations of paternity, adjudications of paternity by judicial or administrative agencies, and voluntary rescissions of paternity shall be filed with and maintained by the state registrar for the purpose of comparing information with the state case registry maintained by the Office of Recovery Services pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(9): The department may notify the Division of Professional Licensing that an individual who is required to complete a birth registration under Subsection (4)(a)(i) has failed to register a birth if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(9)(a): the department has notified the individual that the individual is required by state law to complete the birth registration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-104(9)(b): the individual is a physician, physician assistant, nurse, nurse practitioner, or certified nurse midwife.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-105 Requirement to obtain parents' social security numbers.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-105(1): 26B-8-104; 26B-8-104 For each live birth that occurs in this state, the administrator of the birthing facility, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-105(2): (1); (1) Each parent shall furnish his or her social security number to the person authorized to obtain the numbers under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-105(3): The state registrar shall, as soon as practicable, supply those social security numbers to the Office of Recovery Services within the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-105(4): The social security numbers obtained under this section may not be recorded on the child's birth certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-105(5): The state may not use any social security number obtained under this section for any reason other than enforcement of child support orders in accordance with the federal Family Support Act of 1988, Pub. L. No. 100-485.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-106 Foundling certificates.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-106(1): A foundling certificate shall be filed for each infant of unknown parentage found in the state.  The certificate shall be prepared and filed with the local registrar of the district in which the infant was found by the person assuming custody.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-106(2): The certificate shall be filed within 10 days after the infant is found and is acceptable for all purposes in lieu of a certificate of birth.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-107 Correction of errors or omissions in vital records -- Conflicting birth and foundling certificates -- Rulemaking.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-107(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act In accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-107(1)(a): governing applications to correct alleged errors or omissions on any vital record;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-107(1)(b): establishing procedures to resolve conflicting birth and foundling certificates;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-107(1)(c): allowing for the correction and reissuance of a vital record that was originally created omitting a diacritical mark; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-107(1)(d): notwithstanding any other provision of law, allowing for the change of a child's name on the child's birth certificate within one year from the day the child is born.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-107(2): (1)(a); (2)(b)(i)(B) For a birth certificate, the department may correct an error or omission under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-107(2)(a): the error or omission is a result of a scrivener's error or a data entry error; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-107(2)(b): (2)(b)(i)(B) the department receives:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-107(2)(b)(i): (2)(b)(i)(B)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-107(2)(b)(i)(A): an affidavit from the applicant attesting that there is an error on the birth certificate;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-107(2)(b)(i)(B): supporting documentation from the health care facility or attending health care provider; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-107(2)(b)(i)(C): (2)(b)(i)(B) an affidavit from the health care facility or health care provider described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-107(2)(b)(ii): documentation deemed sufficient by the state registrar to establish the facts of the error or omission.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-107(3): The department may amend a birth certificate's sex designation for an intersex individual at the request of the individual or the guardian of the individual if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-107(3)(a): the sex designation indicating the biological sex at birth of the individual was misidentified on the original certificate due to the individual's condition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-107(3)(b): the department receives:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-107(3)(b)(i): a correction affidavit attesting the individual is intersex;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-107(3)(b)(ii): chromosomal, molecular, karyotypic, DNA, or genetic testing results that confirm the individual is intersex; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-107(3)(b)(iii): an affidavit from the health care facility, health care professional, or laboratory testing facility that conducted the test or analyzed the test results, attesting to the test results and accuracy.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-108 Birth registration -- Delayed registration.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-108(1): 26B-8-104 When a birth registration for an individual born in this state has not been filed in accordance with the time provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-108(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-108(2)(a): The registrar shall mark a certificate of birth as "delayed" and show the date of registration if the certificate is registered one year or more after the date of birth.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-108(2)(b): The registrar shall abstract a summary statement of the evidence submitted in support of delayed registration onto the certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-108(3): When the minimum evidence required for delayed registration is not submitted or when the state registrar has reasonable cause to question the validity or adequacy of the evidence supporting the application, and the deficiencies are not corrected, the state registrar:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-108(3)(a): may not register the certificate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-108(3)(b): shall provide the applicant with a written statement indicating the reasons for denial of registration.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-108(4): The state registrar has no duty to take further action regarding an application which is not actively pursued.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-109 Birth certificates -- Petition for issuance of delayed certificate -- Court procedure.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-109(1): 26B-8-108
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-109(1)(a): 26B-8-108 If registration of a certificate of birth under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-109(1)(b): The petition shall request an order establishing a record of the date and place of the birth and the parentage of the person whose birth is to be registered.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-109(2): The petition shall be on a form furnished by the state registrar and shall allege:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-109(2)(a): the person for whom registration of a delayed certificate is sought was born in this state and is still living;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-109(2)(b): no registered certificate of birth of the person can be found in the state office of vital statistics or the office of any local registrar;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-109(2)(c): diligent efforts by the petitioner have failed to obtain the evidence required by  department rule; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-109(2)(d): the state registrar has denied the petitioner's request to register a delayed certificate of birth.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-109(3): The petition shall be accompanied by a written statement of the state registrar indicating the reasons for denial of registration and all documentary evidence which was submitted in support of registration.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-109(4): The court shall fix a time and place for hearing the petition and shall give the state registrar 15 days' notice of the hearing.  The state registrar or his authorized representative may appear and testify at the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-109(5): 26B-8-108; (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-109(5)(a): 26B-8-108 If the court finds the person for whom registration of a certificate of birth is sought under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-109(5)(b): The order shall include the birth data to be registered, a description of the evidence presented, and the date of the court's action.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-109(5)(c): The clerk of the court shall forward each order to the state registrar not later than the  tenth day of the calendar month following the month in which the order was entered.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-110 Supplementary certificate of birth.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-110(1): An individual born in this state may request the state registrar to register a supplementary birth certificate for the individual if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-110(1)(a): the individual is legally recognized as a child of the individual's natural parents when the individual's natural parents are subsequently married;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-110(1)(b): the individual's parentage has been determined by a state court of the United States or a Canadian provincial court with jurisdiction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-110(1)(c): the individual has been legally adopted, as a child or as an adult, under the law of this state, any other state, or any province of Canada.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-110(2): (1) The application for registration of a supplementary birth certificate may be made by:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-110(2)(a): (1) the individual requesting registration under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-110(2)(b): a legal representative; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-110(2)(c): any agency authorized to receive children for placement or adoption under the laws of this or any other state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-110(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-110(3)(a): The state registrar shall require that an applicant submit identification and proof according to department rules.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-110(3)(b): In the case of an adopted individual, that proof may be established by order of the court in which the adoption proceedings were held.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-110(4): 78B-6-141; 78B-6-144
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-110(4)(a): After the supplementary birth certificate is registered, any information disclosed from the record shall be from the supplementary birth certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-110(4)(b): 78B-6-141; 78B-6-144 Access to the original birth certificate and to the evidence submitted in support of the supplementary birth certificate are not open to inspection except upon the order of a Utah district court or as described in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111 Birth certificate name or sex designation change -- Registration of court order and amendment of birth certificate.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(1): An individual may obtain a court order in accordance with Title 42, Names, to change the name on the individual's birth certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(2)(a): A court may grant a petition ordering a sex designation change on a birth certificate if the court determines by clear and convincing evidence that the individual seeking the sex designation change:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(2)(a)(i): is not involved in any kind of lawsuit;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(2)(a)(ii): is not on probation or parole;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(2)(a)(iii): is not seeking the amendment:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(2)(a)(iii)(A): to commit a crime;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(2)(a)(iii)(B): to interfere with the rights of others;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(2)(a)(iii)(C): to avoid creditors;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(2)(a)(iii)(D): to influence the sentence, fine, or conditions of imprisonment in a criminal case;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(2)(a)(iii)(E): to commit fraud on the public; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(2)(a)(iii)(F): for any other fraudulent purpose;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(2)(a)(iv): has transitioned from the sex designation of the biological sex at birth to the sex sought in the petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(2)(a)(v): has outwardly expressed as the sex sought in the petition in a consistent and uniform manner for at least six months; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(2)(a)(vi): suffers from clinically significant distress or impairment due to the current sex designation on the birth certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(2)(b): The court shall consider the following when making the determination described in Subsection (2)(a)(iv):
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(2)(b)(i): evidence of medical history, care, or treatment related to sex transitioning; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(2)(b)(ii): evidence that the sex sought in the petition is sincerely held and part of the individual's core identity.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(2)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(2)(c)(i): An individual petitioning for a sex designation change under this section shall indicate on the petition whether the individual is registered with the state's Sex and Kidnap Offender Registry.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(2)(c)(ii): Based on the disclosure described in Subsection (2)(c)(i), the court may request additional information from an individual who is registered with the state's Sex and Kidnap Offender Registry to determine whether to grant a petition under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(3): 78A-2-703; 78A-2-703; 78A-2-302
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(3)(a): 78A-2-703; 78A-2-703; 78A-2-302
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(3)(a)(i): 78A-2-703 When determining whether to grant a sex designation change for a child who is at least 15 years and six months old, unless the child is emancipated, the court shall appoint, notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(3)(a)(ii): 78A-2-703; 78A-2-302 Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(3)(b): The guardian ad litem shall provide the court relevant evidence, whether submitted by the child or other sources of evidence, regarding the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(3)(b)(i): whether the child is capable of making decisions with long-term consequences independently of the child's parent or guardian;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(3)(b)(ii): whether the child is mature and capable of appreciating the implications of the decision to change the sex designation on the child's birth certificate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(3)(b)(iii): whether the child meets the other requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(3)(c): The guardian of a child described in Subsection (3)(a) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(3)(c)(i): give notice of the proceeding to any known parent of the child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(3)(c)(ii): provide the court with a declaration of the status of any divorce or custody matter pertaining to the child, including the case name, case number, court, judge, and current status of the case.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(3)(d): The court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(3)(d)(i): consider any objection given by a parent;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(3)(d)(ii): close the hearing on a petition for a sex designation change;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(3)(d)(iii): receive all evidence; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(3)(d)(iv): make a determination as to whether:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(3)(d)(iv)(A): all of the requirements of Subsection (2) have been met; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(3)(d)(iv)(B): the evidence supports a finding by clear and convincing evidence that the sex designation change is in the best interest of the child and would not create a risk of harm to the minor.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(4)(a): A court may not grant a petition for a sex designation change if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(4)(a)(i): the birth certificate is for a child who is younger than 15 years and six months old; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(4)(a)(ii): the child's parent or guardian with legal custody has not given permission.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(4)(b): An order granting a sex designation change under this section is not effective until the individual is at least 16 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(5): A petition for a sex designation under this section may be combined with a petition under Title 42, Names.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(6)(a): Upon the receipt of a certified order granting a birth certificate amendment, any required application, and an appropriate fee, the department shall issue:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(6)(a)(i): a birth certificate that does not indicate which fields were amended unless requested by the individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(6)(a)(ii): an amendment history of the birth certificate, including the fields of the birth certificate that have been amended and the date of the amendment.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(6)(b): The department shall retain a record of all amendments to a birth certificate, including any amendment history issued by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(7): The provisions of this section are severable.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(8): This section only applies to birth certificates issued by the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-111(9): The provisions of Title 76, Chapter 8, Part 5, Falsification in Official Matters, apply to this section when applicable.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114 Certificate of death -- Execution and registration requirements -- Information provided to lieutenant governor.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(1)(a): A certificate of death for each death that occurs in this state shall be filed with the local registrar of the district in which the death occurs, or as otherwise directed by the state registrar, within five days after death and prior to the decedent's interment, any other disposal, or removal from the registration district where the death occurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(1)(b): A certificate of death shall be registered if the certificate of death is completed and filed in accordance with this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(2)(a): If the place of death is unknown but the dead body is found in this state:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(2)(a)(i): the certificate of death shall be completed and filed in accordance with this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(2)(a)(ii): the place where the dead body is found shall be shown as the place of death.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(2)(b): If the date of death is unknown, the date shall be determined by approximation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(3)(a): When death occurs in a moving conveyance in the United States and the decedent is first removed from the conveyance in this state:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(3)(a)(i): the certificate of death shall be filed with:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(3)(a)(i)(A): the local registrar of the district where the decedent is removed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(3)(a)(i)(B): a person designated by the state registrar; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(3)(a)(ii): the place where the decedent is removed shall be considered the place of death.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(3)(b): When a death occurs on a moving conveyance outside the United States and the decedent is first removed from the conveyance in this state:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(3)(b)(i): the certificate of death shall be filed with:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(3)(b)(i)(A): the local registrar of the district where the decedent is removed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(3)(b)(i)(B): a person designated by the state registrar; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(3)(b)(ii): the certificate of death shall show the actual place of death to the extent it can be determined.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(4)(a): Subject to Subsections (4)(d) and (10), a custodial funeral service director or, if a funeral service director is not retained, a dispositioner shall sign the certificate of death.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(4)(b): The custodial funeral service director, an agent of the custodial funeral service director, or, if a funeral service director is not retained, a dispositioner shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(4)(b)(i): file the certificate of death prior to any disposition of a dead body or fetus; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(4)(b)(ii): obtain the decedent's personal data from the next of kin or the best qualified person or source available, including the decedent's social security number, if known.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(4)(c): The certificate of death may not include the decedent's social security number.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(4)(d): A dispositioner may not sign a certificate of death, unless the signature is witnessed by the state registrar or a local registrar.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(5): 26B-8-115
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(5)(a): 26B-8-115 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(5)(a)(i): the funeral service director; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(5)(a)(ii): if a funeral service director is not retained, a dispositioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(5)(b): In the absence of the health care professional or with the health care professional's approval, the certificate of death may be completed and signed by an associate physician, the chief medical officer of the institution in which death occurred, or a physician who performed an autopsy upon the decedent, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(5)(b)(i): the person has access to the medical history of the case;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(5)(b)(ii): the person views the decedent at or after death; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(5)(b)(iii): the death is not due to causes required to be investigated by the medical examiner.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(5)(c): When completing the immediate cause of death section of a certificate of death, a health care professional may indicate that the immediate cause of death is unknown if the immediate cause of death is unknown.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(5)(d): The department shall create instructions for completing a certificate of death that inform a health care professional that the heath care professional may indicate that the immediate cause of death is unknown in accordance with Subsection (5)(c).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(6): When death occurs more than 365 days after the day on which the decedent was last treated by a health care professional, the case shall be referred to the medical examiner for investigation to determine and certify the cause, date, and place of death.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(7): When inquiry is required by Part 2, Utah Medical Examiner, the medical examiner shall make an investigation and complete and sign the medical section of the certificate of death within 72 hours after taking charge of the case.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(8): If the cause of death cannot be determined within 72 hours after death:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(8)(a): the medical section of the certificate of death shall be completed as provided by department rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(8)(b): the attending health care professional or medical examiner shall give the funeral service director, or, if a funeral service director is not retained, a dispositioner, notice of the reason for the delay; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(8)(c): final disposition of the decedent may not be made until authorized by the attending health care professional or medical examiner.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(9)(a): When a death is presumed to have occurred within this state but the dead body cannot be located, a certificate of death may be prepared by the state registrar upon receipt of an order of a Utah court.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(9)(b): The order described in Subsection (9)(a) shall include a finding of fact stating the name of the decedent, the date of death, and the place of death.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(9)(c): A certificate of death prepared under Subsection (9)(a) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(9)(c)(i): show the date of registration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(9)(c)(ii): identify the court and the date of the order.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(10): It is unlawful for a dispositioner to charge for or accept any remuneration for:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(10)(a): signing a certificate of death; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(10)(b): performing any other duty of a dispositioner, as described in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(11): The state registrar shall, within five business days after the day on which the state registrar or local registrar registers a certificate of death for a Utah resident, inform the lieutenant governor of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(11)(a): the decedent's name, last known residential address, date of birth, and date of death; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(11)(b): any other information requested by the lieutenant governor to assist the county clerk in identifying the decedent for the purpose of removing the decedent from the official register of voters.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-114(12): The lieutenant governor shall, within one business day after the day on which the lieutenant governor receives the information described in Subsection (11), provide the information to the county clerks.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-115 Fetal death certificate -- Filing and registration requirements.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-115(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-115(1)(a): A fetal death certificate shall be filed for each fetal death which occurs in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-115(1)(b): The certificate shall be filed within five days after delivery with the local registrar or as otherwise directed by the state registrar.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-115(1)(c): The certificate shall be registered if it is completed and filed in accordance with this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-115(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-115(2)(a): When a dead fetus is delivered in an institution, the institution administrator or his designated representative shall prepare and file the fetal death certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-115(2)(b): The attending physician, physician assistant, or certified nurse midwife shall state in the certificate the cause of death and sign the certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-115(3): When a dead fetus is delivered outside an institution, the physician or certified nurse midwife in attendance at or immediately after delivery shall complete, sign, and file the fetal death certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-115(4): When a fetal death occurs without medical attendance at or immediately after the delivery or when inquiry is required by Part 2, Utah Medical Examiner, the medical examiner shall investigate the cause of death and prepare and file the certificate of fetal death within five days after taking charge of the case.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-115(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-115(5)(a): When a fetal death occurs in a moving conveyance and the dead fetus is first removed from the conveyance in this state or when a dead fetus is found in this state and the place of death is unknown, the death shall be registered in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-115(5)(b): The place where the dead fetus was first removed from the conveyance or found shall be considered the place of death.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-115(6): Final disposition of the dead fetus may not be made until the fetal death certificate has been registered.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-117 Delayed registration of birth resulting in stillbirth.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
When a birth resulting in stillbirth occurring in this state has not been registered within one year after the date of delivery, a certificate marked "delayed" may be filed and registered in accordance with department rule relating to evidentiary and other requirements sufficient to substantiate the alleged facts of birth resulting in stillbirth.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-118 Certificate of early term stillbirth.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-118(1): 76-7-301 As used in this section, "early term stillborn child" means a product of human conception, other than in the circumstances described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-118(1)(a): is of at least 16 weeks' gestation but less than 20 weeks' gestation, calculated from the day on which the mother's last normal menstrual period began to the day of delivery; and

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120 Certificate of death -- Duties of a custodial funeral service director, an agent of a funeral service director, or a dispositioner -- Medical certification -- Records of funeral service director or dispositioner -- Information filed with local registrar -- Unlawful signing of certificate of death.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120(1): The custodial funeral service director or, if a funeral service director is not retained, a dispositioner shall sign the certificate of death prior to any disposition of a dead body or dead fetus.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120(2): The custodial funeral service director, an agent of the custodial funeral service director, or, if a funeral service director is not retained, a dispositioner shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120(2)(a): obtain personal and statistical information regarding the decedent from the available persons best qualified to provide the information;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120(2)(b): present the certificate of death to the attending health care professional, if any, or to the medical examiner who shall certify the cause of death and other information required on the certificate of death;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120(2)(c): provide the address of the custodial funeral service director or, if a funeral service director is not retained, a dispositioner;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120(2)(d): certify the date and place of burial; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120(2)(e): file the certificate of death with the state or local registrar.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120(3): A funeral service director, dispositioner, embalmer, or other person who removes a dead body or dead fetus from the place of death or transports or is in charge of final disposal of a dead body or dead fetus, shall keep a record identifying the dead body or dead fetus, and containing information pertaining to receipt, removal, and delivery of the dead body or dead fetus as prescribed by department rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120(4): (3); (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120(4)(a): (3) Not later than the tenth day of each month, every licensed funeral service establishment shall send to the local registrar and the department a list of the information required in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120(4)(b): (4)(a) The list described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120(5): (1) Any person who intentionally signs the portion of a certificate of death that is required to be signed by a funeral service director or a dispositioner under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120(5)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120(5)(a)(i): is a funeral service director; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120(5)(a)(ii): is employed by a licensed funeral establishment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120(5)(b): is a dispositioner, if a funeral service director is not retained.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120(6): The state registrar shall post information on the state registrar's website, providing instructions to a dispositioner for complying with the requirements of law relating to the dispositioner's responsibilities for:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120(6)(a): completing and filing a certificate of death; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120(6)(b): possessing, transporting, and disposing of a dead body or dead fetus.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-120(7): The provisions of this part shall be construed to avoid interference, to the fullest extent possible, with the ceremonies, customs, rites, or beliefs of the decedent and the decedent's next of kin for disposing of a dead body or dead fetus.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-121 Certificate of death -- Registration prerequisite to interment -- Burial-transit permits -- Procedure where body donated under anatomical gift law -- Permit for disinterment.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-121(1): (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-121(1)(a): A dead body or dead fetus may not be interred or otherwise disposed of or removed from the registration district in which death or fetal death occurred or the remains are found until a certificate of death is registered.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-121(1)(b): (1)(a) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-121(2): 26B-2-201; 26B-2-201
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-121(2)(a): 26B-2-201 For deaths or fetal deaths which occur in this state, no burial-transit permit is required for final disposition of the remains if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-121(2)(a)(i): disposition occurs in the state and is performed by a funeral service director; or

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-133 Unlawful acts concerning certificates, records, and reports -- Unlawful transportation or acceptance of dead human body.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is unlawful for any person, association, or corporation and the officers of any of them:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-133(1): to willfully and knowingly make any false statement in a certificate, record, or report required to be filed with the department, or in an application for a certified copy of a vital record, or to willfully and knowingly supply false information intending that the information be used in the preparation of any  report, record, or certificate, or an amendment to any of these;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-133(2): to make, counterfeit, alter, amend, or mutilate any certificate, record, or report required to be filed under this code or a certified copy of the certificate, record, or report without lawful authority and with the intent to deceive;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-133(3): to willfully and knowingly obtain, possess, use, sell, furnish, or attempt to obtain, possess, use, sell, or furnish to another, for any purpose of deception, any certificate, record, report, or certified copy of any of them, including any that are counterfeited, altered, amended, or mutilated;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-133(4): without lawful authority, to possess any certificate, record, or report, required by the department or a copy or certified copy of the certificate, record, or report, knowing it to have been stolen or otherwise unlawfully obtained; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-133(5): to willfully and knowingly transport or accept for transportation, interment, or other disposition a dead human body without a permit required by law.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-134 Illegal use of birth certificate -- Penalties.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-134(1): It is a third degree felony for any person to willfully and knowingly:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-134(1)(a): and with the intent to deceive, obtain, possess, use, sell, furnish, or attempt to obtain, possess, use, sell, or furnish to another any certificate of birth or certified copy of a certificate of birth knowing that the certificate or certified copy was issued upon information which is false in whole or in part or which relates to the birth of another person, whether living or deceased; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-134(1)(b): furnish or process a certificate of birth or certified copy of a certificate of birth with the knowledge or intention that it be used for the purpose of deception by a person other than the person to whom the certificate of birth relates.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-134(2): 26B-8-133 The specific criminal violations and the criminal penalty under this section take precedence over any more general criminal offense as described in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(1): 26B-8-101 "Dead body" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(2)(a): "Death by violence" means death that resulted by the decedent's exposure to physical, mechanical, or chemical forces.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(2)(b): "Death by violence" includes death that appears to have been due to homicide, death that occurred during or in an attempt to commit rape, mayhem, kidnapping, robbery, burglary, housebreaking, extortion, or blackmail accompanied by threats of violence, assault with a dangerous weapon, assault with intent to commit any offense punishable by imprisonment for more than one year, arson punishable by imprisonment for more than one year, or any attempt to commit any of the foregoing offenses.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(3): "Immediate relative" means an individual's spouse, child, parent, sibling, grandparent, or grandchild.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(4): 58-31b-301 "Health care professional" means any of the following while acting in a professional capacity:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(4)(a): a physician licensed under Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act, or Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(4)(b): a physician assistant licensed under Title 58, Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(4)(c): 58-31b-301 an advance practice registered nurse licensed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(5): 26B-8-202 "Medical examiner" means the state medical examiner appointed pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(6): "Medical examiner record" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(6)(a): all information that the medical examiner obtains regarding a decedent;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(6)(b): reports that the medical examiner makes regarding a decedent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(6)(c): all administrative forms and correspondence related to a decedent's case.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(7): 26B-8-202 "Regional pathologist" means an American Board of Pathology certified pathologist licensed to practice medicine and surgery in the state, appointed by the medical examiner pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(8): "Sudden death while in apparent good health" means apparently instantaneous death without obvious natural cause, death during or following an unexplained syncope or coma, or death during an acute or unexplained rapidly fatal illness.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(9): "Sudden unexpected infant death" means the death of a child who was thought to be in good health or whose terminal illness appeared to be so mild that the possibility of a fatal outcome was not anticipated.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(10): "Suicide" means death caused by an intentional and voluntary act of an individual who understands the physical nature of the act and intends by such act to accomplish self-destruction.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(11): "Unattended death" means a death that occurs more than 365 days after the day on which a health care professional examined or treated the deceased individual for any purpose, including writing a prescription.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(12): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(12)(a): "Unavailable for postmortem investigation" means that a dead body is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(12)(a)(i): transported out of state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(12)(a)(ii): buried at sea;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(12)(a)(iii): cremated;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(12)(a)(iv): processed by alkaline hydrolysis; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(12)(a)(v): otherwise made unavailable to the medical examiner for postmortem investigation or autopsy.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(12)(b): "Unavailable for postmortem investigation" does not include embalming or burial of a dead body pursuant to the requirements of law.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-201(13): "Within the scope of the decedent's employment" means all acts reasonably necessary or incident to the performance of work, including matters of personal convenience and comfort not in conflict with specific instructions.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-202 Chief medical examiner -- Appointment -- Qualifications -- Authority.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-202(1): The executive director shall appoint a chief medical examiner who shall be licensed to practice medicine in the state and shall meet the qualifications of a forensic pathologist, certified by the American Board of Pathology.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-202(2): 26B-8-321; 26B-8-225
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-202(2)(a): The medical examiner shall serve at the will of the executive director.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-202(2)(b): 26B-8-321; 26B-8-225 The medical examiner has authority to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-202(2)(b)(i): employ medical, technical and clerical personnel as may be required to effectively administer this chapter, subject to the rules of the department and the state merit system;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-202(2)(b)(ii): conduct investigations and pathological examinations;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-202(2)(b)(iii): perform autopsies authorized in this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-202(2)(b)(iv): conduct or authorize necessary examinations on dead bodies; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-202(2)(b)(v): 26B-8-321; 26B-8-225 notwithstanding the provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-202(2)(b)(v)(A): for scientific purposes;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-202(2)(b)(v)(B): where necessary to accurately certify the cause and manner of death; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-202(2)(b)(v)(C): 26B-8-225 for tissue from an unclaimed body, subject to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-202(2)(c): In the case of an unidentified body, the medical examiner shall authorize or conduct investigations, tests and processes in order to determine its identity as well as the cause of death.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-202(3): The medical examiner may appoint regional pathologists, each of whom shall be approved by the executive director.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-203 County medical examiners.
---------------------------------------------------------
The county executive, with the advice and consent of the county legislative body and approval of the chief medical examiner, may appoint medical examiners for their respective counties.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-210(1)(a): the decedent's name;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-212 Order to exhume body -- Procedure.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-212(1): 26B-8-205 In case of any death described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-212(2): 26B-8-205
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-212(2)(a): A body may not be exhumed until notice of the order has been served upon the executor or administrator of the deceased's estate, or if no executor or administrator has been appointed, upon the nearest heir of the deceased, determined as if the deceased had died intestate.  If the nearest heir of the deceased cannot be located within the jurisdiction, then the next heir in succession within the jurisdiction may be served.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-212(2)(b): The executor, administrator, or heir shall have 24 hours to notify the issuing court of any objection to the order prior to the time the body is exhumed.  If no heirs can be located within the jurisdiction within 24 hours, the facts shall be reported to the issuing court which may order that the body be exhumed forthwith.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-212(2)(c): Notification to the executor, administrator, or heir shall specifically state the nature of the action and the fact that any objection shall be filed with the issuing court within 24 hours of the time of service.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-212(2)(d): In the event an heir files an objection, the court shall set hearing on the matter at the earliest possible time and issue an order on the matter immediately at the conclusion of the hearing.  Upon the receipt of notice of objection, the court shall immediately notify the county attorney who requested the order, so that the interest of the state may be represented at the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-212(2)(e): 26B-8-205 When there is reason to believe that death occurred in a manner described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-212(3): An order to exhume a body shall be directed to the medical examiner, commanding the medical examiner to cause the body to be exhumed, perform the required autopsy, and properly cause the body to be reburied upon completion of the examination.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-212(4): The examination shall be completed and the complete autopsy report shall be made to the district attorney or county attorney having criminal jurisdiction for any action the attorney considers appropriate.  The district attorney or county attorney shall submit the return of the order to exhume within 10 days in the manner prescribed by the issuing court.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-213 Autopsies -- When authorized.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-213(1): The medical examiner shall perform an autopsy to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-213(1)(a): aid in the discovery and prosecution of a crime;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-213(1)(b): protect an innocent person accused of a crime; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-213(1)(c): disclose hazards to public health.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-213(2): Title 34A, Chapter 2, Workers' Compensation Act The medical examiner may perform an autopsy:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-213(2)(a): Title 34A, Chapter 2, Workers' Compensation Act to aid in the administration of civil justice in life and accident insurance problems in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-213(2)(b): in other cases involving questions of civil liability.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-215 Deaths in medical centers and federal facilities.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
All death certificates of any decedent who died in a teaching medical center or a federal medical facility unattended or in the care of an unlicensed physician or other medical personnel shall be signed by the licensed supervisory physician, attending physician or licensed resident physician of the medical center or facility.
