Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217 Records of medical examiner -- Confidentiality.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(1): The medical examiner shall maintain complete, original records for the medical examiner record, which shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(1)(a): be properly indexed, giving the name, if known, or otherwise identifying every individual whose death is investigated;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(1)(b): indicate the place where the body was found;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(1)(c): indicate the date of death;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(1)(d): indicate the cause and manner of death;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(1)(e): indicate the occupation of the decedent, if available;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(1)(f): include all other relevant information concerning the death; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(1)(g): include a full report and detailed findings of the autopsy or report of the investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(2): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(2)(a): Upon written request from an individual described in Subsections (2)(a)(i) through (iv), the medical examiner shall provide a copy of the autopsy report, toxicology report, lab reports, investigative reports, documents generated by the medical examiner related to any report, and any other specifically requested portions of the medical examiner record, if any, to any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(2)(a)(i): a decedent's immediate relative;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(2)(a)(ii): a decedent's legal representative;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(2)(a)(iii): a physician or physician assistant who attended the decedent during the year before the decedent's death; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(2)(a)(iv): a county attorney, a district attorney, a criminal defense attorney, or other law enforcement official with jurisdiction, as necessary for the performance of the attorney or official's professional duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(2)(b): (2) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(2)(b)(i): a local health department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(2)(b)(ii): a local mental health authority;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(2)(b)(iii): a public health authority; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(2)(b)(iv): another state or federal governmental agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(2)(c): The medical examiner may provide a copy of a report or portion of the medical examiner's record described in Subsection (2)(a), if the report or portion of the medical examiner's record relates to an issue of public health or safety, as further defined by rule made by the department in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(3): Reports provided under Subsection (2) may not include records that the medical examiner obtains from a third party in the course of investigating the decedent's death.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(4): The medical examiner may provide a medical examiner record to a researcher who:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(4)(a): has an advanced degree;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(4)(b)(i): is affiliated with an accredited college or university, a hospital, or another system of care, including an emergency medical response or a local health agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(4)(b)(ii): is part of a research firm contracted with an accredited college or university, a hospital, or another system of care;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(4)(c): requests a medical examiner record for a research project or a quality improvement initiative that will have a public health benefit, as determined by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(4)(d): provides to the medical examiner an approval from:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(4)(d)(i): the researcher's sponsoring organization; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(4)(d)(ii): the Utah Department of Health and Human Services Institutional Review Board.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(5): Records provided under Subsection (4) may not include a third party record, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(5)(a): a court has ordered disclosure of the third party record; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(5)(b): disclosure is conducted in compliance with state and federal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(6): 26B-1-209 A person who obtains a medical examiner record under Subsection (4) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(6)(a): maintain the confidentiality of the medical examiner record by removing personally identifying information about a decedent or the decedent's family and any other information that may be used to identify a decedent before using the medical examiner record in research;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(6)(b): conduct any research within and under the supervision of the Office of the Medical Examiner, if the medical examiner record contains a third party record with personally identifiable information;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(6)(c): limit the use of a medical examiner record to the purpose for which the person requested the medical examiner record;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(6)(d): destroy a medical examiner record and the data abstracted from the medical examiner record at the conclusion of the research for which the person requested the medical examiner record;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(6)(e): 26B-1-209 reimburse the medical examiner, as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(6)(f): allow the medical examiner to review, before public release, a publication in which data from a medical examiner record is referenced or analyzed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(6)(g): provide the medical examiner access to the researcher's database containing data from a medical examiner record, until the day on which the researcher permanently destroys the medical examiner record and all data obtained from the medical examiner record.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(7): The department may make rules, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, and in consideration of applicable state and federal law, to establish permissible uses and disclosures of a medical examiner record or other record obtained under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(8): Except as provided in this chapter or ordered by a court, the medical examiner may not disclose any part of a medical examiner record.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-217(9): A person who obtains a medical examiner record under Subsection (4) is guilty of a class B misdemeanor, if the person fails to comply with the requirements of Subsections (6)(a) through (d).


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-218 Records of medical examiner -- Admissibility as evidence -- Subpoena of person who prepared record.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The records of the medical examiner or transcripts thereof certified by the medical examiner are admissible as evidence in any civil action in any court in this state except that statements by witnesses or other persons, unless taken pursuant to Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-219 Personal property of deceased -- Disposition.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-219(1): Personal property of the deceased not held as evidence shall be turned over to the legal representative of the deceased within 30 days after completion of the investigation of the death of the deceased. If no legal representative is known, the county attorney, district attorney, or the medical examiner shall, within 30 days after the investigation, turn the personal property over to the county treasurer to be handled pursuant to the escheat laws.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-219(2): An affidavit shall be filed with the county treasurer by the county attorney, district attorney, or the medical examiner within 30 days after investigation of the death of the deceased showing the money or other property belonging to the estate of the deceased person which has come into his possession and the disposition made of the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-219(3): Property required to be turned over to the legal representative of the deceased may be held longer than 30 days if, in the opinion of the county attorney, district attorney, or attorney general, the property is necessary evidence in a court proceeding. Upon conclusion of the court proceedings, the personal property shall be turned over as described in this section and in accordance with the rules of the court.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-220 Officials not liable for authorized acts.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Except as provided in this part, a criminal or civil action may not arise against the county attorney, district attorney, or his deputies, the medical examiner or his deputies, or regional pathologists for authorizing or performing autopsies authorized by this part or for any other act authorized by this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-221 Authority of county attorney or district attorney to subpoena witnesses and compel testimony -- Determination if decedent died by unlawful means.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-221(1): The district attorney or county attorney having criminal jurisdiction may subpoena witnesses and compel testimony concerning the death of any person and have such testimony reduced to writing under his direction and may employ a court reporter for that purpose at the same compensation as is allowed to reporters in the district courts.  When the testimony has been taken down by the court reporter, a transcript thereof, duly certified, shall constitute the deposition of the witness.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-221(2): Upon review of all facts and testimony taken concerning the death of a person, the district attorney or county attorney having criminal jurisdiction shall determine if the decedent died by unlawful means and shall also determine if criminal prosecution shall be instituted.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-222 Additional powers and duties of department.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department may:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-222(1): establish rules to carry out the provisions of this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-222(2): arrange for the state health laboratory to perform toxicologic analysis for public or private institutions and fix fees for the services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-222(3): cooperate and train law enforcement personnel in the techniques of criminal investigation as related to medical and pathological matters; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-222(4): pay to private parties, institutions or funeral directors the reasonable value of services performed for the medical examiner's office.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-223 Authority of examiner to provide organ or other tissue for transplant purposes.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-223(1): When requested by the licensed physician of a patient who is in need of an organ or other tissue for transplant purpose, by a legally created Utah eye bank, organ bank or medical facility, the medical examiner may provide an organ or other tissue if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-223(1)(a): a decedent who may provide a suitable organ or other tissue for the transplant is in the custody of the medical examiner;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-223(1)(b): the medical examiner is assured that the requesting party has made reasonable search for and inquiry of next of kin of the decedent and that no objection by the next of kin is known by the requesting party; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-223(1)(c): the removal of the organ or other tissue will not interfere with the investigation or autopsy or alter the post-mortem facial appearance.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-223(2): When the medical examiner has jurisdiction over a decedent who may provide a suitable organ or other tissue for transplant purposes, he may contact the appropriate eye bank, organ bank or medical facility and notify them concerning the suitability of the organ or other tissue. In such contact the medical examiner may disclose the name of the decedent so that necessary clearances can be obtained.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-223(3): No person shall be held civilly or criminally liable for any acts performed pursuant to this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-224 Autopsies -- Persons eligible to authorize.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-224(1): 34A-2-603 Autopsies may be authorized:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-224(1)(a): 34A-2-603 by the commissioner of the Labor Commission or the commissioner's designee as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-224(1)(b): by individuals by will or other written document;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-224(1)(c): upon a decedent by the next of kin in the following order and as known: surviving spouse, child, if 18 years old or older, otherwise the legal guardian of the child, parent, sibling, uncle or aunt, nephew or niece, cousin, others charged by law with the duty of burial, or friend assuming the obligation of burial;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-224(1)(d): by the county attorney, district attorney, or the district attorney's deputy, or a district judge; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-224(1)(e): by the medical examiner as provided in this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-224(2): (1)(a); (1)(d) Autopsies authorized under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-224(3): No criminal or civil action arises against a pathologist or a physician who proceeds in good faith and performs an autopsy authorized by this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-225 Burial of an unclaimed body -- Request by the school of medicine at the University of Utah -- Medical examiner may retain tissue for dog training.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-225(1): Except as described in Subsection (2) or (3), a county shall provide, at the county's expense, decent disposition of an unclaimed body found in the county.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-225(2): 53B-17-301 A county is not responsible for decent disposition of an unclaimed body found in the county if the body is requested by the dean of the school of medicine at the University of Utah under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-225(3): For an unclaimed body that is temporarily in the medical examiner's custody before disposition under Subsection (1), the medical examiner may retain tissue from the unclaimed body in order to donate the tissue to an individual who is affiliated with an established search and rescue dog organization, for the purpose of training a dog to search for human remains.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-226 Social security number in certification of death.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A certification of death shall include, if known, the social security number of the deceased person, and a copy of the certification shall be sent to the Office of Recovery Services within the department upon request.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-227 Registry of unidentified deceased persons.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-227(1): 26B-8-205 If the identity of a deceased person over which the medical examiner has jurisdiction under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-227(1)(a): assign a unique identifying number to the body;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-227(1)(b): create and maintain a file under the assigned number;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-227(1)(c): examine the body, take samples, and perform other related tasks for the purpose of deriving information that may be useful in ascertaining the identity of the deceased person;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-227(1)(d): use the identifying number in all records created by the medical examiner that pertains to the body;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-227(1)(e): record all information pertaining to the body in the file created and maintained under Subsection (1)(b);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-227(1)(f): communicate the unique identifying number to the county in which the body was found; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-227(1)(g): access information from available government sources and databases in an attempt to ascertain the identity of the deceased person.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-227(2): The medical examiner shall cooperate and share information generated and maintained under this section with a person who demonstrates:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-227(2)(a): a legitimate personal or governmental interest in determining the identity of a deceased person; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-227(2)(b): a reasonable belief that the body of that deceased person may have come into the custody of the medical examiner.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-228 Testing for suspected suicides -- Maintaining information -- Compensation to deputy medical examiners.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-228(1): In all cases where it is suspected that a death resulted from suicide, including assisted suicide, the medical examiner shall endeavor to have the following tests conducted upon samples taken from the body of the deceased:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-228(1)(a): a test that detects all of the substances included in the volatiles panel of the Bureau of Forensic Toxicology within the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-228(1)(b): a test that detects all of the substances included in the drugs of abuse panel of the Bureau of Forensic Toxicology within the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-228(1)(c): a test that detects all of the substances included in the prescription drug panel of the Bureau of Forensic Toxicology within the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-228(2): The medical examiner shall maintain information regarding the types of substances found present in the samples taken from the body of a person who is suspected to have died as a result of suicide or assisted suicide.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-228(3): (1) Within funds appropriated by the Legislature for this purpose, the medical examiner shall provide compensation, at a standard rate determined by the medical examiner, to a deputy medical examiner who collects samples for the purposes described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-232 Injury reporting requirements by health care provider -- Contents of report -- Penalties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-232(1): 26B-8-232 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-232(1)(a): "Health care provider" means any person, firm, corporation, or association which furnishes treatment or care to persons who have suffered bodily injury, and includes hospitals, clinics, podiatrists, dentists and dental hygienists, nurses, nurse practitioners, physicians and physicians' assistants, osteopathic physicians, naturopathic practitioners, chiropractors, acupuncturists, paramedics, and emergency medical technicians.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-232(1)(b): "Injury" does not include any psychological or physical condition brought about solely through the voluntary administration of prescribed controlled substances.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-232(1)(c): "Law enforcement agency" means the municipal or county law enforcement agency:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-232(1)(c)(i): having jurisdiction over the location where the injury occurred; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-232(1)(c)(ii): if the reporting health care provider is unable to identify or contact the law enforcement agency with jurisdiction over the injury, "law enforcement agency" means the agency nearest to the location of the reporting health care provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-232(1)(d): 26B-8-232 "Report to a law enforcement agency" means to report, by telephone or other spoken communication, the facts known regarding an injury subject to reporting under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-232(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-232(2)(a): Any health care provider who treats or cares for any person who suffers from any wound or other injury inflicted by the person's own act or by the act of another by means of a knife, gun, pistol, explosive, infernal device, or deadly weapon, or by violation of any criminal statute of this state, shall immediately report to a law enforcement agency the facts regarding the injury.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-232(2)(b): The report shall state the name and address of the injured person, if known, the person's whereabouts, the character and extent of the person's injuries, and the name, address, and telephone number of the person making the report.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-232(3): A health care provider may not be discharged, suspended, disciplined, or harassed for making a report pursuant to this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-232(4): A person may not incur any civil or criminal liability as a result of making any report required by this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-232(5): A health care provider who has personal knowledge that the report of a wound or injury has been made in compliance with this section is under no further obligation to make a report regarding that wound or injury under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-232(6): Any health care provider who intentionally or knowingly violates any provision of this section is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(1): "Adult" means an individual who is at least 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(2): "Agent" means an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(2)(a): authorized to make health care decisions on the principal's behalf by a power of attorney for health care; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(2)(b): expressly authorized to make an anatomical gift on the principal's behalf by any other record signed by the principal.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(3): "Anatomical gift" means a donation of all or part of a human body to take effect after the donor's death for the purpose of transplantation, therapy, research, or education.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(4): "Decedent" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(4)(a): a deceased individual whose body or part is or may be the source of an anatomical gift; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(4)(b): includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(4)(b)(i): a stillborn infant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(4)(b)(ii): subject to restrictions imposed by law other than this part, a fetus.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(5): 26B-8-310
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(5)(a): "Disinterested witness" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(5)(a)(i): a witness other than the spouse, child, parent, sibling, grandchild, grandparent, or guardian of the individual who makes, amends, revokes, or refuses to make an anatomical gift; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(5)(a)(ii): another adult who exhibited special care and concern for the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(5)(b): 26B-8-310 "Disinterested witness" does not include a person to which an anatomical gift could pass under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(6): "Document of gift" means a donor card or other record used to make an anatomical gift.  The term includes a statement or symbol on a driver license, identification card, or donor registry.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(7): "Donor" means an individual whose body or part is the subject of an anatomical gift.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(8): "Donor registry" means a database that contains records of anatomical gifts and amendments to or revocations of anatomical gifts.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(9): "Driver license" means a license or permit issued by the Driver License Division of the Department of Public Safety, to operate a vehicle, whether or not conditions are attached to the license or permit.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(10): "Eye bank" means a person that is licensed, accredited, or regulated under federal or state law to engage in the recovery, screening, testing, processing, storage, or distribution of human eyes or portions of human eyes.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(11): "Guardian":
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(11)(a): means a person appointed by a court to make decisions regarding the support, care, education, health, or welfare of an individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(11)(b): does not include a guardian ad litem.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(12): "Hospital" means a facility licensed as a hospital under the law of any state or a facility operated as a hospital by the United States, a state, or a subdivision of a state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(13): "Identification card" means an identification card issued by the Driver License Division of the Department of Public Safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(14): "Know" means to have actual knowledge.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(15): "Minor" means an individual who is under 18 years of age.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(16): "Organ procurement organization" means a person designated by the Secretary of the United States Department of Health and Human Services as an organ procurement organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(17): "Parent" means a parent whose parental rights have not been terminated.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(18): "Part" means an organ, an eye, or tissue of a human being.  The term does not include the whole body.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(19): "Person" means an individual, corporation, business trust, estate, trust, partnership, limited liability company, association, joint venture, public corporation, government or governmental subdivision, agency, or instrumentality, or any other legal or commercial entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(20): "Physician" means an individual authorized to practice medicine or osteopathy under the law of any state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(21): "Procurement organization" means an eye bank, organ procurement organization, or tissue bank.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(22): "Prospective donor":
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(22)(a): means an individual who is dead or near death and has been determined by a procurement organization to have a part that could be medically suitable for transplantation, therapy, research, or education; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(22)(b): does not include an individual who has made a refusal.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(23): "Reasonably available" means able to be contacted by a procurement organization without undue effort and willing and able to act in a timely manner consistent with existing medical criteria necessary for the making of an anatomical gift.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(24): "Recipient" means an individual into whose body a decedent's part has been or is intended to be transplanted.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(25): "Record" means information that is inscribed on a tangible medium or that is stored in an electronic or other medium and is retrievable in perceivable form.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(26): 26B-8-306 "Refusal" means a record created under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(27): "Sign" means, with the present intent to authenticate or adopt a record:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(27)(a): to execute or adopt a tangible symbol; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(27)(b): to attach to or logically associate with the record an electronic symbol, sound, or process.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(28): "State" means a state of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands, or any territory or insular possession subject to the jurisdiction of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(29): "Technician":
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(29)(a): means an individual determined to be qualified to remove or process parts by an appropriate organization that is licensed, accredited, or regulated under federal or state law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(29)(b): includes an enucleator.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(30): "Tissue" means a portion of the human body other than an organ or an eye.  The term does not include blood unless the blood is donated for the purpose of research or education.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(31): "Tissue bank" means a person that is licensed, accredited, or regulated under federal or state law to engage in the recovery, screening, testing, processing, storage, or distribution of tissue.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-301(32): "Transplant hospital" means a hospital that furnishes organ transplants and other medical and surgical specialty services required for the care of transplant patients.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-302 Applicability.
----------------------------------------------
This part applies to an anatomical gift or amendment to, revocation of, or refusal to make an anatomical gift, whenever made.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-303 Who may make anatomical gift before donor's death.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Subject to SectionUtah Code Annotated § 26B-8-303(1): the donor, if the donor is an adult or if the donor is a minor and is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-303(1)(a): emancipated; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-303(1)(b): authorized under state law to apply for a driver license because the donor is at least 15 years old;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-303(2): an agent of the donor, unless the power of attorney for health care or other record prohibits the agent from making an anatomical gift;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-303(3): a parent of the donor, if the donor is an unemancipated minor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-303(4): the donor's guardian.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-304 Manner of making anatomical gift before donor's death.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-304(1): (2) A donor may make an anatomical gift:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-304(1)(a): by authorizing a statement or symbol indicating that the donor has made an anatomical gift to be imprinted on the donor's driver license or identification card;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-304(1)(b): in a will;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-304(1)(c): during a terminal illness or injury of the donor, by any form of communication addressed to at least two adults, at least one of whom is a disinterested witness; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-304(1)(d): (2) as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-304(2): 26B-8-303; (2)(a) A donor or other person authorized to make an anatomical gift under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-304(2)(a): be witnessed by at least two adults, at least one of whom is a disinterested witness, who have signed at the request of the donor or the other person; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-304(2)(b): (2)(a) state that it has been signed and witnessed as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-304(3): Revocation, suspension, expiration, or cancellation of a driver license or identification card upon which an anatomical gift is indicated does not invalidate the gift.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-304(4): An anatomical gift made by will takes effect upon the donor's death whether or not the will is probated.  Invalidation of the will after the donor's death does not invalidate the gift.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-306 Refusal to make anatomical gift -- Effect of refusal.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-306(1): (2) An individual may refuse to make an anatomical gift of the individual's body or part by:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-306(1)(a): (2) a record signed by:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-306(1)(a)(ii): (2) subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-306(1)(b): the individual's will, whether or not the will is admitted to probate or invalidated after the individual's death; or

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-312 Delivery of document of gift not required -- Right to examine.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-313 Rights and duties of procurement organization and others.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-313(1): When a hospital refers an individual at or near death to a procurement organization, the organization shall make a reasonable search of the records of the Department of Public Safety and any donor registry that it knows exists for the geographical area in which the individual resides to ascertain whether the individual has made an anatomical gift.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-313(2): A procurement organization shall be allowed reasonable access to information in the records of the Department of Public Safety to ascertain whether an individual at or near death is a donor.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-313(3): When a hospital refers an individual at or near death to a procurement organization, the organization may conduct any reasonable examination necessary to ensure the medical suitability of a part that is or could be the subject of an anatomical gift for transplantation, therapy, research, or education from a donor or a prospective donor.  During the examination period, measures necessary to ensure the medical suitability of the part may not be withdrawn unless the hospital or procurement organization knows that the individual expressed a contrary intent.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-313(4): 26B-8-310 Unless prohibited by law other than this part, at any time after a donor's death, the person to which a part passes under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-313(5): (3); (4) Unless prohibited by law other than this part, an examination under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-313(6): Upon the death of a minor who was a donor or had signed a refusal, unless a procurement organization knows the minor is emancipated, the procurement organization shall conduct a reasonable search for the parents of the minor and provide the parents with an opportunity to revoke or amend the anatomical gift or revoke the refusal.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-313(7): (1); 26B-8-308 Upon referral by a hospital under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-313(8): 26B-8-310(9); 26B-8-322; 26B-8-310; 26B-8-310 Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-313(9): Neither the physician or physician assistant who attends the decedent at death nor the physician or physician assistant who determines the time of the decedent's death may participate in the procedures for removing or transplanting a part from the decedent.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-313(10): A physician, physician assistant, or technician may remove a donated part from the body of a donor that the physician, physician assistant, or technician is qualified to remove.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-314 Coordination of procurement and use.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Each hospital in this state shall enter into agreements or affiliations with procurement organizations for coordination of procurement and use of anatomical gifts.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-315 Sale or purchase of parts prohibited.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-315(1): (2) Except as otherwise provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-315(2): A person may charge a reasonable amount for the removal, processing, preservation, quality control, storage, transportation, implantation, or disposal of a part.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-316 Other prohibited acts.
------------------------------------------------------
A person that, in order to obtain a financial gain, intentionally falsifies, forges, conceals, defaces, or obliterates a document of gift, an amendment, or revocation of a document of gift, or a refusal commits a third degree felony.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-317 Immunity.
-----------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-317(1): A person that acts in accordance with this part or with the applicable anatomical gift law of another state, or attempts in good faith to do so, is not liable for the act in a civil action, criminal prosecution, or administrative proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-317(2): Neither the person making an anatomical gift nor the donor's estate is liable for any injury or damage that results from the making or use of the gift.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-317(3): 26B-8-308(1)(b); (c); (d); (e); (f); (g); (h); (i); (j) In determining whether an anatomical gift has been made, amended, or revoked under this part, a person may rely upon representations of an individual listed in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-318 Law governing validity -- Choice of law as to execution of document of gift -- Presumption of validity.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-318(1): A document of gift is valid if executed in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-318(1)(a): this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-318(1)(b): the laws of the state or country where it was executed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-318(1)(c): the laws of the state or country where the person making the anatomical gift was domiciled, has a place of residence, or was a national at the time the document of gift was executed.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-318(2): If a document of gift is valid under this section, the law of this state governs the interpretation of the document of gift.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-318(3): A person may presume that a document of gift or amendment of an anatomical gift is valid unless that person knows that it was not validly executed or was revoked.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-319(2): The Driver License Division of the Department of Public Safety shall cooperate with a person that administers any donor registry that this state establishes, contracts for, or recognizes for the purpose of transferring to the donor registry all relevant information regarding a donor's making, amendment to, or revocation of an anatomical gift.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-319(3): 26B-8-303; (3)(a); (b) A donor registry shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-320 Effect of anatomical gift on advance health care directive.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-320(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-320(1)(a): "Advance health care directive" means a power of attorney for health care or a record signed or authorized by a prospective donor containing the prospective donor's direction concerning a health care decision for the prospective donor.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-320(1)(b): "Declaration" means a record signed by a prospective donor specifying the circumstances under which a life support system may be withheld or withdrawn from the prospective donor.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-320(1)(c): "Health care decision" means any decision regarding the health care of the prospective donor.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-320(2): 26B-8-308 If a prospective donor has a declaration or advance health care directive and the terms of the declaration or directive and the express or implied terms of a potential anatomical gift are in conflict with regard to the administration of measures necessary to ensure the medical suitability of a part for transplantation or therapy, the prospective donor's attending physician and prospective donor shall confer to resolve the conflict.  If the prospective donor is incapable of resolving the conflict, an agent acting under the prospective donor's declaration or directive, or if no declaration or directive exists or the agent is not reasonably available, another person authorized by a law other than this part to make a health care decision on behalf of the prospective donor, shall act for the donor to resolve the conflict.  The conflict shall be resolved as expeditiously as possible.  Information relevant to the resolution of the conflict may be obtained from the appropriate procurement organization and any other person authorized to make an anatomical gift for the prospective donor under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-321 Cooperation between medical examiner and procurement organization.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-321(1): A medical examiner shall cooperate with procurement organizations to maximize the opportunity to recover anatomical gifts for the purpose of transplantation, therapy, research, or education.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-321(2): 26B-8-322 If a medical examiner receives notice from a procurement organization that an anatomical gift might be available or was made with respect to a decedent whose body is under the jurisdiction of the medical examiner and a postmortem examination is going to be performed, unless the medical examiner denies recovery in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-321(3): (3) A part may not be removed from the body of a decedent under the jurisdiction of a medical examiner for transplantation, therapy, research, or education unless the part is the subject of an anatomical gift.  The body of a decedent under the jurisdiction of the medical examiner may not be delivered to a person for research or education unless the body is the subject of an anatomical gift.  This Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-322 Facilitation of anatomical gift from decedent whose body is under jurisdiction of medical examiner.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-322(1): Upon request of a procurement organization, a medical examiner shall release to the procurement organization the name, contact information, and available medical and social history of a decedent whose body is under the jurisdiction of the medical examiner.  If the decedent's body or part is medically suitable for transplantation, therapy, research, or education, the medical examiner shall release postmortem examination results to the procurement organization.  The procurement organization may make a subsequent disclosure of the postmortem examination results or other information received from the medical examiner only if relevant to transplantation or therapy.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-322(2): The medical examiner may conduct a medicolegal examination by reviewing all medical records, laboratory test results, x-rays, other diagnostic results, and other information that any person possesses about a donor or prospective donor whose body is under the jurisdiction of the medical examiner which the medical examiner determines may be relevant to the investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-322(3): (2) A person that has any information requested by a medical examiner pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-322(4): If an anatomical gift has been or might be made of a part of a decedent whose body is under the jurisdiction of the medical examiner and a postmortem examination is not required, or the medical examiner determines that a postmortem examination is required but that the recovery of the part that is the subject of an anatomical gift will not interfere with the examination, the medical examiner and procurement organization shall cooperate in the timely removal of the part from the decedent for the purpose of transplantation, therapy, research, or education.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-322(5): If an anatomical gift of a part from the decedent under the jurisdiction of the medical examiner has been or might be made, but the medical examiner initially believes that the recovery of the part could interfere with the postmortem investigation into the decedent's cause or manner of death, the medical examiner shall consult with the procurement organization or physician or technician designated by the procurement organization about the proposed recovery.  After consultation, the medical examiner may allow the recovery.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-322(6): (5) Following the consultation under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-322(7): (6) If the medical examiner or designee denies recovery under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-322(7)(a): explain in a record the specific reasons for not allowing recovery of the part;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-322(7)(b): include the specific reasons in the records of the medical examiner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-322(7)(c): provide a record with the specific reasons to the procurement organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-322(8): (4); (5); (6) If the medical examiner or designee allows recovery of a part under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-322(9): (6); (6) If a medical examiner or designee is required to be present at a removal procedure under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-323 Uniformity of application and construction.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
In applying and construing the uniform act in this part, consideration shall be given to the need to promote uniformity of the law with respect to its subject matter among states that enact it.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-324 Relation to Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This act modifies, limits, and supersedes the Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 7001 et seq., but does not modify, limit or supersede Section 101(a) of that act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 7001, or authorize electronic delivery of any of the notices described in Section 103(b) of that act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 7003(b).

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-401 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-401(1): "Disclosure" or "disclose" means the communication of health data to any individual or organization outside the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-401(2): 26B-8-101 "Health data" means any information, except vital records as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-401(3): "Identifiable health data" means any item, collection, or grouping of health data which makes the individual supplying it or described in it identifiable.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-401(4): "Individual" means a natural person.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-401(5): "Organization" means any corporation, association, partnership, agency, department, unit, or other legally constituted institution or entity, or part of any of these.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-401(6): "Research and statistical purposes" means the performance of activities relating to health data, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-401(6)(a): describing the group characteristics of individuals or organizations;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-401(6)(b): analyzing the interrelationships among the various characteristics of individuals or organizations;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-401(6)(c): the conduct of statistical procedures or studies to improve the quality of health data;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-401(6)(d): the design of sample surveys and the selection of samples of individuals or organizations;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-401(6)(e): the preparation and publication of reports describing these matters; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-401(6)(f): other related functions.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-402 Powers of department to collect and maintain health data.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department may on a voluntary basis, except when there is specific legal authority to compel reporting of health data:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-402(1): collect and maintain health data on:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-402(1)(a): the extent, nature, and impact of illness and disability on the population of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-402(1)(b): the determinants of health and health hazards;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-402(1)(c): health resources, including the extent of available manpower and resources;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-402(1)(d): utilization of health care;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-402(1)(e): health care costs and financing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-402(1)(f): other health or health-related matters;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-402(2): (1) undertake and support research, demonstrations, and evaluations respecting new or improved methods for obtaining current data on the matters referred to in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-402(3): collect health data under other authorities and on behalf of other governmental or not-for-profit organizations.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-403 Quality and publication of statistics.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
The department shall:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-403(1): take such actions as may be necessary to assure that statistics developed under this part are of high quality, timely, and comprehensive, as well as specific, standardized, and adequately analyzed and indexed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-403(2): publish, make available, and disseminate such statistics on as wide a basis as practicable.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-404 Coordination of health data collection activities.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-404(1): The department shall coordinate health data activities within the state to eliminate unnecessary duplication of data collection and maximize the usefulness of data collected.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-404(2): Except as specifically provided, this part does not independently provide authority for the department to compel the reporting of information.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-405 Uniform standards -- Powers of department.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department may:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-405(1): participate and cooperate with state, local, and federal agencies and other organizations in the design and implementation of uniform standards for the management of health information  at the federal, state, and local levels; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-405(2): undertake and support research, development, demonstrations, and evaluations that support uniform health information standards.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-406 Disclosure of health data -- Limitations.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department may not make a disclosure of any identifiable health data unless:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-406(1): one of the following persons has consented to the disclosure:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-406(1)(a): the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-406(1)(b): the next-of-kin if the individual is deceased;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-406(1)(c): the parent or legal guardian if the individual is a minor or mentally incompetent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-406(1)(d): a person holding a power of attorney covering such matters on behalf of the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-406(2): the disclosure is to a governmental entity in this or another state or the federal government, provided that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-406(2)(a): the data will be used for a purpose for which they were collected by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-406(2)(b): the recipient enters into a written agreement satisfactory to the department agreeing to protect such data in accordance with the requirements of this part and department rule and not permit further disclosure without prior approval of the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-406(3): the disclosure is to an individual or organization, for a specified period, solely for bona fide research and statistical purposes, determined in accordance with department rules, and the department determines that the data are required for the research and statistical purposes proposed and the requesting individual or organization enters into a written agreement satisfactory to the department to protect the data in accordance with this part and department rule and not permit further disclosure without prior approval of the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-406(4): the disclosure is to a governmental entity for the purpose of conducting an audit, evaluation, or investigation of the department and such governmental entity agrees not to use those data for making any determination affecting the rights, benefits, or entitlements of any individual to whom the health data relates;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-406(5): the disclosure is of specific medical or epidemiological information to authorized personnel within the department, local health departments, public health authorities, official health agencies in other states, the United States Public Health Service, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), or agencies responsible to enforce quarantine, when necessary to continue patient services or to undertake public health efforts to control communicable, infectious, acute, chronic, or any other disease or health hazard that the department considers to be dangerous or important or that may affect the public health;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-406(6): 78B-3-403
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-406(6)(a): 78B-3-403 the disclosure is of specific medical or epidemiological information to a "health care provider" as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-406(6)(b): this Subsection (6) does not create a duty to warn third parties;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-406(7): the disclosure is necessary to obtain payment from an insurer or other third-party payor in order for the department to obtain payment or to coordinate benefits for a patient;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-406(8): the disclosure is to the subject of the identifiable health data; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-406(9): 53-3-111; 26B-1-216 the disclosure is limited to the results of a blood or urine test and the disclosure is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-406(9)(a): 53-3-111 to the Driver License Division, as authorized by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-406(9)(b): 26B-1-216 to the requesting law enforcement agency as part of an investigation, as authorized by Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-408 Health data not subject to subpoena or compulsory process -- Exception.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Identifiable health data obtained in the course of activities undertaken or supported under this part may not be subject to discovery, subpoena, or similar compulsory process in any civil or criminal, judicial, administrative, or legislative proceeding, nor shall any individual or organization with lawful access to identifiable health data under the provisions of this part be compelled to testify with regard to such health data, except that data pertaining to a party in litigation may be subject to subpoena or similar compulsory process in an action brought by or on behalf of such individual to enforce any liability arising under this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-409 Department measures to protect security of health data.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department shall protect the security of identifiable health data by use of the following measures and any other measures adopted by rule:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-409(1): limit access to identifiable  health data to authorized individuals who have received training in the handling of such data;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-409(2): designate a person to be responsible for physical security;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-409(3): develop and implement a system for monitoring security; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-409(4): review periodically all identifiable health data to determine whether identifying characteristics should be removed from the data.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-410 Relation to other provisions.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Because the following parts contain specific provisions regarding collection and disclosure of data, the provisions of this part do not apply to data that is subject to the following parts:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-410(1): Part 1, Vital Statistics
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-410(2): Part 2, Utah Medical Examiner
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-410(3): 26B-7-201; 26B-7-223 Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(1): 26B-1-413 "Committee" means the Health Data Committee created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(2): "Control number" means a number or other identifier that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(2)(a): is assigned by the department to an individual's health data;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(2)(b): is consistent with the best practices of data privacy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(2)(c): is used to ensure health data is not able to be readily associated with an individual when the health data is provided for research or statistical analysis.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(3): "Data supplier" means a health care facility, health care provider, self-funded employer, third-party payor, health maintenance organization, or government department which could reasonably be expected to provide health data under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(4): "Disclosure" or "disclose" means the communication of health care data to any individual or organization outside the department, its staff, and contracting agencies.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(5)(a): "Health care facility" means a facility that is licensed by the department under Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(5)(b): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the department, in consultation with the committee,  may by rule add, delete, or modify the list of facilities that come within this definition for purposes of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(6): 78B-3-403 "Health care provider" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(7): 26B-8-101 "Health data" means information relating to the health status of individuals, health services delivered, the availability of health manpower and facilities, and the use and costs of resources and services to the consumer, except vital records as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(8): 31A-8-101 "Health maintenance organization" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(9): "Identifiable health data" means any item, collection, or grouping of health data that makes the individual supplying or described in the health data identifiable.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(10): "Organization" means any corporation, association, partnership, agency, department, unit, or other legally constituted institution or entity, or part thereof.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(11): "Research and statistical analysis" means activities using health data analysis including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(11)(a): describing the group characteristics of individuals or organizations;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(11)(b): analyzing the noncompliance among the various characteristics of individuals or organizations;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(11)(c): conducting statistical procedures or studies to improve the quality of health data;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(11)(d): designing sample surveys and selecting samples of individuals or organizations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(11)(e): preparing and publishing reports describing these matters.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(12): "Self-funded employer" means an employer who provides for the payment of health care services for employees directly from the employer's funds, thereby assuming the financial risks rather than passing them on to an outside insurer through premium payments.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(13): "Plan" means the plan developed and adopted by the department under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(14): 31A-1-301 "Third party payor" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(14)(a): 31A-1-301 an insurer offering a health benefit plan, as defined by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(14)(b): a nonprofit health service insurance corporation licensed under Title 31A, Chapter 7, Nonprofit Health Service Insurance Corporations;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(14)(c): a program funded or administered by Utah for the provision of health care services, including the Medicaid and medical assistance programs described in Chapter 3, Part 1, Health Care Assistance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(14)(d): a corporation, organization, association, entity, or person:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(14)(d)(i): which administers or offers a health benefit plan to at least 2,500 enrollees in the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501(14)(d)(ii): which is required by administrative rule adopted by the department in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to supply health data to the department.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1 Health data authority duties.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(1): The department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(1)(a): in consultation with the committee and in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, develop and adopt by rule, following public hearing and comment, a health data plan that shall among its elements:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(1)(a)(i): identify the key health care issues, questions, and problems amenable to resolution or improvement through better data, more extensive or careful analysis, or improved dissemination of health data;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(1)(a)(ii): document existing health data activities in the state to collect, organize, or make available types of data pertinent to the needs identified in Subsection (1)(a)(i);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(1)(a)(iii): describe and prioritize the actions suitable for the department to take in response to the needs identified in Subsection (1)(a)(i) in order to obtain or to facilitate the obtaining of needed data, and to encourage improvements in existing data collection, interpretation, and reporting activities, and indicate how those actions relate to the activities identified under Subsection (1)(a)(ii);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(1)(a)(iv): detail the types of data needed for the department's work, the intended data suppliers, and the form in which such data are to be supplied, noting the consideration given to the potential alternative sources and forms of such data and to the estimated cost to the individual suppliers as well as to the department of acquiring the data in the proposed manner and reasonably demonstrate that the department has attempted to maximize cost-effectiveness in the data acquisition approaches selected;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(1)(a)(v): describe the types and methods of validation to be performed to assure data validity and reliability;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(1)(a)(vi): explain the intended uses of and expected benefits to be derived from the data specified in Subsection (1)(a)(iv), including the contemplated tabulation formats and analysis methods; the benefits described shall demonstrably relate to one or more of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(1)(a)(vi)(A): promoting quality health care;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(1)(a)(vi)(B): managing health care costs; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(1)(a)(vi)(C): improving access to health care services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(1)(a)(vii): describe the expected processes for interpretation and analysis of the data flowing to the department, noting specifically the types of expertise and participation to be sought in those processes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(1)(a)(viii): describe the types of reports to be made available by the department and the intended audiences and uses;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(1)(b): have the authority to collect, validate, analyze, and present health data in accordance with the plan while protecting individual privacy through the use of the best practices of data privacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(1)(c): evaluate existing identification coding methods and, if necessary, require by rule adopted in accordance with Subsection (2), that health data suppliers use a uniform system for identification of patients, health care facilities, and health care providers on health data they submit under this section and Chapter 8, Part 5, Utah Health Data Authority; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(1)(d): advise, consult, contract, and cooperate with any corporation, association, or other entity for the collection, analysis, processing, or reporting of health data.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(2): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the department, in consultation with the committee, may adopt rules to carry out the provisions of this section and Chapter 8, Part 5, Utah Health Data Authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(3)(a): Except for data collection, analysis, and validation functions described in this section, nothing in this part shall be construed to authorize or permit the department to perform regulatory functions which are delegated by law to other agencies of the state or federal governments or to perform quality assurance or medical record audit functions that health care facilities, health care providers, or third party payors are required to conduct to comply with federal or state law.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(3)(b): The department may not recommend or determine whether a health care provider, health care facility, third party payor, or self-funded employer is in compliance with federal or state laws including federal or state licensure, insurance, reimbursement, tax, malpractice, or quality assurance statutes or common law.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(4): Nothing in this part, shall be construed to require a data supplier to supply health data identifying a patient by name or describing detail on a patient beyond that needed to achieve the approved purposes included in the plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(5): No request for health data shall be made of health care providers and other data suppliers until a plan for the use of such health data has been adopted.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(6)(a): If a proposed request for health data imposes unreasonable costs on a data supplier, due consideration shall be given by the department to altering the request.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(6)(b): If the request is not altered, the department shall pay the costs incurred by the data supplier associated with satisfying the request that are demonstrated by the data supplier to be unreasonable.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(7): 26B-8-504 After a plan is adopted as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(8)(a): The department may not publish any health data collected under Subsection (7) that would disclose specific terms of contracts, discounts, or fixed reimbursement arrangements, or other specific reimbursement arrangements between an individual provider and a specific payer.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(8)(b): Nothing in Subsection (7) shall prevent the department from requiring the submission of health data on the reimbursements actually made to health care providers from any source of payment, including consumers.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(9): Any data collected by the department shall be done in accordance with state and federal data privacy laws.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(10)(a): The department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(10)(a)(i): create an opt-out system where an individual may choose to have an individual's identifiable health data suppressed or restricted from being accessible for department duties described under this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(10)(a)(ii): maintain a list of people who have opted out for use in accordance with Subsection (10)(b); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(10)(a)(iii): provide instructions for the opt-out system described in Subsection (10)(a)(i) in a conspicuous location on the department's website.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(10)(b): For an individual who opts out under Subsection (10)(a), the department may not share, analyze, or use any identifiable health data from the health data obtained under this part for the individual, including data previously obtained under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(11)(a): For identifiable health data, the department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(11)(a)(i): use the minimum necessary data to accomplish the duties described in this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(11)(a)(ii): only use personally identifiable information for:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(11)(a)(ii)(A): quality assurance;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(11)(a)(ii)(B): referential integrity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(11)(a)(ii)(C): complying with breach notification requirements.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(11)(b): If the department receives an individual's social security number with data obtained under this part, the department may not share any part of the social security number with any person.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(12): The department shall annually report to the Health and Human Services Interim Committee regarding privacy practices and efforts the department is undertaking to enhance data privacy.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(13): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(13)(a): Before October 1, 2024, the department shall review all state statutory mandates related to the collection of any form of health data and provide a written report to the Health and Human Services Interim Committee outlining the mandates that are older than 10 years old with:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(13)(a)(i): a description regarding how the data is used; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(13)(a)(ii): a recommendation regarding whether the department should continue collecting the data.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-501.1(13)(b): The department may request assistance from the Office of Legislative Research and General Counsel to determine when statutory mandates were enacted.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-502 Executive secretary -- Appointment -- Powers.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-502(1): An executive secretary shall be appointed by the executive director, in consultation with the committee, and shall serve under the administrative direction of the executive director.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-502(2): The executive secretary shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-502(2)(a): employ full-time employees necessary to carry out this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-502(2)(b): supervise the development of a draft health data plan for the department's review, modification, and approval; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-502(2)(c): supervise and conduct the staff functions of the committee in order to assist the committee in meeting its responsibilities under this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-503 Limitations on use of health data.
------------------------------------------------------------------
The department may not use the health data provided to it by third-party payors, health care providers, or health care facilities to make recommendations with regard to a single health care provider or health care facility, or a group of health care providers or health care facilities.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-504 Health care cost and reimbursement data.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-504(1): 31A-22-614.5; 26B-4-106; 67-3-11 The department shall, as funding is available:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-504(1)(a): establish a plan for collecting data from data suppliers to determine measurements of cost and reimbursements for risk-adjusted episodes of health care;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-504(1)(b): share data regarding insurance claims and an individual's and small employer group's health risk factor and characteristics of insurance arrangements that affect claims and usage with the Insurance Department, only to the extent necessary for:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-504(1)(b)(i): risk adjusting; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-504(1)(b)(ii): the review and analysis of health insurers' premiums and rate filings;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-504(1)(c): assist the Legislature and the public with awareness of, and the promotion of, transparency in the health care market by reporting on:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-504(1)(c)(i): geographic variances in medical care and costs as demonstrated by data available to the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-504(1)(c)(ii): rate and price increases by health care providers:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-504(1)(c)(ii)(A): that exceed the Consumer Price Index - Medical as provided by the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-504(1)(c)(ii)(B): as calculated yearly from June to June; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-504(1)(c)(ii)(C): as demonstrated by data available to the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-504(1)(d): 31A-22-614.5 provide on at least a monthly basis, enrollment data collected by the department to a not-for-profit, broad-based coalition of state health care insurers and health care providers that are involved in the standardized electronic exchange of health data as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-504(1)(d)(i): for the department or the Office of Inspector General of Medicaid Services to determine insurance enrollment of an individual for the purpose of determining Medicaid third party liability;
