Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505 Comparative analyses.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(1): The department may publish compilations or reports that compare and identify health care providers or data suppliers from the data it collects under this part or from any other source.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(2)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (7)(c), the department shall publish compilations or reports from the data it collects under this part or from any other source which:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(2)(a)(i): contain the information described in Subsection (2)(b); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(2)(a)(ii): compare and identify by name at least a majority of the health care facilities, health care plans, and institutions in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(2)(b): Except as provided in Subsection (7)(c), the report required by this Subsection (2) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(2)(b)(i): be published at least annually;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(2)(b)(ii): list, as determined by the department, the median paid amount for at least the top 50 medical procedures performed in the state by volume;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(2)(b)(iii): describe the methodology approved by the department to determine the amounts described in Subsection (2)(b)(ii); and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(2)(b)(iv): contain comparisons based on at least the following factors:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(2)(b)(iv)(A): nationally or other generally recognized quality standards;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(2)(b)(iv)(B): charges; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(2)(b)(iv)(C): nationally recognized patient safety standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(3)(a): The department may contract with a private, independent analyst to evaluate the standard comparative reports of the department that identify, compare, or rank the performance of data suppliers by name.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(3)(b): The evaluation described in this Subsection (3) shall include a validation of statistical methodologies, limitations, appropriateness of use, and comparisons using standard health services research practice.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(3)(c): The independent analyst described in Subsection (3)(a) shall be experienced in analyzing large databases from multiple data suppliers and in evaluating health care issues of cost, quality, and access.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(3)(d): The results of the analyst's evaluation shall be released to the public before the standard comparative analysis upon which it is based may be published by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(4): The department, in consultation with the committee shall make rules in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to adopt a timetable for the collection and analysis of data from multiple types of data suppliers.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(5): The comparative analysis required under Subsection (2) shall be available free of charge and easily accessible to the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(6): 26B-8-506
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(6)(a): The department shall include in the report required by Subsection (2)(b), or include in a separate report, comparative information on commonly recognized or generally agreed upon measures of cost and quality identified in accordance with Subsection (7), for:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(6)(a)(i): routine and preventive care; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(6)(a)(ii): the treatment of diabetes, heart disease, and other illnesses or conditions as determined by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(6)(b): The comparative information required by Subsection (6)(a) shall be based on data collected under Subsection (2) and clinical data that may be available to the department, and shall compare:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(6)(b)(i): results for health care facilities or institutions;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(6)(b)(ii): results for health care providers by geographic regions of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(6)(b)(iii): a clinic's aggregate results for a physician who practices at a clinic with five or more physicians; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(6)(b)(iv): a geographic region's aggregate results for a physician who practices at a clinic with less than five physicians, unless the physician requests physician-level data to be published on a clinic level.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(6)(c): The department:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(6)(c)(i): may publish information required by this Subsection (6) directly or through one or more nonprofit, community-based health data organizations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(6)(c)(ii): may use a private, independent analyst under Subsection (3)(a) in preparing the report required by this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(6)(d): 26B-8-506 A report published by the department under this Subsection (6):
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(6)(d)(i): 26B-8-506 is subject to the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(6)(d)(ii): shall, prior to being published by the department, be submitted to a neutral, non-biased entity with a broad base of support from health care payers and health care providers in accordance with Subsection (7) for the purpose of validating the report.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(7)(a): The department shall, for purposes of Subsection (6)(a), use the quality measures that are developed and agreed upon by a neutral, non-biased entity with a broad base of support from health care payers and health care providers.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(7)(b): If the entity described in Subsection (7)(a) does not submit the quality measures, the department may select the appropriate number of quality measures for purposes of the report required by Subsection (6).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(7)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(7)(c)(i): For purposes of the reports published on or after July 1, 2014, the department may not compare individual facilities or clinics as described in Subsections (6)(b)(i) through (iv) if the department determines that the data available to the department can not be appropriately validated, does not represent nationally recognized measures, does not reflect the mix of cases seen at a clinic or facility, or is not sufficient for the purposes of comparing providers.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-505(7)(c)(ii): The department shall report to the Health and Human Services Interim Committee prior to making a determination not to publish a report under Subsection (7)(c)(i).


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-506 Limitations on release of reports.
------------------------------------------------------------------
The department may not release a compilation or report that compares and identifies health care providers or data suppliers unless it:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-506(1): allows the data supplier and the health care provider to verify the accuracy of the information submitted to the department and submit to the department any corrections of errors with supporting evidence and comments within a reasonable period of time to be established by rule , with the concurrence of the department, made in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-506(2): corrects data found to be in error; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-506(3): allows the data supplier a reasonable amount of time prior to publication to review the department's interpretation of the data and prepare a response.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-507(3): No person, corporation, or entity may be held civilly liable for having provided data to the department in accordance with this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-508(4): A request for disclosure of information that may include identifiable health data shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-508(4)(b)(ii): the requesting entity to enter into a written agreement satisfactory to the department to protect the data in accordance with this part or other applicable law.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-508(5)(a): without prior approval of the department; and

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-510 Health data not subject to subpoena or compulsory process -- Exception.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Identifiable health data obtained in the course of activities undertaken or supported under this part are not subject to subpoena or similar compulsory process in any civil or criminal, judicial, administrative, or legislative proceeding, nor shall any individual or organization with lawful access to identifiable health data under the provisions of this part be compelled to testify with regard to such health data, except that data pertaining to a party in litigation may be subject to subpoena or similar compulsory process in an action brought by or on behalf of such individual to enforce any liability arising under this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511 Consumer-focused health care delivery and payment reform demonstration project.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(1): The Legislature finds that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(1)(a): current health care delivery and payment systems do not provide system wide incentives for the competitive delivery and pricing of health care services to consumers;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(1)(b): there is a compelling state interest to encourage consumers to seek high quality, low cost care and educate themselves about health care options;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(1)(c): some health care providers and health care payers have developed consumer-focused ideas for health care delivery and payment system reform, but lack the critical number of patient lives and payer involvement to accomplish system-wide consumer-focused reform; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(1)(d): there is a compelling state interest to encourage as many health care providers and health care payers to join together and coordinate efforts at consumer-focused health care delivery and payment reform that would provide to consumers enrolled in a high-deductible health plan:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(1)(d)(i): greater choice in health care options;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(1)(d)(ii): improved services through competition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(1)(d)(iii): more affordable options for care.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(2)(a): The department shall meet with health care providers and health care payers for the purpose of coordinating a demonstration project for consumer-based health care delivery and payment reform.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(2)(b): Participation in the coordination efforts is voluntary, but encouraged.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(3): The department, in order to facilitate the coordination of a demonstration project for consumer-based health care delivery and payment reform, shall convene and consult with pertinent entities including:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(3)(a): the Utah Insurance Department;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(3)(b): the Office of Consumer Services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(3)(c): the Utah Medical Association;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(3)(d): the Utah Hospital Association; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(3)(e): neutral, non-biased third parties with an established record for broad based, multi-provider and multi-payer quality assurance efforts and data collection.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(4): (3) The department shall supervise the efforts by entities under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(4)(a): applying for and obtaining grant funding and other financial assistance that may be available for demonstrating consumer-based improvements to health care delivery and payment;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(4)(b): obtaining and analyzing information and data related to current health system utilization and costs to consumers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-8-511(4)(c): consulting with those health care providers and health care payers who elect to participate in the consumer-based health delivery and payment demonstration project.

--------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-101(6): "Director" means the director of the Office of Recovery Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-101(7): 7-1-103; 61-1-13 "Financial institution" means:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-101(7)(d): 61-1-13 a broker-dealer as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-101(7)(e): any benefit association, insurance company, safe deposit company, money-market mutual fund, or similar entity authorized to do business in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-101(8): "Financial record" means the same as that term is defined in the Right to Financial Privacy Act of 1978, 12 U.S.C. Sec. 3401.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-101(9):

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-101(9)(b)(vi): disability benefits.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-101(11): "IV-D child support services" means child support services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-101(12): 35A-7-103 "New hire registry" means the centralized new hire registry created in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-101(14): "Obligor" means a person, firm, corporation, or the estate of a decedent owing money to this state, to an individual, to another state, or other comparable jurisdiction in whose behalf this state is acting.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-102 Legislative intent -- Liberal construction.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is the intent of the Legislature that the integrity of the public assistance programs of this state be maintained and that the taxpayers support only those persons in need and only as a resource of last resort. To this end, this part should be liberally construed.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-103 Office of Recovery Services -- Creation.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-103(1): There is created within the department the Office of Recovery Services which has the powers and duties provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-103(2): The office is under the administrative and general supervision of the executive director.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104 Duties of the Office of Recovery Services.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1): 26B-9-208; 35A-7-103; 26B-9-213; 26B-9-207 The office has the following duties:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(a): except as provided in Subsection (2), to provide child support services if:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(a)(i): the office has received an application for child support services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(a)(ii): the state has provided public assistance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(a)(iii): a child lives out of the home in the protective custody, temporary custody, or custody or care of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(b): for the purpose of collecting child support, to carry out the obligations of the department contained in:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(b)(i): this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(b)(ii): Title 78B, Chapter 14, Utah Uniform Interstate Family Support Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(b)(iii): Title 78B, Chapter 15, Utah Uniform Parentage Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(b)(iv): Title 81, Chapter 6, Child Support;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(c): to collect money due the department which could act to offset expenditures by the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(d): to cooperate with the federal government in programs designed to recover health and social service funds;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(e): to collect civil or criminal assessments, fines, fees, amounts awarded as restitution, and reimbursable expenses owed to the state or any of its political subdivisions, if the office has contracted to provide collection services;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(f): to implement income withholding for collection of child support in accordance with Part 3, Income Withholding in IV-D Cases;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(g): 26B-9-208 to enter into agreements with financial institutions doing business in the state to develop and operate, in coordination with such financial institutions, a data match system in the manner provided for in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(h): to establish and maintain the state case registry in the manner required by the Social Security Act, 42 U.S.C. Sec. 654a, which shall include a record in each case of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(h)(i): the amount of monthly or other periodic support owed under the order, and other amounts, including arrearages, interest, late payment penalties, or fees, due or overdue under the order;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(h)(ii): any amount described in Subsection (1)(h)(i) that has been collected;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(h)(iii): the distribution of collected amounts;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(h)(iv): the birth date of any child for whom the order requires the provision of support; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(h)(v): the amount of any lien imposed with respect to the order pursuant to this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(i): 35A-7-103 to contract with the Department of Workforce Services to establish and maintain the new hire registry created under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(j): 26B-9-213 to determine whether an individual who has applied for or is receiving cash assistance or Medicaid is cooperating in good faith with the office as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(k): to finance any costs incurred from collections, fees, General Fund appropriation, contracts, and federal financial participation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(1)(l): 26B-9-207 to provide notice to a noncustodial parent in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(2): The office may not provide child support services to the Division of Child and Family Services for a calendar month when the child to whom the child support services relate is:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(2)(a): in the custody of the Division of Child and Family Services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(2)(b): lives in the home of a custodial parent of the child for more than seven consecutive days, regardless of whether:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(2)(b)(i): the greater than seven consecutive day period starts during one month and ends in the next month; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(2)(b)(ii): the child is living in the home on a trial basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-104(3): The Division of Child and Family Services is not entitled to child support, for a child to whom the child support relates, for a calendar month when child support services may not be provided under Subsection (2).

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-105(1)(a): a public or private employer shall disclose an employee's name, address, date of birth, income, social security number, and health insurance information pertaining to the employee and the employee's dependents;

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-105(4): An employer, financial institution, or insurance organization, or its agent or employee, is not civilly or criminally liable for providing information to the office in accordance with this section, whether the information is provided pursuant to oral or written request.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-106 Adjudicative proceedings.
---------------------------------------------------------
The office and the department shall comply with the procedures and requirements of

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-107 Office may file as real party in interest -- Written consent to payment agreements -- Money judgment in favor of obligee considered to be in favor of office to extent of right to recover.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-107(1): The office may file judicial proceedings as a real party in interest to establish, modify, and enforce a support order in the name of the state, any department of the state, the office, or an obligee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-107(2): No agreement between an obligee and an obligor as to past, present, or future obligations, reduces or terminates the right of the office to recover from that obligor on behalf of the department for public assistance provided, unless the department has consented to the agreement in writing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-107(3): Any court order that includes a money judgment for support to be paid to an obligee by any person is considered to be in favor of the office to the extent of the amount of the office's right to recover public assistance from the judgment debtor.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-108 Director -- Powers of office -- Representation by county attorney or attorney general -- Receipt of grants -- Rulemaking and enforcement.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-108(1): The director of the office shall be appointed by the executive director.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-108(2): The office has power to administer oaths, certify to official acts, issue subpoenas, and to compel witnesses and the production of books, accounts, documents, and evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-108(3): The office has the power to seek administrative and judicial orders to require an obligor who owes past-due support and is obligated to support a child receiving public assistance to participate in appropriate work activities if the obligor is unemployed and is not otherwise incapacitated.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-108(4): The office has the power to enter into reciprocal child support enforcement agreements with foreign countries consistent with federal law and cooperative enforcement agreements with Indian Tribes.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-108(5): 78B-6-315 The office has the power to pursue through court action the withholding, suspension, and revocation of driver's licenses, professional and occupational licenses, and recreational licenses of individuals owing overdue support or failing, after receiving appropriate notice, to comply with subpoenas or orders relating to paternity or child support proceedings pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-108(6): It is the duty of the attorney general or the county attorney of any county in which a cause of action can be filed, to represent the office.  Neither the attorney general nor the county attorney represents or has an attorney-client relationship with the obligee or the obligor in carrying out the duties arising under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-108(7): The office, with department approval, is authorized to receive any grants or stipends from the federal government or other public or private source designed to aid the efficient and effective operation of the recovery program.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-108(8): The office may adopt, amend, and enforce rules as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-109 Office designated as criminal justice agency -- Access by IV-D agencies to motor vehicle and law enforcement data through the office.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-109(1): The office is designated as a criminal justice agency for the purpose of requesting and obtaining access to criminal justice information, subject to appropriate federal, state, and local agency restrictions governing the dissemination of that information.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-109(2): All federal and state agencies conducting activities under Title IV-D of the Social Security Act shall have access through the office to any system used by this state to locate an individual for purposes relating to motor vehicles or law enforcement.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110 Lien provisions.
------------------------------------------------
Provisions for collection of any lien placed as a condition of eligibility for any federally or state-funded public assistance program are as follows:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(1): Any assistance granted after July 1, 1953 to the spouse of an old-age recipient who was not eligible for old-age assistance but who participated in the assistance granted to the family is recoverable in the same manner as old-age assistance granted to the old-age recipient.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(2): (2)(c) At the time of the settlement of a lien given as a condition of eligibility for the old-age assistance program, there shall be allowed a cash exemption of $1,000, less any additional money invested by the department in the home of an old-age recipient or recipients of other assistance programs either as payment of taxes, home and lot improvements, or to protect the interest of the state in the property for necessary improvements to make the home habitable, to be deducted from the market or appraised value of the real property.  When it is necessary to sell property or to settle an estate the department may grant reasonable costs of sale and settlement of an estate as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(2)(a): When the total cost of probate, including the sale of property when it is sold, and the cost of burial and last illness do not exceed $1,000, the exemption of $1,000 shall be the total exemption, which shall be the only amount deductible from the market or appraised value of the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(2)(b): (2)(c) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(2)(b)(i): cost of funeral expenses not exceeding $1,500;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(2)(b)(ii): costs of terminal illness, provided the medical expenses have not been paid from any state or federally-funded assistance program;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(2)(b)(iii): realty fees, if any;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(2)(b)(iv): costs of revenue stamps, if any;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(2)(b)(v): costs of abstract or title insurance, whichever is the least costly;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(2)(b)(vi): attorney fees not exceeding the recommended fee established by the Utah State Bar;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(2)(b)(vii): administrator's fee not to exceed $150;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(2)(b)(viii): court costs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(2)(b)(ix): delinquent taxes, if any.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(2)(c): An attorney, who sells the property in an estate that the attorney is probating, is entitled to the lesser of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(2)(c)(i): a real estate fee; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(2)(c)(ii): an attorney fee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(3): (2)(b) The amounts listed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(4): When both husband and wife are recipients and one or both of them own an interest in real property, the lien attaches to the interests of both for the reimbursement of assistance received by either or both spouses.  Only one exemption, as provided in this section, is allowed.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(5): (4) When a lien was executed by one party on property that is owned in joint tenancy with full rights of survivorship, the execution of the lien severs the joint tenancy and a tenancy in common results, insofar as a department lien is affected, unless the recipients are husband and wife.  When recipients are husband and wife who own property in joint tenancy with full rights of survivorship, the execution of a lien does not sever the joint tenancy, insofar as a department lien might be affected, and settlement of the lien shall be in accordance with the provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(6): The amount of the lien given for old-age assistance shall be the total amount of assistance granted up to the market or appraised value of the real or personal property, less the amount of the legal maximum property limitations from the execution of the lien until settlement thereof.  There shall be no exemption of any kind or nature allowed against real or personal property liens granted for old-age assistance except assistance in the form of medical care, and nursing home care, other types of congregate care, and similar plans for persons with a physical or mental disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(7): When it is necessary to sell property or to settle an estate, the department is authorized to approve payment of the reasonable costs of sale and settlement of an estate on which a lien has been given for old-age assistance.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(8): The amount of reimbursement of all liens held by the department shall be determined on the basis of the formulas described in this section, when they become due and payable.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(9): All lien agreements shall be recorded with the county recorder of the county in which the real property is located, and that recording has the same effect as a judgment lien on any real property in which the recipient has any title or interest.  All such real property including but not limited to, joint tenancy interests, shall, from the time a lien agreement is recorded, be and become charged with a lien for all assistance received by the recipient or his spouse as provided in this section.  That lien has priority over all unrecorded encumbrances.  No fees or costs shall be paid for such recording.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(10): Liens shall become due and payable, and the department shall seek collection of each lien now held:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(10)(a): when the property to which the lien attaches is transferred to a third party prior to the recipient's death, provided, that if other property is purchased by the recipient to be used by the recipient as a home, the department may transfer the amount of the lien from the property sold to the property purchased;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(10)(b): upon the death of the recipient and the recipient's spouse, if any.  When the heirs or devisees of the property are also recipients of public assistance, or when other hardship circumstances exist, the department may postpone settlement of the lien if that would be in the best interest of the recipient and the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(10)(c): when a recipient voluntarily offers to settle the lien; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(10)(d): when property subject to a lien is no longer used by a recipient and appears to be abandoned.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(11): 75-3-805(1)(e) When a lien becomes due and payable, a certificate in a form approved by the department certifying to the amount of assistance provided to the recipient and the amount of the lien, shall be mailed to the recipient, the recipient's heirs, or administrators of the estate, and the same shall be allowed, approved, filed, and paid as a preferred claim, as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(12): (11) If heirs are unable to make a lump-sum settlement of the lien at the time it becomes due and payable, the department may permit settlement based upon periodic repayments in a manner prescribed by the department, with interest as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(13): All sums so recovered, except those credited to the federal government, shall be retained by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(14): The department is empowered to accept voluntary conveyance of real or personal property in satisfaction of its interest therein.  All property acquired by the department under the provisions of this section may be disposed of by public or private sale under rules prescribed by the department.  The department is authorized to execute and deliver any document necessary to convey title to all property that comes into its possession, as though the department constituted a corporate entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-110(15): Any real property acquired by the department, either by foreclosure or voluntary conveyance, is tax exempt, so long as it is so held.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-111 Assignment of support -- Children in state custody.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-111(1): Child support is assigned to the department by operation of law when a child is residing outside of his home in the protective custody, temporary custody, custody, or care of the state for at least 30 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-111(2): (1) The department has the right to receive payment for child support assigned to it under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-111(3): The Office of Recovery Services is the payee for the department for payment received under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-112 Alternative payment by obligor through electronic funds transfer.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-112(1): Part 3, Income Withholding in IV-D Cases; Part 4, Income Withholding in Non IV-D Cases The office may enter into a written alternative payment agreement with an obligor which provides for electronic payment of child support under
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-112(2): The alternative payment agreement shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-112(2)(a): provide for electronic payment of child support in lieu of income withholding;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-112(2)(b): specify the date on which electronic payments will be withdrawn from an obligor's account; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-112(2)(c): specify the amount which will be withdrawn.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-112(3): 26B-9-301 The office may terminate the agreement and initiate immediate income withholding, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-112(3)(a): required to meet federal or state requirements or guidelines;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-112(3)(b): funds available in the account at the scheduled time of withdrawal are insufficient to satisfy the agreement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-112(3)(c): requested by the obligor.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-112(4): If the payment amount requires adjusting, the office may initiate a new written agreement with the obligor.  If, for any reason, the office and obligor fail to agree on the terms, the office may terminate the agreement and initiate income withholding.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-112(5): If an agreement is terminated for insufficient funds, a new agreement may not be entered into between the office and obligor for a period of at least 12 months.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-112(6): The office shall make rules specifying eligibility requirements for obligors to enter into alternative payment agreements.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(1): "Adjudicative proceeding" means an action or proceeding of the office conducted in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(2): "Administrative order" means an order that has been issued by the office, the department, or an administrative agency of another state or other comparable jurisdiction with similar authority to that of the office.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(3): "Arrears" means support debt.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(4): 26B-9-101 "Assistance" means public assistance as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(5): "Cash medical support" means an obligation to equally share all reasonable and necessary medical and dental expenses of children.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(6): 81-6-101 "Child" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(7): 26B-9-101 "Child support" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(8): 81-6-101 "Child support guidelines" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(9): "Child support order" means a judgment, decree, or order, whether temporary, final, or subject to modification, issued by a tribunal for child support and related costs and fees, interest and penalties, income withholding, attorney fees, and other relief.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(10): 26B-9-101 "Child support services" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(11): "Court order" means a judgment or order of a tribunal of appropriate jurisdiction of this state, another state, Native American tribe, the federal government, or any other comparable jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(12): "Director" means the director of the Office of Recovery Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(13): "Disposable earnings" means that part of the earnings of an individual remaining after the deduction of all amounts required by law to be withheld.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(14): "High-volume automated administrative enforcement" in interstate cases means, on the request of another state, the identification by the office, through automatic data matches with financial institutions and other entities where assets may be found, of assets owned by persons who owe child support in the requesting state, and the seizure of the assets by the office, through levy or other appropriate processes.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(15): 26B-9-101 "Income" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(16): "IV-D services" means services provided pursuant to Part D of Title IV of the Social Security Act, 42 U.S.C. Sec. 651, et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(17): 63G-4-201 "Notice of agency action" means the notice required to commence an adjudicative proceeding in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(18): "Obligee" means an individual, this state, another state, or  other comparable jurisdiction to whom a duty of child support is owed, or who is entitled to reimbursement of child support or public assistance.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(19): "Obligor" means a person, firm, corporation, or the estate of a decedent owing a duty of support to this state, to an individual, to another state, or other corporate jurisdiction in whose behalf this state is acting.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(20): "Office" means the Office of Recovery Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(21): 81-1-101 "Parent" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(22): "Past-due support" means support debt.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(23): "Person" includes an individual, firm, corporation, association, political subdivision, department, or office.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(24): 26B-9-101 "Public assistance" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(25): 63G-4-103 "Presiding officer" means a presiding officer described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(26): "Support" includes past-due, present, and future obligations established by:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(26)(a): a tribunal or imposed by law for the financial support, maintenance, medical, or dental care of a child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(26)(b): a tribunal for the financial support of a spouse or former spouse with whom the obligor's child resides if the obligor also owes a child support obligation that is being enforced by the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(27): "Support debt" means the debt created by nonpayment of support.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(28): "Support order" means a child support order.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-201(29): "Tribunal" means the district court, the department, the Office of Recovery Services, or court or administrative agency of any state, territory, possession of the United States, the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, Native American Tribe, or other comparable domestic or foreign jurisdiction.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-202 Common-law and statutory remedies augmented by act -- Public policy.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-202(1): The state of Utah, exercising its police and sovereign power, declares that the common-law and statutory remedies pertaining to family desertion and nonsupport of children shall be augmented by this part, which is directed to the real and personal property resources of the responsible parents.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-202(2): In order to render resources more immediately available to meet the needs of children, it is the legislative intent that the remedies provided in this part are in addition to, and not in lieu of, existing law.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-202(3): It is declared to be the public policy of this state that this part be liberally construed and administered to the end that children shall be maintained from the resources of responsible parents, thereby relieving or avoiding, at least in part, the burden often borne by the general citizenry through public assistance programs.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-203 Application for child support services.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-203(1): Any person applying to the office for child support services shall be required to attest to the truthfulness of the information contained in the application.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-205 Expedited procedures for establishing paternity or establishing, modifying, or enforcing a support order.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-209 Support collection services requested by agency of another state.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-209(1): Title 78B, Chapter 14, Utah Uniform Interstate Family Support Act; 26B-9-206 In accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-209(1)(a): support collection services are requested by an agency of another state that is operating under Part IV-D of the Social Security Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-209(1)(b): an individual applies for services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-209(2): The office shall use high-volume automated administrative enforcement, to the same extent it is used for intrastate cases, in response to a request made by another state's IV-D child support agency to enforce support orders.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-209(3): A request by another state shall constitute a certification by the requesting state:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-209(3)(a): of the amount of support under the order of payment of which is in arrears; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-209(3)(b): that the requesting state has complied with procedural due process requirements applicable to the case.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-209(4): The office shall give automated administrative interstate enforcement requests the same priority as a two-state referral received from another state to enforce a support order.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-209(5): The office shall promptly report the results of the enforcement procedures to the requesting state.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-209(6): As required by the Social Security Act, 42 U.S.C. Sec. 666(a)(14), the office shall maintain records of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-209(6)(a): the number of requests for enforcement assistance received by the office under this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-209(6)(b): the number of cases for which the state collected support in response to those requests; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-209(6)(c): the amount of support collected.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-211 Mandatory review and adjustment of child support orders for TANF recipients.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If a child support order has not been issued, adjusted, or modified within the previous three years and the children who are the subject of the order currently receive TANF funds, the office shall review the order, and if appropriate, move the tribunal to adjust the amount of the order if there is a difference of 10% or more between the payor's ordered support amount and the payor's support amount required under the child support guidelines.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213 Duties of obligee after assignment of support rights.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(1): 35A-3-108 An obligee whose rights to support have been assigned under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(1)(a): Unless a good cause or other exception applies, the obligee shall, at the request of the office:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(1)(a)(i): cooperate in good faith with the office by providing the name and other identifying information of the other parent of the obligee's child for the purpose of:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(1)(a)(i)(A): establishing paternity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(1)(a)(i)(B): establishing, modifying, or enforcing a child support order;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(1)(a)(ii): supply additional necessary information and appear at interviews, hearings, and legal proceedings; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(1)(a)(iii): submit the obligee's child and himself to judicially or administratively ordered genetic testing.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(1)(b): The obligee may not commence an action against an obligor or file a pleading to collect or modify support without the office's written consent.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(1)(c): The obligee may not do anything to prejudice the rights of the office to establish paternity, enforce provisions requiring health insurance, or to establish and collect support.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(1)(d): The obligee may not agree to allow the obligor to change the court or administratively ordered manner or amount of payment of past, present, or future support without the office's written consent.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(2)(a): The office shall determine and redetermine, when appropriate, whether an obligee has cooperated with the office as required by Subsection (1)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(2)(b): If the office determines that an obligee has not cooperated as required by Subsection (1)(a), the office shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(2)(b)(i): forward the determination and the basis for it to the Department of Workforce Services, which shall inform the department of the determination, for a determination of whether compliance by the obligee should be excused on the basis of good cause or other exception; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(2)(b)(ii): send to the obligee:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(2)(b)(ii)(A): a copy of the notice; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(2)(b)(ii)(B): information that the obligee may, within 15 days of notice being sent:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(2)(b)(ii)(B)(I): contest the office's determination of noncooperation by filing a written request for an adjudicative proceeding with the office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(2)(b)(ii)(B)(II): assert that compliance should be excused on the basis of good cause or other exception by filing a written request for a good cause exception with the Department of Workforce Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(3): The office's right to recover is not reduced or terminated if an obligee agrees to allow the obligor to change the court or administratively ordered manner or amount of payment of support regardless of whether that agreement is entered into before or after public assistance is furnished on behalf of a child.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(4)(a): If an obligee receives direct payment of assigned support from an obligor, the obligee shall immediately deliver that payment to the office.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(4)(b)(i): If an obligee agrees with an obligor to receive payment of support other than in the court or administratively ordered manner and receives payment as agreed with the obligor, the obligee shall immediately deliver the cash equivalent of the payment to the office.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(4)(b)(ii): If the amount delivered to the office by the obligee under Subsection (4)(b)(i) exceeds the amount of the court or administratively ordered support due, the office shall return the excess to the obligee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(5)(a): If public assistance furnished on behalf of a child is terminated, the office may continue to provide paternity establishment and support collection services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-213(5)(b): Unless the obligee notifies the office to discontinue these services, the obligee is considered to have accepted and is bound by the rights, duties, and liabilities of an obligee who has applied for those services.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-215 Effect of lien.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-215(1): After receiving notice that a support lien has been filed under this part by the office, no person in possession of any property which may be subject to that lien may pay over, release, sell, transfer, encumber, or convey that property to any person other than the office, unless he first receives:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-215(1)(a): a release or waiver thereof from the office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-215(1)(b): a court order that orders release of the lien on the basis that the debt does not exist or has been satisfied.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-215(2): Whenever any such person has in his possession earnings, deposits, accounts, or balances in excess of $100 over the amount of the debt claimed by the office, that person may, without liability under this part, release that excess to the obligor.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-216 Enforcement of liens arising in another state.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A lien arising in another state shall be accorded full faith and credit in this state, without any additional requirement of judicial notice or hearing prior to the enforcement of the lien, if the office, parent, or state IV-D agency who seeks to enforce the lien complies with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-217 Requirement to honor voluntary assignment of earnings -- Discharge of employee prohibited -- Liability for discharge -- Earnings subject to support lien or garnishment.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-217(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-217(1)(a): Every person, firm, corporation, association, political subdivision, or department of the state shall honor, according to its terms, a duly executed voluntary assignment of earnings which is presented by the office as a plan to satisfy or retire a support debt or obligation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-217(1)(b): The requirement to honor an assignment of earnings, and the assignment of earnings itself, are applicable whether the earnings are to be paid presently or in the future, and continue in effect until released in writing by the office.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-217(1)(c): Payment of money pursuant to an assignment of earnings presented by the office shall serve as full acquittance under any contract of employment, and the state shall defend the employer and hold the employer harmless for any action taken pursuant to the assignment of earnings.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-217(1)(d): The office shall be released from liability for improper receipt of money under an assignment of earnings upon return of any money so received.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-217(2): An employer may not discharge or prejudice any employee because the employee's earnings have been subjected to support lien, wage assignment, or garnishment for any indebtedness under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-217(3): If an employer discharges an employee in violation of Subsection (2), the employer is liable to the employee for the damages the employee may suffer, and, additionally, to the office in an amount equal to the debt which is the basis of the assignment or garnishment, plus costs, interest, and attorney fees, or a maximum of $1,000, whichever is less.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-217(4): The maximum part of the aggregate disposable earnings of an individual for any work pay period which may be subjected to a garnishment to enforce payment of a judicial or administrative judgment arising out of failure to support children may not exceed 50% of the individual's disposable earnings for the work pay period.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-217(5): The support lien or garnishment shall continue to operate and require the employer to withhold the nonexempt portion of earnings at each succeeding earnings disbursement interval until released in writing by the court or office.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-218 Release of lien, attachment, or garnishment by department.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The office may, at any time, release a support lien, wage assignment, attachment, or garnishment on all or part of the property of the obligor, or return seized property without liability, if assurance of payment is considered adequate by the office, or if that action will facilitate collection of the support debt.  However, that release or return does not prevent future action to collect from the same or other property.  The office may also waive provisions providing for the collection of interest on accounts due, if that waiver would facilitate collection of the support debt.

Sec.  1673(b).

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-220 Review and adjustment of child support order in three-year cycle -- Substantial change in circumstances not required.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-220(1): 35A-3-108 If a child support order has not been issued, modified, or reviewed within the previous three years, the office shall review a child support order, taking into account the best interests of the child involved, if:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-220(2):

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-220(2)(b): If there is such a difference and the difference is not of a temporary nature, the office shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-220(2)(b)(ii): with respect to a child support order issued or modified by a court, file the appropriate pleading with the court to adjust the amount to that which is provided for in the child support guidelines.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-220(3)(b): identify child support orders in which there is a difference of 10% or more between the amount of child support ordered and the amount that would be required under the child support guidelines for review under Subsection (1)(b).

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-221(2)(b)(i): with respect to a support order issued or modified by the office, adjust the amount in accordance with the child support guidelines; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-221(2)(b)(ii): with respect to a support order issued or modified by a court, file a petition with the court to adjust the amount in accordance with the child support guidelines.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-221(3): The office may use automated methods to collect information for a review conducted under Subsection (2).

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-223 Posting bond or security for payment of support debt -- Procedure.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-223(1): The office shall, or an obligee may, petition the court for an order requiring an obligor to post a bond or provide other security for the payment of a support debt, if the office or an obligee determines that action is appropriate, and if the payments are more than 90 days delinquent.  The office shall establish rules for determining when it shall seek an order for bond or other security.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-223(2): When the office or an obligee petitions the court under this section, it shall give written notice to the obligor, stating:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-223(2)(a): the amount of support debt;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-223(2)(b): that it has petitioned the court for an order requiring the obligor to post security; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-223(2)(c): that the obligor has the right to appear before the court and contest the office's or obligee's petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-223(3): After notice to the obligor and an opportunity for a hearing, the court shall order a bond posted or other security to be deposited upon the office's or obligee's showing of a support debt and of a reasonable basis for the security.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-225 Enrollment of child in accident and health insurance plan -- Order -- Notice.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-225(1): The office may issue a notice to existing and future employers or unions to enroll a child in an accident and health insurance plan that is available through the child's parent or legal guardian's employer or union, when the following conditions are satisfied:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-225(1)(a): the parent or legal guardian is already required to obtain insurance coverage for the child by a prior court or administrative order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-225(1)(b): the parent or legal guardian has failed to provide written proof to the office that:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-225(1)(b)(i): the child has been enrolled in an accident and health insurance plan in accordance with the court or administrative order; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-225(1)(b)(ii): the coverage required by the order was not available at group rates through the employer or union 30 or more days prior to the date of the mailing of the notice to enroll.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-225(2): 26B-9-207 The office shall provide concurrent notice to the parent or legal guardian in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-225(2)(a): the notice to enroll sent to the employer or union; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-225(2)(b): the opportunity to contest the enrollment due to a mistake of fact by filing a written request for an adjudicative proceeding with the office within 15 days of the notice being sent.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-225(3): A notice to enroll shall result in the enrollment of the child in the parent's accident and health insurance plan, unless the parent successfully contests the notice based on a mistake of fact.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-225(4): A notice to enroll issued under this section may be considered a "qualified medical support order" for the purposes of enrolling a child in a group accident and health insurance plan as defined in Section 609(a), Federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-226 Compliance with order -- Enrollment of  child for insurance.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-226(1): 26B-9-225 An employer or union shall comply with a notice to enroll issued by the office under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-226(1)(a): accident and health insurance plan in which the parent or legal guardian is enrolled, if the plan satisfies the prior court or administrative order; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-226(1)(b): least expensive plan, assuming equivalent benefits, offered by the employer or union that complies with the prior court or administrative order which provides coverage that is reasonably accessible to the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-226(2): The employer, union, or insurer may not refuse to enroll a child pursuant to a notice to enroll because a parent or legal guardian has not signed an enrollment application.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-226(3): Upon enrollment of the child, the employer shall deduct the appropriate premiums from the parent or legal guardian's wages and remit the premiums directly to the insurer.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-226(4): The insurer shall provide proof of insurance to the office upon request.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-226(5): The signature of the custodial parent of the insured child is a valid authorization to the insurer for purposes of processing any insurance reimbursement claim.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-228 Reporting past-due support to consumer reporting agency.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The office shall periodically report the name of any obligor who is delinquent in the payment of support and the amount of overdue support owed by the obligor to consumer reporting agencies as defined in the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 1681a(f):Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-228(1): only after the obligor has been afforded notice and a reasonable opportunity to contest the accuracy of the information; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-228(2): only to an entity that has provided satisfactory evidence that it is a consumer reporting agency under 15 U.S.C. Sec. 1681a(f).

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-230 Right to judicial review.
---------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-230(1)(b): 26B-9-207 For purposes of Subsection (1)(a), notice includes:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-230(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-230(4)(a): If the petition is regarding the amount of the child support obligation established in accordance with Title 81, Chapter 6, Child Support, the court may issue a temporary order for child support until a final order is issued.

The temporary order shall be valid for 60 days, unless extended by the court while the action is being pursued.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-230(4)(c): If the court upholds the amount of support established in Subsection (4)(a), the petitioner shall be ordered to make up the difference between the amount originally ordered in Subsection (4)(a) and the amount temporarily ordered under Subsection (4)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-230(4)(d): This Subsection (4) does not apply to an action for the court-ordered modification of a judicial child support order.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-230(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-230(5)(a): The court may, on its own initiative and based on the evidence before it, determine whether the petitioner violated Rule 11 of the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure by filing the action.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-230(5)(b): If the court determines that Rule 11 of the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure was violated, it shall, at a minimum, award to the office attorney fees and costs for the action.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-230(6): Nothing in this section precludes the obligor from seeking administrative remedies as provided in this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-301 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part and Part 4, Income Withholding in Non IV-D Cases:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-301(1): "Business day" means a day on which state offices are open for regular business.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-301(2): 81-6-101 "Child" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-301(3): 26B-9-101 "Child support" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-301(4): 26B-9-201 "Child support order" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-301(5): 26B-9-101 "Child support services" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-301(6): "Delinquency" means that child support in an amount at least equal to current child support payable for one month is overdue.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-301(7): "Delinquent" means delinquency.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-301(8): "Immediate income withholding" means income withholding without regard to whether a delinquency has occurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-301(9): 26B-9-101 "Income" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-301(10): 26B-9-201 "IV-D services" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-301(11): "Jurisdiction" means a state or political subdivision of the United States, a territory or possession of the United States, the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, an Indian tribe or tribal organization, or any comparable foreign nation or political subdivision.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-301(12): 26B-9-201 "Obligee" means the same as that term is defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-301(14): "Office" means the Office of Recovery Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-301(15): "Payor" means an employer or any person who is a source of income to an obligor.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-302 Administrative procedures.
----------------------------------------------------------
Because the procedures of this part are mandated by federal law they shall be applied for the purposes specified in this part and control over any other statutory administrative procedures.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-303 Provision for income withholding in child support order -- Immediate income withholding.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-303(1): Whenever a child support order is issued or modified in this state the obligor's income is subject to immediate income withholding for the child support described in the order in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-303(1)(a): the court or administrative body which entered the order finds that one of the parties has demonstrated good cause so as not to require immediate income withholding; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-303(1)(b): a written agreement which provides an alternative payment arrangement is executed by the obligor and obligee, and reviewed and entered in the record by the court or administrative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-303(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-303(2)(a): In every child support order issued or modified on or after January 1, 1994, the court or administrative body shall include a provision that the income of an obligor is subject to immediate income withholding in accordance with this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-303(2)(b): If for any reason other than the provisions of Subsection (1) that provision is not included in the child support order the obligor's income is nevertheless subject to immediate income withholding.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-303(3): In determining good cause, the court or administrative body may, in addition to any other requirement it considers appropriate, consider whether the obligor has:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-303(3)(a): obtained a bond, deposited money in trust for the benefit of the children, or otherwise made arrangements sufficient to guarantee child support payments for at least two months;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-303(3)(b): arranged to deposit all child support payments into a checking account belonging to the obligee, or made arrangements insuring that a reliable and independent record of the date and place of child support payments will be maintained; or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-303(3)(c): arranged for electronic transfer of funds on a regular basis to meet court-ordered child support obligations.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-304 Office procedures for income withholding for orders issued or modified on or after October 13, 1990.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-304(1): 35A-3-108 With regard to obligees or obligors who are receiving IV-D services, each child support order issued or modified on or after October 13, 1990, subjects the income of an obligor to immediate income withholding as of the effective date of the order, regardless of whether a delinquency occurs unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-304(1)(a): the court or administrative body that entered the order finds that one of the parties has demonstrated good cause not to require immediate income withholding; or

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-304(2)(a)(ii): proof of timely payment of any previously ordered support; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-304(2)(b): in determining good cause, the court or administrative body may, in addition to any other requirement that it determines appropriate, consider whether the obligor has:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-304(2)(b)(ii): arranged to deposit all child support payments into a checking account belonging to the obligee or made arrangements insuring that a reliable and independent record of the date and place of child support payments will be maintained.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-304(3)(a): included in the court or administrative agency's child support order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-304(3)(b): negated without further administrative or judicial action:

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-304(4): If an exception to immediate income withholding has been ordered on the basis of good cause under Subsection (1)(a), the office may commence income withholding under this part:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-304(4)(a): in accordance with Subsection (3)(b); or
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-304(4)(b): if the administrative or judicial body that found good cause determines that circumstances no longer support that finding.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-306 Notice to payor.
------------------------------------------------
Upon compliance with the applicable provisions of this part the office shall mail or deliver to each payor at the payor's last-known address written notice stating:Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-306(1): the amount of child support to be withheld from income;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-306(2): that the child support must be withheld from the obligor's income each time the obligor is paid, but that the amount withheld may not exceed the maximum amount permitted under Section 303 (b) of the Consumer Credit Protection Act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 1673(b);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-306(3): that the payor must mail or deliver the withheld income to the office within seven business days of the date the amount would have been paid or credited to the employee but for this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-306(4): that the payor may deduct from the obligor's income an additional amount which is equal to the amount payable to a garnishee under Rule 64D of the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure, as the payor's fee for administrative costs, but the total amount withheld may not exceed the maximum amount permitted under Section 303(b) of the Consumer Credit Protection Act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 1673(b);
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-306(5): that the notice to withhold is binding on the payor and on any future payor until further notice by the office or a court;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-306(6): (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-306(6)(a): (3) that if the payor fails to mail or deliver withheld income to the office within the time period set in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-306(6)(b): that if the payor willfully fails to withhold income in accordance with the notice, the payor is liable to the office for $1,000 or the accumulated amount the payor should have withheld, whichever is greater, plus interest on that amount;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-306(7): that the notice to withhold is prior to any other legal process under state law;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-306(8): that the payor must begin to withhold income no later than the first time the obligor's earnings are normally paid after five working days from the date the payor receives the notice;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-306(9): that the payor must notify the office within five days after the obligor terminates employment or the periodic income payment is terminated, and provide the obligor's last-known address and the name and address of any new payor, if known;
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-306(10): 26B-9-217 that if the payor discharges, refuses to employ, or takes disciplinary action against an obligor because of the notice to withhold, the payor is liable to the obligor as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-306(11): that, in addition to any other remedy provided in this section, the payor is liable for costs and reasonable attorneys' fees incurred in enforcing any provision in a notice to withhold mailed or delivered to the payor's last-known address.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-308 Termination of income withholding.
------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-308(1)(a): 26B-9-304; 26B-9-304 At any time after the date income withholding begins, a party to the child support order may request a judicial hearing or administrative review to determine whether income withholding should be terminated due to:
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-308(1)(a)(i): 26B-9-304 good cause under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-308(1)(a)(ii): 26B-9-304 the execution of a written agreement under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-308(1)(a)(iii): the completion of an obligor's support obligation.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-308(1)(b): An obligor's payment of overdue child support may not be the sole basis for termination of income withholding.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-308(1)(c): If it is determined by a court or the office that income withholding should be terminated, the office shall give written notice of termination to each payor within 10 days after receipt of notice of that decision.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-308(1)(e)(iv): the office, based on internal procedures and standards, determines reinstatement is appropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-308(2): The office shall give written notice of termination to each payor when the obligor no longer owes child support to the obligee.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-308(3): A notice to withhold income, served by the office, is binding on a payor until the office notifies the payor that the obligation to withhold income has been terminated.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-309 Payor's compliance with income withholding.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-309(1): Payment by a payor under this part satisfies the terms for payment of income under any contract between a payor and obligor.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-309(2): A payor who complies with an income withholding notice that is regular on its face may not be subject to civil liability to any person for conduct in compliance with the notice.

Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-312 Records and documentation -- Distribution or refund of collected income -- Allocation of payments among multiple notices to withhold.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-312(1): The office shall keep adequate records to document and monitor all child support payments received under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-312(2): The office shall promptly distribute child support payments which it receives from a payor, to the obligee, unless those payments are owed to the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-312(3): The office shall promptly refund any improperly withheld income to the obligor.
Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-312(4): The office may allocate child support payments received from an obligor under this part among multiple notices to withhold which it has issued with regard to that obligor, in accordance with rules promulgated by the office to govern that procedure.


Utah Code Annotated § 26B-9-313 Income withholding upon obligor's request.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Whether or not a delinquency has occurred, an obligor may request that the office implement income withholding procedures under this part for payment of the obligor's child support obligations.
